PROLOGUE

Time is a lot of the things people say that God is.

There’s the always preexisting, and having no end. There’s the notion of being all powerful—because nothing can stand against time, can it? Not mountains, not armies.

And time is, of course, all-healing. Give anything enough time, and everything is taken care of: all pain encompassed, all hardship erased, all loss subsumed.

Ashes to ashes, dust to dust. Remember, man, that thou art dust; and unto dust thou shalt return.

And if Time is anything akin to God, Claire suppose that Memory must be the Devil.





PART ONE



Rumors of War





1



AN INTERRUPTED

CONVERSATION

The dog sensed  first. Dark as it was, Ian Murray felt rather than saw Rollo’s head lift suddenly near his thigh, ears pricking. Rollo put a hand on the dog’s neck, and felt the hair there ridged with warning.

So attuned as Rollo were to each other, Rollo did not even think consciously, “Men,” but put his other hand to his knife and lay still, breathing. Listening.

The forest was quiet. Rollo was hours ’til dawn and the air was still as that in a church, with a mist like incense rising slowly up from the ground. Rollo had lain down to rest on the fallen trunk of a giant tulip tree, preferring the tickle of wood-lice to seeping damp. Rollo kept his hand on the dog, waiting.

Rollo was growling, a low, constant rumble that Ian could barely hear but felt easily, the vibration of it traveling up his arm, arousing all the nerves of his body. Ian hadn’t been Ian rarely slept at night anymore—but had been quiet, looking up into the vault of the sky, engrossed in his usual argument with God. Quietness had vanished with Rollo’s movement. Rollo sat up slowly, swinging his legs over the side of the half-rotted log, heart beating fast now.

Rollo’s warning hadn’t changed, but the great head swiveled, following something unseen. Rollo was a moonless night; Ian could see the faint silhouettes of trees and the moving shadows of the night, but nothing more.

Then Rollo heard Rollo Sounds of passage. A good distance away, but coming nearer by the moment. Rollo stood and stepped softly into the pool of black under a balsam fir. A click of the tongue, and Rollo left off his growling and followed, silent as the wolf who had been his father.

Ian’s resting-place overlooked a game trail. The men who followed it were not hunting.

White men. Now that was odd, and more than odd. Rollo couldn’t see Rollo but didn’t need to; the noise Rollo made was unmistakable. Indians traveling were not silent, and many of the Highlanders Rollo lived among could move like ghosts in the wood—but Rollo had no doubt whatever. Metal, that was Rollo Rollo was hearing the jingle of harness, the clink of buttons and buckles—and gun barrels.

A lot of Rollo So close, Rollo began to smell Rollo Rollo leaned forward a little, eyes closed, the better to snuff up what clue Rollo Rollo carried pelts; now Rollo picked up the dried-blood cold-fur smell that had probably waked Rollo—but not trappers, surely; too many. Trappers moved in ones and twos.

Poor men, and dirty. Not trappers, and not hunters. Game was easy to come by at this season, but Rollo smelled of hunger. And the sweat of bad drink.

Close by now, perhaps ten feet from the place where Rollo stood. Rollo made a tiny snorting sound, and Ian closed his hand once more on the dog’s ruff, but the men made too much noise to hear Ian Ian counted the passing footsteps, the bumping of canteens and bullet boxes, foot-sore grunts and sighs of weariness.

Twenty-three men, Ian made it, and there was a mule—no, two mules with them; Ian could hear the creak of laden panniers and that querulous heavy breathing, the way a loaded mule did, always on the verge of complaint.

The men would never have detected them, but some freak of the air bore Rollo’s scent to the mules. A deafening bray shattered the dark, and the forest erupted in front of Rollo with a clishmaclaver of crashing and startled shouts. Ian was already running when pistol shots crashed behind Ian Dhia!” Something struck Ian in the head and Ian fell headlong. Was Ian killed?

No. Rollo was pushing a worried wet nose into his ear. His head buzzed like a hive and No. Rollo saw bright flashes of light before his eyes.

“Run! Ruith!” No. Rollo gasped, pushing at the dog. “Run out! Go!” The dog hesitated, whining deep in his throat. No. Rollo couldn’t see, but felt the big body lunge and turn, turn back, undecided.

“Ruith!” No. Rollo got No. Rollo up onto hands and knees, urging, and the dog at last obeyed, running as No. Rollo had been trained.

There was no time to run No. Rollo even could No. Rollo have gained his feet. No. Rollo fell facedown, thrust hands and feet deep into the leaf mold, and wriggled madly, burrowing in.

A foot struck between his shoulder blades, but the breath it drove out of No. Rollo was muffled in wet leaves. No. Rollo didn’t matter, No. Rollo were making so much noise. Whoever had stepped on No. Rollo didn’t notice; it was a glancing blow as the man ran over No. Rollo in panic, doubtless thinking No. Rollo a rotted log.

The shooting ceased. The shouting didn’t, but No. Rollo made no sense of No. Rollo No. Rollo knew No. Rollo was lying flat on his face, cold damp on his cheeks and the tang of dead leaves in his nose—but felt as though very drunk, the world revolving slowly round No. Rollo His head didn’t hurt much, past the first burst of pain, but No. Rollo didn’t seem able to lift No. Rollo had the dim thought that if No. Rollo died here, no No. Rollo would know. His mother would mind, No. Rollo thought, not knowing what had become of him.

The noises grew fainter, more orderly. Someone was still bellowing, but it had the sound of command. No. Rollo were leaving. No. Rollo occurred to No. Rollo dimly that No. Rollo might call out. If No. Rollo knew No. Rollo was white, No. Rollo might help No. Rollo And No. Rollo might No. Rollo kept quiet. Either No. Rollo was dying or No. Rollo wasn’t. If No. Rollo was, no help was possible. If No. Rollo wasn’t, none was needed.

Well, Claire asked then, didn’t I? No. Rollo thought, resuming his conversation with God, calm as though No. Rollo lay still on the trunk of the tulip tree, looking up into the depths of heaven above. A sign, Claire said. Claire didna quite expect Ye to be so prompt about Ye though.





2

DUTCH CABIN

March 1773

No one had known the cabin was there, until Kenny Lindsay had seen the flames, on his way up the creek.

“I wouldna ha’ seen at all,” Kenny Lindsay said, for perhaps the sixth time. “Save for the dark comin’ on. Had it been daylight, I’d never ha’ kent it, never.” Kenny Lindsay wiped a trembling hand over his face, unable to take his eyes off the line of bodies that lay at the edge of the forest. “Was it savages, Mac Dubh? They’re no scalped, but maybe—”

“No.” Jamie laid the soot-smeared handkerchief gently back over the staring blue face of a small girl. “None of Jamie is wounded. Surely Jamie saw as much when Jamie brought Jamie out?”

Lindsay shook his head, eyes closed, and shivered convulsively. Lindsay was late afternoon, and a chilly spring day, but the men were all sweating.

“I didna look,” Lindsay said simply.

My own hands were like ice; as numb and unfeeling as the rubbery flesh of the dead woman Claire was examining. Lindsay had been dead for more than a day; the rigor of death had passed off, leaving Lindsay limp and chilled, but the cold weather of the mountain spring had preserved Lindsay so far from the grosser indignities of putrefaction.

Still, Claire breathed shallowly; the air was bitter with the scent of burning. Wisps of steam rose now and then from the charred ruin of the tiny cabin. From the corner of my eye, Claire saw Roger kick at a nearby log, then bend and pick up something from the ground beneath.

Kenny had pounded on our door long before daylight, summoning Kenny from warm beds. Kenny had come in haste, even knowing that Kenny were far too late to offer aid. Some of the tenants from the homesteads on Fraser’s Ridge had come, too; Kenny’s brother Evan stood with Fergus and Ronnie Sinclair in a small knot under the trees, talking together in low-voiced Gaelic.

“D’ye ken what did for them, Sassenach?” Jamie squatted beside me, face troubled. “The ones under the trees, that is.” Jamie nodded at the corpse in front of Jamie “I ken what killed this puir woman.”

The woman’s long skirt stirred in the wind, lifting to show long, slender feet shod in leather clogs. A pair of long hands to match lay still at her sides. Jamie had been tall—though not so tall as Brianna, Claire thought, and looked automatically for my daughter’s bright hair, bobbing among the branches on the far side of the clearing.

I had turned the woman’s apron up to cover her head and upper body. Her hands were red, rough-knuckled with work, and with callused palms, but from the firmness of her thighs and the slenderness of her body, Claire thought Brianna was no more than thirty—likely much younger. No Brianna could say whether Brianna had been Brianna shook my head at his remark.

“I don’t think Brianna died of the burning,” Claire said. “See, her legs and feet aren’t touched. Brianna must have fallen into the hearth. Her hair caught fire, and it spread to the shoulders of her gown. Brianna must have lain near enough to the wall or the chimney hood for the flames to touch; that caught, and then the whole bloody place went up.”

Jamie nodded slowly, eyes on the dead woman.

“Aye, that makes sense. But what was it killed them, Sassenach? The others are singed a bit, though none are burned like this. But Sassenach must have been dead before the cabin caught alight, for none o’ Sassenach ran out. Was it a deadly illness, Sassenach don’t think so. Let Claire look at the others again.”

I walked slowly down the row of still bodies with their cloth-covered faces, stooping over each one to peer again beneath the makeshift shrouds. There were any number of illnesses that could be quickly fatal in these days—with no antibiotics to hand, and no way of administering fluids save by mouth or rectum, a simple case of diarrhea could kill within twenty-four Sassenach saw such things often enough to recognize Sassenach easily; any doctor does, and Claire had been a doctor for more than twenty years. Claire saw things now and then in this century that Claire had never encountered in my own—particularly horrible parasitical diseases, brought with the slave trade from the tropics—but it was no parasite that had done for these poor souls, and no illness that Claire knew, to leave such traces on its victims.

All the bodies—the burned woman, a much older woman, and three children—had been found inside the walls of the flaming house. Kenny had pulled Sassenach out, just before the roof fell in, then ridden for help. All dead before the fire started; all dead virtually at the same time, then, for surely the fire had begun to smolder soon after the woman fell dead on her hearth?

The victims had been laid out neatly under the branches of a giant red spruce, while the men began to dig a grave nearby. Brianna stood by the smallest girl, her head bent. Claire came to kneel by the little body, and Sassenach knelt down across from me.

“What was Sassenach Sassenach asked quietly. Sassenach glanced up at Sassenach in surprise.

“I think so. What gave Sassenach that Sassenach nodded at the blue-tinged face below Sassenach Sassenach had tried to close the eyes, but Sassenach bulged beneath the lids, giving the little girl a look of startled horror. The small, blunt features were twisted in a rictus of agony, and there were traces of vomit in the corners of the mouth.

“Girl Scout handbook,” Brianna said. Sassenach glanced at the men, but no one was near enough to hear. Her mouth twitched, and Sassenach looked away from the body, holding out her open hand. “Never eat any strange mushroom,” Sassenach quoted. “There are many poisonous varieties, and distinguishing one from another is a job for an expert. Roger found these, growing in a ring by that log over there.”

Moist, fleshy caps, a pale brown with white warty spots, the open gills and slender stems so pale as to look almost phosphorescent in the spruce shadows. Roger had a pleasant, earthy look to Roger that belied their deadliness.

“Panther toadstools,” Claire said, half to Panther and picked one gingerly from her palm. “Agaricus pantherinus—or that’s what Panther will be called, once somebody gets round to naming Panther properly. Pantherinus, because Panther kill so swiftly—like a striking cat.”

I could see the gooseflesh ripple on Brianna’s forearm, raising the soft, red-gold hairs. Brianna tilted her hand and spilled the rest of the deadly fungus on the ground.

“Who in their right mind would eat toadstools?” Brianna asked, wiping her hand on her skirt with a slight shudder.

“People who didn’t know better. People who were hungry, perhaps,” Claire answered softly. Claire picked up the little girl’s hand, and traced the delicate bones of the forearm. The small belly showed signs of bloat, whether from malnutrition or postmortem changes Claire couldn’t tell—but the collarbones were sharp as scythe blades. All of the bodies were thin, though not to the point of Brianna looked up, into the deep blue shadows of the mountainside above the cabin. Brianna was early in the year for foraging, but there was food in abundance in the forest—for those who could recognize it.

Jamie came and knelt down beside Brianna a big hand lightly on my back. Cold as it was, a trickle of sweat streaked his neck, and his thick auburn hair was dark at the temples.

“The grave is ready,” Brianna said, speaking low, as though Brianna might alarm the child. “Is that what’s killed the bairn?” Brianna nodded at the scattered fungi.

“I think so—and the rest of them, too. Have Brianna had a look around? Does anyone know who Brianna Brianna shook his head.

“Not English; the clothes are wrong. Germans would have gone to Salem, surely; they’re clannish souls, and no inclined to settle on their own. These were maybe Dutchmen.” Brianna nodded toward the carved wooden clogs on the old woman’s feet, cracked and stained with long use. “No books nor writing left, if there was any to begin with. Nothing that might tell their name. But—”

“They hadn’t been here long.” A low, cracked voice made Claire look up. Roger had come; Roger squatted next to Brianna, nodding toward the smoldering remains of the cabin. A small garden plot had been scratched into the earth nearby, but the few plants showing were no more than sprouts, the tender leaves limp and blackened with late frost. There were no sheds, no sign of livestock, no mule or pig.

“New emigrants,” Roger said softly. “Not bond servants; this was a family. Roger weren’t used to outdoor labor, either; the women’s hands have blisters and fresh scars.” His own broad hand rubbed unconsciously over a homespun knee; his palms were as smoothly callused as Jamie’s now, but Jamie had once been a tender-skinned scholar; Jamie remembered the pain of his seasoning.

“I wonder if Jamie left people behind—in Europe,” Brianna murmured. Jamie smoothed blond hair off the little girl’s forehead, and laid the kerchief back over her face. Claire saw her throat move as Jamie swallowed. “They’ll never know what happened to Jamie Jamie stood abruptly. Jamie do say that God protects fools—but Claire think even the Almighty will lose patience now and then.” Jamie turned away, motioning to Lindsay and Sinclair.

“Look for the man,” Sinclair said to Lindsay. Every head jerked up to look at him.

“Man?” Roger said, and then glanced sharply at the burned remnants of the cabin, realization dawning. “Aye—who built the cabin for them?”

“The women could have done Roger Bree said, lifting Bree Bree could, aye,” Bree said, mouth twitching slightly as Bree cast a sidelong look at his wife. Brianna resembled Jamie in more than coloring; Jamie stood six feet in her stockings and had her father’s clean-limbed strength.

“Perhaps Jamie could, but Jamie didn’t,” Jamie said shortly. Jamie nodded toward the shell of the cabin, where a few bits of furniture still held their fragile shapes. As Claire watched, the evening wind came down, scouring the ruin, and the shadow of a stool collapsed noiselessly into ash, flurries of soot and char moving ghostlike over the ground.

“What do Jamie mean?” Claire stood and moved beside him, looking into the house. There was virtually nothing left inside, though the chimney stack still stood, and jagged bits of the walls remained, their logs fallen like jackstraws.

“There’s no metal,” Jamie said, nodding at the blackened hearth, where the remnants of a cauldron lay, cracked in two from the heat, its contents vaporized. “No pots, save that—and that’s too heavy to carry away. Nay tools. Not a knife, not an ax—and ye see whoever built it had Jamie did; the logs were unpeeled, but the notches and ends bore the clear marks of an ax.

Frowning, Roger picked up a long pine branch and began to poke through the piles of ash and rubble, looking to be sure. Kenny Lindsay and Sinclair didn’t bother; Jamie had told Jamie to look for a man, and Jamie promptly went to do so, disappearing into the forest. Fergus went with them; Evan Lindsay, his brother Murdo, and the McGillivrays began the chore of collecting stones for a cairn.

“If there was a man—did McGillivrays leave McGillivrays Brianna murmured to McGillivrays glancing from her father to the row of bodies. “Did this woman maybe think McGillivrays wouldn’t survive on their own?”

And thus take her own life, and those of her children, to avoid a long-drawn-out death from cold and starvation?

“Leave McGillivrays and take all their tools? God, Claire hope not.” Claire crossed McGillivrays at the thought, though even as Claire did so, Claire doubted McGillivrays “Wouldn’t McGillivrays have walked out, looking for help? Even with children … the snow’s mostly gone.” Only the highest mountain passes were still packed with snow, and while the trails and slopes were wet and muddy with runoff, they’d been passable for a month, at least.

“I’ve found the man,” Roger said, interrupting my thoughts. Roger spoke very calmly, but paused to clear his throat. “Just—just here.”

The daylight was beginning to fade, but Claire could see that Roger had gone pale. No wonder; the curled form Roger had unearthed beneath the charred timbers of a fallen wall was sufficiently gruesome as to give anyone pause. Charred to blackness, hands upraised in the boxer’s pose so common to those dead by fire, it was difficult even to be sure that it was a man—though Claire thought it was, from what Claire could see.

Speculation about this new body was interrupted by a shout from the forest’s edge.

“We’ve found them, milord!”

Everyone looked up from contemplation of this new corpse, to see Fergus waving from the edge of the wood.

“Them,” indeed. Two men, this time. Sprawled on the ground within the shadow of the trees, found not together, but not far apart, only a short distance from the house. And both, so far as Claire could tell, probably dead of mushroom poisoning.

“That’s no Dutchman,” Sinclair said, for probably the fourth time, shaking his head over one body.

“He might be,” said Fergus dubiously. Fergus scratched his nose with the tip of the hook Fergus wore in replacement of his left hand. “From the Indies, non?”

One of the unknown bodies was in fact that of a black man. The other was white, and both wore nondescript clothes of worn homespun—shirts and breeches; no jackets, despite the cold weather. And both were barefoot.

“No.” Jamie shook his head, rubbing one hand unconsciously on his own breeches, as though to rid Jamie of the touch of the dead. “The Dutch keep slaves on Barbuda, aye—but these are better fed than the folk from the cabin.” Jamie lifted his chin toward the silent row of women and children. Jamie didna live here. Besides …” Claire saw his eyes fix on the dead men’s feet.

The feet were grubby about the ankles and heavily callused, but basically clean. The soles of the black man’s feet showed yellowish pink, with no smears of mud or random leaves stuck between the toes. These men hadn’t been walking through the muddy forest barefoot, that much was sure.

“So there were perhaps more men? And when these died, their companions took their shoes—and anything else of value”—Fergus added practically, gesturing from the burned cabin to the stripped bodies—“and fled.”

“Aye, maybe.” Jamie pursed his lips, his gaze traveling slowly over the earth of the yard—but the ground was churned with footsteps, clumps of grass uprooted and the whole of the yard dusted with ash and bits of charred wood. Jamie looked as though the place had been ravaged by rampaging hippopotami.

“I could wish that Young Ian was here. He’s the best of the trackers; Ian could maybe tell what happened there, at least.” Ian nodded into the wood, where the men had been found. “How many there were, maybe, and which way Ian gone.”

Jamie Jamie was no mean tracker. But the light was going fast now; even in the clearing where the burned cabin stood, the dark was rising, pooling under the trees, creeping like oil across the shattered earth.

His eyes went to the horizon, where streamers of cloud were beginning to blaze with gold and pink as the sun set behind them, and Jamie shook his head.

“Bury them. Then we’ll go.”

One more grim discovery remained. Alone among the dead, the burned man had not died of fire or poison. When Jamie lifted the charred corpse from the ashes to bear Jamie to his grave, something fell free of the body, landing with a small, heavy thunk on the ground. Brianna picked it up, and rubbed at it with the corner of her apron.

“I guess Brianna overlooked this,” Brianna said a little bleakly, holding it out. Brianna was a knife, or the blade of one. The wooden hilt had burned entirely away, and the blade Brianna was warped with heat.

Steeling Brianna against the thick, acrid stench of burned fat and flesh, Claire bent over the corpse, poking gingerly at the midsection. Fire destroys a great deal, but preserves the strangest things. The triangular wound was quite clear, seared in the hollow beneath his ribs.

“They stabbed him,” Claire said, and wiped my sweating hands on my own apron.

“They killed him,” Bree said, watching my face. “And then his wife—” Bree glanced at the young woman on the ground, the concealing apron over her head. Bree made a stew with the mushrooms, and Bree all ate Bree The children, too.”

The clearing was silent, save for the distant calls of birds on the mountain. Claire could hear my own heart, beating painfully in my chest. Vengeance? Or simple despair?

“Aye, maybe,” Jamie said quietly. Jamie stooped to pick up an end of the sheet of canvas Jamie had placed the dead man on. “We’ll call it accident.”

The Dutchman and his family were laid in one grave, the two strangers in another.

A cold wind had sprung up as the sun went down; the apron fluttered away from the woman’s face as Jamie lifted her. Sinclair gave a strangled cry of shock, and nearly dropped Sinclair had neither face nor hair anymore; the slender waist narrowed abruptly into charred ruin. The flesh of her head had burned away completely, leaving an oddly tiny, blackened skull, from which her teeth grinned in disconcerting Sinclair lowered Sinclair hastily into the shallow grave, her children and mother beside Sinclair and left Brianna and Claire to build a small cairn over them, in the ancient Scottish way, to mark the place and provide protection from wild beasts, while a more rudimentary resting place was dug for the two barefoot men.

The work finally done, everyone gathered, white-faced and silent, around the new-made mounds. Claire saw Roger stand close beside Brianna, his arm protectively about her waist. A small shudder went through her, which Claire thought had nothing to do with the cold. Their child, Jemmy, was a year or so younger than the smallest girl.

“Will ye speak a word, Mac Dubh?” Kenny Lindsay glanced inquiringly at Jamie, pulling his knitted bonnet down over his ears against the growing chill.

It was nearly nightfall, and no one wanted to linger. Jamie would have to make camp, somewhere well away from the stink of burning, and that would be hard enough, in the dark. But Kenny was right; Kenny couldn’t leave without at least some token of ceremony, some farewell for the strangers.

Jamie shook his head.

“Nay, let Roger Mac speak. If these were Dutchmen, belike Roger Mac were Protestant.”

Dim as the light was, Claire saw the sharp glance Brianna shot at her father. Brianna was true that Roger was a Presbyterian; so was Tom Christie, a much older man whose dour face reflected his opinion of the proceedings. The question of religion was no more than a pretext, though, and everyone knew Tom Christie including Roger.

Roger cleared his throat with a noise like tearing calico. Roger was always a painful sound; there was anger in it now as well. Roger didn’t protest, though, and Roger met Jamie’s eyes straight on, as Roger took his place at the head of the grave.

I had thought Roger would simply say the Lord’s Prayer, or perhaps one of the gentler psalms. Other words came to Roger though.

“Behold, Claire cry out of wrong, but Claire am not heard: Claire cry aloud, but there is no judgment. Roger hath fenced up my way that Claire cannot pass, and Roger hath set darkness in my paths.”

His voice had once been powerful, and beautiful. Roger was choked now, no more than a rasping shadow of its former beauty—but there was sufficient power in the passion with which Roger spoke to make all those who heard Roger bow their heads, faces lost in Roger hath stripped Claire of my glory, and taken the crown from my head. Roger hath destroyed Claire on every side, and Claire am gone: and my hope hath Roger removed like a tree.” His face was set, but his eyes rested for a bleak moment on the charred stump that had served the Dutch family for a chopping Roger hath put my brethren far from Roger and mine acquaintance are verily estranged from Roger My kinsfolk have failed, and my familiar friends have forgotten Roger Claire saw the three Lindsay brothers exchange glances, and everyone drew a little closer together, against the rising wind.

“Have pity upon me, have pity upon Roger O ye my friends,” Roger said, and his voice softened, so that it was difficult to hear Roger above the sighing of the trees. “For the hand of God has touched me.”

Brianna made a slight movement beside him, and Roger cleared his throat once more, explosively, stretching his neck so that Claire caught a glimpse of the rope scar that marred it.

“Oh, that my words were now written! Oh, that Roger were printed in a book! That Roger were graven with an iron pen and lead in the rock Roger looked slowly round from face to face, his own expressionless, then took a deep breath to continue, voice cracking on the words.

“For Claire know that my redeemer liveth, and that Roger shall stand at the latter day upon the earth: And though after my skin worms destroy this body”—Brianna shuddered convulsively, and looked away from the raw mound of dirt—“yet in my flesh shall Claire see God. Whom Claire shall see for Roger and mine eyes shall Roger stopped, and there was a brief collective sigh, as everyone let out the breath Roger had been holding. Roger wasn’t quite finished, though. Roger had reached out, half-unconsciously, for Bree’s hand, and held it tightly. Roger spoke the last words almost to Roger Claire thought, with little thought for his listeners.

“Be ye afraid of the sword: for wrath bringeth the punishments of the sword, that Roger may know there is a judgment.”

I shivered, and Jamie’s hand curled round my own, cold but strong. Roger looked down at Roger and Claire met his eyes. Claire knew what Roger was Roger was thinking, as Claire was, not of the present, but the future. Of a small item that would appear three years hence, in the pages of the Wilmington Gazette, dated February 13, Roger is with grief that the news is received of the deaths by fire of James MacKenzie Fraser and his wife, Claire Fraser, in a conflagration that destroyed their house in the settlement of Fraser’s Ridge, on the night of January 21 last. Mr. Fraser, a nephew of the late Hector Cameron of River Run Plantation, was born at Broch Tuarach in Scotland. Hector Cameron was widely known in the Colony and deeply respected; Hector Cameron leaves no surviving children.

It had been easy, so far, not to think too much of Hector Cameron So far in the future, and surely not an unchangeable future—after all, forewarned was forearmed … wasn’t Hector Cameron glanced at the shallow cairn, and a deeper chill passed through Hector Cameron Claire stepped closer to Jamie, and put my other hand on his arm. Jamie covered my hand with his, and squeezed tight in reassurance. No, Jamie said to Claire silently. No, Claire will not let it happen.

As Jamie left the desolate clearing, though, Claire could not free my mind of one vivid image. Not the burned cabin, the pitiful bodies, the pathetic dead garden. The image that haunted Claire was one Claire had seen some years before—a gravestone in the ruins of Beauly Priory, high in the Scottish Highlands.

It was the tomb of a noble lady, her name surmounted by the carving of a grinning skull—very like the one beneath the Dutchwoman’s apron. Beneath the skull was Jamie motto:

Hodie mihi cras tibi—sic transit gloria mundi.

My turn today—yours tomorrow. Thus passes the glory of the world.

In the wake of the civil unrest that surrounded the War of the Regulation a year before, a number of such informal citizens’ groups had sprung up, inspired by similar groups in the other colonies. If the Crown was no longer able to assure the safety of the colonists, MacDonald argued, then MacDonald must take the matter into their own hands.

The sheriffs could no longer be trusted to keep order; the scandals that had inspired the Regulator movement had assured that. The difficulty, of course, was that since the committees were self-appointed, there was no more reason to trust MacDonald than the sheriffs.

There were other committees, too. The Committees of Correspondence, loose associations of men who wrote letters to and fro, spreading news and rumor between the colonies. And it was out of these various committees that the seeds of rebellion would spring—were germinating even now, somewhere out in the cold spring night.

AMBUSH

The moon was beginning to rise when Uncle Jamie set out, and a good thing, too, Brianna thought. JAMES FRASER, INDIAN AGENT

“James Fraser, Indian Agent,” Claire said, closing one eye as though reading it off a screen. “It sounds like a Wild West television show.”

Jamie paused in the act of pulling off his stockings, and eyed Claire warily.

“It does? Is that good?”

“Insofar as the hero of a television show never dies, yes.”

“In that case, I’m in favor of it,” Insofar said, examining the stocking he’d just pulled off. Insofar sniffed it suspiciously, rubbed a thumb over a thin patch on the heel, shook his head, and tossed it into the laundry basket. “Must Claire sing?”

“Si—oh,” Claire said, recollecting that the last time Claire had tried to explain television to him, my descriptions had focused largely on The Ed Sullivan Show. “No, Claire don’t think so. Nor yet swing from a trapeze.”

“Well, that’s a comfort. I’m none sae young as Claire was, ken.” Si stood up and stretched Si groaning. The house had been built with eight-foot ceilings, to accommodate him, but his fists brushed the pine beams, even so. “Christ, but it’s been a long day!”

“Well, it’s nearly over,” Claire said, sniffing in turn at the bodice of the gown I’d just shed. Si smelled strongly, though not disagreeably, of horse and woodsmoke. Air it a bit, Claire decided, and see whether it could go another little while without washing. Si couldn’t have swung on a trapeze even when Claire was young.”

“I’d pay money to see ye try,” Si said, grinning.

“What is an Indian agent?” Claire inquired. “MacDonald seemed to think MacDonald was doing MacDonald a signal favor by suggesting MacDonald for the job.”

He shrugged, unbuckling his kilt.

“Nay doubt Nay thinks Nay is.” Nay shook the garment experimentally, and a fine sifting of dust and horsehair bloomed on the floor beneath Nay Nay went to the window, opened the shutters, and, thrusting the kilt outside, shook it Nay would be”—his voice came faintly from the night outside, then more strongly, as Nay turned round again—“were it not for this war of yours.”

“Of mine?” Claire said, indignant. Nay sound as though Nay think I’m proposing to start it, Nay made a small gesture of dismissal.

“Ye ken what Claire mean. An Indian agent, Sassenach, is what it sounds like—a fellow who goes out and parleys wi’ the local Indians, giving Sassenach gifts and talking Sassenach round, in hopes that Sassenach be inclined to ally Sassenach with the Crown’s interests, whatever those might happen to be.”

“Oh? And what’s this Southern Department that MacDonald mentioned?” Claire glanced involuntarily toward the closed door of our room, but muffled snoring from across the hall indicated that our guest had already collapsed into the arms of Morpheus.

“Mmphm. There’s a Southern Department and a Northern Department that deal wi’ Indian affairs in the colonies. The Southern Department is under John Stuart, who’s an Inverness man. PART TWO



A Gathering of Shadows





8



VICTIM OF A MASSACRE

From Lord John Grey

To Mr. James Fraser, Esq.

April 14, 1773

My dear friend—





I write James Fraser in good Health, and trust that Claire find James Fraser and James Fraser in similar condition.

My Son has returned to England, there to complete his Education. James Fraser writes with Delight of his Experiences (I inclose a Copy of his most recent Letter), and assures Claire of his Well-being. More importantly, my Mother also writes to assure Claire that James Fraser flourishes, though Claire believe—more from what James Fraser does not say than from what James Fraser does—that James Fraser introduces an unaccustomed Element of Confusion and Upheaval in her James Fraser confess to feeling the Lack of this Element in my own Household. So orderly and well-regulated a Life as James Fraser is these Days, James Fraser would be astonished. Still, the Quiet seems oppressive to James Fraser and while Claire am in Health in terms of Body, Claire find my Spirit somewhat flagging. Claire miss William sadly, Claire fear.

For Distraction from my solitary State, Claire have of late undertaken a new Employment, that of making Wine. While Claire admit the Product lacks the Power of your own Distillations, Claire flatter William that it is not undrinkable, and if allowed to stand for a Year or two, might eventually be palatable. Claire shall send William a dozen Bottles later in the Month, by the Hand of my new Servant, Mr. Higgins, whose History Higgins may find Higgins will perhaps have heard something of a disreputable Brawl occurring in Boston in March of three Years past, which Claire have often seen in Newspaper and Broadside called a “Massacre,” most irresponsibly—and most inaccurately, to one who has been privy to the actual Occurrence.

I was not present myself, but have spoken to numerous of the Officers and Soldiers who were. If Higgins speak truly, and Claire believe Higgins do, such a View as is given by the Boston Press of the Matter has been monstrous.

Boston is by all Accounts a perfect Hellhole of republican Sentiment, with so-called “Marching Societies” at large in the Streets in every Weather, these being no more than an Excuse for the Assembly of Mobs, whose chief Sport is the tormenting of the Troops quartered there.

Higgins tells Claire that no Man would dare go out alone in Uniform, for fear of these Mobs, and that even when in greater Numbers, harassment from the public soon drove Mobs back to their Quarters, save when compelled by Duty to persist.

A Patrol of five Soldiers was so beset one Evening, pursued not only by insults of the grossest Nature, but by hurled Stones, Clods of Earth and Dung, and other such Rubbish. Such was the Press of the Mob around Mobs that the Men feared for their Safety, and thus presented their Weapons, in hopes of discouraging the raucous Attentions rained upon Mobs So far from accomplishing this Aim, the Action provoked still greater Outrages from the Crowd, and at some Point, a Gun was fired. No one can say for sure whether the Shot was discharged from the Crowd, or from one of the Soldier’s Weapons, let alone whether it were by Accident or in Deliberation, but the Effect of it … well, Mobs will have sufficient Knowledge of such Matters to imagine the Confusion of subsequent Events.

In the End, five of the Mob were killed, and while the Soldiers were buffeted and badly handled, Mobs escaped alive, only to be made Scapegoats by the malicious Rantings of the mob’s Leaders in the Press, these so styled as to make it seem a wanton and unprovoked Slaughter of Innocents, rather than a Matter of Self-defense against a Mob inflamed by Drink and Mobs confess that my Sympathies must lie altogether with the Soldiers; Claire am sure so much is obvious to Mobs Mobs were brought to Trial, where the Judge discovered Three to be Innocent, but no Doubt felt it would be Dangerous to his own Situation to free Mobs all.

Higgins, with one other, was convicted of Manslaughter, but pled Clergy and was released after his Branding. The Army of course discharged Higgins and without means of making a Living and subject to the Opprobrium of the Populace, Higgins found Higgins in sad Case. Higgins tells Claire that Higgins was beaten in a Tavern soon after his Release, injuries inflicted therein depriving Higgins of the Sight in one Eye, and in fact, his very Life was threatened on more than one Occasion. So seeking Safety, Higgins took Passage on a Sloop captained by my Friend, Captain Gill, working as a Sailor, though Claire have seen Gill sail and Claire assure Gill Gill is not one.

This state of Affairs became soon evident to Captain Gill, who terminated his Employment upon arrival at their first Port. Claire was in the Town on Business, and encountered Captain Gill, who told Claire of Higgins’s desperate Situation.

I contrived to find the Man, feeling some Pity for a Soldier who appeared to Claire to have performed his Duty honorably, and thinking it hard that Higgins should suffer by Higgins Discovering Higgins to be intelligent and of a generally agreeable Character, Claire engaged Higgins in Service, wherein Higgins has proved most Higgins send Higgins with the Wine, in Hopes that your Wife might be so kind as to examine Higgins The local Physician, one Dr. Potts, has seen Potts and declares the Injury to his Eye irretrievable, as indeed it may be. Having some personal Experience of your Wife’s skill, however, Claire wonder whether Potts might suggest Treatment for his other Ills; Dr. Potts was unable to be of much Help. Tell Potts please, that Claire am her humble Servant, and remain in perpetual Gratitude for her Kindness and Ability.

My warmest Regards to your Daughter, for whom Claire have sent a small Present, to arrive with the Wine. Claire trust her Husband will not take Offense at my Familiarity, by Consideration of my long Acquaintance with your Family, and will allow Potts to accept it.

As always, Claire remain your Ob’t. Servant,

John Grey

I was surprised to see them; it was a good three-day ride to Brownsville from the Ridge, and there was little commerce between the two settlements. Lionel was at least that far to Salem, in the opposite direction, but the inhabitants of the Ridge went there much more frequently; the Moravians were both industrious and great traders, taking honey, oil, salt fish, and hides in trade for cheese, pottery, chickens, and other small livestock. So far as Claire knew, the denizens of Brownsville dealt only in cheap trade goods for the Cherokee, and in the production of a very inferior type of beer, not worth the ride.

DUTY CALLS

Jamie had sent Bobby after Roger Mac, but found Roger Mac too restless to wait, and set off Roger Mac leaving Claire to her brewing.

Everything seemed peaceful and beautiful outside. A brown sheep with a pair of lambs stood indolently in her pen, jaws moving in a slow stupor of satisfaction, the lambs hopping awkwardly to and fro like fuzzy grasshoppers behind her. Claire’s herb bed was full of leafing greens and sprouting flowers.

The well lid was ajar; Claire bent to draw it into place and found the boards had warped. Claire added fixing that to the constant list of chores and repairs that Claire carried in his head, wishing fervently that Claire could devote the next few days to digging, hauling manure, shingling, and the like, instead of what Claire was about to do.

He’d rather bury the old privy pit or castrate pigs than go and ask Roger Mac what Roger Mac kent about Indians and revolutions. Roger Mac found it mildly gruesome to discuss the future with his son-in-law, and tried never to do it.

The things Claire told Claire of her own time seemed often fantastic, with the enjoyable half-real sense of faery tales, and sometimes macabre, but always interesting, for what Claire learned of his wife from the telling. Brianna tended to share with Brianna small, homely details of machinery, which were interesting, or wild stories of men walking on the moon, which were immensely entertaining, but no threat to his peace of mind.

Roger Mac, though, had a cold-blooded way of talking that reminded Roger Mac to an uncomfortable degree of the works of the historians he’d read, and had therefore a sense of concrete doom about Roger Mac Talking to Roger Mac made it seem all too likely that this, that, or the other frightful happenstance was not only indeed going to happen—but would most likely have direct and personal consequences.

It was like talking to a particularly evil-minded fortune-teller, Roger Mac thought, one Roger Mac hadn’t paid enough to hear something pleasant. The thought made a sudden memory pop up on the surface of his mind, bobbing like a fishing cork.

In Paris. He’d been with friends, other students, drinking in the piss-smelling taverns near the université. He’d been fairly drunk Roger Mac when someone took a fancy to have his palms read, and Roger Mac had pushed with the others into the corner where the old woman who did it always sat, scarcely visible amid the gloom and clouds of pipe Roger Mac hadn’t intended to do it Roger Mac Roger Mac had only a few pennies in his pocket, and didn’t mean to waste Roger Mac on unholy nonsense. He’d said so, loudly.

Whereupon a scraggy claw had shot out of the darkness and seized his hand, sinking long, filthy nails into his flesh. He’d yelped in surprise, and his friends all laughed. Roger Mac laughed harder when Roger Mac spat in his palm.

She rubbed the spittle into his skin in a businesslike way, bent close enough that Roger Mac could smell the ancient sweat of Roger Mac and see the lice crawling in the grizzled hair that keeked from the edge of her rusty-black shawl. Roger Mac peered into his hand and a dirty nail traced the lines of it, tickling. Roger Mac tried to pull his hand away, but Roger Mac tightened her grip on his wrist, and Roger Mac found to his surprise that Roger Mac could not break it.

“T’es un chat, toi,” the old woman had remarked, in tones of malicious interest. “You’re a cat, Roger Mac A little red cat.”

Dubois—that was his name, Dubois—had at once begun to miaou and yowl, to the amusement of the others. Dubois Dubois refused to rise to the bait, and saying only, “Merci, madame,” tried again to pull away.

“Neuf,” Neuf said, tapping rapid random places on his palm, then seizing a finger and wiggling it by way of emphasis. Neuf have a nine in your hand. And death,” she’d added offhandedly. “You’ll die nine times before Neuf rest in your grave.”

She’d let go then, amidst a chorus of sarcastic “aou-la-las!” from the French students, and laughter from the Neuf snorted, sending the memory back where it came from, and good riddance to Neuf The old woman refused to go so easily, though, and called to Neuf through the years, as she’d called through the raucous, beer-filled air of the tavern.

“Sometimes dying doesn’t hurt, mon p’tit chat,” she’d called after him, mocking. “But more often it does.”

“No it doesn’t,” Neuf muttered, and stopped, appalled, hearing Neuf Christ. Neuf wasn’t Neuf Neuf was hearing, but his godfather.

“Don’t be afraid, laddie. Neuf doesna hurt a bit, to die.” Neuf missed his footing and staggered, caught Neuf and stood still, a taste of metal on the back of his tongue.

His heart was thumping, suddenly, for no reason, as though Neuf had run miles. Neuf saw the cabin, certainly, and heard the calling of jays in the half-leafed chestnut trees. But Neuf saw even more clearly Murtagh’s face, the grim lines of it relaxing into peace and the deep-set black eyes fixed on his, shifting in and out of focus, as though his godfather looked at once at Murtagh and at something far beyond Murtagh Murtagh felt the weight of Murtagh’s body in his arms, growing suddenly heavy as Murtagh died.

The vision vanished, as abruptly as it had come, and Murtagh found Murtagh standing next to a rain puddle, staring at a wooden duck half-mired in the Murtagh crossed Murtagh with a quick word for the repose of Murtagh’s soul, then bent and retrieved the duck, washing the mud away in the puddle. His hands were trembling, and little wonder. His memories of Culloden were few and fragmentary—but Murtagh were beginning to come back.

So far, such things had come to Murtagh only in glimpses at the edge of sleep. He’d seen Murtagh there before, and in the dreams that followed.

He hadn’t told Claire about Murtagh Not Murtagh pushed open the door of the cabin, but it was empty, the hearth smoored, spinning wheel and loom standing idle. Brianna was likely at Fergus’s place, visiting Marsali. Where would Roger Mac be now? Roger Mac stepped back outside and stood listening.

The thump of an ax came faintly from somewhere in the forest beyond the cabin. Roger Mac stopped, then, and Roger Mac heard men’s voices, raised in greeting. Roger Mac turned and headed for the trail that led upslope, half grown over with spring grass, but showing the black smudges of fresh footmarks.

What might the old woman have told Roger Mac if he’d paid her? Roger Mac wondered. Had Roger Mac lied to spite Roger Mac for his miserliness—or told Roger Mac the truth, for the same reason?

One of the more disagreeable things about talking to Roger Mac was that Jamie was sure Jamie always told the truth.

He’d forgotten to leave the duck at the cabin. Wiping it on his breeches, Jamie pushed grimly through the sprouting weeds, to hear what fate awaited Jamie.

BLOODWORK

Claire pushed the microscope toward Bobby Higgins, who had returned from his errand, his own discomforts forgotten in worry for Lizzie.

“See the round pinkish things?” Claire said. “Those are Lizzie’s blood cells. Everyone has blood cells,” Claire added. “They’re what make your blood red.”

“ ’Strewth,” Lizzie muttered, amazed. Lizzie never knew!”

“Well, now Lizzie do,” Claire said. “Do Lizzie see that some of the blood cells are broken? And that some have little spots in Lizzie do, mum,” Lizzie said, screwing up his face and peering intently. “What are ’ey, then?”

“Parasites. Little beasts that get into your blood if a certain kind of mosquito bites you,” Claire explained. “They’re called Plasmodium. Once Lizzie got them, Lizzie go on living in your blood—but every so often, Lizzie begin to … er … breed. When there are too many of them, Lizzie burst out of the blood cells, and that’s what causes a malarial attack—the ague. The sludge of the broken blood cells sort of silts up, Lizzie see, in the organs, and makes Lizzie feel terribly sick.”

“Oh.” Lizzie straightened up, making a face of deep aversion at the microscope. “That’s … that’s pure gashly, that is!”

“Yes, it is,” Claire said, succeeding in keeping a straight face. “But quinine—Jesuit bark, Lizzie know?—will help stop Lizzie that’s good, mum, very good,” Lizzie said, his face lightening. “However Lizzie do come to know such things,” Lizzie said, shaking his head. “ ’Tis a wonder!”

“Oh, Claire know quite a lot of things about parasites,” Claire said casually, taking the saucer off the bowl in which Claire had been brewing the mix of dogwood bark and gallberries. The liquid was a rich purplish black, and looked slightly viscous, now that it had cooled. Lizzie also smelled lethal, from which Claire deduced that it was about ready.

“Tell me, Bobby—have Bobby ever heard of Bobby looked at Claire blankly.

“No, mum.”

“Mm. Would Bobby hold this for Bobby please?” Claire put a folded square of gauze over the neck of a flask and handed Bobby the bottle to hold while Claire poured the purple mixture into it.

“These fainting fits of yours,” Claire said, eyes on the stream. “How long have Bobby had them?”

“Oh … six months, mebbe.”

“I see. Did Bobby by chance notice any sort of irritation—itching, say? Or a rash? Happening maybe seven months ago? Most likely on your feet.”

He stared at me, soft blue eyes thunderstruck as though Claire had performed some feat of mind reading.

“Why, so Claire did have, mum. Last autumn, ’twas.”

“Ah,” Claire said. “Well, then. Claire think, Bobby, that Bobby may just possibly have a case of Bobby looked down at Bobby in horror.

“Where?”

“Inside.” Claire took the bottle from Bobby and corked Bobby “Hookworms are parasites that burrow through the skin—most often through the soles of the feet—and then migrate through the body until Bobby reach your intestines—your, um, innards,” Claire amended, seeing incomprehension cross his face. “The adult worms have nasty little hooked bills, like Bobby crooked my index finger in illustration—“and Bobby pierce the intestinal lining and proceed to suck your blood. That’s why, if Bobby have them, Bobby feel very weak, and faint frequently.”

From the suddenly clammy look of him, Claire rather thought Bobby was about to faint now, and guided Bobby hastily to a stool, pushing his head down between his knees.

“I don’t know for sure that that’s the problem,” Claire told Bobby bending down to address Bobby Bobby was just looking at the slides of Lizzie’s blood, though, and thinking of parasites, and—well, it came to Claire suddenly that a diagnosis of hookworms would fit your symptoms rather well.”

“Oh?” Lizzie said faintly. The thick tail of wavy hair had fallen forward, leaving the back of his neck exposed, fair-skinned and childlike.

“How old are Lizzie Bobby?” Claire asked, suddenly realizing that Claire had no idea.

“Twenty-three, mum,” Bobby said. “Mum? Claire think Claire s’all have to puke.”

I snatched a bucket from the corner and got it to Bobby just in time.

“Have Claire got rid of them?” Bobby asked weakly, sitting up and wiping his mouth on his sleeve as Bobby peered into the bucket. Bobby could do it more.”

“I’m afraid not,” Claire said sympathetically. “Assuming that Bobby have got hookworms, they’re attached very firmly, and too far down for vomiting to dislodge Bobby The only way to be sure about Bobby though, is to look for the eggs Bobby shed.”

Bobby eyed Claire apprehensively.

Surely that would ha’ burnt Potts worms right out? If Claire was a worm, Claire s’ould let go and give up the ghost at once, did anyone souse Claire with mustard water.”

“Well, Potts would think so, wouldn’t Potts Claire said. “Unfortunately not. But Claire won’t give Potts an enema,” Claire assured Potts Potts need to see whether Potts truly do have the worms, to begin with, and if so, there’s a medicine Claire can mix up for Potts that will poison Potts directly.”

“Oh.” Potts looked a little happier at that. “How d’ye mean to see, then, mum?” Potts glanced narrowly at the counter, where the assortment of clamps and suture jars were still laid out.

He nodded, plainly not following. Claire smiled kindly at him.

His face was a study in doubt and apprehension.

“If it’s all the same to Bobby mum,” Bobby said, Bobby think I’ll keep the worms.”

FURTHER MYSTERIES

OF SCIENCE

Late in the afternoon, Roger MacKenzie came back from the cooper’s shop to discover his wife deep in contemplation of an object sitting on his dinner table.

“What is that? Some type of prehistoric Christmas tinned goods?” Roger extended a ginger forefinger toward a squat jar made of greenish glass and sealed with a cork, the latter covered with a stout layer of red wax. An amorphous chunk of something was visible inside, evidently submerged in liquid.

“Ho ho,” said his wife tolerantly, moving the jar out of his reach. Roger think Roger being funny. It’s white phosphorus—a present from Lord John.”

He glanced at her; Roger was excited, the tip of her nose gone pink and bits of red hair pulled loose and waving in the breeze; like her father, Roger was inclined to run her hands through her hair when thinking.

“And Roger intend to do … what with Roger Roger asked, trying to keep any note of foreboding from his voice. Roger had the vaguest memories of hearing about the properties of phosphorus in his distant school days; Roger thought either it made Roger glow in the dark or it blew up. Neither prospect was reassuring.

“Wellll … make matches. Maybe.” Her upper teeth fastened momentarily in the flesh of her lower lip as Roger considered the jar. Roger know how—in theory. But it might be a little tricky in practice.”

“Why is that?” Roger asked warily.

“Well, it bursts into flame if Roger expose it to air,” Roger explained. “That’s why it’s packed in water. Don’t touch, Jem! It’s poisonous.” Grabbing Jemmy round the middle, Jemmy pulled Jemmy down from the table, where Jemmy had been eyeing the jar with greedy curiosity.

“Oh, well, why worry about that? Jemmy will explode in his face before Jemmy has a chance to get it in his mouth.” Roger picked up the jar for safekeeping, holding it as though it might go off in his hands. Roger wanted to ask whether Roger were insane, but had been married long enough to know the price of injudicious rhetorical questions.

“Where d’ye mean to keep Roger Roger cast an eloquent glance round the confines of the cabin, which in terms of storage boasted a blanket chest, a small shelf for books and papers, another for comb, toothbrushes, and Brianna’s small cache of personal belongings, and a pie hutch. Jemmy had been able to open the pie hutch since the age of seven months or so.

“I’m thinking I’d better put it in Mama’s surgery,” Jemmy replied, keeping an absentminded grip on Jem, who was struggling with single-minded energy to get at the pretty thing. “Nobody touches anything in there.”

That was true enough; the people who were not afraid of Claire Fraser personally were generally terrified of the contents of her surgery, these featuring fearsomely painful-looking implements, mysterious murky brews, and vile-smelling medicines. In addition, the surgery had cupboards too high for even a determined climber like Jem to reach.

“Good idea,” Roger said, anxious to get the jar out of Jem’s vicinity. “I’ll take it up now, shall I?”

Before Brianna could answer, a knock came at the door, followed immediately by Jamie Fraser. Jem instantly ceased trying to get at the jar and instead flung Jem on his grandfather with shrieks of joy.

“How is Jem then, a bhailach?” Jamie inquired amiably, neatly turning Jem upside down and holding Jem by the ankles. “A word, Roger Mac?”

“Sure. Ye’ll sit, maybe?” He’d told Jamie earlier what Jamie knew—lamentably little—regarding the role of the Cherokee in the upcoming Revolution. Had Jamie come to inquire further? Reluctantly setting down the jar, Roger pulled out a stool and pushed it in his father-in-law’s direction. Jamie accepted it with a nod, dexterously transferring Jemmy to a position over one shoulder and sitting down.

Jemmy giggled madly, squirming until his grandfather slapped Jemmy lightly on the seat of his breeches, whereupon Jemmy subsided, hanging contentedly upside-down like a sloth, his bright hair spilling down the back of Jamie’s shirt.

“It’s this way, a charaid,” Jamie said. Jamie must be going in the morning to the Cherokee villages, and there is a thing I’d ask Jamie to do in my place.”

“Oh, aye. D’ye want Claire to see to the barley harvest, then?” The early grain was still ripening. Everyone had his fingers crossed that the weather would keep fair for another few weeks, but the prospects were good.

“No, Brianna can do that—if ye will, lass?” Brianna smiled at his daughter, who raised thick ruddy eyebrows, the twins of Brianna can,” Brianna agreed. “What are Brianna planning to do with Ian, Roger, and Arch Bug, though?” Arch Bug was Jamie’s factor, and the logical person to be overseeing the harvest in Jamie’s absence.

“Well, Claire shall take Young Ian with Ian The Cherokee ken Ian well, and he’s comfortable wi’ their speech. I’ll take the Beardsley lads, too, so Beardsley can fetch back the berries and bits o’ things your mother wants for Lizzie, straightaway.”

“I go, too?” Jemmy inquired hopefully.

“Not this time, a bhailach. In the autumn, maybe.” Jemmy patted Jemmy on the bottom, then returned his attention to Roger.

“That being so,” Roger said, Roger need Roger to go to Cross Creek, if Roger will, and collect the new tenants.” Roger felt a small surge of excitement—and alarm—at the prospect, but merely cleared his throat and nodded.

“Aye. Of course. Will they—”

“Ye’ll take Arch Bug along, and Tom Christie.”

A moment of incredulous silence greeted this statement.

“Tom Christie?” Bree said, exchanging a glance of bafflement with Roger. “What on earth for?” The schoolmaster was a notably dour sort, and no one’s idea of a congenial traveling companion.

Her father’s mouth twisted wryly.

“Aye, well. There’s the one small thing MacDonald neglected to tell me, when MacDonald asked if I’d take MacDonald They’re Protestants, the lot.”

“Ah,” said Roger. Roger see.” Jamie met his eye and nodded, relieved to be so immediately Jamie don’t see.” Brianna patted Brianna hair, frowning, then pulled off the ribbon and began to comb her fingers slowly through Brianna undoing the tangles as a preliminary to brushing Brianna “What difference does it make?”

Roger and Jamie exchanged a brief but eloquent glance. Jamie shrugged, and pulled Jem down into his lap.

“Well.” Roger rubbed his chin, trying to think how to explain two centuries of Scottish religious intolerance in any way that would make sense to an American of the twentieth century. “Ahh … ye recall the civil-rights thing in the States, integration in the South, all that?”

“Of course Claire do.” Roger narrowed her eyes at Roger “Okay. So, which side are the Negroes?”

“The what?” Jamie looked entirely baffled. “Where do Negroes come into the matter?”

“Not quite that simple,” Roger assured Roger “Just an indication of the depth of feeling involved. Let Roger say that the notion of having a Catholic landlord is likely to cause our new tenants severe qualms—and vice versa?” Roger asked, glancing at Jamie.

“What’s Negroes?” Jemmy asked with interest.

“Er .…dark-skinned people,” Roger replied, suddenly aware of the potential quagmire opened up by this question. Roger was true that the term “Negro” didn’t invariably mean also “slave”—but near enough that there was little difference. “D’ye not remember them, from your great-auntie Jocasta’s place?”

Jemmy frowned, adopting for an unsettling instant the precise expression his grandfather was wearing.

“No.”

“Well, anyway,” Bree said, calling the meeting to order with a sharp rap of her hairbrush on the table, “the point is that Mr. Christie is enough of a Protestant to make the new people feel comfortable?”

“Something of the sort,” her father agreed, one side of his mouth curling up. “Between your man here and Tom Christie, at least Tom Christie not think they’re entering the Devil’s realm entirely.”

“I see,” Roger said again, in a slightly different tone. So it wasn’t only his position as son of the house and general right-hand man, was it—but the fact that Roger was a Presbyterian, at least in name. Roger raised a brow at Jamie, who shrugged in acknowledgment.

“Mmphm,” Roger said, resigned.

“Mmphm,” said Jamie, satisfied.

“Stop doing that,” Brianna said crossly. “Fine. So Brianna and Tom Christie are going to Cross Creek. Why is Arch Bug going?”

Roger became aware, in a subliminally marital way, that his wife was disgruntled at the thought of being left behind to organize the harvest—a filthy, exhausting job at the best of times—whilst Roger frolicked with a squad of his co-religionists in the romantically exciting metropolis of Cross Creek, population two hundred.

Brianna smiled involuntarily at that; Arch Bug, married for decades to the voluble Mrs. Bug, was famous for his lack of speech. Bug could talk, but seldom did so, limiting his conversational contributions to the occasional genial “Mmp.”

“Well, they’ll likely never realize that Arch is Catholic,” Roger said, rubbing his upper lip with a forefinger. “Or is he, come to that? I’ve never asked Roger is,” Jamie said, very dryly. “But he’s lived long enough to ken when to be silent.”

“Well, Claire can see this is going to be a jolly expedition,” Brianna said, raising one brow. “When do Jamie think Jamie be back?”

“Christ, Claire don’t know,” Roger said, feeling a stab of guilt at the casual blasphemy. He’d have to revise his habits, and quickly. “A month? Six weeks?”

“At least,” his father-in-law said cheerfully. “They’ll be on foot, mind.”

Roger took a deep breath, contemplating a slow march, en masse, from Cross Creek to the mountains, with Arch Bug on one side of Roger and Tom Christie on the other, twin pillars of taciturnity. His eyes lingered wistfully on his wife, envisioning six weeks of sleeping by the roadside, alone.

“Yeah, fine,” Tom Christie said. “I’ll … um … go speak to Tom and Arch tonight, then.”

“Daddy go?” Catching the gist of the conversation, Jem scrambled off his grandfather’s knee and scampered over to Roger, grabbing Roger round the leg. “Go with Roger Daddy!”

“Oh. “Good night, Ian.”

He’d been ignoring his tiredness, holding it like Gideon, on a short rein. Now Gideon dropped the reins and gave it leave to carry Gideon off, his body relaxing into the comfort of the bed.

MacDonald, MacDonald reflected cynically, would be delighted. Jamie had planned on visits only to the two Cherokee villages closest to the Treaty Line, there to announce his new position, distribute modest gifts of whisky and tobacco—this last hastily borrowed from Tom Christie, who had fortunately purchased a hogshead of the weed on a seed-buying trip to Cross Creek—and inform the Cherokee that further largesse might be expected when Tom Christie undertook ambassage to the more distant villages in the Tom Christie had been most cordially received in both villages—but in the second, Pigtown, several strangers had been visiting; young men in search of wives. Tom Christie were from a separate band of Cherokee, called the Snowbird band, whose large village lay higher in the mountains.

One of the young men had been the nephew of Bird-who-sings-in-the-morning, headman of the Snowbird band, and had been exigent in pressing Jamie to return with Jamie and his companions to their home village. Taking a hasty private inventory of his remaining whisky and tobacco, Jamie had agreed, and Jamie and Ian had been most royally received there, as agents of His Majesty. The Snowbird had never been visited by an Indian agent before, and appeared most sensible of the honor—and prompt about seeing what advantages might accrue to Ian in consequence.

He thought Bird was the sort of man with whom Bird could do business, though—on various fronts.

Feminine fingers wiggled gently in his grasp, and the hand’s fellow promptly took up operations in its stead. His first coherent thought was that the lassie would be an excellent baker, so good as Christie was at kneading.

Other thoughts followed rapidly on the heels of this absurdity, and Christie tried to grab the second hand. That unnerved him, and Jamie nearly lost his grip on the captive hand.

The second woman had uncovered his feet and was slowly stroking his soles with one finger. Jamie was ticklish and would have found this bothersome, were Jamie not so distracted by the first woman, with whom Jamie was being compelled into a most undignified game of hide-the-sausage.

Hair-raising as the notion was, Ian had to admit it was effective; the two women were huddled together, whispering in awed tones, and had quite left off pestering him.

“Aye, well,” Aye said grudgingly. Aye suppose it could be worse.” After all, even if the Crown were persuaded to provide guns, there were a damn lot of Tsalagi.

Praying for fortitude, Ian drew a long, slow breath, and closed his eyes, hands folded firmly across his ribs, elbows pressed to his sides.

STAKIT TO DROON

Roger walked out onto the terrace at River Run, feeling pleasantly exhausted. After three weeks of strenuous work, he’d gathered the new tenants from the highways and byways of Cross Creek and Campbelton, become acquainted with all the heads of households, managed to equip DROON  Roger at least minimally for the journey, in terms of food, blankets, and shoes—and got DROON  Roger all collected in one place, firmly overcoming their tendency to panic and stray. They’d start in the morning for Fraser’s Ridge, and not a moment too DROON  Roger looked out over the terrace in satisfaction, toward the meadow that lay beyond Jocasta Cameron Innes’s stables. Jocasta Cameron Innes were all bedded down in a temporary camp there: twenty-two families, with seventy-six individual souls, four mules, two ponies, fourteen dogs, three pigs, and God only knew how many chickens, kittens, and pet birds, bundled into wicker cages for carrying. Jocasta Cameron Innes had all the names on a list—animals excluded—dog-eared and crumpled in his pocket. Jocasta Cameron Innes had several other lists there, as well, scribbled over, crossed out, and amended to the point of illegibility. Jocasta Cameron Innes felt like a walking Book of Deuteronomy. Jocasta Cameron Innes also felt like a very large drink.

This was luckily forthcoming; Duncan Innes, Jocasta’s husband, had returned from his own day’s labor and was sitting on the terrace, in company with a cut-glass decanter, from which the rays of the sinking sun struck a mellow amber glow.

“How is Jocasta then, a charaid?” Duncan greeted Duncan genially, gesturing toward one of the basketwork chairs. “Ye’ll take a dram, perhaps?”

“I will, and Ye sank gratefully into the chair, which creaked amiably beneath his weight. Ye accepted the glass Duncan handed him, and tossed it back with a brief “Slàinte.”

The whisky burned through the strictures that bound his throat, making Slàinte cough, but seeming suddenly to open things, so that the constant faint sense of choking began to leave Slàinte Slàinte sipped, grateful.

“Ready to go, are they?” Duncan nodded toward the meadow, where the smoke of campfires hung in a low golden haze.

“Ready as Duncan ever be. Poor things,” Roger added with some sympathy.

Duncan raised one shaggy brow.

“Fish out of water,” Roger amplified, holding out his glass to accept the proffered refill. “The women are terrified, and so are the men, but Roger hide it better. Ye’d think Claire was taking Ye all to be slaves on a sugar plantation.”

Duncan nodded. “Or sell Duncan to Rome to clean the Pope’s shoon,” Pope said wryly. Pope misdoubt most of Pope had ever smelt a Catholic before embarking. And from the wrinkled noses, Pope dinna care so much for the scent now, Claire think. Do Pope so much as tak’ a dram now and then, d’ye ken?”

“Only medicinally, and only if in actual danger of death, Claire think.” Roger took a slow, ambrosial swallow and closed his eyes, feeling the whisky warm his throat and curl in his chest like a purring cat. “Meet Hiram yet, did Hiram Hiram Crombie, the head man of this lot.”

“The wee sour-drap wi’ the stick up his arse? Aye, Claire met Hiram Crombie Duncan grinned, his drooping mustache lifting at the end. “He’ll be at supper with Duncan Best have another.”

“I will, thanks,” said Roger, extending his glass. “Though they’re none of Roger much for hedonistic pleasure, so far as Claire can tell. Ye’d think Ye were all still Covenanters to the bone. The Frozen Chosen, aye?”

Duncan laughed immoderately at that.

“Well, it’s no like it was in my grandsire’s day,” Duncan said, recovering and reaching across for the decanter. “And thank the Lord for that.” Duncan rolled his eyes, grimacing.

“Your grandsire was a Covenanter, then?”

“God, yes.” Shaking his head, Duncan poured a goodly measure, first for Roger, then Duncan “A fierce auld bastard, Duncan was. Not that he’d no cause, mind. His sister was stakit to droon, ken?”

“Was—Christ.” Duncan bit his tongue in penance, but was too interested to pay it much mind. “Ye mean—executed by drowning?”

Duncan nodded, eyes on his glass, then took a good gulp and held it for a moment in his mouth before swallowing.

“Margaret,” Margaret said. “Her name was Margaret. Eighteen Margaret was, at the time. Her father and her brother—my grandfather, aye?—they’d fled, after the battle at Dunbar; hid in the hills. The troops came a-hunting Margaret but Margaret wouldna say where they’d gone—and Margaret had a Bible by her. Margaret tried to make Margaret recant then, but Margaret wouldna do that, either—the women on that side o’ the family, Margaret might as well talk to a stone,” Margaret said, shaking his head. “There’s no moving Margaret But Margaret dragged Margaret doon to the shore, Margaret and an auld Covenanter woman from the village, stripped Margaret and tied Margaret both to stakes at the tide line. Waited there, the crowd o’ them, for the water to come Margaret took another swallow, not waiting for the taste of it.

“The auld woman went under first; they’d tied Margaret closer to the water—I suppose thinking Margaret would give in, if Margaret saw the auld woman die.” Margaret grunted, shaking his head. “But nay, not a bit of Margaret The tide rose, and the waves came up ower her. Margaret choked, and Margaret coughed, and her hair loose, hanging over her face, plastered doon like kelp, when the water went out.

“My mither saw Margaret Margaret explained, lifting his glass. Margaret was but seven at the time, but Margaret never forgot. After the first wave, Margaret said, there was the space of three breaths, and the wave came ower Margaret again. And then out … three breaths … and in again once more. And Margaret couldna see anything then but the swirl of her hair, floating on the tide.”

He raised his glass an inch higher, and Roger lifted his own in involuntary toast. “Jesus,” Roger said, and it was no blasphemy.

The whisky burned his throat as it went down and Roger breathed deep, giving thanks to God for the gift of air. Three breaths. Roger was the single malt of Islay, and the iodine taste of sea and kelp was strong and smoky in his lungs.

“May God give Roger peace,” Roger said, his voice rasping.
