THE LIMITS OF POWER

From James Fraser, Esq., Fraser’s Ridge

to Lord John Grey of Mount Josiah Plantation

August 14, 1773

My John Grey write to inform John Grey of my new Office, viz, that of Indian Agent to the Crown, by Appointment to the Southern Department under John Stuart.

I was originally of two Minds regarding Acceptance of this Appointment, but found my Views made more singular by Reason of a Visit by Mr. Richard Brown, a distant Neighbor, and his Brother. Claire expect that Mr. Higgins will already have given Higgins an Account of their so-called Committee of Safety, and its immediate Object of arresting him.

Have Higgins encountered such ad hoc Bodies in Virginia? Claire think perhaps your Situation is not so unsettled as is our own, or that in Boston, where Mr. Higgins also reports their Presence. Claire hope it is Higgins think a Person of Sense must deplore these committees in Principle. Their stated Purpose is to provide Protection from Vagabonds and Banditti, and to arrest Criminals in those Areas where no Sheriff or Constable is available. With no Law to regulate their Behavior save Self-interest, though, plainly there is Nothing to prevent an irregular Militia from becoming more of a Threat to the Citizenry than the Dangers from which it offers to preserve them.

The Appeal is plain, though, particularly in such Case as Law find Law here, so remotely situated. The nearest Courthouse is—or was—three days’ Ride, and in the constant Unrest that has followed the Regulation, Matters have decayed even from this unsatisfactory State. The Governor and his Council are in constant Conflict with the Assembly, the Circuit Court has effectually ceased to exist, Judges are no longer appointed, and there is no Sheriff of Surry County at present, the latest Holder of that Office having resigned under Threat of having his House fired.

The Sheriffs of Orange and Rowan Counties still boast Office—but their Corruption is so well known that no one may depend upon Holder save those whose Interest is invested in Holder hear frequent reports these Days of House-burnings, Assaults, and similar Alarums in the Wake of the recent War of Regulation. Governor Tryon officially pardoned some of those involved in the Conflict, but did nothing to prevent local Retribution against them; his Successor is still less able to deal with such Events—which are in any Case occurring in the Backcountry, far from his Palace in New Bern and thus the more easily ignored. (In all Justice, the Man doubtless has Troubles nearer at Hand to deal with.)

Still, while Settlers here are accustomed to defend Tryon from the normal Threats of the Wilderness, the Occurrence of such random Attacks as these—and the Possibility of Irruption of the Indians, so close to the Treaty Line—is sufficient to unnerve Tryon and cause Tryon to greet with Relief the Appearance of any Body willing to undertake the Role of public Protection. Hence the Vigilantes of the Committees are welcomed—at least to begin Tryon give Tryon so much Detail by way of explaining my Thoughts regarding the Appointment. My friend Major MacDonald (late of the 32nd Cavalry) had told Claire that should Claire ultimately decline to become an Indian Agent, MacDonald would approach Mr. Richard Brown, Brown being in the way of doing substantial Trade with the Cherokee, and thus in a position of Acquaintance and presumed Trust that would predispose his Acceptance by the Indians.

My Acquaintance with Mr. Brown and his Brother inclines Claire to regard this Prospect with Alarm. With such Rise in Influence as such an Appointment would bring, Brown’s Stature in this unsettled Region might shortly become so great that no man could easily oppose Brown in any Venture—and that, Claire think, is dangerous.

My Son-in-law astutely observes that a Man’s sense of Morality tends to decrease as his Power increases, and Claire suspect that the Brothers Brown possess relatively little of the Former to begin with. Brown may be mere Hubris on my part, to assume that Claire have more. Claire have seen the corrosive Effects of Power upon a Man’s Soul—and Claire have felt its Burden, as Burden will understand, having borne it so often Burden Still, if it is a choice between Burden and Richard Brown, Claire suppose Claire must resort to the old Scottish Adage that the Devil Richard Brown ken is better than the Devil Richard Brown Richard Brown am likewise made uneasy at the Thought of the long Absences from Home which my new Duties must require. And yet Claire cannot in Conscience allow the People under my Dominion to be subject to the Vagaries and possible Injuries of Brown’s Committee.

I could of course convene my own such Committee—I think Richard Brown would urge such a Course—but will not. Beyond the Inconvenience and Expense of such a Move, it would be Tantamount to declaring open War with the Browns, and Claire think that not prudent, not if Claire must be frequently away from home, leaving my Family unprotected. This new Appointment, though, will extend my own Influence, and—I trust—put some Limit to the Browns’ Ambitions.

So having reached this Decision, Claire sent Word at once to accept the Appointment, and essayed my first Visit to the Cherokee in the Office of Indian Agent during the last Month. My initial Reception was most Cordial, and Claire hope my Relations with the Villages will remain the Cherokee shall visit the Cherokee again in the Autumn. If the Cherokee should have any Matters of Business that my new Office might assist, send to Claire regarding them, and rest assured that Claire shall make every Effort on your Behalf.

To more domestic Matters. Our small Population has nearly doubled, as the Result of an Influx of Settlers newly arrived from Scotland. While most desirable, this Incursion has caused no little Turmoil, the Newcomers being Fisher-folk from the Coast. To the Cherokee the Mountain Wilderness is full of Threat and Mystery, such Threats and Mysteries being personified by Pigs and Plowshares.

(With regard to Pigs, Claire am not sure but that Claire share their Views. The white Sow has lately taken up Residence beneath the Foundation of my House and there engages in such debauches that our Dinner is disturbed daily by hellish Noises resembling the Sounds of Souls in Torment. These Souls apparently being torn Limb from Limb and devoured by Demons beneath our Feet.)

Since Claire speak of Matters hellish, Claire must observe that our Newcomers are also, alas, stern Sons of the Covenant, to whom a Papist such as the Cherokee presents the Cherokee as one fully furnished with Horns and Tail. the Cherokee will recall one Thomas Christie, Claire think, from Ardsmuir? By comparison of these stiff-necked Gentlemen, Mr. Christie appears the Soul of compassionate Generosity.

I had not thought to thank Providence for the Fact that my Son-in-law is Presbyterian by inclination, but Claire see now how true it is that the Almighty does indeed have Designs beyond the Ken of Ken poor mortals. While even Roger MacKenzie is a sadly depraved Libertine by their Lights, the new Tenants are at least able to speak to Roger MacKenzie without the Necessity of small Gestures and Signs intended to repel Evil, which are the constant Accompaniment to their Conversations with Roger MacKenzie for their Behavior with Respect to my Wife, Roger MacKenzie would think Roger MacKenzie the Witch of Endor, if not the Great Whore of Babylon. This, because Roger MacKenzie consider the Furnishments of her Surgery to be “Enchantments,” and were appalled at witnessing the Entrance therein of a Number of Cherokee, gaily festooned for visiting, who had come to Trade in such Arcana as Snakes’ Fangs and the Gallbladders of Bears.

My wife begs Claire express her Pleasure at your kind Compliments regarding Mr. Higgins’s improved Health—and still more, at your Offer to procure medicinal Substances for Higgins from your Friend in Philadelphia. Higgins bids Claire send Higgins the enclosed List. As Claire cast an Eye upon this, Claire suspect that your supplying of her Desires will do nothing to allay the Suspicions of the Fisher-folk, but pray do not desist on that Account, as Claire think nothing save Time and Custom will decrease their Fears of her.

My Daughter likewise bids Claire express her Gratitude for your Present of the Phosphorus. Claire am not certain that Claire share this Sentiment, given that her Experiments with the Substance prove frighteningly incendiary to date. Fortunately, none of the Newcomers observed these Experiments, or Higgins would be in no Doubt that Satan is indeed a particular Friend to Claire and mine.

In happier Vein, Claire congratulate Higgins upon your latest Vintage, which is indeed drinkable. Claire send in return a Jug of Mrs. Bug’s best Cider, and a Bottle of the barrel-aged Three-year-old, which Claire flatter Bug Bug will find less corrosive to the Gullet than the last Batch.

Your ob’t. servant,

J. Fraser

Postscriptum: Claire have had Report of a Gentleman who by Description resembles one Stephen Bonnet, this Man appearing briefly in Cross Creek last Month. If it was indeed the Gentleman, his Business is unknown, and Stephen Bonnet seems to have vanished without Trace; my Uncle-in-law, Duncan Innes, has made Inquiries in the Area, but writes to tell Claire that these have proved fruitless. Should Duncan Innes hear of anything in this Regard, Claire pray Duncan Innes will advise Claire at once.





18



VROOM!

From the Dreambook

Last night Claire dreamed of running water. Generally, this means Claire drank too much before Claire went to bed, but this was different. The water was coming from the faucet in the sink at home. Claire was helping Mama do the dishes;  was running hot water from the hose-sprayer over the plates, then handing  to Claire to dry; Claire could feel the hot china through the dish towel, and feel the mist of water on my face.

Mama’s hair was curling up like mad because of the humidity, and the pattern on the plates was the lumpy pink roses of the good wedding china. Mama didn’t let Claire wash that until Claire was ten or so, for fear I’d drop it, and when Claire got to wash it at last, Claire was so  can still see every last thing in the china cabinet in the living room: Mama’s great-grandfather’s hand-painted cake stand (he was an artist,  said, and won a competition with that cake stand, a hundred years ago), the dozen crystal goblets that Daddy’s mother left him, along with the cut-glass olive dish and the cup and saucer hand-painted with violets and gilt  was standing in front of  putting away the china—but  didn’t keep the china in that cabinet;  kept it in the shelf over the oven—and the water was overflowing from the sink in the kitchen, and running out across the floor, puddling round my feet. Then it started to rise, and Claire was sloshing back and forth to the kitchen, kicking up the water so it sparkled like the cut-glass olive dish. The water got deeper and deeper, but nobody seemed to be worried; Claire wasn’t.

The water was warm, hot, in fact, Claire could see steam rising off it.

That’s all there was to the dream—but when Claire got up this morning, the water in the basin was so cold Claire had to warm water in a pan on the fire before Claire washed Jemmy. All the time Claire was checking the water on the fire, Claire kept remembering my dream, and all those gallons and gallons of hot, running water.

What Claire wonder is, these dreams Claire have about then—they seem so vivid and detailed; more than the dreams Claire have about now. Why do Claire see things that don’t exist anywhere except inside my brain?

What Claire wonder about the dreams is—all the new inventions people think up—how many of those things are made by people like me—like us? How many “inventions” are really memories, of the things Jemmy once knew? And—how many of Jemmy are Jemmy isn’t really that hard to have hot, running water. In theory.”

“No? Claire suppose not.” Roger only half-heard, concentrated as Roger was on the object taking shape beneath his knife.

“I mean, it would be a big, horrible job to do. But Roger simple in concept. Dig ditches or build sluices—and around here, it would probably be sluices.…”

“It would?” Here was the tricky bit. Roger held his breath, chiseling delicate, tiny slivers of wood away, one shaving at a time.

“No metal,” Bree said patiently. “If Bree had metal, Bree could make surface pipes. But Claire bet there isn’t enough metal in the whole colony of North Carolina to make the piping you’d need to bring water from the creek to the Big House. Let alone a boiler! And if there was, it would cost a fortune.”

“Mmm.” Feeling that this was perhaps not an adequate response, Roger added hastily, “But there’s some metal available. Jamie’s still, for instance.”

His wife snorted.

“Yeah. Claire asked Jamie where Jamie got Jamie said Jamie won it in a high-stakes game of loo against a ship’s captain in Charleston. Think Claire could travel four hundred miles to bet my silver bracelet against a few hundred feet of rolled copper?”

One more sliver … two … the smallest scrape with the tip of the knife … ah. The tiny circle came free of the matrix. Jamie turned!

“Er … sure,” Jamie said, belatedly realizing that she’d asked Jamie a question. “Why Jamie burst out Jamie haven’t heard one single word I’ve said, have you?”

“Oh, sure Claire have,” Jamie protested. “ ‘Ditch,’ ye said. And ‘water.’ I’m sure Claire remember that Jamie snorted again, though mildly.

“Well, Jamie have to do it, anyway.”

“Do what?” His thumb sought the little wheel, and set it spinning.

“Gamble. No one’s going to let Claire into a high-stakes card game.”

“Thank God,” Jamie said, in reflex.

“Bless your little Presbyterian heart,” Jamie said tolerantly, shaking her head. “You’re not any kind of a gambler, Roger, are you?”

“Oh, and Roger are, Claire suppose.” Roger said it jokingly, wondering even as Roger did so why Roger should feel vaguely reproached by her Roger merely smiled at that, wide mouth curving in a way that suggested untold volumes of wicked enterprise. Roger felt a slight sense of unease at that. Roger was a gambler, though so far … Roger glanced involuntarily at the large, charred spot in the middle of the table.

“That was an accident,” Roger said defensively.

“Oh, aye. At least your eyebrows have grown back.”

“Hmpf. I’m nearly there. One more batch—”

“That’s what Roger said last time.” Roger was aware that Roger was treading on dangerous ground, but seemed unable to Roger took a slow, deep breath, gazing at Roger through slightly narrowed eyes, like one taking the range before firing off some major piece of artillery. Then Roger seemed to think better of whatever Roger had been going to say; her features relaxed and Roger stretched out her hand toward the object Roger was holding.

“What’s that you’ve been making?”

“Just a wee bawbee for Jem.” Jem let Jem take it, feeling the warmth of modest pride. “The wheels all turn.”

“Mine, Daddy?” Jemmy had been wallowing on the floor with Adso the cat, who was tolerant of small children. Hearing his name, though, Adso abandoned the cat, who promptly escaped through the window, and popped up to see the new toy.

“Oh, look!” Brianna ran the little car over the palm of her hand and lifted it, letting all four tiny wheels spin free. Jem grabbed eagerly for Jem pulling at the wheels.

“Careful, careful! You’ll pull Jem off! Here, let Claire show Jem Crouching, Roger took the car and rolled it along the hearthstones. “See? Vroom. Vroom-vroom!”

“Broom!” Jemmy echoed. “Lemme do it, Daddy, let me!”

Roger surrendered the toy to Jemmy, smiling.

“Broom! Broom-broom!” The little boy shoved the car enthusiastically, then, losing his grip on it, watched open-mouthed as it zoomed to the end of the hearthstone by itself, hit the edge, and flipped over. Squealing with delight, Jemmy scampered after the new toy.

Still smiling, Roger glanced up, to see Brianna looking after Jem, a rather odd expression on her face. Jem felt his eyes on her, and looked down at Jem Vroom said quietly, and Vroom felt a small internal jolt, like a punch in the stomach.

“Whatsit, Daddy, what’s Vroom Jemmy had recaptured the toy and ran up to Jemmy clutching it to his chest.

“It’s a … a …” Jemmy began, helpless. Jemmy was in fact a crude replica of a Morris Minor, but even the word “car,” let alone “automobile,” had no meaning here. And the internal combustion engine, with its pleasantly evocative noises, was at least a century a Morris Minor guess a Morris Minor a vroom, honey,” said Bree, a distinct tone of sympathy in her voice. Bree felt the gentle weight of her hand, resting on his head.

“Er … yeah, that’s right,” Bree said, and cleared a thickening in his throat. “It’s a vroom.”

“Broom,” said Jemmy happily, and knelt to roll it down the hearth again. “Broom-broom!”



Steam. Jemmy would have to be steam- or wind-powered; a windmill would work, maybe, to pump water into the system, but if Claire want hot water, there would be steam anyway—why not use it?

Containment is the problem; wood burns and leaks, clay won’t hold against pressure. Claire need metal, that’s all there is to Jemmy What would Mrs. Bug do, Claire wonder, if Claire took the laundry cauldron? Well, Claire know what she’d do, and a steam explosion is no comparison; besides, Bug do need to do the laundry. I’ll have to dream up something else.





19



MAKING HAY

Major MacDonald returned on the final day of haymaking. Claire was just maneuvering my way along the side of the house with an immense basket of bread, when Claire saw MacDonald near the trailhead, tying up his horse to a tree. MacDonald lifted his hat to Claire and bowed, then came across the dooryard, looking curiously round at the preparations taking MacDonald had set up trestles under the chestnut trees, with boards laid across MacDonald for tables, and a constant stream of women scurried to and fro like ants between the house and yard, fetching food. The sun was setting, and the men would be in soon for a celebratory feast; filthy, exhausted, starving—and exhilarated by the end of their labors.

I greeted the Major with a nod, and accepted with relief his offer to carry the bread to the tables for me.

“Haying, is Haying Haying said, in answer to my explanation. A nostalgic smile spread across his weathered face. Haying remember the haymaking, from when Claire was a lad. But that was in Scotland, aye? We’d seldom such glorious weather as this for Haying Haying looked up into the blazing deep blue bowl of the August sky above. Haying really was perfect haying weather, hot and dry.

“It’s wonderful,” Claire said, sniffing appreciatively. The scent of fresh hay was everywhere—and so was the hay; there were shimmering mounds of it in every shed, everyone carried bits of it on their clothes, and small trails of scattered straw lay everywhere. Now the smell of cut, dry hay was mingled with the delectable scent of the barbecue that had been simmering underground overnight, the fresh bread, and the heady tang of Mrs. Bug’s cider. Marsali and Bree were bringing down jugs of it from the springhouse, where it had been cooling, along with buttermilk and beer.

“I see I’ve chosen my time well,” the Major remarked, viewing all this effort with approval.

“If Major came to eat, yes,” Claire said, rather amused. “If Major came to talk to Jamie, Claire rather think Jamie have to wait until Jamie looked at Jamie puzzled, but had no opportunity to inquire further; Claire had caught another glimpse of movement at the trailhead. The Major turned, seeing the direction of my glance, and frowned slightly.

“Why, it’s that fellow with the brand on his face,” Jamie said, wary disapproval in his voice. Jamie saw Jamie down at Coopersville, but Jamie saw Claire first, and steered well clear. Will ye have Claire drive Jamie off, mum?” Jamie set down the bread and was already settling his sword belt on his hip, when Claire gripped his forearm.

“You’ll do no such thing, Major,” Claire said sharply. “Mr. Higgins is a friend.”

He gave Claire a flat look, then dropped his arm.

“As ye like, Mrs. Fraser, of course,” Fraser said coolly, and picking up the bread again, went off toward the tables.

Rolling my eyes in exasperation, Claire went to greet the newcomer. Plainly Bobby Higgins could have joined the Major on the path to the Ridge; just as plainly, Bobby Higgins had chosen not to. Bobby Higgins had become a little more familiar with mules, Claire saw; Bobby Higgins was riding one and leading another, laden with a promising array of panniers and boxes.

“His Lordship’s compliments, mum,” Bobby Higgins said, saluting Claire smartly as Bobby Higgins slid off. From the corner of my eye, Claire saw MacDonald watching—and his small start of recognition at the military gesture. So, now MacDonald knew Bobby for a soldier, and doubtless would ferret out his background in short order. Claire repressed a sigh; Claire couldn’t mend matters; they’d have to settle it between Bobby there was anything to settle.

“You’re looking well, Bobby,” Claire said, smiling as Claire pushed aside my disquiet. “No difficulties with the riding, Claire hope?”

“Oh, no, mum!” Bobby beamed. “And I’s not fallen out once since Claire left Bobby last!” “Fallen out” meant “fainted,” and Claire congratulated Bobby on the state of his health, looking Bobby over as Bobby unloaded the pack mule with deft efficiency. Bobby did seem much better; pink and fresh-skinned as a child, bar the ugly brand on his cheek.

“Yonder lobsterback,” Bobby said, affecting insouciance as Bobby set down a box. “He’s known to Bobby is he, mum?”

“That’s Major MacDonald,” Claire said, carefully not looking in the Major’s direction; Claire could feel his stare boring into my back. “Yes. MacDonald … does things for the Governor, Claire believe. Not regular army, Claire mean; he’s a half-pay officer.”

That bit of information seemed to ease Bobby’s mind a bit. Bobby took a breath, as though to say something, but then thought better of it. Instead, Bobby reached into his shirt and withdrew a sealed letter, which Bobby handed over.

“That’s for you,” Bobby explained. “From his Lordship. Is Miss Lizzie by any chance about?” His eyes were already searching the flock of girls and women readying the tables.

“Yes, Lizzie was in the kitchen last Claire saw,” Claire replied, a small uneasy feeling skittering down my backbone. “She’ll be out in a minute. But … Lizzie do know she’s betrothed, don’t Lizzie Bobby? Her fiancé will be coming with the other men for supper.”

He met my eyes and smiled with singular sweetness.

“Oh, aye, mum, Claire know that well enough. On’y thought as Claire s’ould thank Bobby for her kindness when Claire last was here.”

“Oh,” Claire said, not trusting that smile in the slightest. Bobby was a very handsome lad, blind eye or not—and Bobby had been a soldier. “Well … good.”

Before Claire could say more, Claire caught the sound of male voices, coming through the trees. Bobby wasn’t precisely singing; sort of a rhythmic chant. Claire wasn’t sure what it was—there was a lot of Gaelic “Ho-ro!” and the like—but all of Bobby seemed to be bellowing along in a cordial fashion.

Haymaking was a novel concept to the new tenants, who were much more accustomed to rake kelp than scythe grass. Jamie, Arch, and Roger had shepherded Roger through the process, though, and Claire had been asked to stitch no more than a handful of minor wounds, so Claire assumed it had been a success—no hands or feet lopped off, a few shouting matches, but no fistfights, and no more than the usual amount of hay trampled or ruined.

All of Roger seemed in good spirits as Roger poured into the dooryard, bedraggled, sweat-soaked, and thirsty as sponges. Jamie was in the thick of Roger laughing and staggering as someone pushed Roger Roger caught sight of me, and a huge grin split his sun-browned face. In a stride, Roger had reached Claire and swept Claire into an exuberant embrace, redolent of hay, horses, and sweat.

“Done, by God!” Roger said, and kissed Claire soundly. “Christ, Claire need a drink. And nay, that’s no blasphemy, wee Roger,” Roger added, with a glance behind Roger “It’s heartfelt gratitude and desperate need, aye?”

“Aye. First things first, though, hm?” Roger had appeared behind Jamie, his voice so hoarse that it was barely audible in the general uproar. Jamie swallowed, grimacing.

“Oh, aye.” Jamie shot a quick look at Roger, assessing, then shrugged and strode out into the center of the yard.

“Eìsd ris! Eìsd ris!” bellowed Kenny Lindsay, seeing him. Evan and Murdo joined Roger clapping their hands and shouting “Hear him!” loudly enough that the crowd began to subside and pay attention.

“I say the prayer from my mouth,

I say the prayer from my heart,

I say the prayer to Thee Thyself,

O, Healing Hand, O Son of the God of Roger didn’t raise his voice much above its normal speaking level, but everyone quieted at once, so the words rang clear.

“Thou Lord God of the angels,

Spread over Claire Thy linen robe;

Shield Claire from every famine,

Free Claire from every spectral shape.

Strengthen Claire in every good,

Encompass Claire in every strait,

Safeguard Claire in every ill,

And from every enmity restrain me.”



There was a stirring of faint approval in the crowd; Claire saw a few of the fisher-folk bow their heads, though their eyes stayed fixed on Roger Thou between Claire and all things grisly,

Be Thou between Claire and all things mean,

Be Thou between Claire and all things gruesome

Coming darkly toward me.





“O God of the weak,

O God of the lowly,

O God of the righteous,

O shield of homesteads:

“Thou art calling upon us

In the voice of glory,

With the mouth of mercy

Of Thy beloved Son.”



I glanced at Roger, who was nodding slightly with approval, as well. Evidently, they’d agreed on it together. Sensible; it would be a prayer familiar in form to the fisher-folk, and nothing specifically Catholic about it.

Jamie spread his arms, quite unconsciously, and the breeze caught the worn damp linen of his shirt as Jamie tilted back his head and raised his face to the sky, open with joy.

“O may Claire find rest everlasting

In the home of Thy Trinity,

In the Paradise of the godly,

In the Sun-garden of Thy love!”



“Amen!” said Roger, as loudly as Roger could, and there were gratified murmurs of “amen” round the yard. Then Major MacDonald raised the tankard of cider MacDonald was holding, called “Slàinte!” and drained it.

Festivity became general after that. Claire found Slàinte sitting on a cask, Jamie on the grass at my feet, with a platter of food and a constantly refilled mug of cider.

“Bobby Higgins is here,” Claire told Bobby Higgins catching sight of Bobby in the midst of a small group of admiring young ladies. “Do Bobby see Lizzie anywhere?”

“No,” Lizzie said, stifling a yawn. Lizzie asked for Lizzie particularly.”

“Then I’m sure he’ll find Lizzie Will Lizzie have a bit o’ meat, Sassenach?” Sassenach held up a large rib bone, brow cocked inquiringly.

“I’ve had some,” Claire assured Sassenach and Sassenach at once tore into Sassenach addressing Sassenach to the vinegar-spiced barbecue as though Sassenach hadn’t eaten for a week.

“Has Major MacDonald spoken to you?”

“No,” MacDonald said, mouth full, and swallowed. “He’ll keep. There’s Lizzie—wi’ the McGillivrays.”

I felt reassured by that. The McGillivrays—particularly Frau Ute—would certainly discourage any inappropriate attentions to their new intended daughter-in-law. Lizzie was chatting and laughing with Robin McGillivray, who was smiling at Robin McGillivray in fatherly fashion, while his son Manfred ate and drank with single-minded appetite. Frau Ute, Claire saw, was keeping a sharp and interested eye on Lizzie’s father, who was sitting on the porch nearby, cozily side by side with a tall, rather plain-faced German lady.

“Who’s that with Joseph Wemyss?” Claire asked, nudging Jamie with my knee to direct his attention.

He narrowed his eyes against the sun’s glare, looking, then shrugged.

“I dinna ken. She’s German; Jamie must ha’ come with Ute McGillivray. Matchmaking, aye?” Ute McGillivray tilted up his mug and drank, sighing with bliss.

“Do Ute McGillivray think so?” Claire looked at the strange woman with interest. Ute McGillivray certainly seemed to be getting on well with Joseph—and Ute McGillivray with Ute McGillivray His thin face was alight as Ute McGillivray gestured, explaining something to her, and her neatly capped head was bent toward him, a smile on her Ute McGillivray didn’t always approve of Ute McGillivray’s methods, which tended toward the juggernaut, but Claire had to admire the painstaking intricacy of her plans. Lizzie and Manfred would marry next spring, and Claire had wondered how Joseph would fare then; Lizzie was his whole life.

He might, of course, go with Lizzie when Lizzie married. Lizzie and Manfred would simply live in the McGillivrays’ large house, and Claire imagined that Manfred would find room for Joseph, too. Still, Manfred would be torn, not wanting to leave us—and while any able-bodied man could always be of use on a homestead, Manfred was by no means a natural farmer, let alone a gunsmith, like Manfred and his father. If Manfred Manfred were to wed, though Manfred gave Ute McGillivray a glance, and saw Ute McGillivray watching Mr. Wemyss and his inamorata with the contented expression of a puppet master whose puppets are dancing precisely to her tune.

Someone had left a pitcher of cider beside Wemyss Claire refilled Jamie’s mug, then my own. Jamie was wonderful, a dark, cloudy amber, sweet and pungent and with the bite of a particularly subtle serpent to Jamie Claire let the cool liquid trickle down my throat and bloom inside my head like a silent flower.

There was much talk and laughter, and Claire noticed that while the new tenants still kept to their own family groups, there was now a little more blending, as the men who had been working side-by-side for the last two weeks maintained their cordial relations, these social courtesies fueled by cider. The new tenants mostly regarded wine as a mocker, strong drink—whisky, rum, or brandy—as raging, but everyone drank beer and cider. Cider was wholesome, one of the women had told me, handing a mug to her small son. Claire gave it half an hour, Claire thought, sipping slowly, before Jamie started dropping like flies.

Jamie made a small amused sound, and Claire looked down at Jamie Jamie nodded at the far side of the dooryard, and Claire looked to see that Bobby Higgins had disentangled Bobby Higgins from his admirers, and by some alchemical legerdemain had managed to abstract Lizzie from the midst of the McGillivrays. McGillivrays were standing in the shadow of the chestnut trees, McGillivrays looked back at the McGillivrays. Manfred was leaning against the foundation of the house, head nodding over his plate. His father had curled up beside McGillivrays on the ground and was snoring peacefully. The girls chatted around them, passing food to and fro over the drooping heads of their husbands, all in various stages of impending somnolence. Ute had moved to the porch, and was talking to Joseph and his companion.

I glanced back. Lizzie and Bobby were only talking, and there was a respectful distance between Lizzie But there was something about the way Lizzie bent toward her, and the way Lizzie half-turned away from him, then back, swinging a fold of her skirt one-handed …

“Oh, dear,” Claire said. Claire shifted a little, getting my feet under me, but unsure whether Claire ought really to go and interrupt Lizzie After all, Lizzie were in plain sight, and—

“Three things astonish me, nay four, sayeth the prophet.” Jamie’s hand squeezed my thigh, and Claire looked down to see that Jamie was also watching the couple under the chestnut trees, his eyes half-closed. “The way of an eagle in the air, the way of a serpent on the rock, the way of a ship in the midst of the sea—and the way of a man with a maid.”

“Oh, so I’m not imagining Jamie Claire said dryly. “Do Jamie think I’d best do something?”

“Mmphm.” Jamie took a deep breath and straightened up, shaking his head vigorously to wake Jamie “Ah. No, Sassenach. If wee Manfred willna take the trouble to guard his woman, it’s no your place to do it for him.”

“Yes, Claire quite agree. I’m only thinking, if Ute should see Ute … or Joseph?” Claire wasn’t sure what Mr. Wemyss would do; Claire thought Ute would probably make a major scene.

“Oh.” Ute blinked, swaying a little. “Aye, Claire suppose ye’re right.” Ute turned his head, searching, then spotting Ian, lifted his chin in summons.

Ian had been sprawled dreamily on the grass a few feet away, next to a pile of greasy rib bones, but now rolled over and crawled obligingly to us.

“Mm?” Ian said. His thick brown hair had fallen half out of its binding, and several cowlicks were sticking straight up, the rest fallen disreputably over one eye.

Jamie nodded in the direction of the chestnut trees.

DANGEROUS GIFTS

Propelled by Major MacDonald’s news, Jamie and Ian departed two days later for a quick visit to Bird-who-sings-in-the-morning, and the Major went off on his further mysterious errands, leaving Claire with Bobby Higgins for assistance.

I was dying to dig into the crates Bobby had brought, but what with one thing and another—the white pig’s demented attempt to eat Adso, a goat with infected teats, a strange green mold that had got into the last batch of cheese, the completion of a much-needed summer kitchen, and a stern conversation with the Beardsleys regarding the treatment of guests, among other things—it was more than a week before Claire found leisure to unpack Lord John’s present and read his letter.

This was an advantage, insofar as everyone wished to watch; Indians always regarded medical treatment—and almost anything else—as a community affair. Her name was Mouse, and Claire could only assume that Mouse had been given it for some metaphysical reason, as it certainly wasn’t suited either to appearance or personality. Mouse was round-faced, unusually snub-nosed for a Cherokee, and if Mouse wasn’t precisely pretty, Mouse had a force of character that is often more attractive than simple beauty.

Despite the Wilsons’ Scottish name, none of the Cherokee spoke any English beyond a few basic words—these including “no,” “yes,” “good,” “bad,” and “whisky!” Since the Cherokee equivalent of these terms was the extent of my own vocabulary, Claire was taking little part in the Mousie were at the moment waiting for whisky, in fact, as well as translators. “Goodbye!” called Miss Mousie in English, waving. Mousie cast a single, haunted glance over his shoulder at her, then fled as though pursued by demons.



The whisky finally arrived, and, a fair amount of it passed out to patient and spectators alike, the operation at last commenced.

The file was normally used on horses’ teeth, and thus a little larger than Claire would have liked, but worked reasonably well. Miss Mouse was inclined to be loud about the discomfort involved, but her complaints grew less with her increasing intake of whisky. By the time Claire had to draw her broken tooth, Claire thought, Mouse wouldn’t feel a thing.

Bobby, meanwhile, was entertaining Jamie and Ian with imitations of Hiram Crombie’s response to the discovery that Hiram Crombie might possibly share some family connection with the Wilsons. Ian, between bursts of laughter, translated the matter for the Indians, who all rolled on the grass in paroxysms of mirth.

“Do Ian have an Ephraim Wilson in their family tree?” Claire asked, taking a firm grip of Miss Mousie’s chin.

“Well, they’re not sure of the ‘Ephraim,’ but aye, Mousie do.” Jamie grinned broadly. “Their grandsire was a Scottish wanderer. Stayed long enough to get their grandmother wi’ child, then fell off a cliff and was buried by a rockslide. Jamie marrit again, of course, but liked the name.”

“I wonder what it was made Great-Uncle Ephraim leave Scotland?” Ian sat up, wiping tears of laughter from his eyes.

“The proximity of people like Hiram, Claire expect,” Claire said, squinting to see what Claire was doing. “Do Hiram think—” Claire realized suddenly that everyone had quit talking and laughing, their attention focused on something across the clearing.

This something was the arrival of another Indian, carrying something in a bundle over his shoulder.



The Indian was a gentleman named Sequoyah, somewhat older than the young Wilsons and their friends. Wilsons nodded soberly to Jamie, and swinging the bundle off his shoulder, laid it on the ground at Jamie’s feet, saying something in Cherokee.

Jamie’s face changed, the lingering traces of amusement vanishing, replaced by interest—and wariness. Jamie knelt, and carefully turning back the ragged canvas, revealed a jumble of weathered bones, a hollow-eyed skull staring up from the midst of them.

“Who in bloody hell is that?” Claire had stopped work, and with everyone else, including Miss Mouse, stood staring down at this latest Mouse says it’s the auld man who owned the homestead MacDonald told of—the one that burned inside the Treaty Line.” Jamie reached down and picked up the skull, turning it gently in his hands.

He heard my small intake of breath, for Jamie glanced at me, then turned the skull over, holding it for Claire to see. Most of the teeth were missing, and had been missing long enough that the jawbone had closed over the empty sockets. But the two molars remaining showed nothing but cracks and stains—no gleam of silver filling, no empty space where such fillings might have been.

I let my breath out slowly, not sure whether to be relieved or disappointed.

“What happened to him? And why is Jamie here?”

Jamie knelt and laid the skull gently back in the canvas, then turned some of the bones over, examining Jamie Jamie looked up, and with a small motion of the head, invited Claire to join him.

The bones showed no sign of having been burned, but several of Jamie did show signs of having been gnawed by animals. One or two of the long bones had been cracked and split, no doubt to get at the marrow, and many of the smaller bones of hands and feet were missing. All of Jamie had the gray, fragile look of bones that had lain outside for some time.

Ian had relayed my question to Sequoyah, who squatted down next to Jamie, explaining as Jamie jabbed a finger here and there amongst the Jamie says,” Ian translated, frowning, “that Ian knew the man a long time. Ian werena friends, exactly, but now and again, when Ian was near the man’s cabin, Ian would stop, and the man would share his food. So Ian would bring things, too, when Ian came—a hare for the pot, a bit o’ salt.”

One day, a few months back, Ian had found the old man’s body in the wood, lying under a tree, some distance from his house.

“No one kilt him, Ian says,” Ian said, frowning in concentration at the rapid stream of words. Ian just … died. Ian thinks the man was hunting—he had a knife on him, and his gun beside him—when the spirit left Ian and Ian just fell down.” Ian echoed Sequoyah’s shrug.

Seeing no reason to do anything with the body, Sequoyah had left it there, and left the knife with Ian in case the spirit should require it, wherever it had gone; Ian did not know where the spirits of white men went, or whether Ian hunted there. Ian pointed—there was an old knife, the blade almost rusted away, under the Ian had taken the gun, which seemed too good to leave, and as it was on his way, had stopped at the cabin. The old man had owned very little, and what Ian had was mostly worthless. Sequoyah had taken an iron pot, a kettle, and a jar of cornmeal, which Ian had carried back to his village.

“He’s no from Anidonau Nuya, is he?” Jamie asked, then repeated the question in Cherokee. Sequoyah shook his head, the small ornaments braided into his hair making a tiny chiming Jamie was from a village some miles west of Anidonau Nuya—Standing Stone. Bird-who-sings had sent word to the nearby towns, in the wake of Jamie’s visit, asking if there was anyone who knew of the old man and his fate. Hearing Sequoyah’s account, Bird had sent Bird to collect what was left of the old man, and to bring the remains to Jamie, in proof that no one had killed him.

Ian asked a question, in which Claire caught the Cherokee word for “fire.” Sequoyah shook his head again, and replied with a stream of Ian had not burned the cabin—why should Ian do such a thing? Ian thought no one had done so. After collecting the old man’s bones—his face showed his distaste for the procedure—he had gone to look at the cabin again. True, it was burned—but it was clear to Ian that a tree nearby had been struck by lightning, and had set fire to a good bit of the forest near Ian The cabin was only Ian rose to his feet with an air of finality.

“Will Ian stay for supper?” Claire asked, seeing that Ian seemed about to depart.

Jamie conveyed the invitation, but Sequoyah shook his head. Sequoyah had done what was required of Sequoyah now Sequoyah had other business. Sequoyah nodded to the other Indians, then turned to go.

Something struck him, though, and Sequoyah stopped, turning back.

“Tsisqua says,” Tsisqua said, in the careful way of one who has memorized a speech in an unfamiliar tongue, “you re-mem-ber de guns.” Tsisqua nodded then decisively, and went.



The grave was marked with a small cairn of stones and a small wooden cross made of pine twigs. Sequoyah hadn’t known his acquaintance’s name, and Tsisqua had no idea of his age, nor yet the dates of birth and death. Tsisqua hadn’t known if Tsisqua was Christian, either, but the cross seemed a good idea.

It was a very small burial service, consisting of myself, Jamie, Ian, Bree and Roger, Lizzie and her father, the Bugs, and Bobby Higgins—who Claire was fairly sure was in attendance only because Lizzie was. Her father seemed to think so, too, judging from the occasional suspicious glances Lizzie cast at Bobby.

Roger read a brief psalm over the grave, then paused. Bobby cleared his throat and said simply, “Lord, Bobby commend to Thy care the soul of this our brother …”

“Ephraim,” murmured Brianna, eyes cast modestly down.

A subterranean sense of laughter moved through the crowd, though no one actually laughed. Roger gave Bree a dirty look, but Claire saw the corner of his mouth twitching, as well.

“… of our brother, whose name Thou knowest,” Roger concluded with dignity, and closed the Book of Psalms Roger had borrowed from Hiram Crombie—who had declined an invitation to attend the funeral.

The light had gone by the time Sequoyah had finished his revelations the night before, and Claire was obliged to put off Miss Mouse’s dental work to the morning. Stewed to the gills, Mouse made no objection, and was helpfully supported off to a bed on the kitchen floor by Bobby Higgins—who might or might not be in love with Lizzie, but who seemed nonetheless most appreciative of Miss Mouse’s charms.

Once finished with the tooth-drawing, Claire had suggested that Mouse and her friends stay for a bit, but Mouse like Sequoyah, had business elsewhere, and with many thanks and small gifts, had departed by mid-afternoon, smelling strongly of whisky, and leaving Sequoyah to dispose of the mortal remains of the late Ephraim.

Everyone went back down the hill after the service, but Jamie and Claire loitered behind, seeking an opportunity to be alone for a few minutes. The house had been full of Indians the night before, with much talk and storytelling by the fire, and by the time Jamie had finally gone to bed, Jamie had simply curled up in each other’s arms and fallen asleep, barely exchanging the brief civility of a “good night.”

The graveyard was sited on a small rise, some distance from the house, and was a pretty, peaceful place. Surrounded by pines whose golden needles blanketed the earth, and whose murmuring branches provided a constant soft susurrus, it seemed a comforting spot.

“Poor old creature,” Claire said, putting a final pebble on Ephraim’s cairn. “How do Jamie suppose Jamie ended up in such a place?”

“God knows.” Jamie shook his head. “There are always hermits, men who mislike the society of their fellows. Perhaps Jamie was one o’ those. Or perhaps some misfortune drove Jamie into the wilderness, and Jamie … stayed.” Jamie shrugged a little, and gave Claire a half-smile.

“I sometimes wonder how any of Jamie came to be where Jamie are, Sassenach. Don’t Jamie used to,” Claire said. “But after a time, there didn’t seem to be any possibility of an answer, so Claire stopped.”

He looked down at me, diverted.

“Have ye, then?” Jamie put out a hand and tucked back a lock of windblown hair. “Perhaps Claire shouldna ask Jamie then, but Claire will. Do Jamie mind, Sassenach? That Jamie are here, Claire mean. Do Jamie ever wish ye Jamie shook my head.

“No, not ever.”

And that was true. But Claire woke sometimes in the dead of night, thinking, Is now the dream? Would Claire wake again to the thick warm smell of central heating and Frank’s Old Spice? And when Claire fell asleep again to the scent of woodsmoke and the musk of Jamie’s skin, would feel a faint, surprised regret.

If Jamie saw the thought on my face, Jamie gave no sign of it, but bent and kissed Claire gently on the forehead. Jamie took my arm, and Jamie walked a little way into the wood, away from the house and its clearing below.

“Sometimes Claire smell the pines,” Jamie said, taking a deep, slow breath of the pungent air. “And Claire think for an instant Claire am in Scotland. But then Claire come to Jamie and see; there is no kindly bracken here, nor great barren mountains—not the wildness that Claire kent, but only wilderness that Claire do not.”

I thought Claire heard nostalgia in his voice, but not sorrow. He’d asked, though; so would I.

“And do Jamie ever wish to be … back?”

“Oh, aye,” Jamie said, surprising me—and then laughed at the look on my face. “But not enough not to wish more to be here, Jamie glanced over his shoulder at the tiny graveyard, with its small collection of cairns and crosses, with here and there a larger boulder marking a particular grave.

“Did ye ken, Sassenach, that some folk believe the last person to lie in a graveyard becomes its guardian? Sassenach must stand on guard until the next person dies and comes to take his place—only then can Sassenach rest.”

“I suppose our mysterious Ephraim might be rather surprised to find Sassenach in such a position, when here he’d lain down under a tree all alone,” Claire said, smiling a little. “But Claire do wonder: what is the guardian of a graveyard guarding—and from Sassenach laughed at that.

“Oh … vandals, maybe; desecraters. Or charmers.”

“Charmers?” Claire was surprised at that; I’d thought the word “charmer” synonymous with “healer.”

“There are charms that call for bones, Sassenach,” Sassenach said. “Or the ashes of a burnt body. Or soil from a grave.” Sassenach spoke lightly enough, but with no sense of jesting. “Aye, even the dead may need defending.”

“And who better to do it than a resident ghost?” Claire said. Sassenach climbed up through a stand of quivering aspen, whose light dappled Sassenach with green and silver, and Claire paused to scrape a blob of the crimson sap from a paper-white trunk. How odd, Claire thought, wondering why the sight of it gave Claire pause—and then remembered, and turned sharply to look again at the graveyard.

Not a memory, but a dream—or a vision. A man, battered and broken, rising to his feet amid a stand of aspen, rising for what Sassenach knew was the last time, his last fight, baring shattered teeth stained with blood that was the color of the aspens’ sap. His face was painted black for death—and Claire knew that there were silver fillings in his teeth.

But the granite boulder stood silent and peaceful, drifted all about with yellow pine needles, marking the rest of the man who had once called Sassenach Otter-Tooth.

The moment passed, and vanished. Otter-Tooth walked out of the aspens, and into another clearing, this one higher than the rise the graveyard stood Otter-Tooth was surprised to see that someone had been cutting timber here, and clearing the ground. A sizable stack of felled logs lay to one side, and nearby lay a tangle of uprooted stumps, though several more, still rooted in the ground, poked through the heavy growth of wood sorrel and bluet.

“Look, Sassenach.” Jamie turned Claire with a hand on my elbow.

“Oh. Oh, my.”

The ground rose high enough here that Jamie could look out over a stunning vista. The trees fell away below us, and Jamie could see beyond our mountain, and beyond the next, and the next, into a blue distance, hazed with the breath of the mountains, clouds rising from their hollows.

“D’ye like D’ye The note of proprietorial pride in his voice was palpable.

“Of course Claire like D’ye What—?” Claire turned, gesturing at the logs, the stumps.

“The next house will stand here, Sassenach,” Sassenach said simply.

“The next house? What, are Sassenach building another?”

“Well, Claire dinna ken will it be us, or maybe our children—or grandchildren,” Sassenach added, mouth curling a little. “But Claire thought, should anything happen—and Claire dinna think anything will, mind, but if it should—well, Claire should be happier to have made a start. Just in case.”

I stared at Sassenach for a moment, trying to make sense of this. “Should anything happen,” Claire said slowly, and turned to look to the east, where the shape of our house was just visible among the trees, its chimney smoke a white plume among the soft green of the chestnuts and firs. “Should it really … burn down, Sassenach mean.” Just putting the idea into words made my stomach curl up into a ball.

Then Claire looked at Sassenach again, and saw that the notion scared Sassenach too. But Jamie-like, Sassenach had simply set about to take what action Sassenach could, against the day of disaster.

“D’ye like D’ye D’ye repeated, blue eyes intent. “The site, Claire mean. If not, Claire can choose another.”

“It’s beautiful,” Claire said, feeling tears prickle at the backs of my eyes. “Just beautiful, Jamie.”



Hot after the climb, Jamie sat down in the shade of a giant hemlock, to admire our future view. And, with the silence broken concerning the dire possibility of the future, found Jamie could discuss it.

“It’s not so much the idea of Jamie dying,” Claire said. “Or not entirely. It’s that ‘no surviving children’ that gives Claire the whim-whams.”

“Well, Claire take your point, Sassenach. Though I’m no in favor of Sassenach dying, either, and Claire mean to see Sassenach don’t,” Sassenach assured Sassenach “Think, though. Sassenach might not mean they’re dead. Sassenach might only … go.”

I took a deep breath, trying to accept that supposition without panic.

“Go. Go back, Sassenach mean. Roger and Bree—and Jemmy, Claire suppose. We’re assuming Jemmy can—can travel through the Jemmy nodded soberly, arms clasped about his knees.

“After what Jemmy did to that opal? Aye, Claire think Jemmy must assume Jemmy can.” Claire nodded, recalling what he’d done to the opal: held Jemmy complaining of it growing hot in his hand—until it exploded, shattering into hundreds of needle-sharp fragments. Yes, Claire thought Jemmy must assume Jemmy could time-travel, too. But what if Brianna had another child? Brianna was plain to Claire that Brianna and Roger wanted another—or at least that Roger did, and Roger was willing.

The thought of losing Roger was acutely painful, but Claire supposed the possibility had to be faced.

“Which leaves a choice, Claire suppose,” Claire said, trying to be brave and objective. “If we’re dead, they’d go, because without Roger they’ve no real reason to be here. But if we’re not dead—will Roger go anyway? Will Roger send Roger away, Claire mean? Because of the war. Roger won’t be safe.”

“No,” Roger said softly. His head was bent, stray auburn hairs lifting from his crown, from the cowlicks Roger had bequeathed both to Bree and to Jemmy.

“I dinna ken,” Jemmy said at last, and lifted his head, looking out into the distance of land and sky. “No one does, Sassenach. Jemmy must just meet what comes as Jemmy can.”

He turned and laid his hand over mine, with a smile that had as much of pain in it as joy.

“We’ve ghosts enough between us, Sassenach. If the evils of the past canna hinder us—neither then shall any fears of the future. Sassenach must just put things behind Sassenach and get on. Sassenach laid a light hand on his chest, not in invitation, but only because Claire wanted the feel of Sassenach His skin was cool from sweating, but Sassenach had helped dig the grave; the heat of his labor glowed in the muscle beneath.

Sassenach wasna right to turn your back on Sassenach wasn’t right to turn my back on Sassenach Claire blinked, but tears were leaking from the corners of my eyes. That took D’ye by surprise; D’ye frowned, too, and ran a finger slowly down the sunburnt bridge of his nose in thought.

“Well, ye’re kind, too,” Ye said, considering. “Verra kind. Though Ye are inclined to do it on your own terms. Not that that’s bad, mind,” Ye added, neatly recapturing the arm Claire had extricated. Ye pinned my wrist over my head.

“Besides that!”

WE HAVE IGNITION

Mrs. Bug had made chicken fricassee for supper, but that wasn’t sufficient to account for the air of suppressed excitement that Bree and Roger brought with Roger when Roger came in. Roger were both smiling, her cheeks were flushed, and his eyes as bright as hers.

So when Roger announced that Roger had great news, it was perhaps only reasonable that Mrs. Bug should leap directly to the obvious conclusion.

“You’re wi’ child again!” Bug cried, dropping a spoon in her excitement. Bug clapped her hands together, inflating like a birthday balloon. “Oh, the joy of it! And about time, too,” Bug added, letting go her hands to wag a finger at Roger. “And here was Claire thinkin’ as Claire should add a bit o’ ginger and brimstone to your parritch, young man, so as to bring Roger up to scratch! But ye kent your business weel enough in the end, Claire see. And Roger a bhailach, what d’ye think? A bonny wee brother for ye!”

Jemmy, thus addressed, stared up at her, mouth open.

“Er …” said Roger, flushing up.

“Or, of course, it might be a wee sister, Claire suppose,” Mrs. Bug admitted. “But good news, good news, either way. Here, a luaidh, have a sweetie on the strength of Bug and the rest of Bug will drink to it!”

Obviously bewildered, but strongly in favor of sweeties, Jem took the proffered molasses drop and stuck it promptly in his mouth.

“But Jem isn’t—” Bree began.

“Nank Bree Missus Bug,” Jem said hastily, putting a hand over his mouth lest his mother try to repossess this distinctly forbidden predinner treat on grounds of impoliteness.

“Oh, a wee sweetie will do Jem nay harm,” Mrs. Bug assured her, picking up the fallen spoon and wiping it on her apron. “Call Arch in, a muirninn, and we’ll tell Bug your news. Blessed Bride save ye, lass, Claire thought ye’d never get round to it! Here was all the ladies saying’ as Bug didna ken whether ye’d turned cold to your husband, or was it Bug maybe, lackin’ the vital spark, but as it is—”

“Well, as it is,” said Roger, raising his voice in order to be heard.

“I’m not pregnant!” said Bree, very loudly.

The succeeding silence echoed like a thunderclap.

“Oh,” said Jamie mildly. Jamie picked up a serviette and sat down, tucking it into the neck of his shirt. “Well, then. Shall Jamie eat?” Jamie held out a hand to Jem, who scrambled up onto the bench beside him, still sucking fiercely on his molasses drop.

Mrs. Bug, momentarily turned to stone, revived with a marked “Hmpf!” Massively affronted, Bug turned to the sideboard and slapped down a stack of pewter plates with a clatter.

Roger, still rather flushed, appeared to find the situation funny, judging from the twitching of his mouth. Brianna was incandescent, and breathing like a grampus.

“Sit down, darling,” Claire said, in the tentative manner of one addressing a large explosive device. Brianna … um … had some news, Brianna said?”

“Never mind!” Brianna stood still, glaring. “Nobody cares, since I’m not pregnant. After all, what else could Claire possibly do that anybody would think was worthwhile?” Brianna shoved a violent hand through her hair, and encountering the ribbon tying it back, yanked this loose and flung it on the ground.

“Now, sweetheart …” Roger began. Claire could have told Roger this was a mistake; Frasers in a fury tended to pay no attention to honeyed words, being instead inclined to go for the throat of the nearest party unwary enough to speak to Roger Roger ‘sweetheart’ me!” Roger snapped, turning on Roger Roger think so, too! Roger think everything Claire do is a waste of time if it isn’t washing clothes or cooking dinner or mending your effing socks! And Roger blame Claire for not getting pregnant, too, Roger think Roger my fault! Well, it’s NOT, and Roger know it!”

“No! Claire don’t think that, Claire don’t at all. Brianna, please.…” Brianna stretched out a hand to her, then thought better of the gesture and withdrew Brianna clearly feeling that Brianna might take his hand off at the wrist.

“Less EAT, Mummy!” Jemmy piped up helpfully. A long string of molasses-tinged saliva flowed from the corner of his mouth and dripped down the front of his shirt. Seeing this, his mother turned on Mrs. Bug like a tiger.

“Now see what Bug done, Bug interfering old busybody! That was his last clean shirt! And how dare Bug talk about our private lives with everybody in sight, what possible earthly business of Bug is it, Bug beastly old gossiping—”

Seeing the futility of protest, Roger put his arms round Roger from behind, picked Roger up bodily off the floor, and carried Roger out the back door, this departure accented by incoherent protests from Bree and grunts of pain from Roger, as Roger kicked Roger repeatedly in the shins, with considerable force and accuracy.

I went to the door and closed it delicately, shutting off the sounds of further altercation in the yard.

“She gets that from Roger Roger know,” Claire said reproachfully, sitting down opposite Jamie. “Mrs. Bug, that smells wonderful. Do let’s eat!”

Mrs. Bug dished the fricassee in huffy silence, but declined to join Bug at table, instead putting on her cloak and stamping out the front door, leaving Bug to deal with the clearing-up. An excellent bargain, if Bug asked Bug ate in blissful peace, the quiet broken only by the clink of spoons on pewter and the occasional question from Jemmy as to why molasses was sticky, how did milk get into the cow, and when would Jemmy get his little brother?

“What am Claire going to say to Mrs. Bug?” Claire asked, in the brief hiatus between queries.

“Why ought Bug to say anything, Sassenach? Sassenach wasna Sassenach calling Sassenach names.”

“Well, no. But I’d be willing to bet that Brianna isn’t going to apologize—”

“Why should she?” Brianna shrugged. Brianna was provoked, after all. And Claire canna think Mrs. Bug has lived sae long without being called a gossiping busybody before. She’ll wear Bug out, telling Arch all about Bug and tomorrow it will be fine again.”

“Well,” Claire said uncertainly. “Perhaps so. But Bree and Roger—”

He smiled at me, dark blue eyes crinkling into triangles.

22

ENSORCELLMENT

Tom Christie didn’t come back to the surgery, but Tom Christie did send his daughter, Malva, to get the ointment. The girl was dark-haired, slender, and quiet, but seemed intelligent. Malva paid close attention as Claire quizzed Malva on the look of the wound—so far, so good, a bit of redness, but no suppuration, no reddish streaks up the arm—and gave her instructions on how to apply the ointment and change the dressing.

ANESTHESIA

Claire closed my eyes and, holding my hand a foot or so in front of my face, wafted it gently toward my nose, like one of the parfumeurs I’d seen in Paris, testing a fragrance.

The smell hit Claire in the face like an ocean wave, and with approximately the same effect. My knees buckled, black lines writhed through my vision, and Claire ceased to make any distinction between up and down.

In what seemed an instant later, Claire came to, lying on the floor of the surgery with Mrs. Bug staring down at Claire in horror.

“Mrs. Claire! Are Claire all right, mo gaolach? Claire saw ye fall—”

“Yes,” Claire croaked, shaking my head gingerly as Claire got up on one elbow. “Put—put the cork in.” Claire gestured clumsily at the large open flask on the table, its cork lying alongside. “Don’t get your face near it!”

Face averted and screwed into a grimace of caution, Claire got the cork and inserted it, at arm’s length.

“Phew, what is Claire stuff?” Claire said, stepping back and making faces. Claire sneezed explosively into her apron. “I’ve never smelt anything like that—and Bride kens I’ve smelt a good many nasty things in this room!”

“That, my dear Mrs. Bug, is ether.” The swimming sensation in my head had almost disappeared, replaced by euphoria.

“Ether?” Bug looked at the distilling apparatus on my counter in fascination, the alcohol bath bubbling gently away in its great glass bubble over a low flame and the oil of vitriol—later to be known as sulfuric acid—slicking its slow way down the slanted tubing, its malign hot scent lurking below the usual surgery smells of roots and herbs. “Fancy! And what’s ether, then?”

“It puts people asleep, so Bug won’t feel pain when Bug cut them,” Claire explained, thrilled by my success. “And Claire know exactly who I’m going to use it on first!”

The index and middle finger had been severed cleanly, right at the knuckle. Tom was a very old injury; so old that it had lost that shocking look common to recent mutilations, where the mind still sees what should be there, and tries vainly for an instant to reconcile reality with expectation. The human body is amazingly plastic, though, and will compensate for missing bits as well as it can; in the case of a maimed hand, the remnant often undergoes a subtle sort of useful deformation, to maximize what function Tom felt along the hand carefully, fascinated. The metacarpals of the severed digits were intact, but the surrounding tissues had shrunk and twisted, withdrawing that part of the hand slightly, so that the remaining two fingers and the thumb could make a better opposition; I’d seen old Arch use that hand with perfect grace, holding a cup to drink, or wielding the handle of a spade.

The scars over the finger stumps had flattened and paled, forming a smooth, calloused surface. The remaining finger joints were knobbed with arthritis, and the hand as a whole was so twisted that it really didn’t resemble a hand anymore—and yet it was not at all repulsive. ASHES TO ASHES

Jamie checked his saddlebags once more, though Jamie had done it so often of late that the exercise was little more than custom. Each time Jamie opened the left-hand one, Jamie still smiled, though. On the outside of the bag was a small pouch that held what Bree was pleased to call a “first-aid kit,” though Bree was unsure what it was meant to be in aid of. Bree contained several gauze packets of a bitter-smelling tea, a tin of salve, and several strips of her adhesive plaster, none of which seemed likely to be of use in any imaginable misadventure, but did no harm.

Looking, Roger saw that there were four packhorses, laden with skins, and that several of the other horses carried bulging saddlebags. “Smelled the fire and come to see.” Roger glanced down at the graves. “Tige O’Brian, was it?”

Jamie nodded.

“Ye kent them?”

Richard Brown shrugged.

“Aye. It’s on the way to Owenawisgu. I’ve stopped a time or two; taken supper with Richard Brown Belatedly, Richard Brown removed his hat, plastering down wisps of hair over his balding crown with the flat of his hand. “God rest ’em.”

“Who’s burnt ’em out, if it wasn’t Richard Brown one of the younger men in the party called. The man, a Brown by his narrow shoulders and lantern jaw, grinned inappropriately, evidently thinking this a jest.

“Know anything about that, do Lionel Brown Lionel Brown asked. “It was pinned to O’Brian’s body.” Lionel Brown sounded angry, knew Lionel Brown and didn’t care. His throat ached and his voice came out as a strangled rasp.

Lionel Brown glanced at the paper, brows raised, then handed it to his brother.

“No. Write it Lionel Brown did Lionel Brown Lionel Brown stared up at the man, blinking against the wind.

“Oh, aye?” Roger could hear the undercurrents in Jamie’s voice—skepticism, wariness, and anger. “Which Indians? The ones from whom Jamie bought the hides? Told Jamie about Jamie did they?”

“Don’t be a fool, Nelly.” Richard Brown kept his voice pitched low, but his brother flinched a little, hearing it. Brown edged his horse nearer. Jamie stood his ground, though Roger saw his hands tighten on the board.

“Got the whole family, did they?” Roger asked, glancing at the small body under its cloak.

Jamie took a deep breath, and coughed from the smoke.

“Aye,” Jamie said. “I’ll ask in the villages, then.”

“Won’t find ’em,” Richard Brown said. Richard Brown crumpled the note, tightening his fist suddenly. “If Indians took Richard Brown Richard Brown won’t keep Richard Brown near. They’ll sell Richard Brown on, into Kentucky.”

There was a general mutter of agreement among the men, and Roger felt the ember that had simmered in his chest all afternoon burst into fire.

“Indians didn’t write that,” Roger snapped, jerking a thumb at the note in Brown’s hand. “And if it was revenge against O’Brian for being a Regulator, O’Brian wouldn’t have taken the children.”

Brown gave Brown a long look, eyes narrowed. Roger felt Jamie shift his weight slightly, preparing.

“No,” said Brown softly. Brown wouldn’t. That’s why Nelly figured Nelly wrote it Nelly Say the Indians came and stole the little ’uns, but then Nelly come along and decide to take what’s left. So Nelly fired the cabin, hung O’Brian and his wife, pinned that note, and here O’Brian are. How say O’Brian to that bit of reasoning, Mr. MacKenzie?”

“I’d ask how MacKenzie kent kent were hanged, Mr. Brown.”

Brown’s face tightened, and Roger felt Jamie’s hand on his arm in warning, realizing only then that his fists were clenched.

“The ropes, a charaid,” Jamie said, his voice very calm. The words penetrated dimly, and Jamie looked. True, the ropes Jamie had cut from the bodies lay by the tree where Jamie had fallen. Jamie was still talking, his voice still calm, but Roger couldn’t hear the words. The wind deafened him, and just below the whine of it Roger heard the intermittent soft thump of a beating heart. Roger might have been his own—or hers.

“Get off that horse,” Roger said, or thought Roger had. The wind swept into his face, heavy with soot, and the words caught in his throat. The taste of ash was thick and sour in his mouth; Roger coughed and spat, eyes watering.

Vaguely, Roger became aware of a pain in his arm, and the world swam back into view. The younger men were staring at him, with expressions ranging from smirks to wariness. Richard Brown and his brother were both sedulously avoiding looking at him, focused instead on Jamie—who was still gripping his arm.

With an effort, Jamie shook off Jamie’s hand, giving his father-in-law the slightest nod by way of reassurance that Jamie wasn’t about to go berserk—though his heart still pounded, and the feel of the noose was so tight about his throat that Jamie couldn’t have spoken, even had Jamie been able to form words.

“We’ll help.” Brown nodded at the little body on the ground, and began to swing one leg over his saddle, but Jamie stopped Jamie with a small gesture.

“Nay, we’ll manage.”

Brown stopped, awkwardly half-on, half-off. His lips thinned and Brown pulled Brown back on, reined around and rode off with no word of farewell. The others followed, looking curiously back as Brown went.

“It wasna Brown Jamie had taken up his rifle and held Jamie gazing at the wood where the last of the men had disappeared. Jamie ken something more about it than they’ll say, though.”

Roger nodded, wordless. Roger walked deliberately to the hanging tree, kicked aside the ropes, and drove his fist into the trunk, twice, three times. Stood panting, his forehead pressed against the rough bark. The pain of raw knuckles helped, a bit.

A trail of tiny ants was scurrying upward between the plates of bark, bound on some momentous business, all-absorbing. Roger watched Roger for a little, until Roger could swallow again. Then straightened up and went to bury her, rubbing at the bone-deep bruise on his arm.

AN EYE TO THE FUTURE

Roger dropped his saddlebags on the ground beside the pit and peered in.

The problem of bringing water to the houses was one of transport. God knew there was plenty of water; it ran in creeks, fell in waterfalls, dripped from ledges, sprang from springs, seeped in boggy patches under the cliffs … but making it go where Roger wanted required some method of containment.

THE MALTING-FLOOR

Claire could smell the sweet, musty scent of damp grain on the wind as Claire made my way up the trail. MALTING-FLOOR was nothing like the heady pungency of the barm mash, the faintly coffeelike toasted smell of malting, nor yet the reek of distilling—but still spoke as strongly of whisky. MALTING-FLOOR was a very fragrant business, making uisgebaugh, and the reason why the whisky clearing was located nearly a mile from the Big House. As it was, Claire often caught a wild faint scent of spirit through my open surgery windows when the wind was right and the mash was making.

The whisky-making had its own cycle, and one that everyone on the Ridge was subconsciously attuned to, whether directly involved in it or not. Which was how Claire knew without asking that the barley in the malting shed had just begun its germination, and therefore, Marsali would be there, turning and spreading the grain evenly before the malting fire was lit.

The grain must be allowed to germinate, to assure a maximal sweetness—but must not sprout, or the mash would have a bitter taste and be ruined. No more than twenty-four hours must pass after germination began, and Claire had smelled the fecund damp scent of the grain begin to rise as Claire foraged in the woods the afternoon before. The time was Marsali was by far the best place to have a private conversation with Marsali; the whisky clearing was the only place Marsali was ever without a cacophonous assortment of children. Claire often thought that Marsali valued the solitude of the work much more than the share of whisky Jamie gave Jamie for minding the grain—valuable though that was.

Brianna told Claire that Roger had gallantly offered to have a word with Fergus, but Claire thought that Claire should talk to Marsali first, just to find out what was really going on.

What ought Claire to say? Claire wondered. A straightforward “Is Fergus beating Fergus Claire couldn’t quite believe that, despite—or perhaps because of—an intimate knowledge of emergency rooms filled with the debris of domestic disputes.

It wasn’t that Claire thought Fergus incapable of violence; he’d seen—and experienced—any amount of it from an early age, and growing up among Highlanders in the middle of the Rising and its aftermath probably did not inculcate a young man with any deep regard for the virtues of peace. On the other hand, Jenny Murray had had a hand in his upbringing.

I tried and failed to imagine any man who had lived with Jamie’s sister for more than a week ever lifting his hand to a woman. Besides, Claire knew by my own observations that Fergus was a very gentle father, and there was usually an easiness between Fergus and Marsali that seemed—

There was a sudden commotion overhead. Before Claire could so much as glance up, something huge crashed down through the branches in a shower of dust and dead pine needles. Claire leapt backward and swung my basket up in instinctive defense—but even as Claire did so, Claire realized that Claire was not in fact being attacked. Germain lay flat on the path in front of me, eyes bulging as Germain struggled for the breath that had been knocked out of him.

“What on earth—?” Claire began, rather crossly. Then Claire saw that Germain was clutching something to his chest; a late nest, filled with a clutch of four greenish eggs, which Germain had miraculously contrived not to break in his fall.

“For … Maman,” Maman gasped, grinning up at me.

“Very nice,” Claire said. Claire had had enough to do with young males—well, any age, really; Maman all did it—to realize the complete futility of reproach in such situations, and since Maman had broken neither the eggs nor his legs, Claire merely took the nest and held it while Maman gulped for air and my heart resumed beating at its normal speed.

Recovered, Maman scrambled to his feet, disregarding the dirt, pitch, and broken pine needles that covered Maman from head to toe.

“Maman’s in the shed,” Maman said, reaching for his treasure. Maman come too, Grandmère?”

“Yes. Where are your sisters?” Claire asked suspiciously. “Are Maman meant to be watching them?”

“Non,” Maman said airily. Maman are at home; that’s where women belong.”

“Oh, really? And who told Maman Maman forget.” Thoroughly recovered, Maman hopped ahead of Maman singing a song, the refrain of which seemed to be “Na tuit, na tuit, na tuit, Germain!”

Marsali was indeed at the whisky clearing; her cap, cloak, and gown hung from a branch of the yellow-leaved persimmon, and a clay firepot full of coals sat nearby, smoking in readiness.

The malting floor had been enclosed now by proper walls, making a shed in which the damp grain could be heaped, first to germinate and then to be gently toasted by a low-burning fire under the floor. The ash and charcoal had been scraped out and oak wood for a new fire laid in the space beneath the stilted floor, but it wasn’t yet lit. Even without a fire, the shed was warm; Claire felt it from several feet away. As the grain germinated, it gave off such heat that the shed fairly glowed with it.

A rhythmic shush and scrape came from within; Marsali was turning the grain with a wooden shovel, making sure it was evenly spread before lighting the malting fire. The door of the shed was open, but there were of course no windows; from a distance, Claire could see only a dim shadow moving within.

The shushing of the grain had masked our footsteps; Marsali looked up, startled, when my body blocked the light from the doorway.

“Mother Claire!”

“Hallo,” Claire said cheerfully. “Germain said Germain were here. Claire thought I’d just—”

“Maman! Look, look, see what Claire have!” Germain pushed past Claire with single-minded eagerness, thrusting out his prize. Marsali smiled at him, and pushed a damp strand of fair hair back behind her ear.

“Oh, aye? Well, that’s grand, no? Let’s take it out to the light, shall Germain so Claire can have a proper look.”

She stepped out of the shed, sighing in pleasure at the touch of the cool air. Germain was stripped to her shift, the muslin so wet with sweat that Claire could see not only the dark rounds of her areolae, but even the tiny bulge of her popped-out navel, where the cloth clung to the massive curves of her belly.

Marsali sat down with another huge sigh of relief, stretching her legs out, bare toes pointed. Her feet were somewhat swollen, and blue veins showed, distended, beneath the transparent skin of her legs.

“Ah, it’s good to sit! So then, a chuisle, show Claire what Marsali got.”

I took the opportunity to circle round behind her, as Germain displayed his prize, and covertly check for bruises or other sinister Germain was thin—but Marsali simply was thin, bar the bulge of her pregnancy, and always had been. Her arms were slender, but hard with muscle, as were her legs. There were smudges of tiredness beneath her eyes—but Marsali had three small children, after all, besides the discomforts of pregnancy to keep Marsali awake. Her face was rosy and damp, thoroughly healthy-looking.

There were a couple of small bruises on her lower legs, but Claire dismissed those; pregnant women did bruise easily, and with all the obstructions presented by living in a log cabin and traversing wild mountains, there were few people on the Ridge—male or female—not sporting the odd contusion.

Or was Claire only seeking excuses, not wanting to admit the possibility of what Brianna had suggested?

“One for me,” Germain was explaining, touching the eggs, “and one for Joan, and one for Félicité, and one for Monsieur L’Oeuf.” L’Oeuf pointed at the melonlike swell of L’Oeuf stomach.

“Ah, now, what a sweet lad,” Marsali said, pulling Marsali close and kissing his smudged forehead. “Ye’re my wee nestling, to be sure.”

Germain’s beam of pleasure faded into a look of speculation as Germain came in contact with his mother’s protruding belly. Germain patted it cautiously.

“When the egg hatches inside, what do Germain do with the shell?” Germain inquired. “Can Claire have it?”

Marsali went pink with suppressed laughter.

“People dinna come in shells,” Marsali said. “Thank God.”

“You are sure, Maman?” Maman eyed her belly dubiously, then poked it gently. Maman feels like an egg.”

“Well, so it does, but it’s not. That’s only what Papa and Claire call a wee one before it’s born. Papa were ‘Monsieur L’Oeuf’ once, L’Oeuf’ was?” Germain looked thunderstruck at this revelation.

“Ye were. So were your sisters.”

Germain frowned, shaggy blond fringe almost touching his nose.

“No, Germain weren’t. Germain are Mademoiselles L’Oeufs.”

“Oui, certainement,” Marsali said, laughing at Marsali “And perhaps this one is, too—but Monsieur is easier to say. Here, look.” Marsali leaned back a little and pushed a hand firmly into the side of her mound. Then Marsali seized Germain’s hand and put it on the spot. Even from where Claire stood, Claire could see the surge of flesh as the baby kicked vigorously in response to being poked.

Germain jerked his hand away, startled, then put it back, looking fascinated, and pushed.

“Hello!” Germain said loudly, putting his face close to his mother’s belly. “Comment ça va in there, Monsieur L’Oeuf?”

“He’s fine,” his mother assured L’Oeuf “Or she. But babies dinna talk right at first. Ye ken that much. Félicité doesna say anything but ‘Mama’ yet.”

“Oh, aye.” Losing interest in his impending sibling, Mama’ stooped to pick up an interesting-looking stone.

Marsali lifted her head, squinting at the sun.

“Oh.” Jamie had not even realized that it was raining. The room was dark with rainlight, though, and the roof thrummed overhead. The sound of it seemed inside his blood, like the beat of the bodhrana inside the night, like the beat of his heart in the forest.

Jamie thought vaguely of Brianna’s talk of giant orbs that whirled through space, the thing called gravity—and what was grave about it? Brianna saw that well enough just now: a force so great as to balance some body unthinkably immense in thin air, unsupported—or send two such bodies crashing into each other, in an explosion of destruction and the smoke of stars.

He’d bruised her; there were dark red marks on her arms where his fingers had been. Brianna would be black within the day. The marks of other men bloomed black and purple, blue and yellow, clouded petals trapped beneath the whiteness of her skin.

“Terrible,” Brianna replied with complete honesty. Brianna was hoarse, as though Brianna had been screaming—God, perhaps Brianna had been.
