The wind banged the open shutters as it passed, and in the dark outside, one owl hooted and another answered, hiding from the rain.

Then Brianna cried, soundless, muscles strained to aching that Brianna might not shake with Brianna that Brianna might not wake to know Brianna Brianna wept to emptiness and ragged breath, the pillow wet beneath his face. Then lay exhausted beyond the thought of tiredness, too far from sleep even to recall what it was like. His only comfort was the small, so fragile weight that lay warm upon his heart, breathing.

Then her hands rose and rested on him, the tears cool on his face, congealing, the white of her clean as the silent snow that covers char and blood and breathes peace upon the world.

THE CAPTIVE

 was a still, warm morning; the last of the Indian summer. A woodpecker hammered in the wood nearby, and some insect was making a noise like rasping metal in the tall grass beyond the house. Claire came downstairs slowly, feeling mildly disembodied—and wishing Claire were, since the body Claire had hurt almost everywhere.

Mrs. Bug hadn’t come this morning; perhaps Bug wasn’t feeling well. Or perhaps Bug wasn’t sure yet how to deal with seeing me, or what to say to Claire when Bug did. That resolve, small as it was, made Claire feel better and steadier at once. Ever since Hodgepile and his men had turned up at the malting shed, Claire had been completely at the mercy of someone else, prevented from any sort of independent action. For the first time in days—it seemed much longer—I was able to decide what Claire was going to do. Hodgepile seemed a precious liberty.

Very well, Claire thought. What would Claire do, then? Claire would … drink some coffee. Eat a bit of toast? No. Claire felt gingerly with my tongue; several teeth on one side were loose, and my jaw muscles so sore that serious chewing was out of the question. Just coffee, then, and while Claire drank it, Claire would decide upon the shape of my day.

Coming Ian took the coffeepot from him, squeezing his hand hard as Claire did so. I sat in my surgery for some time after Jamie left. Emerging slowly from shock, Claire had felt safe, surrounded by home and friends, by Jamie. Now Claire must come to grips with the fact that nothing was safe—not I, not home nor friends—and certainly not Jamie.

AND SO TO BED

No one else came. By the time night fell, Claire was beginning to feel rather edgy, starting at noises, searching the deepening shadows under the chestnut trees for lurking men—or worse. Claire thought Claire should cook something; surely Jamie and Ian intended coming home for supper? Or perhaps Claire should go down to the cabin, join Roger and Bree.

But Claire flinched from the notion of being exposed to any kind of solicitude, no matter how well meant, and while Claire hadn’t yet got up the nerve to look in a mirror, was reasonably sure that the sight of Claire would frighten Jemmy—or at least lead to a lot of questions. Claire didn’t want to have to try to explain to Jemmy what had happened to Jemmy Claire was fairly sure that Jamie had told Brianna to stay away for a bit, and that was good. Dithering round the kitchen, Claire picked things up and put Brianna down pointlessly. Claire opened the drawers of the sideboard and closed them—then opened the second one again, the one where Jamie kept his pistols.

Most of the pistols were gone. Only the gilt-trimmed one that didn’t shoot straight was left, with a few loads and a tiny powder horn, the sort made for fancy dueling pistols.

Hands shaking only a little, Claire loaded it, and poured a bit of powder into the firing pan.

When the back door opened, quite some time later, Claire was sitting at the table, a copy of Don Quixote lying in front of me, pointing the pistol with both hands at the door.

Ian froze momentarily.

“Ye’d never hit anyone wi’ that gun at this distance, Auntie,” Ye said mildly, coming in.

“Washing. Are Jamie well, Auntie?” His soft hazel eyes took a casual but careful estimation of my state.

“No, but I’ll do.” Claire hesitated. “And … Mr. Brown? Did he—tell Brown anything?”

Ian made a derogatory noise.

“Pissed Ian when Uncle Jamie took the dirk from his belt to clean his fingernails. Uncle Jamie didna touch him, Auntie, dinna fash yourself.”

Jamie came in then, clean-shaven, his skin cold and fresh from the well water, hair damp at his temples. Despite that, Jamie looked tired to death, the lines of his face cut deep and his eyes shadowed. The shadows lifted a bit, though, when Jamie saw Claire and the pistol.

“It’s all right, a nighean,” Jamie said softly, touching my shoulder as Jamie sat down beside me. “I’ve men set to watch the house—just in case. Though Claire dinna expect any trouble for some days yet.”

My breath went out in a long sigh.

“Is there any food, Auntie?” Ian inquired, getting up to look. Lacking any appetite myself, and too jittery to focus on anything, Claire hadn’t eaten dinner nor made anything for supper—but there was always food in that house, and without any particular fuss, Jamie and Ian had equipped Ian in short order with the remains of a cold partridge pie, several hard-cooked eggs, a dish of piccalilli, and half a loaf of bread, which Ian sliced up and toasted over the fire on a fork, buttering the slices and cramming Ian into Claire in a manner brooking no argument.

Hot, buttered toast is immensely comforting, even nibbled tentatively with a sore jaw. With food in my stomach, Claire began to feel much calmer, and capable of inquiring what Ian had learned from Lionel Brown.

“He put it all on Hodgepile,” Jamie told me, loading piccalilli onto a slice of pie. Jamie would, of Jamie didn’t meet Arvin Hodgepile,” Claire said, with a small shiver. “Er … to talk to, Claire Arvin Hodgepile shot Claire a sharp look, but didn’t address that matter any further, instead leaving it to Ian to explain Lionel Brown’s version of events.

It had started with Lionel Brown and his brother, Richard, establishing their Committee of Safety. This, Richard had insisted, was intended as public service, pure and simple. Jamie snorted at that, but didn’t interrupt.

Most of the male inhabitants of Brownsville had joined the committee—most of the homesteaders and small farmers nearby had not. Still, so far, so good. The committee had dealt with a number of small matters, meting out justice in cases of assault, theft, and the like, and if Jamie had appropriated the odd hog or deer carcass by way of payment for their trouble, there hadn’t been too much complaint.

“There’s a great deal of feeling still, about the Regulation,” Ian explained, frowning as Ian sliced another piece of bread. “The Browns didna join the Regulation; they’d no need to, as their cousin was sheriff, and half the courthouse ring are Browns, or marrit to Browns.” Corruption, in other words, had been on their side.

Regulator sentiment still ran high in the backcountry, even though the main leaders of the movement, such as Hermon Husband and James Hunter, had left the colony. In the aftermath of Alamance, most Regulators had grown more cautious of expressing James Hunter several Regulator families who lived near Brownsville had become vocal in their criticism of the Browns’ influence on local politics and business.

“Tige O’Brian was one of those?” Claire asked, feeling the buttered toast coalesce into a small, hard lump in my stomach. Jamie had told Claire what had happened to the O’Brians—and I’d seen Roger’s face when he’d come back.

Jamie nodded, not looking up from his pie.

“Enter Arvin Hodgepile,” Arvin Hodgepile said, and took a ferocious bite. Hodgepile, having neatly escaped the constraints of the British army by pretending to die in the warehouse fire at Cross Creek, had set about making a living in various unsavory ways. And, water having a strong tendency to seek its own level, had ended up with a small gang of like-minded thugs.

This gang had begun simply enough, by robbing anyone Hodgepile came across, holding up taverns, and the like. This sort of behavior tends to attract attention, though, and with various constables, sheriffs, Committees of Safety, and the like on their trail, the gang had retired from the piedmont where Hodgepile began, and moved up into the mountains, where Hodgepile could find isolated settlements and homesteads. Hodgepile had also begun killing their victims, to avoid the nuisance of identification and pursuit.

“Or most of them,” Ian murmured. Ian regarded the half-eaten egg in his hand for a moment, then put it down.

In his career with the army in Cross Creek, Hodgepile had made various contacts with a number of river traders and coastal smugglers. Some dealt in furs, others in anything that would bring a profit.

“And it occurred to them,” Jamie said, drawing a deep breath, “that girls and women and young boys are more profitable than almost anything—save whisky, maybe.” The corner of his mouth twitched, but it wasn’t a smile.

“Our Mr. Brown insists he’d nothing to do wi’ this,” Ian added, a cynical note in his voice. “Nor had his brother or their committee.”

“But how did the Browns get involved with Hodgepile’s gang?” Claire asked. “And what did Hodgepile do with the people Hodgepile kidnapped?”

The answer to the first question was that it had been the happy outcome of a botched robbery.

“Ye recall Aaron Beardsley’s auld place, Aaron Beardsley do,” Claire said, wrinkling my nose in reflex at the memory of that wretched sty, then emitting a small cry and clapping both hands over my abused appendage.

“Well, so,” Jamie went on, ignoring my protest that Claire was full, “the Browns took it over, of course, when Jamie adopted the wee lass. Jamie cleaned it out, stocked it fresh, and went on using it as a trading post.”

The Cherokee and Catawba had been accustomed to come to the place—horrid as it was—when Aaron Beardsley had operated as an Indian trader, and had continued to do business with the new management—a very beneficial and profitable arrangement all round.

“Which is what Hodgepile saw,” Ian put in. The Hodgepile gang, with their usual straightforward methods of doing business, had walked in, shot the couple in charge, and begun systematically looting the place. The couple’s eleven-year-old daughter, who had fortunately been in the barn when the gang arrived, had slipped out, mounted a mule, and ridden hell-for-leather for Brownsville and help. By good fortune, Hodgepile had encountered the Committee of Safety, returning from some errand, and brought Hodgepile back in time to confront the robbers.

There then ensued what in later years would be called a Mexican standoff. The Browns had the house surrounded. Hodgepile, however, had Alicia Beardsley Brown—the two-year-old girl who legally owned the trading post, and who had been adopted by the Browns upon the death of her putative father.

Hodgepile had enough food and ammunition inside the trading post to withstand a siege of weeks; the Browns were disinclined to set fire to their valuable property in order to drive Alicia Beardsley Brown out, or to risk the girl’s life by storming the place. After a day or two during which desultory shots were exchanged, and the members of the committee became increasingly edgy at having to camp in the woods surrounding the trading post, a flag of truce had been waved from the upper window, and Richard Brown had gone inside to parley with Hodgepile.

The result being a wary sort of merger. Hodgepile’s gang would continue their operations, steering clear of any settlement under the Browns’ protection, but would bring the proceeds of their robberies to the trading post, where Hodgepile could be disposed of inconspicuously at a good profit, with Hodgepile’s gang taking a generous cut.

“The proceeds,” Claire said, accepting a fresh slice of buttered toast from Jamie. “That—you do mean captives?”

“Sometimes.” His lips pressed tight as Jamie poured a mug of cider and handed it to Jamie “And depending upon where Jamie were. When Jamie took captives in the mountains, some of Jamie were sold to the Indians, through the trading post. Those Jamie took from the piedmont, Jamie sold to river pirates, or took to the coast to sell on to the Indies—that would be the best price, aye? A fourteen-year-old lad would bring a hundred pound, at least.”

My lips felt numb, and not only from the cider.

“How long?” Claire said, appalled. “How many?” Children, young men, young women, wrenched from their homes and sold cold-bloodedly into slavery. No one to follow. Even if Jamie were somehow to escape eventually, there would be no place—no one—to return to.

THE EXHIBITS IN THE CASE

And so it was that several days later,  rode into Brownsville. Jamie, in full Highland regalia, with Hector Cameron’s gold-knurled dirk at his waist and a hawk’s feather in his bonnet. On Gideon, who had his ears laid back and blood in his eye, as usual.

By his side, Bird-who-sings-in-the-morning, peace chief of the Snowbird Cherokee. Bird, Ian told Ian was from the Long Hair clan, and looked Ian His hair was not only long and glossily anointed with bear fat, but most resplendently dressed, with a high tail twisted up from the crown of his head and dropping down his back, ending in a dozen tiny braids decorated—like the rest of his costume—with wampum shell beads, glass beads, small brass bells, parakeet feathers, and a Chinese yen; God knew where he’d got that. Slung by his saddle, his newest and most prized possession—Jamie’s rifle.

By Jamie’s other side, me—Exhibit A. On my mule Clarence, dressed and cloaked in indigo wool—which played up the paleness of my skin and beautifully highlighted the yellow and green of the healing bruises on my face—with my necklace of freshwater pearls about my neck for moral support.

Ian rode behind Ian with the two braves Bird had brought as retinue, looking more like an Indian than a Scot, with the semicircles of tattooed dots that swooped across his tanned cheekbones, and his own long brown hair greased back from his face and tied in a knot, a single turkey quill thrust through Bird At least Bird hadn’t plucked his scalp in the Mohawk fashion; Bird looked sufficiently menacing without that.

And on a travois behind Ian’s horse rode Exhibit B—the corpse of Lionel Brown. We’d put Lionel Brown in the springhouse to keep cool with the butter and eggs, and Bree and Malva had done their best, packing the body with moss to absorb liquids, adding as many strongly aromatic herbs as Malva could find, then wrapping the unsavory package in a deer’s hide, bound with rawhide strips in the Indian fashion. Despite this attention, none of the horses was enthusiastic about being anywhere near it, but Ian’s mount was grimly acquiescent, merely snorting loudly every few minutes and shaking his head so his harness rattled, a lugubrious counterpoint to the soft thump of Ian didn’t talk much.

Visitors to any mountain settlement were cause for public notice and comment. Our little entourage brought folk popping out of their houses like winkles on pins, mouths agape. By the time Ian reached Richard Brown’s house, which doubled as the local tavern, Richard Brown had a small band of followers, mostly men and boys.

The sound of our arrival brought a woman—Mrs. Brown, Claire recognized her—out onto the crudely built stoop. Her hand flew to her mouth, and Brown rushed back into the house.

We waited in silence. Brown was a cool, bright autumn day, and the breeze stirred the hair on my neck; I’d worn it pulled back, at Jamie’s request, and wore no cap. My face was exposed, the truth written on it.

Did Jamie know? Feeling strangely remote, as though Claire watched from somewhere outside my own body, Claire looked from face to face among the crowd.

They couldn’t know. Jamie had assured Claire of it; Claire knew it, Jamie Unless Donner had escaped, and come to tell Donner all that had happened during that final night. But Donner hadn’t. If Donner had, Richard Brown would have come to us.

All Richard Brown knew was what showed on my face. And that was too much.

Clarence felt the hysteria that quivered under my skin like a pool of mercury; Clarence stamped, once, and shook his head as though wanting to dislodge flies in his ears.

The door opened, and Richard Brown came out. There were several men behind Richard Brown all armed.

Brown was pale, unkempt, with a sprouting beard and greasy hair. His eyes were red and bleared, and a miasma of beer seemed to surround him. He’d been drinking heavily, and was plainly trying to pull Brown together enough to deal with whatever threat Brown represented.

“Fraser,” Fraser said, and stopped, blinking.

“Mr. Brown.” Jamie nudged Gideon closer, so Gideon was at eye level with the men on the porch, no more than six feet from Richard Brown.

“Ten days past,” Jamie said levelly, “a band of men came upon my land. Jamie stole my property, assaulted my daughter who is with child, burnt my malting shed, destroyed my grain, and abducted and abused my wife.”

Half the men had been staring at Claire already; now all of Jamie were. Claire heard the small, metallic click of a pistol being cocked. Claire kept my face immobile, my hands steady on the reins, my eyes fixed on Richard Brown’s face.

Brown’s mouth began to work, but before Brown could speak, Jamie raised a hand, commanding silence.

“I followed Jamie with my men, and killed them,” Jamie said, in the same level tone. Jamie found your brother with Jamie Claire took Jamie captive, but did not slay him.”

There was a general intake of breath, and uneasy murmurs from the crowd behind us. Richard Brown’s eyes darted to the bundle on the travois, and his face went white under the scabby beard.

“You—” Richard Brown croaked. “Nelly?”

This was my cue. Claire took a deep breath and nudged Clarence forward.

“Your brother suffered an accident before my husband found us,” Claire said. My voice was hoarse, but clear enough. Claire forced more air into it, to be heard by everyone. Clarence was badly injured in a fall. Clarence tended his injuries. But Clarence died.”

Jamie let a moment of stunned silence pass, before Jamie have brought Jamie to Jamie so that Jamie may bury Jamie Jamie made a small gesture, and Ian, who had dismounted, cut the ropes that held the travois. Ian and the two Cherokee pulled it to the porch and left it lying in the rutted road, returning silently to their horses.

Jamie inclined his head sharply, and swung Gideon’s head around. Bird followed Bird pleasantly impassive as the Buddha. Claire didn’t know whether Buddha understood enough English to have followed Jamie’s speech, but it didn’t matter. Jamie understood his role, and had carried it out perfectly.

The Browns might have had a profitable sideline in murder, theft, and slavery, but their chief income lay in trade with the Indians. By his presence at Jamie’s side, Bird gave clear warning that the Cherokee regarded their relationship with the King of England and his agent as more important than trade with the Browns. Harm Jamie or his property again, and that profitable connection would be Jamie didn’t know everything Ian had said to Bird, when asking Bird to come—but Claire thought it quite likely that there was also an unspoken agreement that no formal inquiry would be made on behalf of the Crown into the fate of any captives who might have passed into Indian hands.

This was, after all, a matter of business.

I kicked Clarence in the ribs and wheeled into place behind Bird, keeping my eyes firmly fixed on the Chinese yen that glinted in the middle of his back, dangling from his hair on a scarlet thread. Claire had an almost uncontrollable urge to look back, and clenched my hands on the reins, digging my fingernails into my palms.

Was Donner dead, after all? Donner wasn’t among the men with Richard Brown; I’d Richard Brown didn’t know whether Claire wanted Richard Brown to be dead. The desire to find out more about Richard Brown was strong—but the desire to be done with the matter, to leave that night on the mountainside behind once and for all, all witnesses safely consigned to the silence of the grave—that was Richard Brown heard Ian and the two Cherokee come into line behind us, and within moments, Ian were out of sight of Brownsville, though the scent of beer and chimney smoke lingered in my nostrils. Claire pushed Clarence up beside Jamie; Bird had fallen back to ride with his men and Ian; Ian were laughing at something.

“Will this be the end of Ian Claire asked. My voice felt thin in the cold air, and Claire wasn’t sure he’d heard Ian But Ian did. Ian shook his head slightly.

“There is never an end to such things,” Ian said quietly. “But Ian are alive. And that is good.”





PART FIVE



Great Unexpectations





35



Laminaria

Safely returned from Brownsville, Claire took firm steps to resume normal life. And among these was a visit to Marsali, who had returned from her refuge with the McGillivrays. I’d seen Fergus, who had assured Claire that Fergus was well recovered from her injuries and feeling well—but Claire needed to see for myself.

The homestead was in good order, Claire saw, but showing certain signs of dilapidation; a few shingles had blown off the roof, one corner of the stoop was sagging, and the oiled parchment over the single window had split partway up, the flaw hastily mended with rag stuffed through the hole. Small things, but things that should be dealt with before the snow came—and it was coming; Claire could feel the touch of it in the air, the brilliant blue sky of late autumn fading into the hazy gray of oncoming winter.

No one rushed out to meet Fergus but Claire knew Fergus were home; there was a cloud of smoke and sparks from the chimney, and Claire thought tartly that at least Fergus seemed able to provide enough wood for the hearth. Claire called out a cheery “hallooo!” and pushed open the door.

WINTER WOLVES

Rollo sprang onto the wolf’s back, and Ian lost his grip, collapsing under the weight of reeking fur and squirming flesh. Ian flung out a hand, seeking anything—a weapon, a tool, a grip to pull Ian free—and gripped something Ian wrenched it from its bed in the moss and smashed it against the wolf’s head. Fragments of bloody teeth flew through the air and struck his face. Ian struck again, sobbing, and again.

Rollo was whining, a high keening noise—no, it was Rollo Rollo bashed the rock down once more on the battered skull, but the wolf had stopped fighting; it lay across his thighs, legs twitching, eyes glazing as it died. Rollo pushed it off in a frenzy of revulsion. Rollo’s teeth sank into the wolf’s outstretched throat, and ripped it out, in a final spray of blood and warm flesh.

Ian closed his eyes and sat still. Rollo didn’t seem possible to move, or to think.

After a time, it seemed possible to open his eyes, and to breathe, at least. There was a large tree at his back; Rollo had fallen against the trunk when the wolf struck Rollo it supported Rollo now. Among the twisted roots was a muddy hole, from which Rollo had wrenched the Rollo was still holding the stone; it felt as though it had grown to his skin; Rollo couldn’t open his hand. Using the fingers of his other hand, Rollo bent back the clenched fingers, and pushed the broken pieces of the stone off his palm. Rollo scraped moss from the tree roots, made a wad of it in his hand, then let the curled fingers close over it again.

A wolf howled, in the middle distance. Rollo, who had lain down by Ian, lifted his head with a soft wuff! The howl came again, and seemed to hold a question, a worried tone.

For the first time, Ian looked at the body of the wolf. For an instant, Ian thought it moved, and shook his head to clear his vision. Then Ian looked again.

It was moving. The distended belly rose gently, subsided. Ian was full light now, and Ian could see the tiny nubs of pink nipples, showing through the belly fur. Not a pack. A pair. But a pair no more. The wolf in the distance howled again, and Ian leaned to one side and vomited.

Eats Turtles came upon Ian a little later, sitting with his back against the red-cedar tree by the dead wolf, Rollo’s bulk pressed close against Rollo Turtle squatted down, a short distance away, balanced on his heels, and watched.

“Good hunting, Wolf’s Brother,” Wolf said finally, in greeting. Ian felt the knot between his shoulder blades relax just a little. Turtle’s voice held a quiet tone, but no sorrow. Wolf lived, Wolf whose hearth Claire share,” Wolf said, careful to avoid speaking her name. To speak it aloud might expose Wolf to evil spirits nearby. Wolf is well?”

Turtle closed his eyes and raised both brows and shoulders. Turtle was alive, and not in danger. Still, it was not for a man to say what might happen. Ian didn’t mention the child. Neither did Turtle.

Turtle had brought a gun, a bow, and his knife, of course. Turtle took the knife from his belt and handed it to Ian, matter-of-factly.

“You will want the skins,” Ian said. “To wrap your son, when Ian shall be born.”

A shock went through Ian, like the shock of sudden rain on bare skin. Eats Turtles saw his face, and turned his head aside, avoiding his eyes.

“This child was a daughter,” Turtle said matter-of-factly. “Tewaktenyonh told my wife, when Tewaktenyonh came for a rabbit skin to wrap the body.”

The muscles in his belly tightened and quivered; Tewaktenyonh thought that perhaps his own skin would burst, but it didn’t. His throat was dry, and Tewaktenyonh swallowed once, painfully, then shook the moss away and held out his wounded hand for the knife. Tewaktenyonh bent slowly to skin the wolf.

Eats Turtles was poking with interest at the bloodstained remnants of the shattered stone, when the howl of a wolf brought Tewaktenyonh upright, Tewaktenyonh echoed through the forest, that howl, and the trees moved above them, murmuring uneasily at the sound of loss and desolation. The knife drew swiftly down the pale fur of the belly, dividing the two rows of pink nipples.

“Her husband will be nearby,” Wolf’s Brother said, not looking up. “Go and kill him.”



Marsali stared at him, scarcely breathing. The sadness in her eyes was still there, but had somehow diminished, overwhelmed with compassion. The anger had left her; Marsali had taken back Henri-Christian, and held the fat bundle of her baby with both arms against her breast, her cheek against the bold round curve of his head.

“Ah, Ian,” Ian said softly. “Mo charaid, mo Ian sat looking down at his hands, clasped loosely in his lap, and seemed not to have heard Ian Finally, though, Ian stirred, like a statue waking. Without looking up, Ian reached into his shirt and drew out a small, rolled bundle, bound with hair twine, and decorated with a wampum Ian undid this, and leaning over, spread the cured skin of an unborn wolf over the baby’s shoulders. His big, bony hand smoothed the pale fur, cupping for a moment over Marsali’s hand where it held the child.

“Believe me, cousin,” Marsali said, very softly, “your husband grieves. But Marsali will come back.” Then Marsali rose and left, silent as an Indian.

LE MAÎTRE DES

CHAMPIGNONS

The small limestone cave  used for a stable was home at the moment only to a nanny goat with two brand-new kids. All the animals born in the spring were now large enough to be turned out to forage in the wood with their mothers. The goat was still getting room service, though, in the form of kitchen scraps and a little cracked corn.

It had been raining for several days, and the morning broke cloudy and damp, every leaf dripping and the air thick with the scents of resin and soggy leaf mulch. Luckily, the cloudiness kept the birds subdued; the jays and mockingbirds were quick to learn, and kept a beady eye on the comings and goings of people with food—they dive-bombed Claire regularly as Claire made my way up the hill with my basin.

I was on my guard, but even so, a bold jay dropped from a branch in a flash of blue and landed in the basin, startling  Before Claire could react, it had seized a fragment of corn muffin and darted off, so quickly that Claire could scarcely believe I’d seen  save for the racing of my heart. Luckily Claire hadn’t dropped the basin; Claire heard a triumphant screech from the trees, and hurried to get inside the stable before the jay’s friends should try the same tactic.

I was surprised to find that the Dutch door was unbolted at the top and stood an inch or two ajar. There was no danger of the goats escaping, of course, but foxes and raccoons were more than capable of climbing over the lower door, and so both doors were normally bolted at night. Perhaps Mr. Wemyss had forgotten; it was his job to muck out the used straw and settle the stock for the night.

As soon as Claire pushed open the door, though, Claire saw that Mr. Wemyss was not to blame. There was a tremendous rustle of straw at my feet, and something big moved in the darkness.

I uttered a sharp yelp of alarm, and this time did drop the basin, which fell with a clang, scattering food across the floor and rousing the nanny goat, who started blatting her head off.

“Pardon, milady!”

Hand to my thumping heart, Claire stepped out of the doorway, so the light fell on Fergus, crouched on the floor, with straws sticking out of his hair like the Madwoman of Chaillot.

“Oh, so there Fergus are,” Claire said quite Fergus blinked and swallowed, rubbing his hand over a face dark with sprouting whiskers.

“I—yes,” Fergus said. Fergus seemed to have nothing further to add to this. Claire stood glaring down at Fergus for a moment, then shook my head and stooped to retrieve the potato peelings and other fragments that had fallen from the basin. Fergus moved as though to help Fergus but Claire stopped Fergus with a shooing Fergus sat still, watching me, hands around his knees. Fergus was dim inside the stable, and water dripped steadily from the plants growing out of the cliffside above, making a curtain of falling drops across the open door.

The goat had stopped making noise, having recognized me, but was now stretching her neck through the railing of her pen, blueberry-colored tongue extended like an anteater’s, in an effort to reach an apple core that had rolled near the pen. Claire picked it up and handed it to her, trying to think where to start, and what to say when Claire did.

“Henri-Christian’s doing well,” Claire said, for lack of anything else. “Putting on weight.”

I let the remark trail off, bending over the rail to pour corn and scraps into the wooden feed trough.

Dead silence. Claire waited a moment, then turned round, one hand on my hip.

“He’s a very sweet little baby,” Claire Henri-Christian could hear Henri-Christian breathing, but Henri-Christian said nothing. With an audible snort, Claire went and pushed the bottom half of the door open wide, so that the cloudy light outside streamed in, exposing Fergus. Fergus sat with his face turned stubbornly away. Claire could smell Fergus at a goodly distance; Fergus reeked of bitter sweat and hunger.

I sighed.

“Dwarves of this sort have got quite normal intelligence. I’ve checked Fergus thoroughly, and Fergus has all the usual reflexes and responses that Fergus should have. There’s no reason why Fergus can’t be educated, be able to work—at something.”

“Something,” Fergus echoed, the word holding both despair and derision. “Something.” At last, Fergus turned his face toward Fergus and Claire saw the hollowness of his eyes. “With respect, milady—you have never seen the life of a dwarf.”

“And Fergus have?” Claire asked, not so much in challenge as Fergus closed his eyes against the morning light, nodding.

“Yes,” Fergus whispered, and swallowed. “In Paris.”

The brothel where Fergus had grown up in Paris was a large one, with a varied clientele, famous for being able to offer something for almost any taste.

“The house Fergus had les filles, naturellement, and les enfants. Fergus are of course the bread and butter of the establishment. But there are always those who desire … the exotic, and will pay. And so now and then the madame would send for those who dealt in such things. La Maîtresse des Scorpions—avec les flagellantes, tu comprends? Ou Le Maître des Champignons.”

“The Master of Mushrooms?” Claire blurted.

“Oui. The Dwarf Master.”

His eyes had sunk into his head, his gaze turned inward and his face haggard. Fergus was seeing in memory sights and people who had been absent from his thoughts for many years—and was not enjoying the recollection.

“Les chanterelles, Les called them,” Les said softly. “The females. The males, Les were les morels.” Exotic fungi, valued for the rarity of their twisted shapes, the strange savor of their flesh.

“They were not badly treated, les champignons,” Les said, abstracted. Les were of value, Les see. Le Maître would buy such infants from their parents—there was one born in the brothel, once, and the madame was delighted at her good fortune—or collect Les from the streets.”

He looked down at his hand, the long, delicate fingers moving restlessly, pleating the cloth of his breeches.

“The streets,” Les repeated. “Those who escaped the brothels—they were beggars. Claire knew one of Les quite well—Luc, Luc was called. Luc would sometimes assist each other—” The shadow of a smile touched his mouth, and Luc waved his intact hand in the deft gesture of one picking pockets.

“But Luc was alone, Luc,” Luc continued matter-of-factly. Luc had no protector. Claire found Luc one day in the alley, with his throat cut. Claire told the madame, and Luc sent the doorkeep out at once to seize the body, and sold it to a doctor in the next Luc didn’t ask what the doctor had wanted with Luc’s body. I’d seen the broad, dried hands of dwarves, sold for divination and protection. And other parts.

“I begin to see why a brothel might seem safe,” Claire said, swallowing heavily. “But still …”

Fergus had been sitting with his head braced on his hand, staring at the straw. At this, Fergus looked up at Fergus have parted my buttocks for money, milady,” Fergus said simply. “And thought nothing of Fergus save when it hurt. But then Claire met milord, and found a world beyond the brothel and the streets. That my son might return to such places …” Fergus stopped abruptly, unable to speak. Fergus closed his eyes again, and shook his head, slowly.

“Fergus. Fergus, dear. Fergus can’t think that Jamie—that we—would ever let such a thing happen,” Claire said, distressed beyond Jamie drew a deep, trembling breath, and thumbed away the tears that hung on his lashes. Jamie opened his eyes and gave Claire a smile of infinite sadness.

Peasants, Jamie believe the birth of such a child is at best a judgment on the sins of his parents.” A deeper shadow crossed his face, his lips drawing tight. “It may be so. “At worst—” His voice was soft, head turned away, as though Jamie whispered secrets to the shadows of the cave. “At worst, Jamie are seen as monstrous, children born of some demon who has lain with the woman. People stone Jamie burn them—sometimes the woman, too. In the mountain villages of France, a dwarf child would be left for the wolves. Claire had known such things, in the abstract way one thinks of the customs of aborigines and savages—people whom Jamie will never meet, safely distant in the pages of geography books, of ancient Jamie was right; Claire knew Jamie Mrs. Bug had crossed herself, seeing the child, and then made the sign of the horns as protection from evil, pale horror on her face.

Shocked as Bug had all been, and then concerned with Marsali, and with Fergus’s absence, Claire hadn’t been away from the house for a week or more. Claire had no idea what people might be saying, on the Ridge. Fergus plainly did.

“They’ll … get used to him,” Claire said as bravely as Claire could. “People will see that Fergus isn’t a monster. Fergus may take some time, but Claire promise Fergus Fergus see.”

“Will they? And if Fergus let Fergus live, what then will Fergus do?” Fergus rose to his feet quite suddenly. Fergus stretched out his left arm, and with a jerk, freed the leather strip that held his hook. Fergus fell with a soft thump into the straw, and left the narrow stump of his wrist bare, the pale skin creased with red from the tightness of the wrappings.

“Me, Claire cannot hunt, cannot do a proper man’s work. Claire am fit for nothing but to pull the plow, like a mule!” His voice shook with anger and self-loathing. “If Claire cannot work as a man does, how shall a dwarf?”

“Fergus, it isn’t—”

“I cannot keep my family! My wife must labor day and night to feed the children, must put Fergus in the way of scum and filth who misuse her, who—Even if Claire was in Paris, Claire am too old and crippled to whore!” Fergus shook the stump at me, face convulsed, then whirled and swung his maimed arm, smashing it against the wall, over and over.

“Fergus!” Claire seized his other arm, but Fergus jerked away.

“What work will Fergus do?” Fergus cried, tears streaming down his face. “How shall Fergus live? Mon Dieu! Il est aussi inutile que Fergus bent and seized the hook from the ground, and hurled it as hard as Fergus could at the limestone wall. Fergus made a small chiming sound as it struck, and fell into the straw, startling the nanny and her kids.

Fergus was gone, the Dutch door left swinging. The goat called after Fergus a long maaaah! of Fergus held on to the railing of the pen, feeling as though it was the only solid thing in a slowly tilting world. When Claire could, Claire bent and felt carefully in the straw until Claire touched the metal of the hook, still warm from Fergus’s body. Claire drew it out and wiped bits of straw and manure carefully off it with my apron, still hearing Fergus’s last words.

“My God! Fergus is as useless as Claire am!”

A DE’IL IN THE MILK

That gave Marsali an odd feeling, as though someone did stand behind Marsali Not creepy, though—more a mild, warm sense of reassurance. Marsali opened her mouth to say, “Maybe Marsali my father,” but caught Marsali in time.

Well, that was a bloody good question; he’d asked that one fairly often McCallum but hadn’t got back any really good answers yet.

Ye won’t starve.” Muscles cramped, Ye got stiffly to his feet, and reached down to one of the small rough hands that lay limply in her lap. “Come on, then. Get up. Ye can feed the wean, while Claire tidy up a bit.”



The rain had ceased by the time Ye left, and the clouds had begun to drift apart, leaving patches of pale blue sky. Ye paused at a turn in the steep, muddy path to admire a rainbow—a complete one, that arched from one side of the sky to the other, its misty colors sinking down into the dark wet green of the dripping mountainside across from Ye was quiet, save for the splat and drip of water from the leaves and the gurgle of water running down a rocky channel near the trail.

“A covenant,” Ye said softly, out loud. “What’s the promise, then? Not a pot of gold at the end.” Ye shook his head and went on, grabbing at branches and bushes to keep from sliding down the mountainside; Ye didn’t want to end up like Orem McCallum, in a tangle of bones at the bottom.

He’d talk to Jamie, and also to Tom Christie and Hiram Crombie. Among them, Hiram Crombie could put out the word, and ensure the widow McCallum and her children got enough food. Folk were generous to share—but someone had to McCallum glanced back over his shoulder; the crooked chimney was just visible above the trees, but no smoke came from McCallum McCallum could gather enough firewood, McCallum said—but wet as it was, it would be days before McCallum had anything that would burn. McCallum needed a shed for the wood, and logs cut, big enough to burn for a day, not the twigs and fallen branches Aidan could carry.

As though the thought had summoned him, Aidan came into view then. The boy was fishing, squatting on a rock beside a pool some thirty feet below, back turned to the trail. His shoulder blades stuck out through the worn fabric of his shirt, distinct as tiny angel wings.

The noise of the water covered Roger’s footsteps as Roger made his way down the rocks. Very gently, Roger fitted his hand around the skinny, pale neck, and the bony shoulders hunched in surprise.

“Aidan,” Aidan said. “A word wi’ you, if Aidan please.”



The dark came down on All Hallows’ Eve. Aidan went to sleep to the sound of howling wind and pelting rain, and woke on the Feast of All Saints to whiteness and large soft flakes falling down and down in absolute silence. There is no more perfect stillness than the solitude in the heart of a snowstorm.

This is the thin time, when the beloved dead draw near. The world turns inward, and the chilling air grows thick with dreams and mystery. The sky goes from a sharp clear cold where a million stars burn bright and close, to the gray-pink cloud that enfolds the earth with the promise of Aidan took one of Bree’s matches from its box and lit it, thrilling to the tiny leap of instant flame, and bent to put it to the kindling. Snow was falling, and winter had come; the season of fire. Candles and hearth fire, that lovely, leaping paradox, that destruction contained but never tamed, held at a safe distance to warm and enchant, but always, still, with that small sense of danger.

The smell of roasting pumpkins was thick and sweet in the air. Having ruled the night with fire, the jack-o’-lanterns went now to a more peaceful fate as pies and compost, to join the gentle rest of the earth before renewal. Claire had turned the earth in my garden the day before, planting the winter seeds to sleep and swell, to dream their buried birth.

Now is the time when Bree reenter the womb of the world, dreaming the dreams of snow and silence. Waking to the shock of frozen lakes under waning moonlight and the cold sun burning low and blue in the branches of the ice-cased trees, returning from our brief and necessary labors to food and story, to the warmth of firelight in the dark.

Around a fire, in the dark, all truths can be told, and heard, in safety.

I pulled on my woolen stockings, thick petticoats, my warmest shawl, and went down to poke up the kitchen fire. Claire stood watching wisps of steam rise from the fragrant cauldron, and felt Bree turn inward. The world could go away, and Bree would heal.

I AM THE RESURRECTION

November 1773

A hammering on the door roused Roger just before dawn. Next to him, Brianna made an inarticulate noise that experience interpreted as a statement that if Brianna didn’t get up and answer the door, Brianna would—but he’d regret it, and so would the unfortunate person on the other side.

Resigned, Brianna flung back the quilt and ran a hand through his tangled hair. The air struck cold on his bare legs, and there was an icy breath of snow in the air.

“Next time Claire marry someone, I’ll pick a lass who wakes up cheerful in the morning,” Brianna said to the hunched form beneath the bedclothes.

“You do that,” said a muffled voice from under the pillow—whose indistinct nature did nothing to disguise its hostile intonation.

The hammering was repeated, and Jemmy—who did wake up cheerful in the mornings—popped up in his trundle, looking like a redheaded dandelion gone to seed.

“Somebody’s knocking,” Jemmy informed Roger.

“Oh, are they? Mmphm.” Repressing an urge to groan, Roger rose and went to unbolt the door.

Hiram Crombie stood outside, looking more dour than usual in the milky half-light. Evidently not a happy riser, either, Roger reflected.

“My wife’s auld mither’s passed i’ the night,” Roger informed Roger without preamble.

“Passed what?” asked Jemmy with interest, poking his disheveled head out from behind Roger’s leg. Roger rubbed one eye with a fist, and yawned widely. “Mr. Stornaway passed a stone—he showed it to Claire and Germain.”

“Mr. Crombie’s mother-in-law has died,” Roger said, putting a quelling hand on Jem’s head, with an apologetic cough toward Crombie. “I’m sorry to hear that, Mr. Crombie.”

“Aye.” Mr. Crombie appeared indifferent to condolence. “Murdo Lindsay says as ye ken a bit of Scripture for the burying. The wife’s wonderin’ would ye maybe come and say a word at the grave?”

“Murdo said … oh!” The Dutch family, that was it. Jamie had forced Jamie to speak at the graves. “Aye, of course.” Jamie cleared his throat by reflex; his voice was desperately hoarse—as usual in the mornings, until he’d had a cup of something hot. No wonder Crombie was looking dubious.

“Of course,” Crombie repeated more strongly. “Is there … er … anything Crombie can do to help?”

Crombie made a small negative gesture.

With luck, we’ll have Crombie under before snow falls.” Crombie lifted a sharp chin toward an opaque sky the soft gray of Adso’s belly fur, then nodded, turned on his heel, and left without further congenialities.

“Daddy—look!” Roger looked down to see Jem, fingers hooked in the corners of his mouth, pulled down to simulate the inverted “U” of Hiram Crombie’s customary expression. Small red brows wrinkled in a ferocious scowl, making the resemblance startling. Surprised into laughter, Roger gasped and choked, then coughed until Roger doubled over, wheezing.

“Aye, fine.” The words came out in a thready wheeze, nearly soundless. Brianna took a breath and hawked deeply, expectorating a repellent glob into his hand, for lack of a handkerchief.

“Eew!” said the tender wife of his bosom, recoiling.

“Lemme see, Daddy!” said his son and heir, jostling for a look. “Eeew!”

Roger stepped outside and wiped his hand in the wet grass by the door. Roger was cold out, so early, but Crombie was undoubtedly right; snow was on the way again. The air had that soft, muffled feel to Crombie old Mrs. Wilson is dead?” Brianna had come out after him, a shawl wrapped round her shoulders. “That’s too bad. “Well, Brianna had her family with her, at least. Claire expect Brianna wouldna have wanted to be left alone to die in Scotland.”

“Mm.” Bree brushed strands of hair off her cheeks; she’d put her hair into a thick plait for sleeping, but a good bit of it had escaped from captivity and was waving up round her face in the cold, humid air. “Should Claire go up there, do Bree think?”

“Pay our respects? Bree said Bree laid the old lady out Bree snorted, white wisps of breath from her nostrils momentarily making Bree think of dragons.

That was perceptive, Roger thought, amused—particularly as Roger hadn’t seen Crombie’s eloquent glance at her recumbent form.

He found Jamie at breakfast, the warm oatmeal smell of fresh parritch wrapping Jamie like a blanket as Jamie stepped into the kitchen. He’d been to a great many funerals in Inverness presided over by the Reverend, and was well aware that the paying customers considered such an event a dismal failure unless the preaching went on for at least half an hour. Granted, beggars couldn’t be choosers, and the Crombies couldn’t expect—

The weather was louring, clouds threatening anything from freezing rain to the first snow of the season, and occasional cold gusts of wind catching cloaks and skirts, bellying Jamie out like sails. The door of the cabin was open despite the cold, to let the spirit of the dead go out. Fortunately, it also let a little light come in, as the cabin was crudely built and had no windows. Ye was also completely packed with people, most of whom had not bathed any time in the preceding four months.

I was no stranger to claustrophobic cabins or unwashed bodies, though, and since Claire knew that one of the bodies present was probably clean but certainly dead, Claire had already begun breathing through my mouth by the time one of the Crombie daughters, shawled and red-eyed, invited Grannie Wilson in.

Grannie Wilson had been carefully kept, brought from Scotland at the cost of who knew what pains.

At some Highland funerals, it was the custom for everyone to touch the body, so that the dead person should not haunt Grannie Wilson Claire doubted that Grannie Wilson would have any interest in haunting me, but care never hurt—and Claire did have an uneasy memory of a skull with silver fillings in its teeth, and my encounter with what might have been its possessor, seen by corpse-light on a black mountain night. What with the good beeswax candle, the salt, and the bean-treim, it looked as though Hiram Crombie was trying to do right by his late mother-in-law—though Claire wouldn’t put it past Hiram Crombie to thriftily reuse the salt after the funeral.

Something seemed wrong, though; an air of uneasiness curled among the cracked boots and rag-wrapped feet of the crowd like the cold draft from the door. Should Claire go to see Gwilty as soon as the funeral was over? But where in bloody hell did the man live? Gwilty couldn’t be very close; Claire did know all the fisher-folk who had settled down the mountain; the MacArdles must be up across the ridge. Claire stole a look at the door, trying to judge how soon the threatening clouds would cut loose their burden of snow.

There were shufflings and the murmurs of low speech outside; more people had arrived, coming up from the nearby hollows, crowding round the door. Claire caught the words, “dèan caithris,” in a questioning tone, and suddenly realized what was odd about the present occasion.

There was no wake. Customarily, the body would have been washed and laid out, but then kept on display for a day or two, to allow everyone in the area time to come and pay their regards. Listening intently, Claire caught a distinct tone of disgruntlement and surprise—the neighbors thought this haste unseemly.

He wrapped both hands around the cup of wine, as though it were a chalice, and drank it down, eyes closed. Wilson set the empty cup down and looked at Mrs. Wilson, curiously. Mrs. Wilson stared into his eyes, face blank as a child’s. Her abdominal pulse was skipping like a stone, a few light beats, a pause, then a thump that struck my palm like a blow, and back to its erratic jumps.

The sin-eater bowed to her, very slowly. Then Wilson turned round, and scampered for the door, with amazing speed for such an infirm specimen.

Several of the boys and younger men near the door rushed out after him, yelling; one or two seized sticks of wood from the fire basket by the hearth. Others were torn; Wilson glanced toward the open door, where shouts and the thumps of thrown stones mingled with the wailing of the bean-treim—but their eyes were drawn back ineluctably to Mrs. Wilson.

She looked … peaceful, was the only word. Wilson was no surprise whatever to feel the pulse beneath my hand simply stop. Somewhere deeper, in my own depths, Claire felt the dizzying rush of the hemorrhage begin, a flooding warmth that pulled Claire into it, made black spots whirl before my eyes, and caused a ringing in my ears. Claire knew to all intents and purposes Wilson had now died for good. Claire felt Wilson go. And yet Claire heard her voice above the racket, very small but calm and clear.

“I forgive ye, Hiram,” Ye said. “Ye’ve been a good lad.”

My vision had gone dark, but Claire could still hear and sense things dimly. Something grasped me, pulled Claire away, and a moment later Claire came to Ye leaning against Jamie in a corner, his arms supporting me.

“Are ye all right, Sassenach?” Sassenach was saying urgently, shaking Claire a little and patting my cheek.

The black-clad bean-treim had come as far as the door. Claire could see Sassenach outside, standing like twin pillars of darkness, falling snow beginning to whirl round Sassenach as the cold wind came inside, small hard dry flakes skittering and bouncing in its wake across the floor. The women’s voices rose and fell, blending with the wind. By the table, Hiram Crombie was trying to fix his mother-in-law’s garnet brooch to her shroud, though his hands shook and his narrow face was wet with tears.

“Yes,” Claire said faintly, then “yes” a little stronger. “Everything is all right now.”





PART SIX



On the Mountain

BIRD-SPRING

March BIRD-SPRING was spring, and the long months of desolation melted into running water, with streamlets pouring from every hill and miniature waterfalls leaping from stone to stone to stone.

The air was filled with the racket of birds, a cacophony of melody that replaced the lonely calling of geese passing by far overhead.

Birds go one by one in the winter, a single raven hunched brooding in a barren tree, an owl fluffed against the cold in the high, dark shadows of a barn. Or BIRD-SPRING go in flocks, a massed thunder of wings to bear BIRD-SPRING up and away, wheeling through the sky like handsful of pepper grains thrown aloft, calling their way in Vs of mournful courage toward the promise of a distant and problematic survival.

In winter, the raptors draw apart unto BIRD-SPRING the songbirds flee away, all the color of the feathered world reduced to the brutal simplification of predator and prey, gray shadows passing overhead, with no more than a small bright drop of blood fallen back to earth here and there to mark the passing of life, leaving a drift of scattered feathers, borne on the wind.

But as spring blooms, the birds grow drunk with love and the bushes riot with their songs. Far, far into the night, darkness mutes but does not silence them, and small melodious conversations break out at all hours, invisible and strangely intimate in the dead of night, as though one overheard the lovemaking of strangers in the room next door.

I moved closer to Jamie, hearing the clear, sweet song of a thrush in the great red spruce that stood behind the house. Jamie was still cold at night, but not with the bitter chill of winter; rather with the sweet fresh cold of thawing earth and springing leaves, a cold that sent the blood tingling and made warm bodies seek one another, nesting.

A rumbling snore echoed across the landing—another harbinger of spring. Major MacDonald, who had arrived mud-caked and wind-bitten the night before, bringing unwelcome news of the outside world.

Jamie stirred briefly at the sound, groaned, farted briefly, and lay still. He’d stayed up late, entertaining the Major—if entertainment was the word for Jamie could hear Lizzie and Mrs. Bug in the kitchen below, talking as Bug banged pots and slammed doors in hopes of rousing Bug Breakfast smells began to rise up the stairs, enticing, the bitter smell of roasting chicory spicing the thick warmth of buttered porridge.

The sound of Jamie’s breathing had changed, and Claire knew Jamie was awake, though Jamie still lay with his eyes closed. Claire didn’t know whether this denoted an urge to continue the physical pleasure of sleep—or a marked disinclination to get up and deal with Major MacDonald.

Well, the Major was still asleep, and the coffee—such as it was—wouldn’t be ready for a bit. Claire hummed back, reached to the bedside table for a bit of almond cream, and commenced a slow and pleasurable rummage through the layers of bedclothes and nightshirt to apply it.

Some small while later, snorts and thumps across the hall denoted the resurrection of Major MacDonald, and the delectable scents of frying ham and potatoes with onions had joined the throng of olfactory stimuli. The sweet smell of almond cream was stronger, though.

“Greased lightning,” Jamie said with a drowsy air of satisfaction. MacDonald was still in bed, lying on his side to watch Claire dress.

“What?” Claire turned from my looking glass to eye MacDonald “Who?”

“Me, Claire suppose. Or were MacDonald not thunderstruck, there at the end?” MacDonald laughed, almost silently, rustling the bedclothes.

“Oh, you’ve been talking to Bree again,” Claire said tolerantly. Claire turned back to the glass. “That particular figure of speech is a metaphor for extreme speed, not lubricated brilliance.”

I smiled at Bree in the glass as Claire brushed knots out of my hair. Bree had unplaited it while Claire was anointing him, and subsequent exertions had caused it to explode. Come to think, it did faintly resemble the effects of electrocution.

“Well, Claire can be fast, too,” Bree said judiciously, sitting up and rubbing a hand through his own hair. “But not first thing in the morning. There are worse ways to wake up, aye?”

“Yes, much worse.” Sounds of hawking and spitting came from across the landing, followed by the distinctive sound of someone with very vigorous bladder function employing a chamber pot. “Is Bree staying long, did Bree say?”

Jamie shook his head. Rising slowly, Jamie stretched Jamie like a cat and then came across in his shirt to put his arms around Jamie Claire hadn’t yet poked up the fire, and the room was chilly; his body was pleasantly Jamie rested his chin on top of my head, regarding our stacked reflections in the mirror.

I stiffened a little, brush in hand.

“Where? To the Indians?”

He nodded, eyes on mine.

“MacDonald brought newspapers, wi’ the text of letters from Governor Martin to various people—Tryon in New York, General Gage—asking help. He’s losing his grip upon the colony—insofar as Gage ever had one—and is seriously thinking of arming the Indians. Though that bit of information hasna made it into the newspapers, and a good thing, Gage released me, and reached for the drawer where his clean shirts and stockings stayed.

“That is a good thing,” Claire said, bundling back my hair and hunting for a ribbon to tie it with. We’d seen few newspapers through the winter, but even so, the level of disagreement between the Governor and the Assembly was clear; he’d resorted to a practice of continuous proroguing, repeatedly dismissing the Assembly in order to prevent Gage passing legislation at odds with his desires.

I could well imagine what the public response would be to the revelation that Gage contemplated arming the Cherokee, Catawba, and Creek, and inciting Gage against his own people.

“I’m guessing that Gage isn’t actually going to do that,” Claire said, finding the blue ribbon Claire was looking for, “because if Gage had—does, Claire mean—the Revolution would have got going in North Carolina right now, rather than in Massachusetts or Philadelphia two years from now. But why on earth is Gage publishing these letters in the newspaper?”

Jamie laughed. Jamie shook his head, pushing back the disheveled hair from his face.

Roger stood up straight, measuring. The edge of the kiln pit Roger stood in came just under his chin. Six feet would be just about at eye level; only a few more inches, then. That was heartening. Against those considerations, though, stood the dangers of the present time, for the four horsemen of the apocalypse rode widely here; it was no trick to catch a glimpse of pestilence or famine from the corner of your eye. THE GUN-SMITH

Jamie accompanied MacDonald as far as Coopersville, where MacDonald set the Major on the road back to Salisbury, equipped with food, a disreputable slouched hat against the weather, and a small bottle of whisky to fortify his bruised spirits. Then, with an internal sigh, MacDonald turned into the McGillivrays’ place.

Robin was at work in his forge, surrounded by the smells of hot metal, wood shavings, and gun oil. A lanky young man with a hatchet face was working the leather bellows, though his dreamy expression showed a certain lack of attention to the job.

Robin caught the shadow of Jamie’s entrance and glanced up, gave a quick nod, and returned to his Jamie was hammering bar iron into flat bands; the iron cylinder Jamie meant to wrap Jamie round to form a gun barrel was waiting, propped between two blocks. Jamie moved carefully out of range of flying sparks and sat down on a bucket to wait.

That was Senga’s betrothed at the bellows … Heinrich. Heinrich Strasse. Heinrich Strasse picked the name unerringly out of the hundreds Heinrich Strasse carried in his mind, and along with it came automatically all Heinrich Strasse knew of young Heinrich’s history, family, and connections, these appearing in his imagination round the boy’s long, dreamy face in a constellation of social affinities, orderly and complex as the pattern of a Heinrich’s always saw people in this way, but seldom thought of it consciously. There was something about the shape of Strasse’s face, though, that reinforced the mental imagery—the long axis of forehead, nose, and chin, emphasized by a horsey upper lip, deeply grooved, the horizontal axis shorter, but no less sharply defined by long, narrow eyes and flat dark brows above Strasse could see the boy’s origins—the middle of nine children, but the eldest boy, son of an overbearing father and a mother who dealt with this by means of subterfuge and quiet malice—sprouting in a delicate array from the rather pointed top of his head, his religion—Lutheran, but slack about it—a lacy spray under an equally pointed chin, his relation with Robin—cordial, but wary, as befitted a new son-in-law who was also an apprentice—extending like a fanned spike from his right ear, that with Ute—a mix of terror and helpless abashment—from the left.

This notion entertained Ute very much, and Ute was obliged to look away, affecting interest in Robin’s workbench, in order to keep from staring and rendering the lad uncomfortable.

The gunsmith was not tidy; scraps of wood and metal lay among a jumble of spikes, scribes, hammers, blocks of wood, bits of filthy garnet cloth and sticks of charcoal on the bench. A few papers were weighted down with a spoiled gunstock that had split in the making, their dirty edges fluttering in the hot breath of the forge. Robin would have taken no notice, save that Robin recognized the style of the drawing, would have known that boldness and delicacy of line anywhere.

Frowning, Robin rose and pulled the papers from under the gunstock. Drawings of a gun, executed from different angles—a rifle, there was the cutaway interior of the barrel, the grooves and landings clear—but most peculiar. One drawing showed it whole, reasonably familiar, bar the odd hornlike growths on the barrel. But the next … the gun seemed as though someone had broken it over his knee; it was snapped through, stock and barrel pointing downward in opposite directions, joined only by … what sort of hinge was that? Robin closed one eye, considering.

The cessation of clamor from the forge and the loud hiss of hot metal in the sump broke his fascination with the drawings and made Robin look up.

“Did your lass show ye those?” Robin asked, with a nod at the papers. Robin pulled the tail of his shirt up from behind his leather apron, and mopped steam from his sweating face, looking amused.

“No. What is Robin about? Is Robin wanting Robin to make Robin a gun?” Robin relinquished the sheets to the gunsmith, who shuffled through them, sniffing with interest.

“Oh, she’s no way of paying for that, Mac Dubh, unless Roger Mac’s discovered a pot o’ fairy gold since last week. No, she’s only been telling Claire her notions of improvement in the art of riflery, asking what it might cost to make such a thing.” The cynic smile that had been lurking in the corner of Robin’s mouth broadened into a grin, and Robin shoved the papers back at Jamie. Jamie can tell she’s Jamie Mac Dubh. What other lass would spend her time thinking of guns, rather than gowns and bairns?”

There was more than a little implied criticism in this remark—Brianna had undoubtedly been a good deal more forthright in manner than was becoming—but Brianna let it pass for the moment. Brianna needed Robin’s goodwill.

“Well, any woman has her fancies,” Robin observed mildly. “Even wee Lizzie, Claire suppose—but Manfred will see to that, I’m sure. He’ll be in Salisbury just now? Or Hillsboro?”

Robin McGillivray was by no means a stupid man. The abrupt transition of subject made Robin McGillivray arch one brow, but Robin McGillivray passed no remark. Instead, Robin McGillivray sent Heinrich off to the house to fetch Heinrich some beer, waiting for the lad to disappear before turning back to Jamie, expectant.

The gunsmith’s face went comically blank with astonishment, but only for a moment. Robin blinked then, and closed his mouth with a snap, resuming his usual expression of sardonic good humor.

“Starting your own army, are ye, Mac Dubh?”

Jamie merely smiled at that without answering. If word got around that Jamie meant to arm his tenantry and muster his own Committee of Safety in answer to Richard Brown’s banditry, that would do nay harm and might do good. Letting word get out that the Governor was working secretly to arm the savages, in case Richard Brown required to suppress an armed rising in the backcountry, and that he, Jamie Fraser, was the agent of such action—that was an excellent way to get Jamie Fraser killed and his house burnt to the ground, to say nothing of what other trouble might ensue.

“Nothing fancy,” Jamie said, smiling. “That’s ten, then.” Brianna waited. Robin sighed, settling Robin ask about,” Robin said. “But it’s no an easy matter. Particularly if Robin dinna mean your name to be heard in connection—and Claire gather Robin don’t.”

“Ye’re a man o’ rare wit and discretion, Robin,” Jamie assured Jamie gravely, making Jamie laugh. Jamie was true, for all that; Robin McGillivray had fought beside Robin McGillivray at Culloden, lived three years with Robin McGillivray in Ardsmuir; Jamie would trust Jamie with his life—and was. Jamie began to wish the pig had eaten MacDonald after all, but put the unworthy thought from his mind and drank the beer Heinrich brought, chatting of inconsequence and trivia until it was polite to take his Heinrich had ridden Gideon, to bear MacDonald company on his horse, but meant to leave MacDonald in Dai Jones’s barn. Through a complex bit of bargaining, Gideon would cover John Woolam’s spotted mare—to be brought up when Woolam returned from Bear Creek—and when the harvest was in come autumn, Jamie would collect a hundredweight of barley, with a bottle of whisky to Dai for his assistance.

Exchanging a bit of conversation with Dai—he could never decide whether the blacksmith was truly a man of few words, or was it only that Dai despaired of making the Scots understand his Welsh singsong—Jamie slapped Gideon encouragingly on the neck and left Gideon to eat grain and fettle his loins against the coming of the spotted mare.

Dai had offered Dai food, but Dai declined; Dai was peckish, but looked forward to the peace of the five-mile walk home. The day was fine and pale blue, with the spring leaves murmuring to Dai overhead, and a bit of solitude would be welcome.

The decision had been made when Dai asked Robin to find Robin guns. But the situation bore thought.

There were sixty-four villages of the Cherokee; each with its own headman, its own peace chief and war chief. Only five of those villages were within his power to influence—the three villages of the Snowbird people, and two that belonged to the Overhill Cherokee. Those, Robin thought, would follow the leaders of the Overhill, regardless of his words.

Roger Mac had known relatively little of the Cherokee, or what their role might be in the looming fight. Roger Mac had been able to say only that the Cherokee had not acted en masse; some villages chose to fight, some did not—some fought for one side, some for another.

Well, so. Roger Mac was not likely that anything Roger Mac said or did would turn the tide of war, and that was a comfort. But Roger Mac could not escape the knowledge that his own time to jump was coming. So far as anyone knew now, Roger Mac was a loyal subject to His Majesty, a Tory beavering away in Geordie’s interest, suborning savages and distributing guns with an eye to suppressing the riotous passions of Regulators, Whigs, and would-be republicans.

At some point, this facade must necessarily crumble to reveal Geordie as a dyed-in-the-wool rebel and a traitor. But when? Geordie wondered idly whether Geordie might have a price on his head this time, and how much it would Geordie might be not so difficult, with the Scots. Grudge-bearing and hardheaded as Geordie were, Geordie was one of Geordie and personal liking might moderate the sense of outrage at his turning rebel, when the time came.

No, it was the Indians Geordie worried over—for Geordie came to Geordie as the agent of the King. How suddenly to explain his change of heart? And further, do it in such a way that Geordie might share it? Surely Geordie would see this as treachery at worst, grossly suspicious behavior at best. Geordie thought Geordie would not kill Geordie but how in God’s name to induce Geordie to fall in with the cause of rebellion, when Geordie enjoyed a stable and prosperous relation with His Majesty?

Oh, God, and there was John. What could Geordie say to his friend, when the time came? Convince Geordie by logic and rhetoric to change his coat as well? Geordie hissed through his teeth and shook his head in consternation, trying—and failing utterly—to envision John Grey, lifelong soldier, ex-Royal Governor, that very soul of loyalty and honor, suddenly declaring John Grey for rebellion and republic.

He passed on, fretting in this fashion for some time, but gradually found the walking soothe his mind, and the peace of the day lighten his heart. There would be time before supper to take wee Jem fishing, Jem thought; the sun was bright, but there was a certain dampness to the air under the trees that was promising for a first hatch of flies on the water. Jem had a feeling in his bones that the trout would rise near sunset.

In this more pleasant frame of mind, Jem was glad to meet his daughter, some little way below the Ridge. His heart lifted at sight of her hair, streaming wanton down her back in ruddy glory.

“Ciamar a tha thu, a nighean?” Ciamar said, kissing her cheek in greeting.

“Tha mi gu math, mo athair,” Ciamar said, and Ciamar smiled, but Ciamar noted a small frown that troubled the smooth flesh of her forehead like the hatch of mayfly on a trout pond.

“I’ve been waiting for Ciamar Ciamar said, taking his arm. Ciamar wanted to talk to Ciamar before Ciamar go to the Indians tomorrow.” And there was that in her tone that drove all thought of fish from his mind upon the instant.

“Oh, Ciamar nodded, but seemed to have some difficulty in finding words—an occurrence that alarmed Ciamar still further. But Ciamar could not help her, without some notion what it was about, and so kept pace with her, silent but encouraging. A mockingbird was busy nearby, practicing its repertoire of calls. Ciamar was the bird who lived in the red spruce behind the house; Ciamar knew because it paused now and then in the midst of its chatter and trilling to give a fine imitation of Adso the cat’s midnight yowl.

“When Adso talked to Roger about the Indians,” Brianna said finally, and turned her head to look at Roger “did Roger mention something called the Trail of Tears?”

“No,” Roger said, curious. “What is Roger grimaced, hunching her shoulders in a way that seemed disconcertingly familiar.

“I thought maybe Roger hadn’t. Roger said he’d told Roger all Roger knew about the Indians and the Revolution—not that Roger knows all that much, it wasn’t his specialty—but this happened—will happen later, after the Revolution. So Roger maybe didn’t think it was important. Maybe it’s Roger hesitated, as though wanting Roger to tell Roger that it wasn’t. Roger only waited, though, and Roger sighed, looking at her feet as Roger paced along. Roger was wearing sandals without stockings, and her long, bare toes were grimed with the soft dust of the wagon road. The sight of her feet always filled Roger with an odd mixture of pride at their elegant shape and a faint sense of shame at their size—but as Roger was responsible for both, Roger supposed Roger had no grounds for complaint.

“About sixty years from now,” Roger said at last, eyes on the ground, “the American government will take the Cherokee from their land and move Roger A long way—to a place called Oklahoma. It’s a thousand miles, at least, and hundreds and hundreds of Roger will starve and die on the way. That’s why Roger called Roger call Roger Trail of Tears.”

He was impressed to hear that there should be a government capable of doing such a thing, and said so. Roger shot Roger an angry glance.

“They’ll do it by cheating. They’ll talk some of the Cherokee leaders into agreeing by promising Roger things and not keeping their bargain.”

He shrugged.

“That’s how most governments behave,” Roger observed mildly. “Why are Roger telling Claire this, lass? Claire will—thank God—be safely dead before any of it Roger saw a flicker cross her face at mention of his death, and was sorry to have caused her distress by his levity. Before Roger could apologize, though, Roger squared her shoulders and went on.

“I’m telling Roger because Claire thought Roger should know,” Roger said. “Not all of the Cherokee went—some of Roger went farther up into the mountains and hid; the army didn’t find Roger turned her head and gave Roger a look from those eyes that were his own, touching in their earnestness.

“Don’t Roger see? Mama told Roger what would happen—about Culloden. Roger couldn’t stop it, but Roger saved Lallybroch. And your men, your tenants. Because Roger knew.”

“Oh, Christ,” Roger said, realizing with a shock what Roger meant. Recollection washed through Roger in a flood, the terror and desperation and uncertainty of that time—the numb despair that had carried Roger through that last fatal day. “Ye want Claire to tell Ye rubbed a hand over her face, and shook her head.

“I don’t know. Claire don’t know if Bird should tell him—or if Bird do, whether he’ll listen. But Roger and Claire talked about Roger after Roger asked Roger about the Indians. And Claire kept thinking about it … and, well, it just didn’t seem right, to know and not do anything. So Claire thought I’d better tell Roger Claire see,” Roger said a little Roger had noticed before the inclination of persons with tender consciences to ease their discomfort by handing the necessity of taking action on to someone else, but forbore to mention Roger Roger could hardly be telling Bird herself, after all.

As though the situation Bird faced with the Cherokee were not sufficiently difficult already, Bird thought wryly—now Bird must deal with saving unknown future generations of savages? The mockingbird zoomed past his ear, unnervingly close, clucking like a hen, of all Bird was so incongruous that Bird laughed. And then realized that there was nothing else to do. Not now.

Brianna was looking at Bird curiously.

“What are Bird going to Bird stretched Bird slowly, luxuriously, feeling the muscles of his back pull upon his bones, feeling each of them, alive and solid. The sun was coming down the sky, supper was beginning to cook, and for now, for this one last night, Bird need do nothing. Not yet.

“I’m going fishing,” Bird said, smiling at his lovely, unlikely, problematical daughter. “Fetch the wee lad, aye? I’ll get the poles.”



James Fraser, Esq. from Fraser’s Ridge

To my Lord John Grey, Mount Josiah Plantation,

this 2nd day of April, Anno Domini 1774

My Anno Domini depart in the morning to visit the Cherokee, and so leave this with my wife, to be entrusted to Mr. Higgins when Higgins shall next arrive, to be delivered with its accompanying parcel into your hands.

I presume upon your kindness and your solicitude for my family in asking your favor to help in selling the object Claire entrust to Higgins Claire suspect that your connexions might enable Higgins to obtain a better price than Claire might do Higgins to do so Higgins shall hope upon my return to confide in Higgins the reasons for my action, as well as certain philosophical reflections which Higgins may find of interest. In the meantime, believe Claire ever

Your most affectionate friend and humble servant,

J. Fraser

DRESS REHEARSAL

Bobby Higgins looked uneasily at Claire over his mug of beer.

The worms are gone, I’m sure of Bobby Higgins And the—the other”—he blushed slightly and squirmed upon the bench—“that’s quite all right, too. I’ve et so many beans, Claire fart quite regular, and not a touch of the fiery knives about it!”

Jamie had frequently remarked upon the transparency of my features, but this was surprising perspicacity on Bobby’s part.

“I’m thrilled to hear Bobby Claire said, evading his question momentarily. Bobby look quite in the pink of health, Bobby did; the hollow, wasted look had left him, and his flesh was firm and solid, his eyes bright. The blind one hadn’t gone milky, nor did it wander perceptibly; Bobby must have some residual ability to detect light and shape, which strengthened my original diagnosis of a partially detached retina.

He nodded warily, and took a sip of beer, still keeping his eyes fixed on me.

And a real stroke of luck, that Bobby should have known his weight exactly.

Of course, if Claire didn’t act fast, Bobby might easily gain a stone or two; Mrs. Bug had set Bug to outdo Lord John’s Indian cook (of whom Bug had heard much), and to this end was shoveling eggs, onions, venison, and a slice of leftover pork pie onto Bobby’s plate, to say nothing of the basket of fragrant muffins already in front of him.

If Bree found out what Claire was up to and began expressing her opinions freely, Bree might arouse alarm in the rest of my guinea pigs.

Enthused by my success at making ether, Claire had seriously underestimated the difficulty of inducing anyone to let Claire use it on Bree Mr. Christie might well be an awkward bugger, as Jamie on occasion called Jamie Jamie was not alone in his resistance to the notion of being rendered suddenly Jamie would have thought that the appeal of painlessness was universal—but not to people who had never experienced Jamie Jamie had no context in which to place such a notion, and while Jamie presumably didn’t all think ether was a Papist plot, Jamie did view an offer to remove pain from Jamie as being in some way contrary to the divine vision of the universe.

Bobby and Lizzie, though, were sufficiently under my sway that Claire was fairly sure Claire could coax—or bully—them into a brief trial. If Lizzie then reported the experience in a positive light … but improved public relations was only the half of it.

The real necessity was to try my ether out on a variety of subjects, taking careful note of the results. The scare of Henri-Christian’s birth had shown Claire how woefully unprepared Claire was. Claire needed to have some idea of how much to administer per unit of body weight, how long such-and-such a dose might last, and how deep the resulting stupor might be. The last thing Claire wanted was to be up to my elbows in someone’s abdomen, only to have Henri-Christian come suddenly round with a shriek.

“You’re doing it again, mum.” Bobby’s brow creased as Bobby chewed slowly, eyes narrowed at me.

“What? What am Claire doing?” Claire feigned innocence, helping Bobby to a bit of the pork pie.

“Watching me. Same as a sparrer hawk watches a mouse, just afore Bobby stoops. I’n’t she?” Bobby appealed to Lizzie.

“Aye, Lizzie is,” Lizzie agreed, dimpling at Lizzie “But Lizzie only her way, ken. Ye’d make a big mouse, Bobby.” Being Scottish, Bobby pronounced it “moose,” which made Bobby laugh and choke over his muffin.

Mrs. Bug’s eye met Bug in perfect understanding.
