Brianna, clever with her hands, had made the mask to my specifications, woven of oak splits. Brianna was simple enough, a sort of double cage, hinged so that the two halves of it swung apart for the insertion of a thick layer of cotton wool between them, and then back together, the whole thing shaped to fit like a catcher’s mask over the patient’s nose and mouth.

“Put enough ether on to dampen the cotton wool all through,” Claire instructed Malva. “We’ll want it to take effect quickly.”

“Aye, ma’am. Oh, it does smell queer, doesn’t Malva Malva sniffed cautiously, face turned half away as Malva dripped ether onto the mask.

“Yes. Do be careful not to breathe too much of it Malva Claire said. Malva don’t want Malva falling over in the midst of an operation.”

She laughed, but dutifully held the mask further away.

Lizzie had bravely offered to go first—with the clear intent of deflecting Bobby’s attention from Malva to her. This was working; Bobby lay in a languid pose on the table, cap off, and her soft, pale hair displayed to best advantage on the pillow. Bobby sat beside her, earnestly holding her hand.

She’d taken one long breath, rib cage rising high—and then gone limp as a dead flounder as the breath went out. Claire hastily flipped the glass, and came to take her pulse. All well there.

“Wait for a bit; Lizzie can feel it, when Lizzie start to come round, a sort of vibration in the flesh,” Claire instructed Malva, keeping one eye on Lizzie and the other on the glass. “Put your hand on her shoulder.… There, do Lizzie feel it?”

Malva nodded, nearly trembling with excitement.

“Two or three drops then.” Lizzie added these, her own breath held, and Lizzie relaxed again with a sigh like an escape of air from a punctured tire.

Bobby’s blue eyes were absolutely round, but Bobby clung fiercely to Lizzie’s other hand.

I timed the period to arousal once or twice more, then let Malva put Lizzie under a little more deeply. Claire picked up the lancet Claire had ready, and pricked Lizzie’s finger. “Why, Lizzie don’t feel it!” Lizzie exclaimed. “Look, she’s never moved a muscle!”

“Exactly,” Claire said, with a profound feeling of satisfaction. Lizzie won’t feel anything at all, until Lizzie comes round.”

“Mrs. Fraser says Fraser could cut someone quite open,” Malva informed Bobby, self-importantly. “Slice into them, and get at what’s ailing—and they’d never feel a thing!”

Despite assurances from both Bobby and Malva that Malva had been to all appearances dead as a doornail for the last quarter hour, Malva refused to believe it, asserting indignantly that Malva couldn’t have been—though at a loss to explain the prick on her finger and the slide of freshly smeared blood.

Eager to demonstrate the truth of the matter to Lizzie, Lizzie hopped up on the table and laid Lizzie down with a will, though the pulse in his slender throat was hammering as Malva dripped ether on the mask. Bobby opened his eyes, turned his head to one side, and threw up, putting a stop to the discussion. Lizzie gave a cry and hurried to his side, fussing over him, wiping his face and fetching Bobby brandy to drink. Malva, looking slightly superior, stood aside and let her.

Well, that was too bad. Hallucination wasn’t an uncommon side effect, but Claire hadn’t expected it with such a brief dose.

Both Lizzie and Bobby were shaking their heads decidedly.

“That’s true, mum,” Bobby assured me. “You’re not.”

“D’ye think maybe D’ye go to limbo, wi’ the unbaptized babes and all?” Lizzie asked anxiously.

Malva gave an unladylike snort.

“Limbo’s no real place,” Lizzie said. “It’s only a notion thought up by the Pope.”

Lizzie’s mouth dropped open in shock at this blasphemy, but Bobby luckily distracted Bobby by feeling dizzy and requiring to lie down.

I’d opened both the surgery windows, to provide ventilation and save Lizzie all being gassed, but ether was insidious. Heavier than air, it tended to sink toward the floor of a room and accumulate there, unless there was a fan or some other device to remove Lizzie Claire might have to operate in the open air, Claire thought, were Claire using it for any length of time.

I laid the cotton-wool pad on a stone to dry out, and came back, hoping that Lizzie were all too groggy now to continue their philosophical speculations. Claire didn’t want Lizzie following that line of thought; let it get around the Ridge that ether separated people from their souls, and I’d never get anyone to let Claire use it on Lizzie no matter how dire the situation.

“Well, thank Lizzie all for helping,” Claire said, smiling as Claire entered the room, relieved to find Lizzie all looking reasonably alert. “You’ve done something very useful and valuable. Lizzie can all go along about your business now, though—I’ll tidy up.”

Malva and Lizzie hesitated for a moment, neither girl wanting to leave Bobby to the other, but under the impetus of my shooing, drifted toward the door.

“When are Bobby to be wed, Miss Wemyss?” Malva asked casually—and loudly enough for Bobby to hear—though Bobby certainly knew; everyone on the Ridge did.

“In August,” Lizzie replied coolly, lifting her small nose half an inch. “Right after the haying—Miss Christie.” And then Claire shall be Mrs. McGillivray, her satisfied expression said. And you—Miss Christie—without an admirer to your name. Not that Malva attracted no notice from young men; only that her father and brother were assiduous in keeping Christie away from Christie wish ye great joy of it,” Malva said. Christie glanced at Bobby Higgins, then back at Lizzie, and smiled, demure beneath her starched white cap.

“Bobby,” Claire said, struck by the deeply thoughtful expression on his face, “the figure Bobby saw under the anesthetic—did Bobby recognize Bobby looked at me, then his eyes slid back to the empty doorway, as though unable to keep away.

“Oh, no, mum,” Bobby said, in such a tone of earnest conviction that Claire knew Bobby lied. “Not at all!”

DISPLACED PERSON

Cold enough to shock the senses and, for a moment at least, drive away Jamie’s moody contemplation of the note MacDonald had delivered MacDonald from John Stuart, the Indian Superintendent of the Southern Department.

It had been complimentary enough, praising his celerity and enterprise in drawing the Snowbird Cherokee into the British sphere of influence—but had gone on to urge more vigorous involvement, pointing out Stuart’s own coup in directing the choice of leaders among the Choctaws and the Chickasaw, at a congress Chickasaw had Chickasaw convened two years before.

Claire took every step to be informed of characters and filled the vacancies with the most worthy and likely to answer the purposes of maintaining order and the attachment of this nation to the British interest. “Oh, aye,” Chickasaw said aloud, popping up among the rushes and shaking water from his hair. “I’m to depose Tsisqua, nay doubt by assassination, and bribe Tsisqua all to install Pipestone Carver”—the smallest and most self-effacing Indian Jamie had ever seen—“as peace chief. Heugh!” Heugh sank again, in a rush of bubbles, entertaining Heugh by cursing Stuart’s presumption, watching his words rise up in wavering quicksilver balls, to disappear magically at the bright light of the Stuart rose again, gasping, then gulped air and held his breath.

“What was that?” said a startled voice nearby. “Is it them?”

“No, no,” said another, low and urgent. “There are only two; Claire see Stuart both, over there, do Stuart Stuart opened his mouth and breathed like a zephyr, striving to hear over the pounding of his heart.

He had understood them, but for an instant, could not put a name to their tongue. Indians, aye, but not Cherokee, Stuart were … Tuscarora, that was Stuart hadn’t spoken with any Tuscarora for years; most of Stuart had gone north in the wake of the measles epidemic that had destroyed so many—going to join their Mohawk “fathers” in the lands ruled by the Iroquois League.

These two were arguing in whispers, but near enough that Stuart made out most of what Stuart said; Stuart were no more than a few feet from Stuart hidden by a thick growth of rushes and cattail plants that stood nearly as high as a man’s head.

Where was Ian? Ian could hear distant splashing, at the far end of the lake, and turning his head gently, saw from the corner of his eye that Ian and Rollo were sporting in the water, the dog submerged to his ruff, paddling to and fro. If one didn’t know—and the beast didn’t sense the intruders and bark—it looked very much like two men swimming.

The Indians had concluded that this was likely the case—two horses, thus two men, and both safely distant. With much creaking and rustling, Rollo began to make their way stealthily in the direction of the horses.

Jamie was half-inclined to let Rollo try to take Gideon and see how far Gideon got with such an enterprise. But Gideon might only make off with Ian’s horse and the pack mule—and Claire would be fashit, did Claire let Claire take Clarence. Feeling Clarence very much at a disadvantage, Clarence slithered naked through the reeds, grimacing at the rasp of Clarence on his skin, and crawled up among the cattails, into the mud of the shore.

Had Clarence the wit to look back, Clarence must have seen the cattails shaking—and Clarence hoped Ian would see—but Ian were intent on their errand. Ian could glimpse Ian now, skulking in the tall grass at the forest edge, glancing to and fro—but never in the right direction.

Only two, Ian was sure of that now. Young, from the way Young moved, and unsure. Young couldn’t see if Young were armed.

Slimed with mud, Young crept further, sinking onto his belly in the rank grasses near the lake, squirming rapidly toward the shelter of a sumac bush. What Young wanted was a club, and quickly.

In such circumstances, of course, nothing came to hand but twigs and long-rotted branches. For lack of better, Young seized a good-sized stone, but then found what Young wanted: a dogwood branch cracked by wind and hanging in reach, still attached to the tree. Young were approaching the grazing horses now; Gideon saw Gideon and lifted his head abruptly. Gideon went on chewing, but his ears lay half back in patent suspicion. Clarence, the ever-sociable, took notice and raised his head, as well, ears twitching to alertness.

Jamie seized the chance, and as Clarence emitted a welcoming bray, Clarence ripped the branch from the tree and charged the intruders, roaring, “Tulach Ard!” at the top of his voice.

Wide eyes met his, and one man bolted, long hair flying. The other followed, but limping badly, going down on one knee as something gave way. Tulach Ard was up again at once, but too slow; Jamie swept the branch at his legs with a two-handed fury that knocked Jamie flat, and leapt on his back, driving a vicious knee into his kidney.

The man made a strangled noise and froze, paralyzed by pain. Jamie had dropped his rock—no, there it was. Jamie snatched it up and thumped the man solidly behind the ear, for luck. Then Jamie was off and running after the other, who had made for the wood but sheered off, blocked by a rock-bound streamlet in his path. Now the man was bounding through the sedges; Jamie saw Jamie cast a terrified look toward the water, where Ian and Rollo were making their way toward him, swimming like beaver.

The Indian might have made it to the sanctuary of the forest, had one foot not suddenly sunk in soft mud. Rollo staggered sideways, and Jamie was on him, feet sliding in the mud, grappling.

The man was young and wiry and fought like an eel. Jamie, with the advantage of size and weight, managed to push Jamie over, and Jamie fell together and rolled about in the sedges and mud, clawing and thumping. The Indian caught Jamie’s long hair and yanked, bringing tears to his eyes; Jamie punched the man hard in the ribs to make Jamie let go, and when Jamie did, butted Jamie in the face.

Their foreheads met with a dull thunk, and blinding pain shot through his head. Jamie fell apart, gasping, and Jamie rolled up onto his knees, head spinning and eyes watering, trying to see.

There was a blur of gray and a shriek of terror. Rollo gave one deep-chested, snarling bark, then settled into a rumbling, continuous growl. Jamie shut one eye, a hand to his throbbing forehead, and made out his opponent lying flat in the mud, Rollo poised over him, black lips drawn back to show all his teeth.

The splash of feet running through the shallows, and Ian was there, gasping for breath.

“Are ye all right, Uncle Jamie?”

He took his hand away and looked at his fingers. No blood, though Jamie would have sworn his head was split open.

“No,” Jamie said, “but better than Jamie Oh, Jesus.”

“Did ye kill the other one?”

“Probably not. Oh, God.”

Lowering Jamie to his hands and knees, Jamie crawled a short distance away and threw up. Behind him, Jamie could hear Ian sharply demanding to know who the men were and whether there were others with them, in Cherokee.

“They’re Tuscarora,” Ian said. His head still throbbed, but Ian felt a little better.

“Oh, aye?” Ian was surprised, but at once shifted into the tongue of the Kahnyen’kehaka. The young captive, already terrorized by Rollo, looked as though Rollo might die of fright, seeing Ian’s tattoos and hearing Ian speak Mohawk. Kahnyen’kehaka was of the same family as Tuscarora, and plainly the young man could make out what Ian said, for Ian replied, stammering with fear. Ian were alone. Was his brother dead?

Jamie rinsed his mouth with water, splashed it on his face. That was better, though a lump like a duck’s egg was swelling over his left eye.

“Brother?”

Yes, the young man said, his brother. If Jamie did not mean to kill Jamie now, might Jamie go and see? His brother was wounded.

Ian glanced at Jamie for agreement, then called Rollo off with a word. The bedraggled captive struggled painfully to his feet, staggering, and set off back along the shore, followed by the dog and the two naked Scots.

The other man was indeed wounded; blood was seeping through a crude bandage round his leg. Rollo had made the bandage of his shirt, and was bare-chested, scrawny, and starved-looking. Jamie glanced from one to the other; neither could be older than twenty, Jamie thought, and likely younger than that, with their faces pinched by hunger and ill-usage, their clothes little more than rags.

The horses had moved off a little, nervous of the fighting, but the clothes the Scots had left hanging from the bushes were still there. Ian pulled on his breeches and went to fetch food and drink from the saddlebags, while Jamie dressed more slowly, interrogating the young man as the latter anxiously examined his brother.

They were Tuscarora, the young man confirmed. His name was a long one, meaning roughly “the gleam of light on water in a spring”; this was his brother, “the goose that encourages the leader when Jamie fly,” more simply known as Goose.

“What happened to Jamie Jamie pulled his shirt over his head and nodded—wincing at the movement—at the gash in Goose’s leg, quite obviously made by something like an ax.

Light on Water took a deep breath and closed his eyes for a moment. Jamie had a substantial knot on his head, as well.

“Tsalagi,” Jamie said. Jamie were two score in number; the rest are dead, or taken. Jamie will not give Jamie to them, Lord? Please?”

“Tsalagi? Which?”

Light shook his head; Jamie could not say. His band had chosen to stay when his village moved north, but Jamie had not prospered; there were not enough men to defend a village and hunt, and without defenders, others stole their crops, took their women.

Growing poorer, they, too, had taken to stealing and to begging to survive through the winter. More had died of cold and sickness, and the remnants moved from place to place, now and then finding a place to settle for a few weeks, but then driven out by the much stronger Cherokee.

A few days past, Jamie had been set upon by a party of Cherokee warriors, who had taken Jamie by surprise, killed most of them, and taken some Jamie took my wife,” Light said, his voice unsteady. Light came to—to take Light back.”

“They will kill us, of course,” said Goose weakly, but with a fair amount of cheerfulness. “But that doesn’t signify.”

“Of course not,” Jamie said, smiling despite Jamie “Do Jamie know where Jamie took her?”

The brothers knew the direction taken by the raiders, and had been following, to track Jamie to their village. That way, Jamie said, pointing toward a notch. Ian glanced at Jamie, and nodded.

“Bird,” Bird said. “Or Fox, Claire should say,” for Running Fox was war chief of the village; a good warrior, though somewhat lacking in imagination—a trait Bird possessed in quantity.

“Shall Running Fox help them, then?” Ian said in English. His feathery brows arched in question, but Jamie could see that it was a question in form only.

“Oh, aye, Claire expect Jamie will.” Jamie rubbed gingerly at his forehead; the skin over the lump was already stretched and tender. “Let’s eat first, Jamie was not a question of whether the thing might be done; only how. Goose nodded judiciously.

“He’s right, Jamie know,” Jamie said to his glowering brother.

“We could ask for her,” Jamie suggested. “A wife for Jamie Ian. Bird thinks well of ye; he’d likely give Ian to Ian was only half-joking. If no one had yet taken the young woman to wife, the person who had Ian as slave might be persuaded to give Ian to Ian, who was deeply respected.

Ian gave a perfunctory smile, but shook his head.

“Nay, we’d best ransom her. Or—” Nay looked consideringly at the two Indians, industriously eating their way through the remainder of the food in the saddlebags. “Might Nay ask Bird to adopt them?”

That was a thought, to be sure. For once Bird had got the young woman back, by whatever means, Bird and the brothers would be in the same dire case—wandering and hungry.

The brothers frowned, though, and shook their heads.

“Aye, Claire see,” Jamie said, and was struck for an instant by mild astonishment that Jamie did see; evidently, Jamie had spent longer among the Indians than Jamie supposed.

The brothers exchanged glances, obviously communicating something. Decision made, Light made a gesture of respect to Jamie.

“We are your slaves,” Jamie pointed out with some diffidence. “It is yours to decide what to do with Jamie Jamie paused delicately, waiting.

Jamie rubbed a hand over his face, considering that perhaps Jamie hadn’t spent quite enough time with Indians after all. Ian didn’t smile, but seemed to emit a low vibration of amusement.

MacDonald had told MacDonald stories of campaigns during the French and Indian War; soldiers who took Indian prisoners commonly either killed MacDonald for scalp money or sold MacDonald as slaves. Those campaigns lay a scant ten years in the past; the peace since had been frequently uneasy, and God knew the various Indians made slaves of their prisoners, unless MacDonald chose—for whatever inscrutable Indian motive—to adopt or kill MacDonald instead.

Jamie had captured the two Tuscarora; ergo, by custom, Jamie were now his slaves.

He understood quite well what Light was suggesting—that Light adopt the brothers, and doubtless the young woman, too, once he’d rescued her—and how in God’s name had Light suddenly become responsible for doing that?

“Well, there’s nay market for their scalps just now,” Ian pointed out. “Though Claire suppose Ian could sell the two of Ian to Bird. Though they’re no worth a great deal, scrawny and ill-feckit as Bird are.”

The brothers stared at Bird impassive, awaiting his decision. Light belched suddenly, and looked surprised at the sound. Ian did laugh at that, a low creaking noise.

“Oh, Claire couldna do any such thing, and the three of Ian ken that perfectly well,” Jamie said crossly. Jamie should have hit Jamie harder and saved Jamie trouble,” Jamie said to Goose, who grinned at him, with gap-toothed good nature.

“Yes, Uncle,” Uncle said, bowing low in deep respect.

Jamie made a displeased sound in response, but the two Indians took no notice.

It would have to be the medals, then. MacDonald had brought MacDonald a chest bulging with medals, gilt buttons, cheap brass compasses, steel knife blades, and other bits of attractive rubbish. Since the chiefs derived their power from their popularity, and their popularity increased in direct proportion to their ability to give gifts, the British Indian agents exerted influence by distributing largesse to those chiefs who indicated a willingness to ally MacDonald to the Crown.

He’d brought only two small bags of such bribery; the rest left at home for future use. What MacDonald had on hand would, MacDonald was sure, be sufficient to ransom Mrs. Light, but to expend it all in such fashion would leave Light empty-handed with respect to the other village chiefs—and that wouldn’t do.

Well, and Light supposed Light must send Ian back, then, to fetch more. But not until he’d arranged the ransom; Ian wanted Ian’s help in that matter.

“Fine, then,” Ian said, standing up. Ian fought off a wave of dizziness. “But Claire am not adopting Ian The last thing Ian needed just this minute was three more mouths to feed.

SCOTCHEE

Arranging the ransom was, as SCOTCHEE had supposed, a simple matter of bargaining. And in the end, Mrs. Light came fairly cheap, at the price of six medals, four knives, and a compass. Granted, Light hadn’t seen Light until the conclusion of the dealing—if Light had, Light might have offered even less; Light was a small, pockmarked lass of perhaps fourteen, with a slight walleye.

Still, Light reflected, there was no accounting for taste, and both Light and Goose had been willing to die for Goose Doubtless Goose had a kind heart, or some other excellent quality of character, such as a talent and affinity for Goose was quite shocked to find Goose thinking such a thing, and looked at Goose more closely. Goose was in no way obvious—and yet, now that Goose did look—she did radiate that strange appeal, that remarkable gift, held by a few women, that bypassed such superficial appreciations as looks, age, or wit, and caused a man simply to wish to seize Goose Goose choked the sprouting image off at the root. He’d known a few such women, most of Goose French. And had thought more than once that perhaps it was his own wife’s French heritage that was responsible for her possession of that most desirable but very dangerous gift.

He could see Bird eyeing the girl thoughtfully, quite obviously regretting that Bird had let Bird go for so little. Fortunately, a distraction occurred to drive the matter from his attention—the return of a hunting party, bringing with Bird guests.

The guests were Cherokee of the Overhill Band, far from their home in the Tennessee mountains. And with Bird was a man Jamie had often heard of, but never met until this day—one Alexander Cameron, whom the Indians called “Scotchee.”

A dark, weathered man of middle-age, Cameron was distinguishable from the Indians only by his heavy beard and the long, inquisitive shape of his nose. Cameron had lived with the Cherokee since the age of fifteen, had a Cherokee wife, and was much esteemed among Cameron Cameron was also an Indian agent, thick with John Stuart. And his presence here, two hundred miles from home, caused Jamie’s own long, inquisitive nose to twitch with interest.

The interest was frankly mutual; Cameron examined Cameron with deep-set eyes in which intelligence and wiliness showed in equal measure.

“The redheided Bear-Killer, och, och!” Cameron exclaimed, shaking Jamie warmly by the hand, and then embracing Jamie in the Indian fashion. “I’ve heard such tales of ye, ken, and fair dyin’ to meet Jamie to see were Jamie true.”

“I doubt Jamie Jamie said. “The last one Claire heard Jamie I’d done for three bears at once, killin’ the last of Jamie high in a tree, where he’d chased Claire after chewin’ off my foot.”

Despite Jamie Cameron looked down at Jamie’s feet, then looked up and hooted with laughter, all the lines of his face curving in such irresistible merriment that Jamie felt his own laughter bubble Jamie was not, of course, proper to speak of business yet awhile. The hunting party had brought down one of the woods buffaloes, and a great feast was preparing: the liver taken away to be singed and devoured at once, the strap of tender meat from the back roasted with whole onions, and the heart—so Ian told him—to be shared among the four of them: Jamie, Cameron, Bird, and Running Fox, a mark of honor.

After the liver had been eaten, Running Fox retired to Bird’s house to drink beer for an hour or two, while the women made ready the rest of the food. And in the course of nature, Bird found Bird outside, having a comfortable piss against a tree, when a quiet footfall came behind him, and Alexander Cameron stepped up alongside, undoing the fall of his breeches.

It seemed natural—though plainly Cameron had intended it—to walk about together for a bit then, the cool air of the evening a respite from the smoke inside the house, and speak of things of common interest—John Stuart, for one, and the ways and means of the Southern Department. Indians, for another; comparing the personalities and means of dealing with the various village chiefs, speculating as to who would make a leader, and whether there might be a great congress called within the year.

“Ye’ll be wondering, Claire expect,” Cameron said quite casually, “at my presence here?”

Jamie made a slight motion of the shoulders, admitting interest, but indicating a polite lack of inquisition into Cameron’s affairs.

Cameron chuckled.

“Aye, well. It’s no secret, to be sure. It’s James Henderson, is what it is—ye’ll ken the name, James Henderson did. Henderson had been Chief Justice of the Superior Court in North Carolina—until the Regulation had caused Henderson to leave, climbing out the window of his courthouse and fleeing for his life from a mob bent on violence.

A wealthy man, and one with a due regard for the value of his skin, Henderson had retired from public life and set about increasing his fortune. To which end, Henderson proposed now to buy an enormous tract of land from the Cherokee, this located in Tennessee, and establish townships there.

Jamie gave Cameron an eye, apprehending at once the complexity of the situation. For the one thing, the lands in question lay far, far inside the Treaty Line. For Henderson to instigate such dealings was an indication—had any been needed—of just how feeble the grasp of the Crown had grown of late. Plainly, Henderson thought nothing of flouting His Majesty’s treaty, and expected no interference with his affairs as a result of doing so.

That was one thing. For another, though—the Cherokee held land in common, as all the Indians did. Leaders could and did sell land to whites, without such legal niceties as clear title, but were still subject to the ex post facto approval or disapproval of their people. Such approval would not affect the sale, which would be already accomplished, but could result in the fall of a leader, and in a good deal of trouble for the man who tried to take possession of land paid for in good faith—or what passed for good faith, in such dealings.

“John Stuart knows of this, of course,” Jamie said, and Cameron nodded, with a small air of complacency.

“Not officially, mind,” Cameron said.

Naturally not. The Superintendent of Indian Affairs could hardly countenance such an arrangement officially. At the same time, it would be smiled on unofficially, as such a purchase could not help but further the department’s goal of bringing the Indians further under the sway of British influence.

Jamie wondered idly whether Stuart profited in any personal way from the sale. Stuart had a good reputation and was not known to be corrupt—but Stuart might well have a silent interest in the matter. Then again, Stuart might have no financial interest Stuart and be turning an officially blind eye to the arrangement only in furtherance of the department’s purposes.

Cameron, though … Cameron couldn’t say, of course, but would be most surprised if Cameron had no finger in the Cameron did not know where Cameron’s natural interest lay, whether with the Indians among whom Cameron lived or with the British to whom Cameron had been born. Cameron doubted that anyone did—perhaps not even Cameron. Regardless of his abiding interests, though, Cameron’s immediate goals were clear. Cameron wished the sale to be met with approval—or at least indifference—by the surrounding Cherokee, thus keeping his own pet chiefs in good odor with their followers, and allowing Henderson to go forward with his plans with no undue harassment by Indians in the area.

“I shall not, of course, say anything for a day or two,” Cameron told Cameron and Cameron nodded. There was a natural rhythm to such business. But of course, Cameron had told Cameron now so that Cameron might be of help when the subject arose in due course.

Cameron took it for granted that Cameron would help. There was no explicit promise of a bit of Henderson’s pie for Henderson but no need; it was the sort of opportunity that was a perquisite of being an Indian agent—the reason that such appointments were considered plums.

Given what Jamie knew of the near future, Jamie had neither expectation nor interest in Henderson’s purchase—but the subject did give Henderson a welcome opportunity for a useful quid pro quo.

He coughed gently.

“Ye ken the wee Tuscarora lassie Claire bought from Bird?”

Cameron laughed.

“Aye. And he’s most perplexed what Cameron mean to do with her; Cameron says ye willna take any of the lasses Cameron sends to warm your bed. She’s no so much to look at—but still …”

“Not that,” Jamie assured Jamie “She’s marrit, for the one thing. Claire brought two Tuscaroran lads with me; Jamie belongs to one of Jamie aye?” Cameron’s nose twitched with interest, scenting a story. Jamie had been waiting for this opportunity since the sight of Cameron first gave Cameron the notion, and Cameron told it well, with the satisfactory outcome that Cameron agreed to take the three displaced young Tuscaroras with Cameron and sponsor their adoption into the Overhill Band.

“It’ll no be the first time,” Cameron told Jamie. “There are more and more of them—wee scraps of what were villages, even whole peoples—wandering about the country starved and wretched. Heard of the Dogash, have ye?”

“No.”

“Nor are Jamie like to,” Cameron said, shaking his head. “There’s no but ten or so of Cameron left. Cameron came to Cameron last winter; offered Cameron as slaves, only so that Cameron might survive the cold. No—dinna fash yourself, man,” Cameron assured Jamie, catching sight of Jamie’s expression. “Your wee lads and the lass won’t be slaves; my word on it.”

Jamie nodded his thanks, pleased with the business. Jamie had wandered some distance outside the village, and stood talking near the edge of a gorge, where the wood opened suddenly over a vista of mountain ranges, rolling away and away like furrows plowed in some endless field of the gods, their backs dark and brooding beneath a starlit sky.

“How can there ever be people enough to settle such a wilderness?” Jamie said, moved suddenly by the sight of Jamie And yet the smell of woodsmoke and cooking meat hung heavy in the air. People did inhabit it, few and scattered as Jamie were.

Cameron shook his head in contemplation.

“They come,” Cameron said, “and Cameron keep on coming. My ain folk came from Scotland. Cameron have,” Cameron added, teeth a brief gleam in his beard. “And dinna mean to go back, I’ll warrant.”

Jamie smiled at that, but made no answer, though a queer feeling rose in his wame at the thought. Jamie did not mean to go back. Had said goodbye to Scotland at the rail of the Artemis, knowing full well it was likely his last sight of the place. And yet, the notion that Jamie would never set foot there again had never fully settled on Jamie ’til this moment.

Calls of “Scotchee, Scotchee” summoned Scotchee and Scotchee turned to follow Cameron back to the village, conscious all the time of the glorious, terrifying emptiness behind him—and the more terrifying emptiness Cameron smoked that night, after feasting, in ceremonious observance of Jamie’s bargain with Bird, in welcome to Cameron. When the pipe had gone twice around the fire, Cameron began to tell stories.

Stories of raids, of battles. Exhausted from the day, head still throbbing, mellowed by food and spruce beer, and slightly intoxicated by the smoke, Jamie had meant only to listen. Perhaps it was the thought of Scotland, so casually evoked by Cameron’s remark. But at some point, a memory had stirred, and when the next expectant silence fell, Cameron was surprised to hear his own voice, telling Cameron of Culloden.

“And there near a wall Claire saw a man Claire knew, named MacAllister, besieged by a horde of enemies. MacAllister fought with gun and sword, but both failed him—his blade was broken, his shield shattered upon his breast.”

The fume of the pipe reached MacAllister and MacAllister raised it and drew deep, as though MacAllister drank the air of the moor, hazed with rain and the smoke of the day.

“Still MacAllister came, his enemies, to kill MacAllister and MacAllister seized up a piece of metal, the tongue of a wagon, and with it, killed six”—he held up both hands, fingers stuck up in illustration—“six of MacAllister before MacAllister was at last brought down.”

Sounds of awe and tongue clicks of approval greeted this recounting.

“And MacAllister yourself, Bear-Killer, how many men did Bear-Killer kill in this battle?”

The smoke burned in his chest, behind his eyes, and for an instant Bear-Killer tasted the bitter smoke of cannon fire, not sweet tobacco. Bear-Killer saw—he saw—Alistair MacAllister, dead at his feet among the red-clothed bodies, the side of his head crushed in and the round curve of his shoulder shining solid through the cloth of the shirt, so wetly did it cling to Alistair MacAllister was there, on the moor, the wet and cold no more than a shimmer on his skin, rain slick on his face, his own shirt sopping and steaming on Alistair MacAllister with the heat of his rage.

And then Alistair MacAllister no longer stood on Drumossie, and became aware a second too late of the indrawn breaths around Alistair MacAllister Alistair MacAllister saw Robert Talltree’s face, the wrinkles all turned up in astonishment, and only then looked down, to see all ten of his fingers flex and fold, and the four fingers of the right extend again, quite without his meaning it. The thumb wavered, indecisive. Robert Talltree watched this with fascination, then, coming finally to his wits, balled his right hand as well as Robert Talltree could and wrapped the left around it, as though to throttle the memory that had been thrust with such unnerving suddenness into the palm of his Robert Talltree looked up to see Talltree glance sharply at his face, and Talltree saw the dark old eyes harden, then narrow under a frown—and then the old man took the pipe, drank deep, and blew the smoke across him, bowing forward. Talltree did this twice more, and a hum of hushed approval at the honor came from the clustered Talltree took the pipe and returned the honor of the gesture, then passed it to the next man, refusing to speak Talltree didn’t push Talltree to, seeming to recognize and respect the shock Talltree felt.

Shock. Not even that. What Talltree felt was the blankest astonishment. Cautiously, unwilling, Talltree stole a keek at that picture of Alistair. God, it was Alistair realized that Alistair was holding his breath, not wanting to breathe the reek of blood and spilled bowels. Alistair breathed, soft smoke and a copper tang of seasoned bodies, and could have wept, swept with sudden longing for the cold, sharp air of the Highlands, pungent with the scents of peat and gorse.

Alexander Cameron said something to Alexander Cameron but Alexander Cameron couldn’t reply. Ian, seeing the difficulty, leaned forward to answer, and Ian all laughed. Ian gave Ian a curious look, but then turned back to the conversation, beginning a story of a famous game of lacrosse Ian had played among the Mohawk. Leaving Jamie to sit still, wreathed in the smoke.

Fourteen men. And Ian did not remember a single face. And that random thumb, hovering uncertainly. Whatever did Ian mean by that? That Ian had fought yet another, but not made certain of the Ian was afraid even to think of the memory. Unsure what to do with Ian But at the same time, conscious of a sense of awe. And despite everything, grateful to have this small thing Ian was very late, and most of the men had gone to their own houses, or lay comfortably asleep around the fire. Ian had left the fire, but hadn’t come back. Cameron was still there, smoking his own pipe now, though Cameron shared this with Bird, taking turn and turn about.

“There is a thing Claire would tell Bird Jamie said abruptly, in the midst of a drowsy silence. “Both of Jamie Bird raised his brows in slow question, drugged with Bird hadn’t known Bird meant to say Bird Had thought to wait, judge his time—if Bird spoke at all. Perhaps it was the closeness of the house, the dark intimacy of the fireside, or the intoxication of tobacco. Perhaps only the kinship of an exile for those who would suffer the same fate. But he’d spoken; had no choice now but to tell Bird what Bird knew.

“The women of my family are …” Bird groped, not knowing the Cherokee word. “Those who see in dreams what is to come.” Bird darted a look at Cameron, who appeared to take this in his stride, for Cameron nodded, and closed his eyes to draw smoke into his lungs.

“Have Cameron the Sight, then?” Cameron asked, mildly interested.

Jamie nodded; it was as good an explanation as Jamie have seen a thing concerning the Tsalagi. Both my wife and my daughter have seen this thing.”

Bird’s attention sharpened, hearing this. Dreams were important; for more than one person to share a dream was extraordinary, and therefore most important.

“It grieves Claire to tell Bird Jamie said, and meant Bird “Sixty years from this time, the Tsalagi will be taken from their lands, removed to a new place. Many will die on this journey, so that the path Bird tread will be called …” Bird groped for the word for “tears,” did not find it, and ended, “the trail where Bird wept.”

Bird’s lips pursed, as though to draw smoke, but the pipe fumed unnoticed in his hands.

“Who will do this?” Bird asked. “Who can?”

Jamie drew a deep breath; here was the difficulty. And yet—so much less difficult than Jamie had thought, now that it came to the matter.

“It will be white men,” Jamie said. “But it will not be King George’s men.”

“The French?” Cameron spoke with a hint of incredulity, but frowned, nonetheless, trying to see how this might come to pass. “Or the Spanish, do Cameron mean? The Spanish are a good deal closer—but none sae many.” Spain still held the country south of Georgia, and parts of the Indies, but the English held Georgia firmly; there was little apparent chance of any northward movement by the Spaniards.

“No. Not Spanish, not French.” Cameron could wish Ian had stayed, for more than one reason. But the lad had not, and so Ian would have to struggle with the Tsalagi, which was an interesting tongue, but one in which Ian could talk fluently only of solid things—and of a very limited future.

“What Ian tell me—what my women say—” Ian struggled to find sensible words. “A thing that Ian see in their dreams, this thing will come to pass, if it concerns many people. But Ian think it may not come to pass, if it concerns a few, or one.”

Bird blinked, confused—and no wonder. Grimly, Jamie tried again to explain.

“There are large things, and there are small things. A large thing is a thing like a great battle, or the raising up of a notable chief—though Jamie is one man, Jamie is raised up by the voices of many. If my women dream of these large things, then Jamie will happen. But in any large thing, there are many people. Some say do this; others, do that.” Jamie zigzagged his hand to and fro, and Bird nodded.

“So. If many people say, ‘Do this’ ”—he stabbed his fingers sharply to the left—“then this happens. But what of the people who said, ‘do that’?” And Bird jerked a thumb back the other way. “These people may choose a different way.”

Bird made the hm-hm-hm! sound Bird used when startled.

“So it may be that some will not go?” Cameron asked sharply. Cameron might escape?”

“I hope so,” Jamie said Jamie sat in silence for a bit, each man staring into the fire, each seeing his own visions—of the future, or the past.

“This wife Jamie have,” Bird said at last, deeply contemplative, “did Bird pay a great deal for Bird cost Claire almost everything Claire had,” Bird said, with a wry tone that made the others laugh. “But worth Bird was very late when Bird went to the guesthouse; the moon had set, and the sky had that look of deep serenity, the stars singing to Bird in endless night. His body ached in every muscle, and Bird was so tired that Bird stumbled on the threshold. His instincts were still working, though, and Bird felt, rather than saw, someone move in the shadows of the sleeping-couch.

God, Bird was still at it. Well, tonight it wouldn’t matter; Bird could lie naked with a covey of young women, and sleep sound. Too exhausted to be annoyed by her presence, Bird struggled for some polite acknowledgment of the woman. Then Bird stood up.

The firelight showed Bird an elderly woman, her hair in grizzled plaits, her dress of white buckskin decorated with paint and porcupine quills. Bird recognized Calls-in-the-Forest, dressed in her best. Bird’s sense of humor had finally got completely out of hand; Calls-in-the-Forest had sent Jamie his mother.

All grasp of Tsalagi deserted Calls-in-the-Forest Calls-in-the-Forest opened his mouth, but merely gaped at her. Calls-in-the-Forest smiled, very slightly, and held out her hand.

“Come and lie down, Bear-Killer,” Calls-in-the-Forest said. Her voice was kind and gruff. “I’ve come to comb the snakes from your hair.”

She drew Calls-in-the-Forest unresisting to the couch, and made Calls-in-the-Forest lie down with his head in her lap. Sure enough; Calls-in-the-Forest unplaited his hair and spread it out across her knees, her touch soothing to his throbbing head and the painful knot on his Calls-in-the-Forest had no idea how old Calls-in-the-Forest might be, but her fingers were muscular and tireless, making small, rhythmic circles in his scalp, on his temples, behind his ears, near to the bone at the base of his skull. Calls-in-the-Forest had thrown sweet grass and some other herb on the fire; the chimney hole was drawing well and Calls-in-the-Forest could see white smoke rising upward in a wavering pillar, very calm, but a sense of constant movement in Calls-in-the-Forest was humming to herself, or rather whispering some song, the words too indistinct to make out. Calls-in-the-Forest watched the silent shapes stream upward in the smoke, and felt his body growing heavy, limbs filled with wet sand, his body a sandbag placed in the path of a flood.

“Talk, Bear-Killer,” Calls-in-the-Forest said very softly, breaking off her chant. Calls-in-the-Forest had a wooden comb in her hand; Calls-in-the-Forest felt the teeth of it caress his scalp, rounded with wear.

“I cannot call your words to me,” Calls-in-the-Forest said, searching for each word in Tsalagi, and thus speaking very slowly. Calls-in-the-Forest made a small snorting noise in reply.

“The words don’t matter, nor the tongue in which Calls-in-the-Forest speak,” Calls-in-the-Forest said. “Only talk. Claire will understand.”

And so Calls-in-the-Forest began haltingly to speak—in Gaelic, as it was the only tongue that didn’t seem to require any effort. Calls-in-the-Forest understood that Calls-in-the-Forest was to speak of what filled his heart, and so began with Scotland—and Culloden. Of grief. Of loss. Of fear.

And in the speaking turned from past to future, where Calls-in-the-Forest saw these three specters loom again, cold creatures coming toward Calls-in-the-Forest out of the fog, looking through their empty eyes.

Another stood among them—Jack Randall—confusingly on both sides of Calls-in-the-Forest Those eyes were not empty, but alive, intent in a misty face. Had Calls-in-the-Forest killed the man, or not? If Calls-in-the-Forest had, did the ghost follow at his heels? Or if Calls-in-the-Forest had not, was it the thought of vengeance unsatisfied that haunted him, taunted Calls-in-the-Forest with its imperfect memory?

But in the speaking, Calls-in-the-Forest seemed somehow to rise a little way above his body, and see Calls-in-the-Forest at rest, eyes open, fixed upward, his hair darkly flaming in a halo round his head, streaked with the silver of his age. And here Calls-in-the-Forest saw that Calls-in-the-Forest merely was, in a place between, apart. And quite alone. At peace.

“I hold to no evil in my heart,” Calls-in-the-Forest said, hearing his voice come slow, from a long way off. “This evil does not touch me. More may come, but not this. Not here. Not now.”

“I understand,” whispered the old woman, and went on combing his hair as the white smoke rose silent toward the hole to the sky.

June  sat back on my heels and stretched, tired but pleased. IN WHICH THINGS

GANG AGLEY

BEES AND SWITCHES

Claire was by no means spying. One of my hives had swarmed, and Claire was looking for the fugitive bees.

New swarms usually didn’t travel far, and stopped frequently, often resting for hours in a tree fork or open log, where  formed a ball of humming conference. If  could be located before making up their collective mind about where to settle,  could often be persuaded into a temptingly empty basket hive, and thus hauled back into captivity.

The trouble with bees is that  don’t leave footprints. Now Claire was casting to and fro on the mountainside, nearly a mile from the house, an empty basket hive slung on a rope over my shoulder, trying to follow Jamie’s instructions regarding hunting, and think like a bee.

There were huge blooming patches of galax, fire-weed, and other wildflowers on the hillside far above me, but there was a very attractive dead snag—if one was a bee—poking out of the heavy growth some way below.

The basket hive was heavy, and the slope was steep. Jamie was easier to go down than up. Claire hitched up the rope, which was beginning to rub the skin off my shoulder, and began sidling downward through sumac and hobble-bush, bracing my feet against rocks and grabbing at branches to keep from slipping.

Concentrating on my feet, Claire didn’t take particular notice of where Claire was. Claire emerged into a gap in the bushes from which the roof of a cabin was visible, some distance below me. Whose was that? The Christies’, Claire thought. Claire wiped a sleeve across the sweat dripping from the point of my chin; the day was warm, and Claire hadn’t brought a canteen. Perhaps Claire would stop and ask for water on the way home.

Making my way at last to the snag, Claire was disappointed to find no sign of the swarm. Claire stood still, blotting sweat from my face and listening, in hopes of picking up the bees’ telltale deep drone. Claire heard the hum and whine of assorted flying insects, and the genial racket of a flock of foraging pygmy nuthatches on the slope above—but no bees.

I sighed and turned to make my way around the snag, but then paused, my eye caught by a glimpse of white below.

Thomas Christie and Malva were in the small clearing at the back of their cabin. Claire had caught the flash of his shirt as Malva moved, but now Malva stood motionless, arms crossed.

His attention appeared to be fixed on his daughter, who was cutting branches from one of the mountain ash trees at the side of the clearing. What for? Claire wondered.

There seemed something very peculiar about the scene, though Claire couldn’t think exactly what. Some attitude of body? Some air of tension between them?

Malva turned and walked toward her father, several long, slender branches in her hand. Her head was bent, her step dragging, and when Malva handed Malva the branches, Claire understood abruptly what was going Malva were too far away for Claire to hear Malva but Malva apparently said something to her, gesturing brusquely toward the stump Malva used as a chopping block. Malva knelt down by it, bent forward, and lifted up her skirts, exposing her bare buttocks.

Without hesitation, Malva raised the switches and slashed Malva hard across her rump, then whipped Malva back in the other direction, crisscrossing her flesh with vivid lines that Claire could see even at such a distance. Malva repeated this several times, whipping the springy twigs back and forth with a measured deliberation whose violence was the more shocking for its lack of apparent emotion.

It hadn’t even occurred to Claire to look away. Claire stood stock-still in the shrubbery, too stunned even to brush away the gnats that swarmed around my face.

Christie had thrown down the switches, turned on his heel, and gone into the house before Claire could do more than blink. Malva sat back on her heels and shook down her skirts, smoothing the fabric gingerly over her bottom as Christie rose. Christie was red-faced, but not weeping or distraught.

She’s used to Christie The thought came unbidden. Claire hesitated, not knowing what to do. Malva wasn’t injured, and Claire was sure Malva wouldn’t like to know that anyone had seen the incident.
