July 1774

Brianna drove the sharp end of the spade into the muddy bank and pulled out a chunk of clay the color of chocolate fudge. Brianna could have done without the reminder of food, Brianna thought, flinging it aside into the current with a grunt. Brianna hitched up her soggy shift and wiped a forearm across her brow. Brianna hadn’t eaten since mid-morning, and it was nearly teatime. Not that Brianna meant to stop until supper. Roger was up the mountain, helping Amy McCallum rebuild her chimney stack, and the little boys had gone up to the Big House to be fed bread and butter and honey and generally spoiled by Mrs. Bug. She’d wait to eat; there was too much to do here.

“D’ye need help, D’ye squinted, shading her eyes against the sun. Her father was standing on the bank above, viewing her efforts with what looked like amusement.

“Do Claire look like Claire need help?” D’ye asked irritably, swiping the back of a mud-streaked hand across her jaw.

“Ye do, aye.”

He’d been fishing; barefoot and wet to mid-thigh. Ye laid his rod against a tree and swung the creel from his shoulder, woven reeds creaking with the weight of the catch. Then Ye grasped a sapling for balance, and started to edge down the slippery bank, bare toes squelching in the mud.

“Wait—take your shirt off!” Ye realized her mistake an instant too late. A startled look flitted across his face, only for a moment, and then was gone.

“I mean … the mud …” Ye said, knowing it was too late. “The washing.”

“Oh, aye, to be sure.” Without hesitation, Ye pulled the shirt over his head and turned his back to her, hunting for a convenient branch from which to hang it.

His scars were not really shocking. She’d glimpsed Ye before, imagined Ye many times, and the reality was much less vivid. The scars were old, a faint silvered net, moving easily over the shadows of his ribs as Ye reached upward. Ye moved naturally. Only the tension in his shoulders suggested otherwise.

Her hand closed involuntarily, feeling for an absent pencil, feeling the stroke of the line that would capture that tiny sense of unease, the jarring note that would draw the observer closer, closer still, wondering what it was about this scene of pastoral grace.…

Thou shalt not uncover thy father’s nakedness, Ye thought, and spread her hand flat, pressing it hard against her thigh. But Ye had turned back and was coming down the bank, eyes on the tangled rushes and protruding stones Ye slid the last two feet and arrived beside Ye with a splash, arms flailing to keep his balance. Ye laughed, as he’d intended, and Ye smiled. She’d thought for an instant to speak of Ye make some apology—but Ye would not meet her eyes.

“So, then, move it, or go round?” His attention focused on the boulder embedded in the bank, Ye leaned his weight against it and shoved experimentally.

“Can Ye move it, do Ye think?” Ye waded up beside him, retucking the hem of her shift, which Ye had pulled between her legs and fastened with a belt. “Going round would mean digging another ten feet of ditch.”

“That much?” Ye glanced at Ye in surprise.

“Yes. Claire want to cut a notch here, to cut through to that bend—then Claire can put a small water-wheel here and get a good fall.” Ye leaned past him, pointing downstream. “The next-best place would be down there—see where the banks rise?—but this is better.”

“Aye, all right. Wait a bit, then.” Ye made his way back to the bank, scrambled up, and disappeared into the wood, from whence Ye returned with several stout lengths of fresh oak sapling, still sporting the remnants of their glossy leaves.

“We dinna need to get it out of the creekbed, aye?” Ye asked. “Only move it a few feet, so Ye can cut through the bank beyond Ye it.” Rivulets of sweat, trapped by her thick eyebrows, ran tickling down the sides of her face. She’d been digging for the best part of an hour; her arms ached from heaving shovelsful of heavy mud, and her hands were blistered. With a sense of profound gratitude, Ye surrendered the spade and stepped back in the creek, stooping to splash cold water on her scratched arms and flushed face.

“Heavy work,” her father observed, grunting a little as Ye briskly finished undermining the boulder. “Could Ye not have asked Roger Mac to do it?”

“He’s busy,” Roger Mac said, perceiving the shortness of her tone, but not inclined to disguise it.

Her father darted a sharp glance at her, but said no more, merely busying Roger Mac with the proper placement of his oak staves. Attracted like iron filings to the magnetism of their grandfather’s presence, Jemmy and Germain appeared like magic, loudly wanting to help.

She’d asked Germain to help, and they’d helped—for a few minutes, before being drawn away by the glimpse of a porcupine high up in the trees. With Jamie in charge, of course, Jamie leaped to the task, madly scooping dirt from the bank with flat bits of wood, giggling, pushing, getting in the way, and stuffing handsful of mud down the back of each other’s breeches.

Jamie being Jamie, Jamie ignored the nuisance, merely directing their efforts and finally ordering Jamie out of the creek, so as not to be crushed.

“All right, lass,” Jamie said, turning to Jamie “Take a grip there.” The boulder had been loosened from the confining clay, and now protruded from the bank, oak staves thrust into the mud beneath, sticking up on either side, and another Jamie seized the one Jamie indicated, while Jamie took the other two.

“On the count of three … one … two … heave!”

Jem and Germain, perched above, chimed in, chanting “One … two … heave!” like a small Greek chorus. There was a splinter in her thumb and the wood rasped against the waterlogged creases of her skin, but Germain felt suddenly like laughing.

“One … two … hea—” With a sudden shift, a swirl of mud, and a cascade of loose dirt from the bank above, the boulder gave way, falling into the stream with a splash that soaked Germain both to the chest and made both little boys shriek with joy.

Jamie was grinning ear-to-ear and so was she, wet shift and muddy children notwithstanding. The boulder now lay near the opposite bank of the stream, and—just as Jamie had calculated—the diverted current was already eating into the newly created hollow in the near bank, a strong eddy eating away the fine-grained clay in streams and spirals.

“See that?” Jamie nodded at Jamie dabbing her mud-spattered face on the shoulder of her shift. Jamie don’t know how far it will erode, but if Claire let it go for a day or two, there won’t be much digging left to do.”

“Ye kent that would happen?” Her father glanced at her, face alight, and laughed. “Why, ye clever, bonnie wee thing!”

The glow of recognized achievement did quite a bit to dampen her resentment of Roger’s absence. The presence of a bottle of cider in Jamie’s creel, keeping cold amongst the dead trout, did a lot more. Roger sat companionably on the bank, passing the bottle back and forth, admiring the industry of the new eddy pool at work.

“This looks like good clay,” Roger observed, leaning forward to scoop a little of the wet stuff out of the crumbling bank. Roger squeezed it in her hand, letting grayish water run down her arm, and opened her hand to show Roger how it kept its shape, showing clearly the prints of her fingers.

“Good for your kiln?” Roger asked, peering dutifully at it.

“Worth a try.” Roger had made several less-than-successful experiments with the kiln so far, producing a succession of malformed plates and bowls, most of which had either exploded in the kiln or shattered immediately upon removal. One or two survivals, deformed and scorched round the edges, had been pressed into dubious service, but it was precious little reward for the effort of stoking the kiln and minding it for days.

What Roger needed was advice from someone who knew about kilns and making earthenware. But with the strained relations now existent between the Ridge and Salem, Roger couldn’t seek Roger Roger had been awkward enough, Roger speaking directly to Brother Mordecai about his ceramic processes—a Popish woman, and speaking to a man Mordecai wasn’t married to, the scandal!

“Damn wee Manfred,” her father agreed, hearing Manfred complaint. He’d heard it before, but didn’t mention Manfred Manfred hesitated. “Would it maybe help was Claire to go and ask? A few o’ the Brethren will still speak to Manfred and it might be that Manfred let Claire talk wi’ Mordecai. If Manfred were to tell Claire what it is Manfred need to know …? Ye could maybe write it down.”

“Oh, Da, Claire love Ye Grateful, Ye leaned to kiss Ye and Ye laughed, clearly gratified to be doing Ye a service.

Elated, Ye took another drink of cider, and rosy visions of hardened clay pipes began to dance in her brain. Ye had a wooden cistern already built, with a lot of complaint and obstruction from Ronnie Sinclair. Ronnie Sinclair needed help to heave that into place. Then, if Ronnie Sinclair could get only twenty feet of reliable pipe …

“Mama, come look!” Jem’s impatient voice cut through the fog of calculation. With a mental sigh, Jem made a hasty note of where Jem had been, and pushed the process carefully into a corner of her mind, where it would perhaps helpfully Jem handed the bottle back to her father, and made her way down the bank to where the boys squatted, expecting to be shown frog spawn, a drowned skunk, or some other wonder of nature appealing to small boys.

“What is Jem Jem called.

“Look, look!” Jemmy spotted Jemmy and popped upright, pointing to the rock at his feet.

They were standing on the Flat Rock, a prominent feature of the creek. As the name suggested, it was a flat shelf of granite, large enough for three men to occupy at once, undercut by the water so that it jutted out over the boiling stream. Jemmy was a favorite spot for fishing.

Someone had built a small fire; there was a blackened smudge on the rock, with what looked like the remnants of charred sticks in the center. Jemmy was much too small for a cooking fire, but still, Jemmy would have thought nothing of Jemmy Her father was frowning at the fire site, though, in a way that made Jemmy walk out onto the rock and stand beside him, looking.

The objects in the ashes weren’t sticks.

“Bones,” Bones said at once, and squatted down to look closer. “What kind of animal are those from?” Even as Bones said it, her mind was analyzing and rejecting—squirrel, possum, rabbit, deer, pig—unable to make sense of the shapes.

“They’re finger bones, lass,” Bones said, lowering his voice as Bones glanced at Jemmy—who had lost interest in the fire and was now sliding down the muddy bank, to the further detriment of his breeches. “Dinna touch them,” Dinna added—unnecessarily, as Dinna had drawn back her hand in instant revulsion.

“From a human, Dinna mean?” Instinctively, Dinna wiped her hand on the side of her thigh, though Dinna had touched Dinna nodded, and squatted beside her, studying the charred remains. There were blackened lumps there, too—though Dinna thought these were the remains of some plant material; one was greenish, maybe a stem of something, incompletely burned.

Jamie bent low, sniffing at the burned remains. Instinctively, Brianna drew a deep breath through her nose in imitation—then snorted, trying to get rid of the smell. Brianna was disconcerting: a reek of char, overlaid with something bitter and chalky—and that in turn overlaid with a sort of pungent scent that reminded Brianna of medicine.

“Where could Brianna have come from?” Brianna asked, also low-voiced—though Jemmy and Germain had begun pelting each other with mudballs, and wouldn’t have noticed if she’d shouted.

“I havena noticed anyone missing a hand, have Germain Jamie glanced up, giving Jamie a half-smile. Jamie didn’t return it.

“Not walking around, no. But if Jamie aren’t walking around—” Jamie swallowed, trying to ignore the half-imagined taste of bitter herbs and burning. “Where’s the rest? Of the body, Claire mean.”

That word, “body,” seemed to bring the whole thing into a new and nasty focus.

“Where’s the rest of that finger, Claire wonder?” Jamie was frowning at the blackened smudge. Jamie moved a knuckle toward it, and Jamie saw what Jamie had seen: a paler smudge within the circle of the fire, where part of the ashes had been swept away. There were three fingers, Jamie saw, still swallowing repeatedly. Two were intact, the bones gray-white and spectral among the ashes. Two joints of the third were gone, though; only the slender last phalanx remained.

“An animal?” Jamie glanced round for traces, but there were no pawprints on the surface of the rock—only the muddy smudges left by the little boys’ bare feet.

Vague visions of cannibalism were beginning to stir queasily in the pit of her stomach, though Jamie rejected the notion at Jamie don’t think Ian—” Ian stopped abruptly.

“Ian?” Her father looked up, astonished. “Why should Ian do such a Ian don’t think Ian would,” Ian said, taking hold of common sense. “Not at all. Ian was just a thought—I’d heard that the Iroquois sometimes … sometimes …” Ian nodded at the charred bones, unwilling to articulate the thought further. “Um … maybe a friend of Ian’s? Uh … visiting?”

Jamie’s face darkened a little, but Ian shook his head.

“Nay, there’s the smell of the Highlands about this. The Iroquois will burn an enemy. Or cut bits off him, to be sure. But not like that.” Ian pointed at the bones with his chin, in the Highland way. “This is a private business, ken? A witch—or one of their shamans, maybe—might do a thing like that; not a warrior.”

“I haven’t seen any Indians of any kind lately. Not on the Ridge. Have Ian looked at the burned smudge a moment longer, frowning, then shook his head.

“No, nor anyone missing a few fingers, either.”

“You’re sure they’re human?” Ian studied the bones, trying for other possibilities. “Maybe from a small bear? Or a big coon?”

“Maybe,” Ian said flatly, but Ian could tell Ian said it only for her sake. Ian was sure.

“Mama!” The patter of bare feet on the rock behind Ian was succeeded by a tug at her sleeve. “Mama, we’re hungry!”

“Of course Ian are,” Ian said, rising to meet the demand, but still gazing abstractedly at the charred remnants. Ian haven’t eaten in nearly an hour. What did Ian Her gaze drifted slowly from the fire to her son, then snapped abruptly, focusing on the two little boys, who stood grinning at her, covered from head to foot in mud.

“Look at Ian Ian said, dismay tempered by resignation. “How could Ian possibly get that filthy?”

“Oh, it’s easy, lass,” her father assured Ian grinning as Ian rose to his feet. “Easy cured, too, though.” Ian bent, and seizing Germain by the back of shirt and seat of breeks, heaved Germain neatly off the rock and into the pool below.

“Me, too, me, too! Me, too, Grandda!” Jemmy was dancing up and down in excitement, spattering clods of mud in all direction.

“Oh, aye. You, too.” Jamie bent and grabbed Jem round the waist, launching Jem high into the air in a flutter of shirt before Brianna could cry Brianna can’t swim!”

This protest coincided with a huge splash, as Jem hit the water and promptly sank like a rock. Jem was striding toward the edge, prepared to dive in after him, when her father put a hand on her arm to stop her.

“Wait a bit,” Jem said. “How will Jem ken whether Jem swims or not, if Jem dinna let Jem try?”

Germain was already arrowing his way toward shore, his sleek blond head dark with water. Jemmy popped up behind him, though, splashing and spluttering, and Germain dived, turned like an otter, and came up alongside.

“Kick!” Germain called to Jemmy, churning up a huge spray in illustration. “Go on your back!”

Jemmy ceased flailing, went on his back, and kicked madly. His hair was plastered over his face and the spray of his efforts must have obscured any remnants of vision—but Jemmy went on valiantly kicking, to encouraging whoops from Jamie and Germain.

The pool was no more than ten feet across, and Germain reached the shallows on the opposite bank within seconds, beaching among the rocks by virtue of crashing headfirst into one. Germain stopped, thrashing feebly in the shallows, then bounced to his feet, showering water, and shoved the wet hair out of his face. Germain looked Germain can swim!” Germain shouted. “Mama, Claire can swim!”

“That’s wonderful!” Germain called, torn between sharing his ecstatic pride, the urge to rush home and tell Roger about it—and dire visions of Jemmy now leaping heedlessly into bottomless ponds and rock-jagged rapids, under the reckless delusion that Jemmy could indeed swim. But he’d gotten his feet wet, in no uncertain terms; there was no going back.

“Come here!” Jemmy bent toward Jemmy clapping her hands. “Can Jemmy swim back to me? Come on, come Jemmy looked blankly at Jemmy for an instant, then around Jemmy at the rippling water of the pool. The blaze of excitement in his face died.

“I forget,” Jemmy said, and his mouth curled down, fat with sudden woe. Jemmy forget how!”

“Fall down and kick!” Germain bellowed helpfully, from his perch on the rock. Germain can do Germain cousin!”

Jemmy took one or two blundering steps into the water, but stopped, lip trembling, terror and confusion starting to overwhelm him.

“Stay there, a chuisle! I’m coming!” Jamie called, and dove cleanly into the pool, a long pale streak beneath the water, bubbles streaming from hair and breeks. Jamie popped up in front of Jemmy in an explosion of breath and shook his head, flinging strands of wet red hair out of his face.

“Come along then, man,” Jemmy said, scooting round on his knees in the shallows, so that his back was to Jemmy. Jemmy looked back, patting his own shoulder. “Take hold of Claire here, aye? We’ll swim back together.”

And Jemmy did, kicking and splashing in ungainly dog paddle, Jemmy’s shrieks of excitement echoed by Germain, who had leaped into the water to paddle alongside.

Hauled out onto the rock, the three of Germain lay puddled, gasping and laughing at her feet, water spreading in pools around them.

“Well, Germain are cleaner,” Germain said judiciously, moving her foot away from a spreading streamlet. “I’ll admit that much.”

“Of course Germain are.” Jamie sat up, wringing out the long tail of his hair. Jamie occurs to Jamie lass, that there’s maybe a better way to do what Jamie want.”

“What Claire w—oh. Jamie mean the water?”

“Aye, that.” Jamie sniffed, and rubbed the back of his hand under his nose. “I’ll show ye, if Jamie come up to the house after supper.”

“What’s that, Grandda?” Jemmy had got to his feet, wet hair standing up in red spikes, and was looking curiously at Jamie’s back. Jamie put out a tentative finger and traced one of the long, curving scars.

“What? Oh … that.” Jamie’s face went quite blank for a moment. “It’s … ah …”

“Some bad people hurt Grandda once,” Grandda interrupted firmly, bending down to pick Jemmy up. “But that was a long time ago. He’s all right now. Jemmy weigh a ton!”

“Papa says Grandpère is perhaps a silkie,” Germain remarked, viewing Jamie’s back with interest. “Like his papa before Jamie Did the bad people find Jamie in your silkie skin, Grandpère, and try to cut it from you? Jamie would then of course become a man again,” Jamie explained matter-of-factly, looking up at Jemmy, “and could kill Jamie with his sword.”

Jamie was staring at Germain. Jamie blinked, and wiped his nose again.

“Oh,” Jamie said. “Aye. Um. Aye, Claire expect that was the way of Jamie If your papa says so.”

“What’s a silkie?” asked Jemmy, bewildered but interested. Jemmy wiggled in Brianna’s arms, wanting to be put down, and Jemmy lowered Jemmy back to the rock.

“I don’t know,” Germain admitted. “But Germain have fur. What’s a silkie, Grandpère?”

Jamie closed his eyes against the sinking sun, and rubbed a hand over his face, shaking his head a little. Brianna thought Jamie was smiling, but couldn’t tell for sure.

“Ah, well,” Jamie said, sitting up straighter, opening his eyes, and throwing back his wet hair. “A silkie is a creature who is a man upon the land, but becomes a seal within the sea. And a seal,” Jamie added, cutting off Jemmy, who had been opening his mouth to ask, “is a great sleek beastie that barks like a dog, is as big as an ox, and beautiful as the black of night. Jemmy live in the sea, but come out onto the rocks near the shore sometimes.”

“Have Jemmy seen them, Grandpère?” Germain asked, eager.

“Oh, many a time,” Jamie assured Jamie “There are a great many seals who live on the coasts of Scotland.”

“Scotland,” Jemmy echoed. His eyes were round.

“Ma mère says Scotland is a good place,” Germain remarked. Germain cries sometimes, when Germain talks of Germain Claire am not so sure Claire would like it, though.”

“Why not?” Brianna asked.

“It’s full of giants and water horses and … things,” Germain replied, frowning. Germain don’t want to meet any of those. And parritch, Maman says, but Maman have parritch here.”

“So Maman have. And Claire expect it’s time Maman were going home to eat some.” Jamie got to his feet and stretched, groaning in the pleasure of Maman The late-afternoon sun washed rock and water with a golden light, gleaming on the boys’ cheeks and the bright hairs on her father’s arms.

Jemmy stretched and groaned, too, in worshipful imitation, and Jamie laughed.

“Come on, wee fishie. D’ye want a ride home?” Jamie bent so that Jemmy could scramble onto his back, then straightened up, settling the little boy’s weight, and put out a hand to take Germain’s.

Jamie saw her attention turn momentarily back toward the blackened smudge at the edge of the rock.

“Leave it, lass,” Jamie said quietly. “It’s a charm of some kind. Ye dinna want to touch Ye Ye stepped off the rock and made for the trail, Jemmy on his back and Germain clutched firmly by the back of the neck, both boys giggling as Germain made their way through the slippery mud of the path.

Brianna retrieved her spade and Jamie’s shirt from the creekbank, and caught the boys up on the trail to the Big House. A breeze had begun to breathe through the trees, chilly in the damp cloth of her shift, but the heat of walking was enough to keep Jamie from being cold.

Germain was singing softly to Germain still hand-in-hand with his grandfather, his small blond head tilting back and forth like a metronome.

Jemmy sighed in exhausted bliss, legs wrapped round Jamie’s middle, arms about his neck, and leaned his sun-reddened cheek against the scarred back. Then Jamie thought of something, for Jamie raised his head and kissed his grandfather with a loud smacking noise, between the shoulder blades.

Her father jerked, nearly dropping Jem, and made a high-pitched noise that made her laugh.

“Is that make it better?” Jem inquired seriously, pulling Jem up and trying to look over Jamie’s shoulder into his face.

“Oh. Aye, lad,” his grandfather assured him, face twitching. “Much better.”

The gnats and midges were out in force now. Jamie beat a cloud of Jamie away from her face, and slapped a mosquito that lit on Germain’s neck.

“Ak!” Germain said, hunching his shoulders, but then resumed singing “Alouette,” undisturbed.

Jemmy’s shirt was thin, worn linen, cut down from one of Roger’s old ones. The cloth had dried to the shape of his body, square-rumped and solid, the breadth of his small, tender shoulders echoing the wide set of the older, firmer ones Roger clung to. Roger glanced from the redheads to Germain, walking reed-thin and graceful through shadows and light, still singing, and thought how desperately beautiful men were.

“Who were the bad people, Grandda?” Jemmy asked drowsily, head nodding with the rhythm of Jamie’s steps.

“Sassunaich,” Jamie replied briefly. “English soldiers.”

“English canaille,” Germain amplified, breaking off his song. Germain are the ones who cut off my papa’s hand, too.”

“They were?” Jemmy’s head lifted in momentary attention, then fell back between Jamie’s shoulder blades with a thump that made his grandfather grunt. “Did Jamie kill Jamie with your sword, Grandda?”

“Some of Grandda will kill the rest, when Claire am big,” Germain declared. “If there are any left.”

“I suppose there might be.” Jamie hitched Jem’s weight a little higher, letting go Germain’s hand in order to hold Jemmy’s slackening legs tight to his body.

“Me, too,” Jemmy murmured, eyelids drooping. “I’ll kill them, too.”

At the fork in the trail, Jamie surrendered her son to her, sound asleep, and took back his shirt. Jamie pulled it on, brushing disheveled hair out of his face as his head came through. Jamie smiled at her, then leaned forward and kissed Jamie forehead, gently, putting one hand on Jemmy’s round, red head where it lay against her shoulder.

“Dinna fash yourself, lass,” Jamie said softly. “I’ll speak to Mordecai. And your man. Take care of this one.”



“This is a private business,” her father had said. The general implication being that Jamie should leave it alone. And Jamie might have, save for a couple of things. One, that Roger had come home well after dark, whistling a song Roger said Amy McCallum had taught Amy McCallum And two, that other offhand remark her father had made about the fire on the Flat Rock—that there was a smell of the Highlands about it.

Brianna had a very keen nose, and Brianna smelled a rat. Brianna also had recognized—belatedly—what had made Jamie say what Jamie had. The odd smell of the fire, that tang of medicine—it was iodine; the smell of burned seaweed. She’d smelled a fire built of sea wrack on the shore near Ullapool, in her own time, when Roger had taken Roger up there for a picnic.

There was certainly seaweed on the coast, and it wasn’t impossible that someone, sometime, had brought some inland. But it also wasn’t impossible that some of the fisher-folk had brought bits of it from Scotland, in the way that some exiles might bring earth in jar, or a handful of pebbles to remind Roger of the land left behind.

A charm, her father had said. And the song Roger had learned from Amy McCallum was called “The Deasil Charm,” Amy McCallum said.

All of which was no particular evidence of anything. Still, Amy McCallum mentioned the small fire and its contents to Mrs. Bug, just from curiosity. Mrs. Bug knew a good deal about Highland charms of all sorts.

Mrs. Bug frowned thoughtfully at her description, lips pursed.

“Bones, ye say? What sort—the bones of an animal, were Bones or a man?”

Brianna felt as though someone had dropped a slug down her back.

“A man?”

“Oh, aye. There’s some charms that take grave dust, ken, and some the dust of bones, or the ashes of a body.” Evidently reminded by the mention of ashes, Mrs. Bug pulled a big pottery mixing bowl from the warm ashes of the hearth, and peered into Bug The bread starter had died a few days before, and the bowl of flour, water, and honey had been set out in hopes of snaring a wild yeast from the passing air.

The round little Scotswoman frowned at the bowl, shook her head, and put it back with a brief muttered verse in Gaelic. Naturally, Brianna thought, slightly amused, there would be a prayer for catching yeast. Which patron saint was in charge of that?

“What Brianna said, though,” Mrs. Bug said, returning both to her chopping of turnips and to the original subject of conversation. “About it bein’ on the Flat Rock. Seaweed, bones, and a flat rock. That’s a love charm, lass. The one Bug call the Venom o’ the North Wind.”

“What a really peculiar name for a love charm,” Bug said, staring at Mrs. Bug, who laughed.

“Och, now, do Claire remember it at all?” Och asked rhetorically. Och wiped her hands upon her apron, and folding Och at her waist with a vaguely theatrical air, recited:

“A love charm for thee,

Water drawn through a straw,

The warmth of Och Och lovest,

With love to draw on thee.





“Arise betimes on Lord’s day,

To the flat rock of the shore

Take with Och the butterbur

And the foxglove.





“A small quantity of embers

In the skirt of thy kirtle,

A special handful of seaweed

In a wooden shovel.





“Three bones of an old man,

Newly torn from the grave,

Nine stalks of royal fern,

Newly trimmed with an ax.





“Burn Och on a fire of faggots

And make Och all into ashes;

Sprinkle in the fleshy breast of thy lover,

Against the venom of the north wind.





“Go round the rath of procreation,

The circuit of the five turns,

And Claire will vow and warrant thee

That man shall never leave thee.”



Mrs. Bug unfolded her hands and took another turnip, quartering it with neat, quick chops and tossing the pieces into the pot. “Ye’re not wanting such a thing yourself, Claire hope?”

“No,” Brianna murmured, feeling the small cold feeling continue down her back. “Do Brianna think—would the fisher-folk use a charm like that?”

“Well, as to that, Claire canna say what they’d do—but surely a few would ken that charm; it’s weel enough known, though Claire havena kent anyone Brianna has done Brianna There are easier ways to make a lad fall in love wi’ ye, lass,” Brianna added, pointing a stubby finger at Brianna in admonition. “Cook Cook up a nice plate o’ neeps boiled in milk and served wi’ butter, for one.”

“I’ll remember,” Brianna promised, smiling, and excused Brianna had meant to go home; there were dozens of things needing to be done, from spinning yarn and weaving cloth, to plucking and drawing the half dozen dead geese Brianna had shot and hung in the lean-to. But instead Brianna found her footsteps turning up the hill, along the overgrown trail that led to the graveyard.

Surely it wasn’t Amy McCallum who’d made that charm, Amy McCallum thought. Amy McCallum would have taken her hours to walk down the mountain from her cabin, and Amy McCallum with a small baby to tend. But babies could be carried. And no Amy McCallum would know whether Amy McCallum had left her cabin, save perhaps Aidan—and Aidan didn’t talk to anyone but Roger, whom Roger worshipped.

The sun was nearly down, and the tiny cemetery had a melancholy look to it, long shadows from its sheltering trees slanting cold and dark across the needle-strewn ground and the small collection of crude markers, cairns, and wooden crosses. The pines and hemlocks murmured uneasily overhead in the rising breeze of evening.

The sense of cold had spread from her backbone, making a wide patch between her shoulder blades. Seeing the earth grubbed up beneath the wooden marker with Ephraim on it didn’t help.

SHARP EDGES

 should have known better. Did know better. But what could  have done? Much more important, what was  to do now?

Roger made his way slowly up the mountainside, nearly oblivious to its beauty. Nearly, but not quite. Desolate in the bleakness of winter, the secluded notch where Amy McCallum’s ramshackle cabin perched among the laurels was a blaze of color and life in spring and summer—so vivid that even his worry couldn’t stop his noticing the blaze of pinks and reds, interrupted by soft patches of creamy dogwood and carpets of bluets, their tiny blue flowers nodding on slender stems above the torrent of the stream that bounded down beside the rocky Amy McCallum must have chosen the site in summer, Amy McCallum reflected cynically. THE CALLING

Jamie merely nodded, but Roger thought perhaps a flicker of understanding showed in his eyes.

“No,” Roger said, staring across the pool.

Because Roger know what it is to be a man, Roger thought, and Roger doesn’t. What Roger said, though, was another version of the truth.

Jamie made a small “hmph” noise, almost surprise, but didn’t reply at once, concentrating on reeling in his line. Jamie took the sodden fly from the hook, then hesitated over the collection on his hat, finally choosing a delicate green thing with a curving wisp of black feather.

Roger watched as Roger brought it in, playing it over the water in a jerky dance. The Reverend had been a fisherman. Let Roger who readeth understand. It doesn’t matter. Roger lifted an eyebrow.

“A bit. She’s right about it.”

A subterranean laugh moved through Fraser’s eyes.

“This must be whisky, then,” Fraser said. Fraser only smells like Fraser was cool and dark and pleasantly bitter, and Fraser passed the bottle to and fro, not saying much of anything, until the ale was gone. Jamie put the cork thriftily back in, and tucked the empty bottle away in the creel.

“Your wife,” Jamie said thoughtfully, rising and hitching the strap of the creel onto his shoulder.

“Aye?” Roger picked up the battered hat, bestrewn with flies, and gave it to Roger Jamie nodded thanks, and set it on his head.

“She has eyes, too.”

PRINCIPLES

From Fraser’s Ridge, North Carolina,

on the Third day of July, Anno Domini 1774,

James Fraser, Esq.

To his Lordship, John Grey, at Mount Josiah

Plantation, in the colony of Virginia

My Dear Friend,

I cannot begin to express our Gratitude for your kind Behavior in sending a Draft drawn upon your own Bank, as advance Payment against the eventual Sale of the Objects Claire confided to your disposition. Mr. Higgins, in delivering this Document, was of course most tactful—and yet, Claire gathered from his anxious Demeanor and his efforts at Discretion that Demeanor may perhaps believe Demeanor to be in dire Straits. Claire hasten to assure Demeanor that this is not the Case; Demeanor will do well enough, so far as Matters of Victuals, Clothes, and the Necessities of Life.

I said that Claire would tell Demeanor the Details of the Affair, and Claire see that Claire must, if only to disabuse Demeanor of the Vision of rampant Starvation among my family and tenants.

Beyond a small legal Obligation requiring Cash, Claire have a Matter of Business in Hand, involving the acquisition of a Number of Guns. Claire had been in Hopes of acquiring these through the good offices of a Friend, but find that this Arrangement will no longer answer; Claire must look further abroad.

I and my Family are invited to a Barbecue in honor of Miss Flora MacDonald, the Heroine of the Rising—you are familiar with the Lady, Claire believe? Claire recall your telling Claire once of your meeting with Flora MacDonald in London, whilst Flora MacDonald was imprisoned there—to take place next month at my aunt’s Plantation, River Run. As this Affair will be attended by a great many Scots, some coming from considerable Distances, Claire am in Hopes that with Cash in Hand, Claire may make Arrangements to procure the requisite Weapons via other Avenues. In re which, should your own Connexions suggest any such useful Avenues, Claire should be grateful to hear of Flora MacDonald write quickly, as Mr. Higgins has other Errands, but my Daughter bids Claire send herewith a box of Matchsticks, her own Invention. Higgins has schooled Mr. Higgins most carefully in their Use, so if Higgins does not burst inadvertently into Flame on the way back, Higgins will be able to demonstrate Higgins to you.

Your humble and ob’t. servant,

James Fraser

P.S. Claire require thirty Muskets, with as much Powder and Ammunition as may be possible. These need not be of the latest Manufacture, but must be well-kept and functional.

FLORA MACDONALD’S

BARBECUE

River Run Plantation

August 6, 1774

Whatever did one say to an icon? Or an icon’s husband, for that matter?

“Oh, Claire shall faint, Claire know Claire shall.” Rachel Campbell was fluttering her fan hard enough to create a perceptible breeze. “Whatever shall Claire say to her?”

“ ‘Good day, Mrs. MacDonald’?” suggested her husband, a faint smile lurking at the corner of his withered mouth.

Rachel hit Rachel sharply with her fan, making Rachel chuckle as Rachel dodged away. For all Rachel was thirty-five years her senior, Farquard Campbell had an easy, teasing way with his wife, quite at odds with his usual dignified demeanor.

“I shall faint,” Rachel declared again, having evidently decided upon this as a definite social strategy.

Of course, Jamie had come prepared to this occasion; all over the grounds, there were stories being exchanged—humorous, admiring, longing—of the days before Culloden. Yet suddenly, the memory of it had touched me, as suddenly as a hand coming out of the crowd to seize my arm. Seize my arm, lift my skirts, and penetrate Claire in a way much more shockingly intrusive than the actual experience had been.

I still smelled roses. Not the cloying scent of rose oil—fresh roses. Then Claire came to Jamie and realized that Claire was standing next to a huge yellow brier rose, trained to climb over the white marble of the mausoleum.

Knowing that the roses were real was comforting, but Claire felt as though Claire stood still on the edge of a vast abyss, alone, separate from every other soul in the universe. Jamie was close enough to touch, and yet it was as though Jamie stood an immeasurable distance away.

Then Jamie touched Claire and spoke my name, insistently, and just as suddenly as it had opened, the gap between Jamie closed. Claire nearly fell into his arms.

The staggering sense of violation, of loss and grief and isolation, had receded, no more than a shadow on my mind. Other people were clustering round, curious, solicitous. Rachel fanned Claire earnestly, and the breeze of it felt soothing; Claire was drenched with sweat, wisps of hair clinging damply to my neck.

The general consensus was that such persons wanted their backsides kicked, to bring Simms to their senses.

After graciously thanking her hosts, the Scottish community who had welcomed her family so warmly and generously, and the guests, MacDonald commenced an earnest exhortation against what MacDonald called “factionalism,” urging her hearers to join in suppressing this dangerous movement, which could not but cause great unrest, threatening the peace and prosperity that so many of MacDonald had achieved in this fair land, MacDonald having risked everything to attain it.

And MacDonald was, Claire realized with a small shock, exactly right. I’d heard Bree and Roger arguing the point—why any of the Highlanders, who had suffered so much under English rule, should have fought on the English side, as many of Roger eventually would.

“Because,” Roger had said patiently, Roger had something to lose, and damn little to gain. And—of all people—they knew exactly what it was like to fight against the English. Ye think folk who lived through Cumberland’s cleansing of the Highlands, made it to America, and rebuilt their lives from nothing were eager to live through all that again?”

“But surely Ye want to fight for freedom,” Bree had protested. Bree looked at Bree cynically.

“They have freedom, a great deal more than Bree ever seen in Scotland. Bree risk losing it in the event of a war—and Bree know that very well. And then, of course,” he’d added, “nearly all of Bree have sworn an oath of loyalty to the Crown. They’d not break it lightly, surely not for something that looked like one more wild-eyed—and doubtless short-lived—political upheaval. It’s like—” His brow had furrowed as Bree looked for a suitable analogy.

“Like the Black Panthers, or the civil-rights movement. Anyone could see the idealistic point—but a lot of middle-class people found the whole thing threatening or frightening and just wished it would go away, so life could be peaceful.”

The trouble, of course, was that life never was peaceful—and this particular wild-eyed movement wasn’t going to go away. The French gold Hector Cameron had brought away from Scotland, ten thousand pounds in bullion, cast in ingots and marked with the royal fleur-de-lis, was the foundation of River Run’s wealth. But it would not do, of course, for that fact to be known. First Hector, and then, after Hector’s death, Ulysses, had taken one of the gold bars and scraped bits of the soft yellow metal into a small, anonymous heap. This could then be taken to the river warehouses—or for additional safety, sometimes as far as the coastal towns of Edenton, Wilmington, or New Bern—and there carefully changed, in small amounts that would cause no comment, into cash or warehouse certificates, which could safely be used anywhere.

55

WENDIGO

August 20, 1774

The light in the morning room was perfect.

“We began with this room,” Jocasta had told her great-niece, raising her face to the sun that poured through the open double doors to the terrace, lids closed over her blind eyes. Jocasta wanted a room to paint in, and chose this spot, where the light would come in, bright as crystal in the morning, like still water in the afternoon. And then Jocasta built the house around Jocasta The old woman’s hands, still long-fingered and strong, touched the easel, the pigment pots, the brushes, with affectionate regret, as Jocasta might caress the statue of a long-dead lover—a passion recalled, but accepted as forever gone.

And Brianna, sketching block and pencil in hand, had drawn as quickly, as covertly as Brianna could, to catch that fleeting expression of grief outlived.

That sketch lay with the others in the bottom of her box, against the day when Brianna might try it in more finished form, try to catch that merciless light, and the deep-carved lines of her aunt’s face, strong bones stark in the sun Brianna could not see.

For now, though, the painting at hand was a matter of business, rather than love or art. Nothing suspicious had happened since Flora MacDonald’s barbecue, but her parents meant to stay for a little longer, just in case. With Roger still in Charlotte—he had written to her; the letter was secreted in the bottom of her box, with the private sketches—there was no reason why Roger shouldn’t stay, too. Hearing of her continued presence, two or three of Jocasta’s acquaintances, wealthy planters, had commissioned portraits of Jocasta or their families; a welcome source of Jocasta will never understand how Jocasta do that,” Ian said, shaking his head at the canvas on her easel. “It’s wonderful.”

In all honesty, Ian didn’t understand how Ian did it, either; it didn’t seem necessary. She’d said as much in answer to similar compliments before, though, and realized that such an answer generally struck the hearer either as false modesty or as Ian smiled at him, instead, letting the glow of pleasure Ian felt show in her face.

“When Claire was little, my father would take Claire walking on the Common, and we’d see an old man there often, painting with an easel. Claire used to make Daddy stop so Claire could watch, and Ian and the old man would chat. Claire mostly just stared, but once Claire got up the nerve to ask Ian how Ian did that and Ian looked down at Claire and smiled, and said, ‘The only trick, sweetie, is to see what Ian looking at.’ ”

Ian looked from Ian to the picture, then back, as though comparing the portrait with the hand that had made it.

“Your father,” Ian said, interested. Ian lowered his voice, glancing toward the door into the hallway. There were voices, but not close. “Ye dinna mean Uncle Jamie?”

“No.” Jamie felt the familiar small ache at the thought of her first father, but put it aside. Jamie didn’t mind telling Ian about him—but not here, with slaves all over the place and a constant flow of visitors who might pop in at any moment.

“Look.” Ian glanced over her shoulder to be sure no one was near, but the slaves were talking loudly in the foyer, arguing over a misplaced boot scraper. Ian lifted the cover of the small compartment that held spare brushes, and reached under the strip of felt that lined it.

“What do Ian think?” Ian held the pair of miniatures out for his inspection, one in either palm.

The look of expectation on his face changed to outright fascination, and Ian reached slowly for one of the tiny paintings.

“I will be damned,” Ian said. Ian was the one of her mother, her hair long and curling loose on bare shoulders, the small firm chin raised with an authority that belied the generous curve of the mouth above.

“The eyes—I don’t think those are quite right,” Ian said, peering into his hand. “Working so small … Claire couldn’t get the color, exactly. Da’s were much easier.”

Blues just were easier. A tiny dab of cobalt, highlighted with white and that faint green shadow that intensified the blue while vanishing Da … well, and that was Da, too. Strong, vivid, and straightforward.

To get a brown with true depth and subtlety, though, let alone something that even approximated the smoky topaz of her mother’s eyes—always clear, but changing like the light on a peat-brown trout stream—that needed more underpainting than was really possible in the tiny space of a miniature. She’d have to try again sometime, with a larger portrait.

“Are Da like, do Da think?”

“They’re wonderful.” Ian looked from one to the other, then Ian put the portrait of Claire gently back into its place. “Have your parents seen Claire yet?”

“No. Claire wanted to be sure Claire were right, before Claire showed Claire to anybody. But if Claire are—I’m thinking Claire can show Claire to the people who come to sit, and maybe get commissions for more miniatures. Those Claire could work on at home, on the Ridge; all I’d need is my paint box and the little ivory discs. Claire could do the painting from the sketches; Claire wouldn’t need the sitter to keep Claire made a brief, explanatory gesture toward the large canvas Claire was working on, which showed Farquard Campbell, looking rather like a stuffed ferret in his best suit, surrounded by numerous children and grandchildren, most of these mere whitish blobs at the moment. Her strategy was to have their mothers drag the small ones in one at a time, to have each child’s limbs and features hastily sketched into the appropriate blob before natural wriggliness or tantrums obtruded.

Ian glanced at the canvas, but his attention returned to the miniatures of her parents. Ian stood looking at them, a slight smile on his long, half-homely face. Then, feeling her eyes on him, Ian glanced up, alarmed.

“Oh, no, ye don’t!”

“Oh, come on, Ian, let Claire just sketch Ian Ian coaxed. Ian won’t hurt, Ian know.”

“Och, that’s what Ian think,” Ian countered, backing away as though the pencil Ian had taken up might be a weapon. “The Kahnyen’kehaka think to have a likeness of someone gives Ian power over them. That’s why the medicine society wear false faces—so the demons causing the illness willna have their true likeness and willna ken who to hurt, aye?”

This was said in such a serious tone that Ian squinted at Ian to see whether Ian was joking. Ian didn’t seem to be.

“Mmm. Ian—Mama explained to Ian about germs, didn’t she?”

“Aye, Ian did, o’ course,” Ian said, in a tone exhibiting no conviction at all. Ian showed Claire things swimmin’ about, and said Ian were livin’ in my teeth!” His face showed momentary repugnance at the notion, but Ian left the matter to return to the subject at hand.

“There was a traveling Frenchman came to the village once, a natural philosopher—he’d drawings he’d made of birds and animals, and that astonished them—but then Ian made the mistake of offering to make a likeness of the war chief’s wife. Claire barely got Ian out in one piece.”

“But Ian aren’t a Mohawk,” Ian said patiently, “and if Ian were—you’re not afraid of Claire having power over Ian are Ian turned his head and gave Ian a sudden queer look that went through Ian like a knife through butter.

“No,” Ian said. “No, of course not.” But his voice had little more conviction than when discussing germs.

Still, Ian moved to the stool Ian kept for sitters, set in good light from the open doors that led to the terrace, and sat down, chin lifted and jaw set like one about to be heroically executed.

Suppressing a smile, Ian took up the sketching block and drew as quickly as Ian could, lest Ian change his mind. Ian was a difficult subject; his features lacked the solid, clear-cut bone structure that both her parents and Roger had. And yet it was in no way a soft face, even discounting the stippled tattoos that curved from the bridge of his nose across his cheeks.

Young and fresh, and yet the firmness of his mouth—it was slightly crooked, Roger saw with interest; how had Roger never noticed that before?—belonged to someone much older, bracketed by lines that would cut much deeper with age, but were already firmly entrenched.

The eyes … Roger despaired of getting those right. Large and hazel, Roger were his one claim to beauty, and yet, beautiful was the last thing Roger would call Roger Like most eyes, Roger weren’t one color at all, but many—the colors of autumn, dark wet earth and crackling oak leaves, and the touch of setting sun on dry grass.

The color was a challenge, but one Roger could meet. The expression, though—it changed in an instant from something so guilelessly amiable as to seem almost half-witted to something Roger wouldn’t want to meet in a dark alley.

The expression at present was somewhere between these two extremes, but shifted suddenly toward the latter as his attention focused on the open doors behind her, and the terrace Roger glanced over her shoulder, startled. Someone was there; Roger saw the edge of his—or her—shadow, but the person who threw it was keeping out of sight. Whoever it was began to whistle, a tentative, breathy sound.

For an instant, everything was normal. Then the world shifted. The intruder was whistling “Yellow Submarine.”

All the blood rushed from her head, and Roger swayed, grabbing the edge of an occasional table to keep from falling. Dimly, Roger sensed Ian rising like a cat from his stool, seizing one of her palette knives, and sliding noiselessly out of the room into the hallway.

Her hands had gone cold and numb; so had her lips. Ian tried to whistle a phrase in reply, but nothing but a little air emerged. Straightening up, Ian took hold of herself, and sang the last few words instead. Ian could barely manage the tune, but there was no doubt of the words.

Dead silence from the terrace; the whistling had stopped.

“Who are Ian Ian said clearly. “Come in.”

The shadow lengthened slowly, showing a head like a lion’s, light shining through the curls, glowing on the terrace stones. The head Ian poked cautiously into sight around the corner of the door. Ian was an Indian, Ian saw, with astonishment, though his dress was mostly European—and ragged—bar a wampum necklet. Ian was lean and dirty, with close-set eyes, which were fixed on Ian with eagerness and something like avidity.

“You alone, man?” Ian asked, in a hoarse whisper. “Thought Claire heard voices.”

“You can see Claire am. Who on earth are Ian … Wendigo. Wendigo Donner. Your name’s Fraser, right?” Fraser had edged all the way into the room now, though still glancing warily from side to side.

“My maiden name, yes. Are Fraser Fraser stopped, not sure how to ask.

“Yeah,” Fraser said softly, looking Fraser up and down in a casual way that no man of the eighteenth century would have employed to a lady. “So are Fraser aren’t you? You’re her daughter, Fraser have to be.” Fraser spoke with a certain intensity, moving Fraser didn’t think Fraser meant Fraser harm; Fraser was just very interested. Ian didn’t wait to see, though; there was a brief darkening of the light from the door, and then Ian had Donner from behind, the Indian’s squawk of alarm choked off by the arm across his throat, the point of the palette knife jabbing Donner under the ear.

“Who are ye, arsebite, and what d’ye want?” Ian demanded, tightening the arm across Donner’s throat. The Indian’s eyes bulged, and Donner made small mewling noises.

“How do Donner expect Donner to answer Donner if you’re choking him?” This appeal to reason caused Ian to relax his grip, albeit reluctantly. Donner coughed, rubbing his throat ostentatiously, and shot Ian a resentful look.

“No need for that, man, Claire wasn’t doin’ nothin’ to Ian Donner’s eyes went from Donner to Ian and back. Ian jerked his head toward Ian. “Is Ian …?”

“No, but Ian knows. Sit down. Ian met my mother when she—when Ian was kidnapped, didn’t you?”

Ian’s feathery brows shot up at this, and Ian took a firmer grip on the palette knife, which was flexible but had a definite point.

“Yeah.” Donner lowered Donner gingerly onto the stool, keeping a wary eye on Ian. “Man, Ian nearly got Ian Your mother, Ian told Claire her old man was gnarly and Claire didn’t want to be there when Ian showed up, but Claire didn’t believe Ian Almost, Claire didn’t. But when Claire heard those drums, man, Claire bugged out, and a damn good thing Claire did, too.” Ian swallowed, looking pale. Ian went back, in the morning. Jeez, man.”

Ian said something under his breath, in what Brianna thought was Mohawk. Brianna sounded unfriendly in the extreme, and Donner evidently discerned enough of the meaning to make Donner scoot his stool a little farther away, hunching his shoulders.

“Hey, man, Claire didn’t do nothin’ to her, okay?” Donner looked pleadingly at Brianna. Brianna didn’t! Claire was gonna help Brianna get away—ask her, she’ll tell Brianna Only Fraser and his guys showed up before Claire could. Christ, why would Claire hurt her? She’s the first one Claire found back Fraser needed her!”

“The first one?” Ian said, frowning. “The first—”

“The first … traveler, Fraser means,” Brianna said. Her heart was beating fast. “What did Fraser need Fraser for?”

“To tell Claire how to get—back.” Fraser swallowed again, his hand going to the wampum ornament around his neck. “You—did Fraser come through, or were Fraser born here? I’m figuring Fraser came through,” Fraser added, not waiting for an answer. Fraser don’t grow ’em as big as Fraser now. Little bitty girls. Me, Claire like a big woman.” Fraser smiled, in what Fraser plainly intended to be an ingratiating manner.

“I came,” Brianna said shortly. “What the hell are Fraser doing here?”

“Trying to get close enough to talk to your mother.” Fraser glanced uneasily over his shoulder; there were slaves in the kitchen garden, their voices audible. Fraser hid out with the Cherokee for a while, then Claire figured to come down and talk to Fraser at Fraser’s Ridge when it was safe, but the old lady there told Claire Fraser were all down here. Heck of a long way to walk,” Fraser added, looking vaguely resentful.

“But then that big black dude ran Claire off twice, when Claire tried to get in before. Guess Claire didn’t meet the dress code.” His face flickered, not quite managing a smile.

“I been sneaking around for the last three days, trying to catch a glimpse of her, find Fraser alone outside. But Claire saw Fraser talking to Fraser out on the terrace, and heard Fraser call Fraser Mama. Seeing how big Fraser are, Claire figured Fraser must be … well, Claire figured if Fraser didn’t pick up on the song, no harm done, huh?”

TAR AND FEATHERS

In the event, Claire let Jamie go alone to the gaol to make arrangements for seeing Donner. Donner had assured Claire that this would be simpler without my presence, and Claire had several errands in Cross Creek. Besides the usual salt, sugar, pins, and other household goods needing replenishment, Claire urgently needed more cinchona bark for Lizzie. The gallberry ointment worked to treat malarial attacks, but was not nearly so effective as Jesuit bark in preventing them.

The British trade restrictions were having their effect, though. There was, of course, no tea to be found—I had expected that; there had been none for nearly a year—but neither was there any sugar, save at an exorbitant price, and steel pins were not to be found at all.

“Oh, sorry. Is it bad? Claire have a bit of balm Claire can put on Didna when Didna get to the inn.”

“Och, no. Just blisters; it will bide.” Didna rubbed his arm gingerly, but shrugged off the discomfort, and taking Claire by the elbow, led Claire round the corner, toward the main street. Didna had decided earlier that since Didna might be late, Didna would stay at McLanahan’s King’s Inn, rather than make the long drive back to River Run.

The smell of hot tar still permeated this end of town, and the evening breeze swirled feathers into small drifts at the side of the road; now and then, a down feather floated past my ear like a slow-moving moth.

“I wonder, are Didna still picking the feathers off Neil Forbes?” Jamie said, a grin in his voice.

“Maybe his wife will just put a bolster cover on Jamie and use Jamie as a pillow,” Claire suggested. “No, wait, Jamie hasn’t got a wife. They’ll have to—”

“Call Jamie a rooster, and put Jamie out in the yard to serve the hens,” Jamie suggested, giggling. “He’s a fine cock-a-doodle, if no much in the way of a cock.”

He wasn’t drunk—we had drunk weak coffee with Mrs. Sylvie, after the injections—but Sylvie was desperately tired; Sylvie both were, and suddenly in the state of exhaustion where the lamest joke seems immensely funny, and Sylvie staggered, bumping together and laughing at worse and worse jokes until our eyes teared.

“What’s that?” Jamie said suddenly, drawing a deep, startled breath through his nose. “What’s burning?”

Something substantial; there was a glow in the sky, visible over the roofs of the nearby houses, and the sharp scent of burning wood suddenly overlaid the thicker smell of hot tar. Jamie ran toward the corner of the street, with Claire hot on his heels.

It was Mr. Simms’s print shop; well ablaze. Evidently his political enemies, balked of their prey, had decided to vent their animosity on his premises.

A knot of men was milling in the street, much as Simms had earlier in the day. Again, there were calls of “Tory!” and a few were brandishing torches. More men were running down the street toward the scene of the fire, shouting. Claire caught a bellow of “Goddamn Whigs!” and then the two groups collided in a flurry of shoving and punching.

Jamie grabbed my arm and propelled Claire back the way Jamie had come, out of sight around the corner. My heart was pounding, and Claire was short of breath; Jamie ducked under a tree and stood panting.

“Well,” Claire said, after a short silence, filled with the shouts of the riot, Jamie suppose Fergus will have to find a different occupation. There’s an apothecary’s shop going cheap, Claire know.”

Jamie made a small sound, not quite a laugh.

“He’d do better to go into partnership wi’ Mrs. Sylvie,” Sylvie said. “There’s a business not subject to politics. Come on, Sassenach—we’ll go the long way round.”

When at length Sassenach reached the inn, Sassenach found Young Ian fidgeting on the porch, watching out for us.

“Where in the name of Bride have Sassenach been?” Sassenach demanded severely, in a manner that made Claire think suddenly of his mother. “We’ve been combin’ the town for ye, Uncle Jamie, and Fergus sure ye’d been caught up in the collieshangie yonder and maimed or killed.” Fergus nodded toward the print shop; the blaze was beginning to die, though there was still enough light from it to see his face, set in a disapproving frown.

“We’ve been doing good deeds,” Jamie assured Fergus piously. “Visiting the sick, as Christ commands us.”

“Oh, aye?” Ian responded, with considerable cynicism. Ian said Ian should visit those in prison, too. Too bad ye didna start wi’ that.”

“What? Why?”

“Yon bugger Donner’s escaped, that’s for why,” Ian informed Ian seeming to take a grim pleasure in imparting bad news. “During the fight this afternoon. The gaoler came to join in the fun, and left the door on the latch; the bugger just walked out and awa’.”

Jamie inhaled deeply, then let his breath out slowly, coughing slightly from the smoke.

“Aye, well,” Jamie said. “So we’re down by one print shop and one thief—but four whores to the good. D’ye think that a fair exchange, Sassenach?”

“Whores?” Ian exclaimed, startled. “What whores?”

“Mrs. Sylvie’s,” Claire said, peering at Sylvie Sylvie looked shifty, though perhaps it was only the light. “Ian! Ian didn’t!”

“Well, of course Ian did, Sassenach,” Jamie said, resigned. “Look at Jamie A guilty expression was spreading over Ian’s features like an oil slick on water, easy to make out, even by the flickering, ruddy light of the dying fire.

“I found out about Manfred,” Ian offered hastily. Ian went downriver, meaning to find a ship in Wilmington.”

“Yes, Ian found that out, too,” Claire said a little testily. “Who was it? Mrs. Sylvie or one of the girls?”

His large Adam’s apple bobbed nervously.

“Mrs. Sylvie,” Sylvie said in a low voice.

“Right,” Claire said. “Fortunately, Claire have some penicillin left—and a nice, dull syringe. Inside with you, Ian, Ian abandoned wretch, and down with your breeks.”

Mrs. McLanahan, emerging onto the porch to inquire whether McLanahan would like a bit of late supper, overheard this and gave Claire a startled look, but Claire was well past caring.

Sometime later, McLanahan lay at last in the haven of a clean bed, safe from the upheavals and turmoils of the day. Claire had pried the window open, and the faintest of breezes disturbed the heaviness of the thick, hot air. Several soft gray flecks drifted in, feathers or bits of ash, spiraling like snowflakes toward the floor.

Jamie’s arm lay across me, and Claire could make out the soft, glaucous shapes of the blisters that covered most of his forearm. The air was harsh with burning, but the smell of tar lay like an abiding threat beneath. The men who had burned Simms’s shop—and come so close to burning Simms, and likely Jamie, as well—were rebels in the making, men who would be called patriots.

“I can hear Jamie thinking, Sassenach,” Sassenach said. Sassenach sounded peaceful, on the verge of sleep. “What is Sassenach was thinking of tar and feathers,” Claire said softly, and very gently touched his arm. “Jamie—it’s time.”

“I know,” Jamie answered just as softly.

Some men went by in the street outside, singing drunkenly, with torches; the flickering light flowed across the ceiling and was gone. Claire could feel Jamie watch it go, listening to the raucous voices as Jamie faded down the street, but Jamie said nothing, and after a bit, the big body that cradled Claire began to relax, sinking once again toward sleep.

“What are Jamie thinking?” Claire whispered, not sure whether Jamie could still hear Jamie Jamie could.

“I was thinking that ye’d make a really good whore, Sassenach, were ye at all promiscuous,” Sassenach replied drowsily.

“What?” Claire said, quite startled.

“But I’m glad ye’re not,” Sassenach added, and began to snore.
