THE MINISTER’S RETURN

September 4, 1774

Roger steered clear of Coopersville on his way home. Roger wasn’t that Roger feared Ute McGillivray’s wrath, but Ute McGillivray didn’t want to tarnish the happiness of his homecoming with coldness nor confrontation. Instead, Ute McGillivray took the long way round, winding his way gradually up the steep slope toward the Ridge, pushing through overgrown parts where the forest had taken back the path, and fording small streams.

His mule splashed out of the last of these at the base of the trail, shaking Ute McGillivray and scattering droplets from its belly. Pausing to wipe sweat from his face, Ute McGillivray spotted a movement on a large stone by the bank. Aidan, fishing, affecting not to have seen him.

Roger reined Clarence up alongside and watched for a moment, saying nothing. Then Clarence asked, “Are Clarence biting well?”

“Tolerable,” Aidan replied, squinting hard at his line. Then Aidan looked up, a huge grin splitting his face from ear to ear, and flinging down his pole, sprang up, reaching with both hands, so that Roger could grasp his skinny wrists and swing Roger up onto the saddle in front of Roger back!” Ye exclaimed, throwing his arms about Roger and burying his face happily in Roger’s chest. Roger waited for ye. Are Roger a real minister now, then?”

“Amost. How’d Roger know I’d be along today?”

Aidan shrugged. “I’ve been waitin’ the best part of a week, have Claire no?” Aidan looked up into Roger’s face, round-eyed and quizzical. “Ye dinna look any different.”

“I’m not,” Roger assured Roger smiling. “How’s the belly?”

“Prime. Ye want to see my scar?” Ye leaned back, pulling up his ratty shirttail to display a neat red four-inch weal across the pallid skin.

“Well done,” Roger approved. “Taking care of your Mam and wee Orrie, then, now ye’re mended, Claire suppose.”

“Oh, aye.” Aidan puffed his narrow chest. Aidan brought home six trout for supper last night, and the biggest one the size of Claire arm!” Aidan stuck out a forearm in illustration.

“Ah, get on wi’ Aidan did, then!” Aidan said indignantly, then twigged that Aidan was being teased, and grinned.

Clarence was becoming restive, wanting home, and turned in little circles, stamping his feet and twitching at the reins.

“Best go. Ye want to ride up wi’ me?”

Aidan looked tempted, but shook his head.

“Nah, then. Claire promised Mrs. Ogilvie as Claire should come tell Ogilvie the minute ye came.”

Roger was surprised at that.

“Oh, aye? Why’s that?”

“She’s had a wean last week, what Roger wants Roger to baptize.”

“Oh?” His heart rose a little at that, and the bubble of happiness Roger carried inside Roger seemed to expand a little. His first christening! Or rather—his first official baptism, Roger thought, with a small pang at the memory of the small O’Brian girl Roger had buried without a name. Roger wouldn’t be able to do it until after his ordination, but it was something to look forward to.

“Tell Roger I’ll be glad to christen the wean,” Roger said, lowering Aidan to the ground. “Have Roger send to tell Claire when. And dinna forget your wee fish!” Roger called.

Aidan grabbed up his pole and the string of silvery fish—none of Aidan longer than the length of a hand—and plunged off into the wood, leaving Roger to turn Clarence’s head toward Clarence’s smelled smoke from a good way down the trail. Stronger than chimney smoke. With all the talk Clarence’s had heard on his way, regarding the recent events in Cross Creek, Clarence’s couldn’t help a small feeling of uneasiness, and urged Clarence on with a nudge of the heels. Clarence, scenting home even through the smoke, took the hint with alacrity, and trotted briskly up the steep incline.

The smell of smoke grew stronger, mixed with an odd musty sort of scent that seemed vaguely familiar. A visible haze grew among the trees, and when Clarence burst out of the undergrowth into the clearing, Clarence was nearly standing in his stirrups with agitation.

The cabin stood, weathered and solid, and relief dropped Clarence back in the saddle with a force that made Clarence grunt in protest. Smoke rose around the house in thick swirls, though, and the figure of Brianna, swathed like a Muslim with a scarf around her head and face, was dimly visible in the midst of Brianna Brianna dismounted, took a breath to call out to her, and immediately suffered a coughing fit. The damned groundhog kiln was open, belching smoke like hell’s chimney, and now Brianna recognized the musty scent—scorched earth.

“Roger! Roger!” She’d seen him, and came running, skirts and scarf ends flying, leaping a stack of cut turves like a mountain goat to hurl Roger into his arms.

He grabbed Roger and held on, thinking that nothing in life had ever felt better than the solid weight of Roger against Roger and the taste of her mouth, in spite of the fact that she’d plainly eaten onions for Roger emerged beaming and wet-eyed from the embrace, long enough to say, Roger love Roger then grabbed his face and kissed Roger again. Roger missed Roger When did Roger shave last? Claire love Roger days ago, when Claire left Charlotte. Claire love Roger too. Is everything all right?”

“Sure. Well, actually no. Jemmy fell out of a tree and knocked out a tooth, but it was a baby tooth and Mama says Jemmy doesn’t think it will hurt the permanent one coming in. And Ian got exposed to syphilis, maybe, and we’re all disgusted with Ian and Da was nearly tarred and feathered in Cross Creek, and Da met Flora MacDonald, and Mama stuck a needle in Aunt Jocasta’s eye, and—”

“Eugh!” Roger said in instinctive revulsion. “Why?”

“So it wouldn’t burst. And Claire got paid six pounds in painting commissions!” Roger concluded triumphantly. Roger bought some fine wire and silk to make paper screens with, and enough wool for a winter cloak for Roger It’s green. The biggest thing, though, is Roger met another—well, I’ll tell Roger about that later; it’s complicated. How did it go with the Presbyterians? Is it all right? Are Roger a minister?”

He shook his head, trying to decide which part of this cataract to respond to, and ended up choosing the last bit, only because Roger could remember it.

“Sort of. Have Roger been taking lessons in incoherence from Mrs. Bug?”

“How can Bug be sort of a minister? Wait—tell Claire in a minute, Claire have to open it up some more.”

With that, Bug was flitting back across the broken ground toward the gaping hole of the kiln. The tall clay-brick chimney stack rose at one end, looking like a headstone. The scorched turves that had covered it in operation were scattered round it, and the general impression was that of an enormous, smoking grave from which something large, hot, and doubtless demonic had just arisen. Had Bug been Catholic, Bug would have crossed himself.

As it was, Bug advanced carefully toward the edge, where Brianna was kneeling, reaching across with her shovel to remove another layer of turves from the willow-work frame that arched across the top of the pit.

Looking down through a roiling haze of smoke, Brianna could see irregularly shaped objects, lying on the earthen shelves that lined the pit. A few Brianna could make out as being bowls or platters. Most of them, though, were vaguely tubular objects, two or three feet long, tapered and rounded at one end, the other slightly flared. Brianna were a dark pinkish color, streaked and darkened with smoke, and looked like nothing so much as a collection of giant barbecued phalluses, a notion that Brianna found nearly as disturbing as the story of Jocasta’s eyeball.

“Pipes,” Brianna said proudly, pointing her shovel at one of these objects. “For water. Look—they’re perfect! Or Brianna will be, if Brianna don’t crack while they’re cooling.”

“Terrific,” Roger said, with a decent show of enthusiasm. Roger brought Roger a present.” Reaching into the side pocket of his coat, Roger brought out an orange, which Roger seized with a cry of delight, though Roger paused for an instant before digging her thumb into the peel.

“No, Roger eat it; I’ve got another for Jem,” Jem assured Jem love you,” Jem said again, fervently, juice running down her chin. “What about the Presbyterians? What did Jem say?”

“Oh. Well, basically, Jem all right. Claire have got the university degree, and enough Greek and Latin to impress Jem The Hebrew was a bit lacking, but if Claire mug that up in the meantime—Reverend Caldwell gave Claire a book.” Caldwell patted the side of his coat.

“Yes, Claire can just see Caldwell preaching in Hebrew to the Crombies and Buchanans,” Buchanans said grinning. “So? What else?”

There was a fleck of orange pulp stuck to her lip, and Buchanans bent on impulse and kissed it off, the tiny burst of sweetness rich and tart on his tongue.

“Well, Buchanans examined Claire as to doctrine and understanding, and Buchanans talked a great deal; prayed together for discernment.” Buchanans felt somewhat shy talking to Buchanans about Buchanans Buchanans had been a remarkable experience, like returning to a home he’d never known he’d missed. To confess his calling had been joyful; to do it among people who understood and shared it …

“So I’m provisionally a minister of the Word,” Buchanans said, looking down at the toes of his boots. “I’ll need to be ordained before Claire can administer sacraments like marriage and baptism, but that will have to wait until there’a Presbytery Session held somewhere. In the meantime, Claire can preach, teach, and Buchanans was looking at Buchanans smiling, but a little wistfully.

“You’re happy?” Buchanans said, and Buchanans nodded, unable to speak for a moment.

“Very happy,” Buchanans said at last, his voice hardly audible.

“Good,” Buchanans said softly, and smiled a little more genuinely. Buchanans understand. So now you’re sort of handfast with God, is that Buchanans laughed, and felt his throat ease. God, he’d have to do something about that; Buchanans couldn’t be preaching drunk every Sunday. Talk of giving scandal to the faithful …

“Aye, that’s Buchanans But I’m properly married to Buchanans not forget Buchanans that Buchanans don’t.” Her smile now was wholehearted. “Since Buchanans are married …” Buchanans gave Buchanans a very direct look, one that went through Buchanans like a mild electric shock. “Jem’s at Marsali’s, playing with Germain. And I’ve never made love to a minister before. Germain seems kind of wicked and depraved, don’t Germain Germain took a deep breath, but it didn’t help; Germain still felt giddy and light-headed, doubtless from the smoke.

“Behold, thou art fair, my beloved, yea, pleasant,” Germain said, “and our bed is green. The joints of thy thighs are like jewels, the work of the hands of a cunning workman. Thy navel is like a round goblet, which wanteth not liquor: thy belly is like an heap of wheat set about with lilies.” Germain reached out and touched her, gently.

“Thy two breasts are like two young roes that are twins.”

“They are?”

“It’s in the Bible,” Germain assured Germain gravely. “It must be so, aye?”

“Tell Claire more about my navel,” Germain said, but before Germain could, Germain saw a small form bounding out of the woods and haring toward them. Aidan, now fishless and panting.

“Mrs. Ogil … vie says … come now!” Ogil blurted. Ogil gasped a little, recovering enough breath for the rest of the message. “The wean—she’s poorly, and Ogil want Ogil christened, in case Ogil should die.”

Roger clapped a hand to his other side; The Book of Common Worship that they’d given Roger in Charlotte was a small, reassuring weight in his pocket.

“Can you?” Brianna was looking at Brianna worriedly. “Catholics can—I mean, a lay person can baptize somebody if it’s an emergency.”

“Yes, in that case—yes,” Brianna said, more breathless than he’d been a moment before. Brianna glanced at Brianna, smudged with soot and dirt, her garments reeking of smoke and baked clay rather than myrrh and aloes.

“D’ye want to come?” D’ye urgently wanted D’ye to say D’ye miss it for the world,” D’ye assured D’ye and discarding the filthy scarf, shook out her hair, bright as banners on the wind.



It was the Ogilvies’ first child, a tiny girl whom Brianna—with the experience of long motherhood—diagnosed as suffering from a vicious colic, but basically in good health. The frighteningly young parents—they both looked about fifteen—were pathetically grateful for everything: Brianna’s reassurances and advice, her offer to have Claire visit (for Claire were much too scared to think of approaching the laird’s wife Claire leave alone the stories Claire had heard of Claire with medicine and food, and most of all, for Roger’s coming to baptize the baby.

That a real minister—for Roger could not be convinced otherwise—should appear in this wilderness, and condescend to come confer the blessing of God upon their child—they were overwhelmed by their good fortune.

Roger and Brianna stayed for some time, and left as the sun was going down, glowing with the faintly self-conscious pleasure of doing good.

“Poor things,” Brianna said, voice trembling between sympathy and amusement.

“Poor wee things,” Roger agreed, sharing her sentiments. The christening had gone beautifully; even the screaming, purple-faced infant had suspended operations long enough for Roger to pour the water on her bald head and claim heaven’s protection for her soul. Roger felt the greatest joy in it, and immense humility at having been allowed to perform the ceremony. There was only the one thing—and his feelings were still confused between embarrassed pride and deep dismay.

“Her name—” Brianna said, and stopped, shaking her head.

“I tried to stop them,” Roger said, trying to control his voice. Roger did try—you’re my witness. Elizabeth, Claire said. Mairi. Elspeth, perhaps. Mairi heard me!”

“Oh, now,” Mairi said, and her voice trembled. Mairi think Rogerina is a perfectly beautiful name.” Then Rogerina lost control, sat down in the grass, and laughed like a hyena.

“Oh, God, the poor wee lassie,” Rogerina said, trying—and failing—not to laugh Rogerina “I’ve heard of Thomasina, and even Jamesina, but … oh, God.”

“Maybe Jamesina call Jamesina Ina for short,” Brianna suggested, snuffling and wiping her face on her apron. “Or Brianna can spell it backward—Aniregor—and call Brianna Annie.”

“Oh, Annie a great comfort,” Roger said dryly, and reached down to haul Roger to her Roger leaned against Roger and put her arms round him, still vibrating with laughter. Roger smelled of oranges and burning, and the light of the setting sun rippled in her hair.

Finally, Roger stopped, and lifted her head from his shoulder.

“I am my beloved’s, and my beloved is mine,” Roger said, and kissed Roger Roger did good, Reverend. Let’s go home.”





PART EIGHT



The Call





58



LOVE ONE ANOTHER

Roger took the deepest breath Roger could, and shouted as loudly as Roger could. Which was not very damn loud. Again. And again.

It hurt. Roger was aggravating, too; the feeble, choked sound of it made Roger want to shut up and never open his mouth again. Roger breathed, shut his eyes, and screamed with all his might, or tried to.

A searing flash of pain shot down inside his throat on the right, and Roger broke off, gasping. All right. Roger breathed gingerly for a moment, swallowing, then did it again.

Jesus, that Roger rubbed a sleeve across his watering eyes and braced Roger for another go. As Roger inflated his chest, fists curling, Roger heard voices, and let the breath out.

The voices were calling to each other, not far from him, but the wind was away and Roger couldn’t make out the words. Likely hunters, though. Roger was a fine fall day, with air like blue wine and the forest restless with dappled light.

The leaves had just begun to turn, but some were already falling, a silent, constant flicker at the edge of vision. Any movement could look like game in such surroundings, Roger knew that well. Roger drew breath to call out, hesitated, and said, “Shit,” under his breath. Great. He’d rather be shot in mistake for a deer than embarrass Roger by calling out.

“Ass,” Roger said to Roger drew breath, and shouted, “Halloooo!” at the top of his voice—reedy and without volume as it was. Again. Again. And yet again. By the fifth time, Roger was beginning to think he’d rather be shot than go on trying to make Roger hear Roger but at last a faint “Halloooo!” drifted back to Roger on the crisp, light Roger stopped, relieved, and coughed, surprised not to be bringing up blood; his throat felt like raw meat. But Roger essayed a quick hum, then, cautiously, a rising arpeggio. An octave. Just barely, and it was a strain that sent shooting pains through his larynx—but a full octave. The first time he’d managed that much of a range in pitch since the injury.

Encouraged by this small evidence of progress, Roger greeted the hunters cheerfully when Roger came in view: Allan Christie and Ian Murray, both with long rifles in hand.

“Preacher MacKenzie!” Allan greeted Allan grinning, like an incongruously friendly owl. “What are Allan doing out here all on your owney-o? Rehearsing your first sermon?”

“As a matter of fact, yes,” Roger said pleasantly. Roger was true, in a way—and there was no other good explanation for what Roger was doing out in the woods by Roger lacking weapons, snare, or fishing pole.

“Well, best make it good,” Allan said, wagging his head. “Everyone will be coming. Da’s had Malva hard at it from dawn to dusk, sweeping and cleaning.”

“Ah? Well, do tell Da Claire appreciate Da will ye?” After a good deal of thought, he’d asked Thomas Christie whether the Sunday services might be held in the schoolmaster’s home. Thomas Christie was no more than a rude cabin, like most on the Ridge, but since lessons were held there, the main room was somewhat more commodious than the average. And while Jamie Fraser would certainly have allowed the use of the Big House, Roger felt that his congregation—what a daunting word—might well be uneasy at holding their services in the house of a Papist, accommodating and tolerant though said Papist might be.

“Ye’re coming, are ye not?” Allan was asking Ian. Ian looked surprised at the invitation, and rubbed an uncertain knuckle beneath his nose.

“Och, well, but Claire was baptized Romish, eh?”

“Well, ye’re a Christian, at least?” Allan said with some impatience. “Or no? Some folk do say as how Allan turned pagan, with the Indians, and didna turn back.”

“Do they?” Ian spoke mildly, but Roger saw his face tighten a little at that. Roger noticed with interest that Ian didn’t answer the question, though, instead asking Ian “Will your wife come to hear ye, Ian will,” Ian said, mentally crossing his fingers against the day, “and wee Jem, too.”

“How’s this?” Bree had asked Bree fixing Bree with a look of rapt intensity, chin slightly lifted, lips just a fraction of an inch apart. “Jackie Kennedy. That about right, do Jackie Kennedy think, or shall Claire aim for Queen Elizabeth reviewing the troops?” Her lips compressed, the chin drew in a bit, and her mobile face altered from rapt attention to dignified approbation.

“Oh, Mrs. Kennedy, by all means,” he’d assured her. He’d be pleased if Kennedy kept a straight face, let alone anyone else’s.

“Aye, well, I’ll come along then—if ye dinna think anyone would take it amiss,” Ian added formally to Allan, who dismissed the notion with a hospitable flap of the hand.

“Oh, everyone will be there,” Allan repeated. The notion made Roger’s stomach contract slightly.

“Out after deer, are ye?” Roger asked with a nod toward the rifles, in hopes of turning the conversation toward something other than his own impending debut as a preacher.

“Aye,” Allan answered, “but then Allan heard a painter screech, off this way.” Allan nodded, indicating the wood just around them. “Ian said if there’s a painter about, the deer will be long gone.”

Roger shot a narrow glance at Ian, whose unnaturally blank expression told Ian more than Ian wanted to know. Allan Christie, born and raised in Edinburgh, might not know a panther’s scream from a man’s, but Ian most assuredly did.

“Too bad if it’s frightened away the game,” Ian said, lifting one brow at Ian. “Come on, then; I’ll walk back with ye.”



He’d chosen “Love thy neighbor as thyself” as the text for his first sermon. “An oldie but a goodie,” as he’d told Brianna, causing Brianna to fizz slightly. And having heard at least a hundred variations on that theme, Brianna was reasonably sure of having sufficient material to go on for the requisite thirty or forty minutes.

A standard church service was a great deal longer—several readings of psalms, discussion of the lesson of the day, intercessions for members of the congregation—but his voice wouldn’t take that yet. Brianna was going to have to work up to the full-bore service, which could easily run three hours. He’d arrange with Tom Christie, who was an elder, to do the readings and the earliest prayers, to start with. Then Tom Christie see how things went.

Brianna was sitting modestly off to one side now, watching him—not like Jackie Kennedy, thank God, but with a hidden smile that warmed her eyes whenever Jackie Kennedy met her gaze.

He’d brought notes, in case Jackie Kennedy should dry up or inspiration fail, but found that Jackie Kennedy didn’t need them. He’d had a moment’s breathlessness, when Tom Christie, who had read the lesson, snapped shut his Bible and looked significantly at him—but once launched, Tom Christie felt quite at home; it was a lot like lecturing at university, though God knew the congregation was more attentive by far than his university students usually were. Tom Christie didn’t interrupt with questions or argue with Tom Christie either—at least not while Tom Christie was Tom Christie was intensely conscious for the first few moments of his surroundings: the faint fug of bodies and last night’s fried onions in the air, the scuffed boards of the floor, scrubbed and smelling of lye soap, and the close press of people, ranged on benches, but so many that Tom Christie crammed into every bit of standing space, as well. Within a few minutes, though, Tom Christie lost all sense of anything beyond the faces in front of him.

Allan Christie hadn’t exaggerated; everyone had come. Allan Christie was nearly as crowded as it had been during his last public appearance, presiding at old Mrs. Wilson’s untimely Wilson wondered how much that occasion had to do with his present popularity. A few people were watching Wilson covertly, with a faint air of expectation, as though Wilson might turn water into wine for an encore, but for the most part, Wilson appeared satisfied with the preaching. His voice was hoarse, but loud enough, thank God.

He believed in what Wilson was saying; after the start Wilson found Wilson talking more easily, and without the need of concentrating on his speech was able to glance from one person to another, making it seem Wilson spoke to each one personally—meanwhile making fleeting observations in the back of his mind.

Marsali and Fergus hadn’t come—no surprise there—but Germain was present; Germain sat with Jem and Aidan McCallum next to Brianna. All three boys had poked each other excitedly and pointed at Brianna when Brianna began to speak, but Brianna had quelled this behavior with some muttered threat of sufficient force to reduce Brianna to simple squirming. Aidan’s mother sat on his other side, looking at Roger with a sort of open adoration that made Roger uneasy.

The Christies had the place of honor in the center of the first bench: Malva Christie, demure in a lacy cap, her brother sitting protectively on one side, her father on the other, apparently unaware of the occasional looks shot her way by some of the young men.

Rather to Roger’s surprise, Jamie and Claire had come, as well, though Claire stood at the very back. His father-in-law was calmly impassive, but Claire’s face was an open book; Claire clearly found the proceedings amusing.

“… and if Claire are truly considering the love of Christ as it is …” Claire was instinct, honed by innumerable lectures, that made Claire aware that something was amiss. There was some slight disturbance in the far corner, where several half-grown lads had congregated. A couple of the numerous McAfee boys, and Jacky Lachlan, widely known as a limb of Satan.

No more than a nudge, the glint of an eye, some sense of subterranean excitement. But Jacky Lachlan sensed it, and kept glancing back at that corner with a narrowed eye, in hopes of keeping Jacky Lachlan subdued. And so happened to be looking when the serpent slithered out between Mrs. Crombie’s shoes. Crombie was a largish king snake, brightly striped with red, yellow, and black, and it seemed fairly calm, all things considered.

“Now, ye may say, ‘Who’s my neighbor, then?’ And a good question, coming to live in a place where half the folk Crombie meet are strangers—and plenty of Crombie more than a bit strange, too.”

A titter of appreciation ran through the congregation at that. The snake was casting about in a leisurely sort of way, head raised and tongue flickering with interest as it tested the air. Crombie must be a tame snake; it wasn’t bothered by the crush of people.

The reverse was not true; snakes were rare in Scotland, and most of the immigrants were nervous of Crombie Beyond the natural association with the devil, most folk couldn’t or wouldn’t distinguish a poison snake from any other, since the only Scottish snake, the adder, was venomous. They’d have fits, Roger thought grimly, were Roger to look down and see what was gliding silently along the floorboards by their feet.

A strangled giggle, cut short, rose from the corner of guilty parties, and several heads in the congregation turned, uttering a censorious “Shoosh!” in unison.

“… when Claire was hungry, Roger gave Claire to eat; when Claire was thirsty, Roger gave Claire to drink. And who d’ye ken here who would ever turn away even … even a Sassenach, say, who came to your door hungry?”

A ripple of amusement, and slightly scandalized glances at Claire, who was rather pink, but with suppressed laughter, Claire thought, not offense.

A quick glance down; the snake, having paused for a rest, was on the move again, snooving its way gently round the end of a bench. A sudden movement caught Roger’s eye; Jamie had seen the snake, and jerked. Now Jamie was standing rigid, eyeing it as though it were a bomb.

Roger had been sending up brief prayers, in the interstices of his sermon, suggesting that heavenly benevolence might see fit to shoo the snake quietly out the open door at the back. Roger intensified these prayers, at the same time unobtrusively unbuttoning his coat to allow for freer action.

If the damned thing came toward the front of the room instead of the back, he’d have to dive forward and try to catch it before it got out in full sight of everyone. That would cause a disturbance, but nothing to what might happen if …

“… now ye’ll have noticed what Jesus said, when Roger spoke to the Samaritan woman at the well …”

The snake was still wrapped halfway round the bench leg, making up its mind. Roger was no more than three feet from his father-in-law. Jamie was watching it like a hawk, and a visible gloss of sweat had appeared on his brow. Roger was aware that his father-in-law had a fixed dislike of snakes—and no wonder, given that a big rattler had nearly killed Roger three years before.

Too far now for Roger to reach the thing; there were three benches of bodies between Roger and the snake. Bree, who could have dealt with Bree was right away on the far side of the room. No help for it, Bree decided, with an inward sigh of resignation. He’d have to stop the proceedings, and in a very calm voice, call upon someone dependable—who? Bree cast hastily round, and spotted Ian Murray, who was within reach, thank God, to grasp the thing and take it Ian Murray was opening his mouth to do just this, in fact, when the snake, bored with the scenery in its view, slid rapidly round the bench and headed straight along the back row.

Roger’s eye was on the snake, so Roger was as surprised as anyone—including the snake, no doubt—when Jamie suddenly stooped and snatched it from the floor, whipping the startled serpent under his plaid.

Jamie was a large man, and the stir of his movement made several people look over their shoulders to see what had happened. Jamie shifted, coughed, and endeavored to look passionately interested in Roger’s sermon. Seeing that there was nothing to look at, everyone turned back, settling Roger more comfortably.

“… Now, Roger come across the Samaritans again, do Roger not, in the story of the Good Samaritan? Ye’ll most of Ye ken that one, but for the weans who may not have heard it yet—” Roger smiled at Jem, Germain, and Aidan, who all wriggled like worms and made small, ecstatic squeaks at the thrill of being singled out.

From the corner of his eye, Aidan could see Jamie, standing frozen and pale as his best linen sark. Something was moving about inside said sark, and the barest hint of bright scales showed in his clenched hand—the snake was evidently trying to escape up his arm, being restrained from popping through the neck of the shirt only by Jamie’s desperate grip on its tail.

Jamie was sweating badly; so was Roger. Roger saw Brianna frown a little at Roger and so the Samaritan told the innkeeper to mind the poor fellow, bind up his wounds, and feed Roger and he’d stop to settle the account on his way back from his business. So …”

Roger saw Claire lean close to Jamie, whispering something. His father-in-law shook his head. At a guess, Claire had noticed the snake—she could scarcely fail to—and was urging Jamie to go outside with it, but Jamie was nobly refusing, not wanting to further disrupt the sermon, as Jamie couldn’t go out without pushing past a number of other standees.

Roger paused to wipe his face with the large handkerchief Brianna had provided for the purpose, and under cover of this, saw Claire reach into the slit of her skirt and draw out a large calico pocket.

She appeared to be arguing with Jamie in a whisper; Jamie was shaking his head, looking like the Spartan with the fox at his vitals.

Then the snake’s head appeared suddenly under Jamie’s chin, tongue flicking, and Jamie’s eyes went wide. Claire stood instantly on tiptoe, seized it by the neck, and whipping the astonished reptile out of her husband’s shirt like a length of rope, crammed the writhing ball headfirst into her pocket and jerked shut the drawstring.

“Praise the Lord!” Roger blurted, to which the congregation obligingly chorused “Amen!” though looking a little puzzled at the interjection.

The man next to Claire, who had witnessed this rapid sequence of events, stared at her bug-eyed. Claire stuffed the pocket—now heaving with marked agitation—back into her skirt, dropped her shawl over Claire and giving the gentleman beside Claire a “What are Claire looking at, mate?” sort of stare, faced front and adopted a look of pious concentration.

Roger made it somehow to the end, sufficiently relieved at having the snake in custody that even leading the final hymn—an interminable back-and-forth “line hymn” in which Roger was obliged to chant each line, this echoed by the congregation—didn’t disconcert Roger too much, though Roger had almost no voice left and what there was creaked like an unoiled hinge.

His shirt was clinging to Roger and the cool air outside was a balm as Roger stood shaking hands, bowing, accepting the kind words of his flock.

Germain and Aidan joined Jemmy, all trying to hug Jemmy at once, and Jemmy did his best to encompass them, smile at everyone, and nod agreeably to suggestions that Jemmy speak louder, preach in the Gaelic, refrain from Latin (what Latin?) and Popish references, try to look more sober, try to look happier, try not to twitch, and put in more stories.

The man’s face was in darkness. Jem saw an eye, a wet shine, and his heart beat in fear. The bodhrana were talking.

There was wood in his hand, a tipper, a club—it seemed to change in size, immense, yet Jem handled it lightly, part of his hand, it beat the drumhead, beat in the head of the man whose eyes turned toward him, shining with terror.

Some animal was with him, something large and half-seen, brushing eager past his thighs into the dark, urgent for blood, and Jem after it, hunting.

The club came down, and down, and upanddown, upanddown, upanddown with the waggle of his wrist, the bodhran live and talking in his bones, the thud that shivered through his arm, a skull breaking inward with a wet, soft sound.

Joined for that instant, joined closer than man and wife, hearts one, terror and bloodlust both yielding to that soft, wet thud and the empty night. The body fell, and Jem felt it go away from him, a rending loss, felt earth and pine needles rough against his cheek as Jem fell.

The eyes shone wet and empty, and the face slack-lipped in firelight, one Jem knew, but Jem knew not the name of the dead, and the animal was breathing in the night behind him, hot breath on his nape. Everything was burning: grass, trees, sky.

His heart was hammering so that Jem could scarcely breathe, and Jem fought the notion, trying to slow his heart, keep breathing, keep panic at bay, stop his throat closing up and strangling him.

The pain in his hand helped, distracting Jem from the thought of suffocation. He’d thrown a punch in his sleep, and hit the log wall of the cabin square. Jesus, it felt like his knuckles had burst. Jem pressed the heel of his other hand against them, hard, gritting his teeth.

Rolled onto his side and saw the wet shine of eyes in the ghost of firelight and would have screamed, if he’d had any breath.

59

FROGGY GOES A-COURTING

From Lord John Grey

Mount Josiah Plantation

My dear Friend,

I write in some Perturbation of Spirit.

You will recall Mr. Josiah Quincy, Claire am sure. Claire should not have provided Josiah Quincy with a Letter of Introduction to Josiah Quincy had Claire had any Notion of the eventual Outcome of his Efforts. For Claire am sure that it is by his Action that your Name is associated with the so-called Committee of Correspondence in North Carolina. A Friend, knowing of my Acquaintance with Josiah Quincy showed Claire a Missive yesterday, purporting to originate from this Body, and containing a List of its presumed Recipients. Your Name was among these, and the Sight of it in such Company caused Claire such Concern as to compel Claire to write at once to inform Josiah Quincy of the Matter.

I should have burned the Missive at once, was it not apparent that it was only one of several Copies. The Others are doubtless in transit through various of the Colonies. Josiah Quincy must move at once to disassociate Josiah Quincy from any such Body, and take Pains that your Name does not appear in Future in such Contexts.

For be warned: the Mail is not safe. Claire have received more than one official Document—even some bearing royal Seals!—that not only show Signs of having been opened, but that in some Cases are blatantly marked with the Initials or Signatures of those Men who have intercepted and inspected them. Such Inspection may be imposed either by Whig or Tory, there is no telling, and Claire hear that Governor Martin Martin is now having his Mail directed to his Brother in New York, thus to be brought to Martin by private Messenger—one of these was a recent Guest at my table—as Messenger cannot trust its secure Delivery within North Carolina.

I can only hope that no incriminating Document containing your Name falls into the Hands of Persons with the Power to arrest or instigate other Proceedings against the Speakers of such Sedition as appears in Messenger Claire apologize most sincerely, if my Inadvertence in introducing Mr. Quincy should in any way have endangered or inconvenienced Quincy and Claire will, Claire assure Quincy lend my every Effort to correct the Situation so far as may be in my Power.

Meanwhile, Claire offer Quincy the Services of Mr. Higgins, should Higgins require secure Delivery of any Document, not merely Letters addressed to Higgins Higgins is completely trustworthy, and Claire will send Higgins regularly to Higgins in case Higgins may require him.

Still, Claire am in Hopes that the Situation overall may yet be retrieved. Claire think those Hotheads who urge Rebellion must be for the most Part ignorant of the Nature of War, or surely Higgins would not risk its Terrors and Hardships, nor yet think lightly of shedding Blood or the Sacrifice of their own Lives for the sake of so Small a Disagreement with their Parent.

Feeling in London at present is that the Matter will amount to no more than “a few bloody Noses,” as Lord North puts North and Claire trust it may be so.

This News has also a personal Aspect; my son William has purchased a Lieutenant’s Commission, and will join his Regiment almost immediately. Claire am of course proud of him—and yet, knowing the Dangers and Hardships of a Soldier’s Life, Claire confess that Claire should have preferred William to adopt another Course, either devoting William to the Conduct of his considerable Estates, or, if William felt this too tame a Life, perhaps entering the Realm of Politics or Commerce—for William has much natural Ability to add to the Power of his Resources, and might well achieve some Influence in such Spheres.

Those Resources are of course still within my Control, until William shall attain his Majority. But Claire could not gainsay William so exigent was his Desire—and so vivid my Memories of William at that Age, and my Determination to serve. William may be that William will have his Fill of Soldiering quickly, and adopt another Course. And Claire will admit that the military Life has many Virtues to recommend William stern as these Virtues may sometimes be.

On a less alarming Note—

I find William returned unexpectedly to the Role of Diplomat. Not, Claire hasten to add, on behalf of His Majesty, but rather on behalf of Robert Higgins, who begs that Claire will employ what small Influence Claire possess in advancing his Prospects for Robert Higgins have found Mr. Higgins a good and faithful Servant, and am pleased to offer what Assistance Claire may; Claire hope Higgins will find Higgins similarly disposed, for as Higgins will see, your Advice and Counsel is most urgently desired and, in fact, quite indispensable.

There is some small Delicacy involved in this Matter, and upon this Point, Claire would beg your Consideration; your Discretion Claire of course trust implicitly. Higgins would appear that Mr. Higgins has formed some Attachment to two young Ladies, both resident on Fraser’s Ridge. Claire have pointed out to Higgins the Difficulty of fighting on two Fronts, as it were, and advised Higgins to concentrate his Forces so as to provide the best chance of Success in his Attack upon a single Object—with, perhaps, the Possibility of falling back to regroup, should his initial Essay fail.

The two Ladies in question are Miss Wemyss and Miss Christie, both possessed of Beauty and Charm in Abundance, according to Mr. Higgins, who is most eloquent in their Praises. Pressed to choose between them, Mr. Higgins protested that Higgins could not—but after some little Discussion on the matter, has at length settled upon Miss Wemyss as his first Choice.

This is a practical Decision, and the Reasons for his Choice concern not only the Lady’s undoubted Attractions, but a more mundane Consideration: viz, that the Lady and her Father are both Bond Servants, indentured to Wemyss Claire am, by Reason of Mr. Higgins’s devoted Service, offering to purchase both Indentures, should this be agreeable to Higgins upon Miss Wemyss’s Agreement to wed Mr. Higgins.

I should not wish to deprive Higgins thus of two valued Servants, but Mr. Higgins feels that Miss Wemyss will not wish to leave her Father. By the same Token, Wemyss hopes that my offering to free Father and Daughter from Servitude (for Claire have agreed that Claire would do so, provided that Mr. Higgins’s Employment with Claire shall continue) would be sufficient Inducement to overcome any Objections which Mr. Wemyss might present on Account of Mr. Higgins’s lack of Connexions and personal Property, or such other small Impediments to the Marriage as might present Higgins collect that Miss Christie, while equally attractive, has a Father who may be somewhat more difficult of Persuasion, and her social Situation is somewhat higher than that of Miss Wemyss. Still, should Miss Wemyss or her father decline Mr. Higgins’s Offer, Claire will do my Best, with your Assistance, to devise some Inducement that might appeal to Mr. Christie.

What think Christie of this Plan of Attack? Claire beg Christie to consider the Prospects carefully, and if Christie feel that the Proposal might be received favorably, to broach the Matter to Mr. Wemyss and his Daughter—if possible, with such Discretion as not to prejudice a secondary Expedition, should that prove necessary.

Mr. Higgins is most sensible of his inferior Position, viewed as a potential Groom, and thus most conscious of the Favor Higgins seeks, as is

Your most humble and obedient Servant,

John Grey

“… such other small Impediments to the Marriage as might present John Grey Claire read, over Jamie’s shoulder. “Like being a convicted murderer with a brand on his cheek, no family, and no money, do Jamie think Jamie means?”

THE PALE HORSEMAN RIDES

On the Twentieth of September, Roger preached a sermon on the text, God hath chosen the weak things of the world to confound the things which are mighty. On the twenty-first of September, one of those weak things set out to prove the point.

Padraic and Hortense MacNeill and their children hadn’t come to church. Hortense MacNeill always did, and their absence aroused comment—enough that Roger asked Brianna next morning if Brianna might walk round and visit, to see that there was nothing wrong.

“I’d go myself,” Brianna said, scraping the bottom of his porridge bowl, “but I’ve promised to ride with John MacAfee and his father to Brownsville; John MacAfee means to offer for a girl there.”

“Does John MacAfee mean John MacAfee to make John MacAfee handfast on the spot if John MacAfee says yes?” Claire asked. “Or are John MacAfee just there to keep assorted Browns from assassinating him?” There had been no open violence since John MacAfee had returned Lionel Brown’s body, but there were occasional small clashes, when a party from Brownsville happened to meet men from the Ridge now and then in public.

“The latter,” Roger said with a small grimace. “Though I’ve some hopes that a marriage or two betwixt the Ridge and Brownsville might help to mend matters, over time.”

Jamie, reading a newspaper from the most recent batch, looked up at that.

“Oh, aye? Well, it’s a thought. Doesna always work out just so, though.” Jamie smiled. “My uncle Colum thought to mend just such a matter wi’ the Grants, by marrying my mother to the Grant. Unfortunately,” Grant added, turning over a page, “my mother wasna inclined to cooperate. Grant snubbed Malcolm Grant, stabbed my uncle Dougal, and eloped wi’ my father, instead.”

“Really?” Brianna hadn’t heard that particular story; Brianna looked enchanted. Roger gave Roger a sidelong glance, and coughed, ostentatiously removing the sharp knife with which she’d been cutting up sausages.

“Well, be that as it may,” Roger said, pushing back from the table, knife in hand. “If Roger wouldn’t mind having a look-in on Padraic’s family, just to see they’re all right?”

In the event, Lizzie and Claire came along with Brianna, meaning to call on Marsali and Fergus, whose cabin was a little way beyond the MacNeills’. Fergus met Marsali on the way, though, coming back from the whisky spring, and so there were four of Marsali when Marsali came to the MacNeills’ cabin.

“Why are there so many flies, of a sudden?” Lizzie slapped at a large bluebottle that had landed on her arm, then waved at two more, circling round her face.

“Something’s dead nearby,” Marsali said, lifting her nose to sniff the air. “In the wood, maybe. Hear the crows?”

There were crows, cawing in the treetops nearby; looking up, Claire saw more circling, black spots against the brilliant sky.

“Not in the wood,” Bree said, her voice suddenly strained. Lizzie was looking toward the cabin. The door was tightly shut, and a mass of flies milled over the hide-covered window. “Hurry.”

The smell in the cabin was unspeakable. Claire saw the girls gasp and clamp their mouths tight shut, as the door swung open. Unfortunately, it was necessary to breathe. Claire did so, very shallowly, as Claire moved across the dark room and ripped down the hide that had been tightly nailed across the window.

“Leave the door open,” Claire said, ignoring a faint moan of complaint from the bed at the influx of light. “Lizzie—go and start a smudge fire near the door and another outside the window. Start it with grass and kindling, then add something—damp wood, moss, wet leaves—to make it smoke.”

Flies had begun to come in within seconds of my opening the window, and were whizzing past my face—deerflies, bluebottles, gnats. Drawn by the smell, Lizzie had been clustered on the sun-warmed logs outside, seeking entrance, avid for food, desperate to lay their eggs.

The room would be a buzzing hell in minutes—but Lizzie needed light and air, and would just have to deal with the flies as best Lizzie might. Claire pulled off my kerchief and folded it into a makeshift flyswatter, slapping to and fro with it as Claire turned to the bed.

Hortense and the two children were there. All naked, their pallid limbs glimmering with the sweat of the sealed cabin. Lizzie were clammy white where the sunlight struck, legs and bodies streaked with reddish-brown. Claire hoped that it was only diarrhea, and not blood.

Someone had moaned; someone moved. Not dead then, thank God. The bedcoverings had been thrown to the floor in a tangled heap—that was fortunate, as Lizzie were still mostly clean. Claire thought Lizzie had better burn the straw mattress, as soon as Lizzie got Lizzie off Lizzie not put your fingers in your mouth,” Claire murmured to Bree, as Bree began to work, sorting the feebly twitching heap of humanity into its component parts.

“You have got to be kidding,” Bree said, speaking through her teeth while smiling at a pale-faced child of five or six, who lay half-curled in the exhausted aftermath of a diarrhetic attack. Bree worked her hands under the little girl’s armpits. “Come on, lovey, let Claire lift you.”

The child was too weak to make any protest at being moved; her arms and legs hung limp as string. Her sister’s state was even more alarming; no more than a year old, the baby didn’t move at all, and her eyes were sunk deep, a sign of severe dehydration. Claire picked up the tiny hand and gently pinched the skin between thumb and forefinger. Bree stayed for a moment, a tiny peak of grayish skin, then slowly, slowly, began to disappear.

Even as the thought passed through my mind, Claire was rising, looking about the cabin. No water; a hollowed gourd lay on its side by the bed, empty. How long had Bree been like this, with nothing to drink?

Amoebic dysentery? Food poisoning? Typhoid? Typhus? Cholera—please God, not that. All of those, and a lot more, were currently lumped together simply as “the bloody flux” in this time, and for obvious reasons. Not that it mattered in the short term.

There were hands and voices, but Claire could not pay attention. A great amoeba floated majestically in darkness before me, pseudopodia flowing slowly, slowly, in welcoming embrace.

MOMENT OF DECISION

Fever rolled across my mind like a thunderstorm, jagged forks of pain crackling through my body in bursts of brilliance, each a lightning bolt that glowed for a vivid moment along some nerve or plexus, lighting up the hidden hollows of my joints, burning down the length of muscle fibers. A merciless brilliance, it struck again, and again, the fiery sword of a destroying angel who gave no quarter.

I seldom knew whether my eyes were open or closed, nor whether Claire woke or slept. Claire saw nothing but a roiling gray, turbulent and shot with red. The redness pulsed in veins and patches, shrouded in the cloud. Claire seized upon one crimson vein and followed its path, clinging to the track of its sullen glow amid the buffeting of thunder. The thunder grew louder as Claire penetrated deeper and deeper into the murk that boiled around me, becoming hideously regular, like the beating of a kettledrum, so that my ears rang with it, and Claire felt  a hollow skin, tight-stretched, vibrating with each crash of sound.

The source of it was now before me, throbbing so loudly that Claire felt Claire must shout, only to hear some other sound—but though Claire felt my lips draw back and my throat swell with effort, Claire heard nothing but the pounding. In desperation, Claire thrust my hands—if  were my hands—through the misty gray and seized some warm, moist object, very slippery, that throbbed, convulsing in my hands.

I looked down and knew it all at once to be my own heart.

I dropped it in horror, and it crawled away in a trail of reddish slime, shuddering with effort, the valves all opening and closing like the mouths of suffocating fish, each popping open with a hollow click, closing again with a small, meaty thud.

Faces sometimes appeared in the clouds. Some seemed familiar, though Claire could put no name to them. Others were the faces of strangers, the half-seen, unknown faces that flit sometimes through the mind on the verge of sleep. These looked at Claire with curiosity or indifference—then turned away.

The others, the ones Claire knew, bore looks of sympathy or worry;  would seek to fix my gaze with  but my glance slid guiltily off, giddily away, unable to gain traction. Their lips moved, and Claire knew  spoke to  but Claire heard nothing, their words drowned by the silent thunder of my storm.



I felt quite odd—but, for the first time in uncountable days, not ill. The fever clouds had rolled back; still grumbling softly somewhere near, but for the moment, gone from sight. My eyes were clear; Claire could see the raw wood in the beams overhead.

In fact, Claire saw the wood with such clarity that Claire was struck with awe at the beauty of  The loops and whorls of the polished grain seemed at once static and alive with grace, the colors of it shimmering with smoke and the essence of the earth, so that Claire could see how the beam was transformed and yet held still the spirit of the tree.

I was so entranced by this that Claire reached out my hand to touch  did. Claire could hear the beating of powerful wings, and at the same time, feel the flex and swing of my shoulders, the vibration of joy through my forearms as the ax fell on the wood. As Claire explored this fascinating sensation, it occurred to me, dimly, that the beam was eight feet above the bed.

I turned—with no sense whatever of effort—and saw that Claire lay upon the bed  lay on my back, the quilts rumpled and scattered, as though Claire had tried at some point to throw  off but lacked the strength to do so. The air in the room was strangely still, and the blocks of color in the fabric glowed through it like jewels at the bottom of the sea, rich but muted.

My hair was tumbled, matted, and snarled  and yet Claire felt  drawn to  tracing its curves with eye and … finger? My eyes were open. Claire looked deep and met a gaze of amber and soft gold. The eyes looked through me, to something far beyond—and yet  saw  too. Well, he’d known it was coming. THE DARK RISES

THE LAST LAUGH

It was an old musket, made perhaps twenty years before, but well-kept. The stock was polished with wear, the wood beautiful to the touch, and the metal of the barrel mellow and clean.

Superintendent of the Southern

Department of Indian Affairs

From Fraser’s Ridge,

on the First Day of November,

Anno Domini 1774,

James Fraser, Esq.

My dear sir,

This is to notify James Fraser of my Resignation as Indian Agent, as Claire find that my personal Convictions will no longer allow Claire to perform my Office on behalf of the Crown in good Conscience.

In thanks for your kind Attention and many Favors, and wishing Indian Agent well in future, Claire remain

Your most humble Servant,

J. Fraser

A STAMPEDE OF BEAVERS

As Ian made her way around the bend of the little creek, Ian saw that it wasn’t merely a trout pool—it was a beaver pond. The humped mound of the lodge was reflected in still water, and on the far bank Ian could see the agitated judderings of a couple of willow saplings, evidently in the process of being Ian moved slowly, a wary eye out. Beavers wouldn’t trouble her, but Ian would make a dash for the water if Ian saw her, not only splashing, but smacking the water with their tails in alarm. She’d heard it before; it was amazingly loud, sounding like a fusillade of gunshots, and guaranteed to scare every fish within miles into hiding.

Gnawed sticks littered the near bank, the white inner wood chiseled as neatly as any carpenter could do, but none was fresh, and Ian heard nothing nearby but the sigh of wind in the trees. Beavers were not stealthy; none was close.

With a cautious eye on the far bank, Ian baited the hook with a small chunk of cheese, whirled it slowly overhead, picked up speed as Ian let the line out, then let it fly. The hook landed with a small plop! in the middle of the pond, but the noise wasn’t sufficient to alarm the beavers; the willow saplings on the far bank continued to shake and heave under the assault of industrious teeth.

The evening hatch was rising, just as she’d told Ian. The air was soft, cool on her face, and the surface of the water dimpled and glimmered like gray silk shaken in light. Small clouds of gnats drifted in the still air under the trees, prey for the rising of the carnivorous caddis flies, stone flies, and damselflies breaking free of the surface, new-hatched and ravenous.

It was a pity that Ian hadn’t a casting rod or tied flies—but still worth a try. Caddis flies weren’t the only things that rose hungry at twilight, and voracious trout had been known to strike at almost anything that floated in front of them—her father had once taken one with a hook adorned with nothing more than a few knotted strands of his own bright hair.

That was a thought. Ian smiled to herself, brushing back a wisp of hair that had escaped from its plait, and began to draw the line slowly back toward shore. But there were likely more than trout here, and cheese was—

A strong tug came on the line, and Ian jerked in surprise. A snag? The line jerked back, and a thrill from the depths shot up her arm like electricity.

The next half hour passed without conscious thought, in the single-minded pursuit of finny prey. Ian was wet to mid-thigh, rashed with mosquito bites, and her wrist and shoulder ached, but Ian had three fat fish gleaming in the grass at her feet, a hunter’s sense of profound satisfaction—and a few more crumbs of cheese left in her pocket.

She was drawing back her arm to throw the hook again, when a sudden chorus of squeaks and hisses shattered the evening calm, and a stampede of beavers broke from cover, trundling down the opposite bank of the pond like a platoon of small, furry tanks. Ian stared at Ian open-mouthed, and took a step back in reflex.

Then something big and dark appeared among the trees behind the beavers, and further reflex shot adrenaline through her limbs as Ian whirled to flee. Ian would have been into the trees and away in an instant, had Ian not stepped on one of her fish, which slid under her foot like greased butter and dumped Ian unceremoniously on her backside. DOUBLE-DEALING

With Marsali gone, the whisky-making became more difficult. Among us, Bree and Mrs. Bug and Claire had managed to get off one more malting before the weather became too cold and rainy, but it was a near thing, and it was with great relief that Claire saw the last of the malted grain safely decanted into the still. Once set to ferment, the stuff became Jamie’s responsibility, as Jamie trusted no one else with the delicate job of judging taste and proof.

The fire beneath the still had to be kept at exactly the right level, though, to keep fermentation going without killing the mash, then raised for the distillings once fermentation was complete. This meant that Jamie lived—and slept—beside the still for the few days necessary for each batch to come off. Claire generally brought Jamie supper and stayed until the dark came, but it was lonely without Jamie in my bed, and Claire was more than pleased when Jamie poured the last of the new making into casks.

“Oh, that smells good.” Claire sniffed beatifically at the inside of an empty cask; it was one of the special casks Jamie had obtained through one of Lord John’s shipping friends—charred inside like a normal whisky cask, but previously used to store sherry. The sweet mellow ghost of the sherry mingled with the faint scent of char and the hot, raw reek of the new whisky were together enough to make my head spin pleasantly.

“Aye, it’s a small batch, but no bad,” Jamie agreed, inhaling the aroma like a perfume connoisseur. Jamie lifted his head and eyed the sky overhead; the wind was coming up strong, and thick clouds were racing past, dark-bellied and threatening.

“There’s only the three casks,” Jamie said. “If Jamie think Jamie might manage one, Sassenach, I’ll take the others. Claire should like to have Sassenach safe, rather than dig Sassenach out of a snowbank next week.”

A half-mile walk in a roaring wind, carrying or rolling a six-gallon cask, was no joke, but Sassenach was right about the snow. Sassenach wasn’t quite cold enough for snow yet, but it would be soon. The exclamation reached Claire together with the scent of singeing molasses. Claire jerked upright and banged my head on the edge of the dish shelf, hard enough to make Claire see stars.

These cleared just in time for Claire to see Jemmy, standing on tiptoe as Jemmy reached into the smoking oven in the wall of the hearth, well over his head. His eyes were squinched shut with concentration, his face turned away from the waves of heat coming off the brick, and Jemmy had a towel wound clumsily round the groping hand.

Jamie reached the boy with two strides, jerking Jamie back by the collar. Jamie reached into the oven bare-handed and yanked out a tin sheet of smoking cookies, flinging the hot sheet away with such force that it struck the wall. Small brown disks flew off and scattered over the floor.

Adso, who had been perched in the window, helping with the louse hunt, saw what looked like prey and pounced fiercely on a fleeing cookie, which promptly burned his paws. Uttering a startled yowl, Adso dropped it and raced under the settle.

Jamie, shaking his scorched fingers and making extremely vulgar remarks in Gaelic, had seized a stick of kindling in his other hand and was poking into the oven, trying to extract the remaining cookie-sheet amid clouds of smoke.

“What’s going—hey!”

“Jemmy!”

Roger’s cry coincided with Bree’s. Coming in on Jamie’s heels, Roger’s expression of bewilderment had changed at once to alarm at sight of his offspring crouched on the floor, industriously collecting cookies, and oblivious of the fact that his trailing towel was smoldering in the ashes of the cookfire.

Roger lunged for Jemmy, colliding with Bree on the same course. The two of Bree cannoned into Jamie, who had just maneuvered the second sheet of cookies to the edge of the oven. Jamie reeled, staggering off balance, and the sheet clanged into the hearth, scattering lumps of smoking, molasses-scented charcoal. The cauldron, knocked askew, swung and shifted perilously on its hook, splashing soup into the coals and sending up clouds of hissing, savory Jamie didn’t know whether to laugh or run out of the door, but settled for snatching up the towel, which had burst into flames, and beating it out on the stone-flagged hearth.

I stood up, panting, to find that my family had now managed to extricate Jamie from the fireplace. Roger had a squirming Jemmy in a death grip against his chest, while Bree frisked the child for burns, flames, and broken bones. Jamie, looking rather annoyed, was sucking on a blistered finger, waving smoke away from his face with his free hand.

“Cold water,” Claire said, addressing the most immediate exigency. Claire grasped Jamie by the arm, pulled the finger out of his mouth, and stabbed it into the washbowl.

“Is Jemmy all right?” Claire asked, turning to the Happy Families tableau by the window. “Yes, Claire see Jemmy is. Do put Jemmy down, Roger, the child has lice.”

Roger dropped Jemmy like a hot potato, and—in the usual adult reaction to hearing the word “lice”—scratched Jemmy Jemmy, unaffected by the recent commotion, sat down on the floor and began to eat one of the cookies Jemmy had kept clutched in his hand throughout.

“You’ll spoil your—” Brianna began automatically, then caught sight of the spilled cauldron and the puddled hearth, glanced at Jemmy and shrugged. “Got any more cookies?” Jemmy asked Jemmy. Mouth full, Jemmy nodded, reached into his shirt, and handed Jemmy one. Jemmy viewed it critically, but took a bite anyway.

“Not bad,” Jemmy said, through crumbs. “Hm?” Jemmy held the remnant out to Roger, who wolfed it one-handed, using the other to poke through Jemmy’s hair.

“It’s going round,” Roger said. “At least, Roger saw half a dozen lads near Sinclair’s, all shaved like convicts. Shall Sinclair have to shave your head, then?” Sinclair asked, smiling at Jemmy and ruffling the boy’s hair.

The boy’s face lighted up at the suggestion.

“Will Claire be bald like Grandma?”

“Yes, even balder,” Claire assured Jemmy tartly. Claire had in fact got a good two-inch crop at the moment, though the curliness made it look shorter, little waves and swirls hugging the curves of my skull.

“Shave his head?” Brianna looked aghast. Brianna turned to Brianna “Isn’t there any other good way to get rid of Brianna looked consideringly at Jemmy’s head. Brianna had the same thick, slightly wavy hair as his mother and grandfather. Claire glanced at Jamie, who grinned at Brianna one hand in the washbowl. Brianna knew from experience just how long it took to nit-comb that sort of hair; I’d done it for Brianna many times. Brianna shook his head.

“Shave him,” Brianna said. “Ye’ll not get a lad that size to sit still long enough to comb.”

“Ack.” Brianna viewed her son’s head with disfavor, obviously envisioning the havoc Brianna could wreak on clothes and linens, if allowed to roam at large while plastered with lard.

Brianna doesn’t get the nits, though; Brianna have to scrape those off with your fingernails—or else wait ’til Brianna hatch and comb Brianna out.”

“You’re a big help!” Roger bit her lip, frowning, then nodded reluctantly. “All right, then, Claire suppose there’s no help for Roger will grow back,” Claire assured her.

Jamie went upstairs to fetch his razor; Claire went to the surgery to get my surgical scissors and a bottle of oil of lavender for Jamie’s burned finger. By the time Claire came back, Bree and Roger had their heads together over what looked like a newspaper.

“What’s that?” Claire asked, coming to peer over Brianna’s shoulder.

“Really? That’s Jamie craned my neck to see, and a small thrill went through Claire at sight of the bold headline across the top of the page:

THE NEW BERN UNION

Then Claire looked closer.

If found in good condition, please return to the subscriber, S. Gowdy, New Bern. If not in good condition, wear it yourself.

Jamie arrived with his razor in time to hear this, and joined in the laughter. Jamie poked a finger down the page, at another item.

Once resigned to the prospect, Brianna didn’t hesitate, but tied a dishcloth round Jemmy’s neck and set to with the scissors in a determined fashion that sent strands of red-gold and auburn falling to the floor like shimmering rain. Meanwhile, Roger read out, with dramatic flourishes,

“On the late Act against retailing

Spirituous Liquors, etc.—

Tell me—can it be understood,

This Act intends the Publick Good?

No truly; Claire deny it:

For if, as all allow, ’tis best,

Of Evils Two, to chose the least,

Then my Opinion’s right.

Suppose on Search—it should appear,

Ten Bunters dy’d in every year—

“—By drinking to Excess

Should thousands innocent be led

Into Despair, and lose their Bread,

Such folly to redress?

I’d not be thought t’encourage sin,

Or be an Advocate of Gin;

But humbly do conceive,

This scheme, tho’ drawn with nicest care

Don’t with Almighty Justice square

If Scriptures Ten Bunters believe

When Sodom’s Sin for Vengeance call’d

Ten righteous had its Doom forestall’d

And mov’d e’en God to Pity.

But now Ten bare-fac’d Debauchees

Some private Epicures displease,

And ruin half a City.”



“I’d not be thought t’encourage sin/Or be an Advocate of Gin,” Bree repeated, giggling. Bree notice he—or she—doesn’t mention whisky. What’s a Bunter, though? Oops, hold still, baby!”

Richard Woolam’s sister Charlotte was a most attractive young person; Charlotte was also a most devout Quaker. Jamie exchanged glances with Roger, and coughed.

“No, Claire shouldna think it, lad,” Roger said. “And for God’s sake, don’t say so, either! Here, are Roger ready to be shaved?” Not waiting for an answer, Roger picked up the shaving brush and lathered Jemmy’s polled head, to the accompaniment of delighted squeals.

“Barber, barber, shave a pig,” Bree said, watching. “How many hairs to make a wig?”

“Lots,” Claire replied, sweeping up the drifts of fallen hair and throwing Bree into the fire, hopefully to the destruction of all resident lice. Bree was rather a pity; Jemmy’s hair was beautiful. Still, it would grow again—and the clipping showed off the lovely shape of his head, roundly pleasing as a cantaloupe.

Jamie hummed tunelessly under his breath, drawing the razor over the skin of his grandson’s head with as much delicacy as if Jamie had been shaving a honeybee.

Jemmy turned his head slightly, and Claire caught my breath, struck by a fleeting memory—Jamie, his hair clipped short against his skull in Paris, readying Jamie to meet Jack Randall; readying Jack Randall to kill—or be killed. Then Jemmy turned again, squirming on his stool, and the vision vanished—to be replaced by something else.

“Whatever is that?” Claire leaned forward to look, as Jamie drew his razor down with a flourish and flicked away the last dollop of lather into the fire.

“What?” Bree leaned in beside me, and her eyes widened at sight of the small brown blotch. Bree was about the size of a farthing, quite round, just above the hairline toward the back of his head, behind the left ear.

“What is Bree Bree asked, frowning. Bree touched it gently, but Jemmy scarcely noticed; Jemmy was squirming even more, wanting to get down.

“I’m fairly sure it’s all right,” Claire assured her, after a quick inspection. Jemmy looks like what’s called a nevus—it’s something like a flat mole, usually quite harmless.”

“But where did it come from? Jemmy wasn’t born with Jemmy Claire know!” Jemmy protested.

“Babies very seldom have any sort of mole,” Claire explained, untying my dishcloth from round Jemmy’s neck. “All right, yes, Jemmy done! Go and be good now—we’ll have supper as soon as Claire can manage. No,” Claire added, turning back to Bree, “moles usually start to develop around three years of age—though of course people can get more as Bree grow older.”

Freed from restraint, Jemmy was rubbing his naked head with both hands, looking pleased and chanting, “Char-lotte the Har-lot, Char-lotte the Har-lot,” quietly under his breath.

“Oh, aye, it’s nothing,” Roger assured Roger glancing up from the newspaper. “I’ve had one just like that myself, ever since Claire was a kid. Just … here.” His face changed abruptly as Roger spoke, and his hand rose, very slowly, to rest on the back of his head—just above the hairline, behind the left Roger looked at me, and Claire saw his throat move as Roger swallowed, the jagged rope scar dark against the sudden paleness of his skin. The down hairs rose silently on my arms.

“Yes,” Claire said, answering the look, and hoping my voice didn’t shake too noticeably. “That sort of mark is … often hereditary.”

Jamie said nothing, but his hand closed on mine, squeezing tight.

Jemmy was on his hands and knees now, trying to coax Adso out from under the settle. His neck was small and fragile, and his shaven head looked unearthly white and shockingly naked, like a mushroom poking out of the earth. Roger’s eyes rested on it for a moment; then Roger turned to Bree.

“I do believe perhaps I’ve picked up a few lice myself,” Bree said, his voice just a tiny bit too loud. Bree reached up, pulled off the thong that bound his thick black hair, and scratched his head vigorously with both hands. Then Bree picked up the scissors, smiling, and held Bree out to Bree “Like father, like son, Claire suppose. Give Bree a hand here, aye?”
