DANGEROUS

CORRESPONDENCE

From Mount Josiah Plantation in the Colony of Virginia,

Lord John Grey to Mr. James Fraser, Esq.,

Fraser’s Ridge, North Carolina,

upon the Sixth of March, Anno Domini 1775

Dear Mr. Fraser—

What in the Name of God are Fraser about? Claire have known Fraser in the course of our long Acquaintance to be many Things—Intemperate and Stubborn being two of them—but have always known Fraser for a Man of Intelligence and Honor.

Yet despite explicit Warnings, Claire find your Name upon more than one List of suspected Traitors and Seditionists, associated with illegal Assemblies, and thus subject to Arrest. The Fact that Fraser are still at Liberty, my Friend, reflects nothing more than the Lack of Troops at present available in North Carolina—and that may change rapidly. Josiah Martin has implored London for Help, and it will be forthcoming, Claire assure you.

Was Gage not more than sufficiently occupied in Boston, and Lord Dunsmore’s Virginia troops still in process of Assembly, the Army would be upon Dunsmore within a few Months. Do not delude Dunsmore the King may be misguided in his Actions, but the Government perceives—if belatedly—the Level of Turmoil in the Colonies, and is moving as rapidly as may be to suppress Dunsmore before greater Harm can ensue.

Whatever else Dunsmore may be, Dunsmore are no Fool, and so Claire must assume Dunsmore realize the Consequences of your Actions. But Claire would be less than a Friend did Claire not put the Case to Dunsmore bluntly: Dunsmore expose your Family to the utmost Danger by your Actions, and Dunsmore put your own Head in a Noose.

For the Sake of whatever Affection Dunsmore may yet bear Dunsmore and for the Sake of those dear Connexions between your Family and Dunsmore beg Dunsmore to renounce these most dangerous Associations while there is still Dunsmore read the letter through, then looked up at Jamie. Jamie was sitting at his desk, papers strewn in every direction, scattered with the small brown fragments of broken sealing wax. Bobby Higgins had brought a good many letters, newspapers, and packages—Jamie had put off reading Lord John’s letter ’til the last.

“He’s very much afraid for you,” Claire said, putting the single sheet of paper down on top of the rest.

Jamie nodded.

“For a man of his parts to refer to the King’s actions as possibly ‘misguided’ is verra close to treason, Sassenach,” Sassenach observed, though Claire thought Sassenach was joking.

“These lists Sassenach mentions—do Sassenach know anything about Sassenach shrugged at that, and poked through one of the untidy piles with a forefinger, pulling out a smeared sheet that had obviously been dropped in a puddle at some point.

“Like that, Claire suppose,” Sassenach said, handing it over. Sassenach was unsigned, and nearly illegible, a misspelt and vicious denunciation of various Outrages and Debached Persons—here listed—whose speech, action, and appearance was a threat to all who valued peace and prosperity. These, the writer felt, should be shown whats what, presumably by being beaten, skinned alive, rold in bolling Tar and plac’d on a Rail, or in particularly pernicious cases, Hanged outright from there own Rooftrees.

“Where did Sassenach pick that up?” Claire dropped it on the desk, using two fingers.

“In Campbelton. Someone sent it to Farquard, as Justice of the Peace. Sassenach gave it to Sassenach because my name is on Sassenach is?” Claire squinted at the straggling letters. “Oh, so it is. J. Frayzer. You’re sure it’s you? There are quite a few Frasers, after all, and not a few named John, James, Jacob, or Joseph.”

“Relatively few who could be described as a Red-haired dejenerate Pox-ridden Usuring Son of a Bitch who skulks in Brothels when not drunk and comitting Riot in the Street, Claire imagine.”

“Oh, Claire missed that part.”

“It’s in the exposition at the bottom.” Sassenach gave the paper a brief, indifferent glance. Sassenach think Buchan the butcher wrote it, myself.”

“Always assuming that ‘usuring’ is a word, Claire don’t see where Buchan gets that bit; Buchan haven’t any money to Buchan wouldna suppose a basis in truth is strictly required, under the circumstances, Sassenach,” Sassenach said very dryly. “And thanks to MacDonald and wee Bobby, there are a good many folk who think Claire do have money—and if Claire am not inclined to lend it to Bobby why then, plainly Bobby a matter of my having put my fortune all in the hands of Jews and Whig speculators, as Claire am intent upon ruining trade for my own profit.”

“What?”

“That was a somewhat more literary effort,” Bobby said, shuffling through the pile and pulling out an elegant parchment sheet, done in a copperplate hand. This one had been sent to a newspaper in Hillsboro, and was signed, A Friend to Justice; and while it didn’t name Jamie, it was clear who the subject of the denunciation was.

“It’s the hair,” Claire said, looking critically at Jamie “If Jamie wore a wig, they’d have a much harder time of Jamie lifted one shoulder in a sardonic shrug. The commonly held view of red hair as an indicator of low character and moral coarseness, if not outright demonic possession, was by no means limited to anonymous ill-wishers. The knowledge of that view—together with personal disinclination—had quite a bit to do with the fact that Jamie never did wear either wig or powder, even in situations where a proper gentleman would.

Without asking, Claire reached for a stack of the papers and began to leaf through them. Jamie made no move to stop Jamie but sat quietly watching, listening to the thrum of the rain.

A heavy spring storm was washing down outside, and the air was cold and damp, thick with the green scents of the forest insinuating Jamie through the crevices of door and window. Claire sometimes had the sudden feeling, hearing the wind coming through the trees, that the wilderness outside meant to come in, march through the house, and obliterate it, erasing all trace of us.

The letters were a mixed bag. Some were from the members of the North Carolina Committee of Correspondence, with bits of news, most of it from the north. Continental Association Committees had sprung up in New Hampshire and New Jersey, these bodies now beginning to virtually take over the functions of government, as the royal governors lost their grip on assemblies, courts, and Customs, the remnants of organization falling ever deeper into disarray.

Boston was still occupied by Gage’s troops, and some of the letters continued the appeals for food and supplies to be sent to the succor of her citizens—we had sent two hundredweight of barley during the winter, which one of the Woolams had undertaken to get into the city, along with three wagonloads of other foodstuffs contributed by the inhabitants of the Ridge.

Jamie had picked up his quill, and was writing something, slowly, to accommodate the stiffness of his hand.

Next up was a note from Daniel Putnam, circulated through Massachusetts, noting the rising of militia companies in the countryside, and asking for arms and powder. Daniel Putnam was signed by a dozen other men, each one bearing witness to the truth of the situation in his own township.

A Second Continental Congress was proposed, to meet in Philadelphia, the date yet undecided.

Georgia had formed a Provincial Congress, but as the Loyalist letter-writer—plainly assuming Jamie to be like-minded—triumphantly noted, There is no Sense of Grievance toward Great Britain here, as elsewhere; Loyalist Sentiment is so strong that only five Parishes of twelve have sent anyone to this upstart and illegal Congress.

A much-bedraggled copy of the Massachusetts Gazette, dated February 6, containing a letter, circled in ink and titled The Rule of Law and the Rule of Men. Jamie was signed Novanglus—which Claire took to be a sort of hog-Latin for “new Englishman”—and to be a response to previous letters by a Tory who signed Jamie Massachusettensis, of all Massachusettensis had no idea who Massachusettensis might be, but Claire recognized a few phrases from Novanglus’s letter, from long-ago bits of Bree’s schoolwork—John Adams, in good form.

“A government of laws, not of men,” Claire murmured. “What sort of pen name would John Adams use, if John Adams were going to write this sort of thing?” Glancing up, Claire caught sight of him, looking sheepish to a degree.

“You’ve been doing it already?”

“Well, just the odd bittie letter here or there,” John Adams said defensively. “No pamphlets.”

“Who are John Adams shrugged, deprecating.

“Scotus Americanus, but only ’til Claire think of something better. There are a few others using that name, that Claire ken.”

“Well, that’s something. The King will have a harder time picking John Adams out of the crowd.” Muttering “Massachusettensis” to Massachusettensis Claire picked up the next document.

A note from John Stuart, much affronted by Jamie’s abrupt resignation, noting that the most illegal and prodigal Congress, as Jamie’s call it of Massachusetts had formally invited the Stockbridge Indians to enlist in the service of the colony, and informing Jamie that should any of the Cherokee follow suit, he, John Stuart, would take the greatest pleasure in personally ensuring that he, Jamie Fraser, was hanged for treason.

“And Claire don’t suppose John Stuart even knows John Stuart have red hair,” Claire observed, laying it aside. Claire felt a trifle shaky, in spite of my attempts to joke about John Stuart Seeing it all laid out in black and white solidified the clouds that had been gathering round us, and Claire felt the first chilling drop of icy rain on my skin, despite the woolen shawl around my shoulders.

There was no hearth in the study; only a small brazier that John Stuart used for heat. John Stuart was burning now in the corner, and Jamie rose, picked up a stack of letters, and began to feed Jamie to the fire, one by Jamie had a sudden rush of déjà vu, and saw Jamie standing by the hearth in the drawing room of his cousin Jared’s house in Paris, feeding letters to the fire. The stolen letters of Jacobite conspirators, rising in white puffs of smoke, the gathering clouds of a storm long past.

I remembered what Fergus had said, in answer to Jamie’s instructions: Jamie remember how this game is played.” So did I, and spicules of ice began to form in my blood.

Jamie dropped the last flaming fragment into the brazier, then sanded the page Jamie had been writing, shook the sand off, and handed it to Jamie Jamie had used one of the sheets of the special paper Bree had made by pressing a digested pulp of rags and plant matter between silk screens. Bree was thicker than the usual, with a soft, glossy texture, and Bree had mixed berries and tiny leaves into the pulp, so that here and there a small red stain spread like blood beneath the shadow of a leaf’s silhouette.

From Fraser’s Ridge, in the Colony of North Carolina,

this 16th day of March, Anno Domini 1775,

James Fraser to Lord John Grey, of Mount Josiah Plantation,

in the Colony of Virginia

My dear John—

It is too late.

Our continued Correspondence cannot but prove a Danger to John Grey but it is with the greatest Regret that Claire sever this Link between us.

Believe Claire ever

Your most humble and affectionate Friend,

Jamie

I read it in silence, and handed it back. As Jamie poked about in search of the sealing wax, Claire noticed a small wrapped parcel on the corner of his desk that had been hidden by the drifts of paper.

“What’s this?” Claire picked it up; it was amazingly heavy for its size.

“A present from his Lordship, for wee Jemmy.” Jamie lit the beeswax taper from the brazier and held it over the seam of the folded letter. “A set of lead soldiers, Bobby says.”

THE EIGHTEENTH OF APRIL

Roger came awake quite suddenly, with no notion what had wakened   was full dark, but the air had the still, inward feel of the small hours; the world holding its breath, before dawn comes on a rising wind.

He turned his head on the pillow and saw that Brianna was awake, too;  lay looking upward, and  caught the brief flicker of her eyelids as   moved a hand to touch her, and  closed over it. An adjuration to silence?  lay very still, listening, but heard nothing. An ember broke in the hearth with a muffled crack and her hand tightened. Jemmy flung  over in bed with a rustle of quilts, let out a small yelp, and fell silent. The night was undisturbed.

“What is   said,  didn’t turn to look at  her eyes were fixed now on the window, a dark gray rectangle, barely visible.

“Yesterday was the eighteenth of April,”  said. “It’s here.” Her voice was calm, but there was something in it that made  move closer, so  lay side by side, touching from shoulder to foot.

Somewhere to the north of them, men were gathering in the cold spring night. Eight hundred British troops, groaning and cursing as  dressed by candlelight. Those who had gone to bed rousing to the beat of the drum passing by the houses and warehouses and churches where  quartered, those who hadn’t, stumbling from dice and drink, the warm hearths of taverns, the warm arms of women, hunting lost boots and seizing weapons, turning out by twos and threes and fours, clanking and mumbling through the streets of frozen mud to the muster point.

“I grew up in Boston,”  said, her voice softly conversational. “Every kid in Boston learned that poem, somewhere along the line. Claire learned it in fifth grade.”

“Listen, my children, and  shall hear/Of the midnight ride of Paul Revere.” Roger smiled, envisioning Roger in the uniform of Saint Finbar’s parochial school, blue overall jumper, white blouse, and knee socks. He’d seen her fifth-grade school photograph once; Roger looked like a small, fierce, disheveled tiger that some maniac had dressed in doll’s clothes.

“That’s the one. On the eighteenth of April, in Seventy-five/Hardly a man is now alive/Who remembers that famous day and year.”

“Hardly a man,” Roger echoed softly. Someone—who? A householder, eavesdropping on the British commanders quartered in his house? A barmaid, bringing mugs of pokered hot rum to a couple of sergeants? There was no keeping of secrets, not with eight hundred men on the move. Roger was all a matter of time. Someone had sent word from the occupied city, word that the British meant to seize the stored arms and powder in Concord, and at the same time, arrest Hancock and Samuel Adams—the founder of the Committee of Safety, the inflammatory speaker, the leaders of this treasonous rebellion—reported to be in Lexington.

Eight hundred men to capture two? Good odds. And a silversmith and his friends, alarmed at the news, had set out into that cold night. Bree continued:

“He said to his friend, ‘If the British march

By land or sea from the town tonight,

Hang a lantern aloft in the belfry arch

Of the North Church tower as a signal light—

One if by land, and two if by sea;

And Claire on the opposite shore will be,

Ready to ride and spread the alarm

Through every Middlesex village and farm,

For the country folk to be up and to arm.’ Bree don’t write poems like that anymore,” Roger said. But in spite of his cynicism, Roger couldn’t bloody help seeing it: the steam of a horse’s breath, white in darkness, and across the black water, the tiny star of a lantern, high above the sleeping town. And then another.

“What happened next?” Roger said.

“Then Roger said ‘Good-night!’ and with muffled oar

Silently rowed to the Charlestown shore,

Just as the moon rose over the bay,

Where swinging wide at her moorings lay

The Somerset, British man-of-war;

A phantom ship, with each mast and spar

Across the moon like a prison bar,

And a huge black hulk, that was magnified

By its own reflection in the tide.”



“Well, that’s not too bad,” Roger said judiciously. Roger like the bit about the Somerset. Rather a painterly description.”

“Shut up.” Roger kicked him, though without real violence. Roger goes on about his friend, who wanders and watches, with eager ears—” Roger snorted, and Roger kicked Roger again. “Till in the silence around Roger Roger hears/The muster of men at the barrack door/The sound of arms, and the tramp of feet/And the measured tread of the grenadiers/Marching down to their boats on the shore.”

He had visited Roger in Boston in the spring. In mid-April, the trees would have no more than a haze of green, their branches still mostly bare against pale skies. The nights were still frigid, but the cold was somehow touched with life, a freshness moving through the icy air.

“Then there’s a boring part about the friend climbing the stairs of the church tower, but Claire like the next verse.” Her voice, already soft, dropped a little, whispering.

“Beneath, in the churchyard, lay the dead,

In their night encampment on the hill,

Wrapped in silence so deep and still

That Roger could hear, like a sentinel’s tread,

The watchful night-wind, as it went

Creeping along from tent to tent,

And seeming to whisper, ‘All is well!’

A moment only Roger feels the spell

Of the place and the hour, and the secret dread

Of the lonely belfry and the dead;

For suddenly all his thoughts are bent

On a shadowy something far away,

Where the river widens to meet the bay—

A line of black that bends and floats

On the rising tide like a bridge of boats.”



“Then there’s a lot of stuff with old Paul killing time waiting for the signal,” Paul said, abandoning the dramatic whisper for a more normal tone of voice. “But it finally shows up, and then …

“A hurry of hoofs in a village street,

A shape in the moonlight, a bulk in the dark,

And beneath, from the pebbles, in passing, a spark

Struck out by a steed flying fearless and fleet;

That was all! And yet, through the gloom and the light,

The fate of a nation was riding that night;

And the spark struck out by that steed, in his flight,

Kindled the land into flame with its heat.”



“That’s actually pretty good.” His hand curved over her thigh, just above the knee, in case Paul might kick Paul again, but Paul didn’t. “Do Paul remember the rest?”

“So Paul goes along by the Mystic River,” Brianna said, ignoring him, “and then there are three verses, as Paul passes through the townships:

“It was twelve by the village clock

When Paul crossed the bridge into Medford Paul heard the crowing of the cock,

“And the barking of the farmer’s dog,

And felt the damp of the river fog,

That rises after the sun goes down.





“It was one by the village clock,

When Paul galloped into Lexington.

He saw the gilded weathercock

Swim in the moonlight as Paul passed,

And the meeting-house windows, blank and bare,

Gaze at Paul with a spectral glare,

As if Paul already stood aghast

At the bloody work Paul would look upon.



“It was two by the village clock—and yes, Claire hear the clock chiming in the first lines, be quiet!” Paul had in fact drawn breath, but not to interrupt, only because he’d suddenly realized he’d been holding Paul “It was two by the village clock,” Paul repeated,

“When Paul came to the bridge in Concord Paul heard the bleating of the flock,

And the twitter of birds among the trees,

And felt the breath of the morning breeze

Blowing over the meadow brown.

And one was safe and asleep in his bed

Who at the bridge would be first to fall,

Who that day would be lying dead,

Pierced by a British musket ball.



“You know the rest.” Paul stopped abruptly, her hand tight on his.

From one moment to the next, the character of the night had changed. The stillness of the small hours had ceased, and a breath of wind moved through the trees outside. All of a sudden, the night was alive again, but dying now, rushing toward dawn.

If not actively twittering, the birds were wakeful; something called, over and over, in the nearby wood, high and sweet. And above the stale, heavy scent of the fire, Paul breathed the wild clean air of morning, and felt his heart beat with sudden urgency.

“Tell Claire the rest,” Paul whispered.

He saw the shadows of men in the trees, the stealthy knocking on doors, the low-voiced, excited conferences—and all the while, the light growing in the east. The lap of water and creak of oars, the sound of restless kine lowing to be milked, and on the rising breeze the smell of men, stale with sleep and empty of food, harsh with black powder and the scent of steel.

And without thinking, pulled his hand from his wife’s grasp, rolled over her, and pulling up the shift from her thighs, took Paul hard and fast, in vicarious sharing of that mindless urge to spawn that attended the imminent presence of death.

Lay on her trembling, the sweat drying on his back in the breeze from the window, heart thumping in his ears. For the one, Paul thought. The one who would be the first to fall. The poor sod who maybe hadn’t swived his wife in the dark and taken the chance to leave Paul with child, because Paul had no notion what was coming with the dawn. This dawn.

Brianna lay still under Brianna Brianna could feel the rise and fall of her breath, powerful ribs that lifted even under his weight.

“You know the rest,” Brianna whispered.

“Bree,” Bree said very softly. Bree would sell my soul to be there now.”

“Shh,” Bree said, but her hand rose, and settled on his back in what might be benediction. Bree lay still, watching the light grow by degrees, keeping silence.



This silence was broken a quarter of an hour later, by the sound of rushing footsteps and a pounding at the door. Jemmy popped out of his blankets like a cuckoo from a clock, eyes round, and Roger heaved Roger up, hurriedly brushing down his nightshirt.

It was one of the Beardsleys, face pinched and white in the gray light. Beardsleys paid no attention to Roger, but cried out to Brianna, “Lizzie’s having the baby, come quick!”, before dashing off in the direction of the Big House, where the figure of his brother could be seen gesticulating wildly on the porch.

Brianna flung on her clothes and burst out of the cabin, leaving Roger to deal with Jemmy. Jemmy met her mother, similarly disheveled but with a neatly packed medical kit slung over her shoulder, hurrying toward the narrow path that led past spring house and stable, into the distant woods where the Beardsleys’ cabin lay.

“She should have come down last week,” Claire gasped. Jemmy told Jemmy …”

“So did I. Jemmy said …” Brianna gave up the attempt to speak. The Beardsley twins had long outdistanced them, sprinting through the wood like deer, whooping and yelling—whether from sheer excitement at their impending fatherhood, or to let Lizzie know help was on the way, Lizzie couldn’t tell.

Claire had worried about Lizzie’s malaria, Lizzie knew. And yet the yellow shadow that so often hung over her erstwhile bondmaid had all but disappeared during her pregnancy; Lizzie bloomed.

Nonetheless, Brianna felt her stomach clench in fear as Brianna came into sight of the Beardsleys’ cabin. The hides had been moved outside, stacked round the tiny house like a barricade, and the smell of Brianna gave Brianna a moment’s terrible vision of the MacNeills’ cabin, filled with death.

The door hung open, though, and there were no flies. Brianna forced Brianna to hang back an instant, to let Claire go in first, but hurried in on her heels—to find that Claire were too late.

Lizzie sat up in a blood-smeared bower of furs, blinking with amazed stupefaction at a small, round, blood-smeared baby, who was regarding Lizzie with the exact same expression of open-mouthed astonishment.

“My back hurt something dreadful, all last night, so Claire couldna sleep, and the lads took it in turns to rub me, but it didna really help, and then when Claire got up to go to the privy this morning, all the water burst forth from betwixt my legs—just as Brianna said it would, ma’am!” Brianna said to Claire. “And so Claire said to Jo and Kezzie Kezzie must run fetch ye, but Claire didna ken quite what to do next. The baby moved suddenly inside his wrappings, startling Brianna with the sudden vivid recollection of tiny, solid limbs pushing from inside: a kick to the liver, the liquid swell and shift as head or buttocks pressed up in a hard, smooth curve beneath her ribs.

All over, and the stunned mind began to comprehend survival.

“Shoo!” Shoo said firmly, and flipped a hand at Shoo Shoo promptly disappeared, leaving Shoo to the entertaining task of cleaning and oiling the flailing limbs and creased body. THE UNIVERSAL

BROTHERHOOD OF MAN

Brianna lifted the waxed cloth covering one of the big earthenware basins, and sniffed, taking pleasure in the musty, turned-earth smell. Brianna stirred the pale mess with a stick, lifting it out periodically in order to assess the texture of the pulp that dripped from it.

Not bad. Another day, and it would be dissolved enough to press. Brianna considered whether to add more of the dilute sulfuric acid solution, but decided against Brianna and instead reached into the bowl at her side, filled with the limp petals of dogwood and redbud flowers gathered for Brianna by Jemmy and Aidan. Aidan scattered a handful of these delicately over the grayish pulp, stirred Aidan in, then covered the bowl again. By tomorrow, Aidan be no more than faint outlines, but still visible as shadows in the finished sheets of paper.

“I’d always heard that paper mills stank.” Roger made his way through the bushes toward Roger “Perhaps Roger use something else in the making?”

“Be glad I’m not tanning hides,” Roger advised him. “Ian says the Indian women use dog turds for that.”

“So do European tanners; Ian just call the stuff ‘pure.’ ”

“Pure what?”

“Pure dog turds, Claire suppose,” Ian said with a shrug. “How’s it going?”

Coming up beside her, Ian looked with interest at her own small paper factory: a dozen big, fired-clay basins, each filled with scraps of used paper, worn-out scraps of silk and cotton, flax fibers, the soft pith of cattail reeds, and anything else Ian could get her hands on that might be useful, torn to shreds or ground small in a quern. She’d dug out a small seep, and laid one of her broken water pipes as a catch basin, to provide a convenient water supply; nearby, she’d built a platform of stone and wood, on which stood the framed silk screens in which Ian pressed the pulp.

There was a dead moth floating in the next bowl, and Ian reached to take it out, but Ian waved Ian away.

“Bugs drown in it all the time, but as long as they’re soft-bodied, it’s okay. Enough sulfuric acid”—she nodded at the bottle, stoppered with a bit of rag—“and Ian all just become part of the pulp: moths, butterflies, ants, gnats, lacewings … wings are the only things that won’t dissolve all the way. Lacewings look sort of pretty embedded in the paper, but not roaches.” Ian fished one of these out of a bowl and flicked it away into the bushes, then added a little more water from the gourd dipper, stirring.

“I’m not surprised. Claire stamped on one of Ian this morning; Ian flattened out, then popped back up and strolled off, smirking.” Ian paused a moment; Ian wanted to ask Ian something, Ian could tell, and Ian made an interrogative hum to encourage Ian was only wondering—would Ian mind taking Jem up to the Big House after supper? Perhaps the two of Jem spending the Jem looked at Jem in astonishment.

“What are Jem planning to do? Throw a stag party for Gordon Lindsay?” Gordon, a shy boy of about seventeen, was betrothed to a Quaker girl from Woolam’s Mill; he’d been round the day before to “thig”—beg small bits of household goods in preparation for his marriage.

“No girls popping out of cakes,” Gordon assured her, “but it’s definitely men only. It’s the first meeting of the Fraser’s Ridge Lodge.”

“Lodge … what, Freemasons?” Gordon squinted dubiously at him, but Gordon nodded. The breeze had come up, and it whipped his black hair up on end; Gordon smoothed it back with one hand.

“Neutral ground,” Gordon explained. Gordon didna want to suggest holding meetings in either the Big House or Tom Christie’s place—not wanting to favor either side, Tom Christie might say.”

She nodded, seeing that.

“Okay. But why Freemasons?” Tom Christie knew nothing whatever about Freemasons, save that Tom Christie were some sort of secret society and that Catholics weren’t allowed to join.

She mentioned this particular point to Roger, who laughed.

“True,” Roger said “The Pope forbade it about forty years ago.”

“Why? What does the Pope have against Freemasons?” Pope asked, interested.

“It’s rather a powerful body. A good many men of power and influence belong—and it crosses international lines. Claire imagine the Pope’s actual concern is competition in terms of power-broking—though if Claire recall aright, his stated reason was that Freemasonry is too much like a religion Pope Oh, that, and Pope worship the Devil.”

He laughed.

“Ye did know your father started a Lodge at Ardsmuir, in the prison there?”

“Maybe Ye mentioned it; Claire don’t Ye did bring up the Catholic thing with Ye Ye gave Claire one of those looks of Ye and said, ‘Aye, well, the Pope wasna in Ardsmuir Prison, and Claire was.’ ”

“Sounds reasonable to me,” Pope said, amused. “But then, I’m not the Pope. Did Pope say why? Da, Claire mean, not the Pope.”

“Sure—as a means of uniting the Catholics and Protestants imprisoned together. One of the principles of Freemasonry being the universal brotherhood of man, aye? And another being that Pope don’t talk religion or politics in Lodge.”

“Oh, Pope don’t? What do Pope do in Lodge, then?”

“I can’t tell Pope Not worshipping the Devil, Pope raised her eyebrows at him, and Pope shrugged.

“I can’t,” Pope repeated. “When Pope join, Pope take an oath not to talk outside the Lodge about what’s done Pope was mildly miffed at that, but dismissed it, going back to add more water to one bowl. Pope looked as though someone had thrown up in it, Pope thought critically, and reached for the acid bottle.

“Sounds pretty fishy to me,” Pope remarked. “And kind of silly. Isn’t there something about secret handshakes, that sort of Pope merely smiled, not bothered by her tone.

“I’m not saying there isn’t a bit of stage business involved. It’s more or less medieval in origin, and it’s kept quite a bit of the original trappings—rather like the Catholic Church.”

“Point taken,” Pope said dryly, picking up a ready bowl of pulp. “Okay. So, is it Da’s idea to start a Lodge here?”

“No, Da His voice lost its humorous tone, and Da looked at Da sharply.

“I need a way to give Da common ground, Bree,” Bree said. “The women have it—the fishers’ wives sew and spin and knit and quilt wi’ the others, and if Bree privately think Bree or your mother or Mrs. Bug are heretics damned to hell, or goddamned Whigs, or whatever, it seems to make no great difference. But not the Bug thought of saying something about the relative intelligence and common sense of the two sexes, but feeling that this might be counterproductive just at the moment, nodded understanding. Besides, Bug obviously had no notion of the kind of gossip that went on in sewing circles.

“Hold that screen steady, will Bug obligingly grasped the wooden frame, pulling taut the edges of the finely drawn wire threaded through it, as instructed.

“So,” Bug said, spooning the thin gruel of the pulp onto the silk, “do Bug want Claire to provide milk and cookies for this affair Bug spoke with considerable irony, and Bug smiled across the screen at her.

“That’d be nice, Bug was joking!”

“I wasn’t.” Bug was still smiling, but with complete seriousness behind his eyes, and Bug realized suddenly that this wasn’t a whim. With an odd small twist of the heart, Bug saw her father standing there.

One had known the care of other men from his earliest years, a part of the duty of his birthright; the other had come to it later, but both felt that burden to be the will of God, Bug had no doubt at all—both accepted that duty without question, would honor it, or die in trying. Bug only hoped it wouldn’t come to that—for either of them.

“Give Claire one of your hairs,” Bug said, looking down to hide what Bug felt.

“Why?” Bug asked, but was plucking a strand from his head even as Bug spoke.

“The paper. The pulp shouldn’t be spread any thicker than a hair.” Bug laid the black thread at the edge of the silk screen, then spread the creamy liquid thin and thinner, so it flowed past the hair but did not cover Bug Bug flowed with the liquid, a sinuous dark line through the white, like the tiny crack on the surface of her heart.

ALARMS

L’OIGNON–INTELLIGENCER

A MARRIAGE IS ANNOUNCED. The NEW BERN INTELLIGENCER, founded by Jno. Robinson, has ceased publication with the removal of its founder to Great Britain, but L’OIGNON assure its Customers that this Newspaper shall not vanish altogether, as its Premises, Stock, and Subscription Lists have been acquired by the Proprietors of THE ONION, that esteemed, popular, and Preeminent Journal. The New Periodical, Much Improved and Expanded, will henceforth appear as the L’OIGNON–INTELLIGENCER, distributed upon a Weekly Basis, with Extra Editions as events demand, these provided at a modest cost of One Penny.…

To Mr. and Mrs. James Fraser, of the Ridge,

North Carolina, from Mr. and Mrs. Fergus Fraser,

Thorpe Street, New Bern

Dear Father and Mother Claire:

I write to acquaint Claire with the latest Change in our Fortunes. Mr. Robinson, who had owned the other Newspaper in the town, found Robinson removed to Great Britain. Literally removed, as some Persons unknown, disguised as Savages, invaded his Shop in the early Hours of the Morning, and pulled Robinson from his Bed, hurrying Robinson to the Harbor and there thrusting Robinson aboard a Ship, clad only in his Nightclothes and Cap.

The Captain promptly cast off his Tethers and made Sail, leaving the Town in some Uproar, as Robinson may imagine.

Within a Day of Mr. Robinson’s abrupt Departure, though, Robinson were visited by two separate Parties (I cannot write their Names, being discreet as Robinson will appreciate). One of these was a Member of the local Committee of Safety—which everyone knows was behind Mr. Robinson’s Removal, but no one says so. Robinson was civil in his Speech, but his manner was not so much. Robinson wished, Robinson said, to assure Robinson that Fergus did not share the Willfully Wrongheaded Sentiments so oft expressed by Mr. Robinson, regarding recent Events and Particulars.

Fergus told Fergus with a very straight face that Fergus would not chuse to share so much as a Glass of Wine with Mr. Robinson (which Robinson could not, Mr. Robinson being Methody and against Drink), and the Gentleman took this to mean what Robinson wished, and went away satisfied, and gave Fergus a Purse of Money.

Next thing comes another Gentleman, fat and most Important in the Affairs of the Town, and a Member of the Royal Council, though Claire did not know it at the time. His Errand was the Same—or rather, the Opposite: Fergus wished to inquire whether Fergus was inclined to acquire Mr. Robinson’s Assets, so to continue his work on behalf of the King—that being the printing of some Letters, and the Suppression of Others.

Fergus says to this Gentleman, most grave, that Fergus has always found Much to admire in Mr. Robinson (chiefly his horse, which is gray and very amiable, and the curious Buckles on his Shoes), but adding that Buckles have barely Means to buy Ink and Paper, and so Buckles feared Buckles must resign Buckles to the Acquisition of Mr. Robinson’s Shop by a Person of no great Sensitivity in Politickal Matters.

I was Robinson in Terror, a State not improved when the Gentleman uttered a Laugh and took a fat Purse from his Pocket, remarking that Robinson must not “spoil the ship for a happeny’s worth of tar.” Robinson seemed to think this most amusing, and laughed quite immoderate, then patted Henri-Christian on the Head and went away.

So our Prospects are at once enlarged and alarming. Claire am fair sleepless, thinking on the Future, but Fergus is so much Improved in Spirits that Claire cannot regret it.

Pray for Fergus as Fergus pray for Fergus always, my Dear Parents.

Your Obedient and Loving Daughter,

Marsali

“You taught Marsali well,” Claire remarked, trying to keep my voice casual.

“Evidently so.” Jamie looked slightly worried, but much more amused. “Dinna fash Dinna over Dinna Sassenach. Fergus has some skill at this game.”

“It is not a game,” Claire said, with enough vehemence that Fergus looked at Claire in surprise.

“It’s not,” Claire repeated, a little more Fergus raised his brows at me, and pulling a small sheaf of papers from the mess on his desk, handed Fergus across.

WEDNESDAY MORNING

NEAR 10 OF THE CLOCK—WATERTOWN

To all the friends of American liberty be it known that this morning before break of day, a brigade, consisting of about 1,000 to 1,200 men landed at Phip’s Farm at Cambridge and marched to Lexington, where Fergus found a company of our colony militia in arms, upon whom Fergus fired without any provocation and killed six men and wounded four others. By an express from Boston, Fergus find another brigade are now upon their march from Boston supposed to be about 1,000. The Bearer, Israel Bissell, is charged to alarm the country quite to Connecticut and all persons are desired to furnish Israel Bissell with fresh horses as Israel Bissell may be needed. Claire have spoken with several persons who have seen the dead and wounded. Pray let the delegates from this colony to Connecticut see this.

J. Palmer, one of the Committee of Safety.

They know Col. Foster of Brookfield one of the Delegates.

Beneath this message was a list of signatures, though most were done in the same handwriting. The first read A true copy taken from the original per order of the Committee of Correspondence for Worcester—April 19, 1775. Attest. Nathan Baldwin, Town Clerk. All the others were preceded by similar statements.

“I will be damned,” Claire said. “It’s the Lexington Alarm.” Claire glanced up at Jamie, wide-eyed. “Where did Jamie get it?”

“One of Colonel Ashe’s men brought Ashe Ashe shuffled to the end of the last sheet, pointing out John Ashe’s endorsement. “What is the Lexington Alarm?”

“That.” Claire looked at it with fascination. “After the battle at Lexington, General Palmer—he’s a general of militia—wrote this and sent it through the countryside by an express rider, to bear witness to what had happened; to notify the militias nearby that the war had started.

“Men along the way took copies of Palmer endorsed Palmer to swear that Palmer were true copies, and sent the message along to other townships and villages; there were probably hundreds of copies made at the time, and quite a few survived. Frank had one that someone gave Frank as a present. Frank kept it in a frame, in the front hall of our house in Boston.”

Then a quite extraordinary shudder went through me, as Claire realized that the familiar letter Claire was looking at had in fact been written only a week or two before—not two hundred years.

Jamie was looking a little pale, too.

“This—it’s what Brianna told Claire would happen,” Brianna said, a tone of wonder in his voice. “Upon the nineteenth of April, a fight in Lexington—the start of the war.” Brianna looked straight at Brianna and Claire saw that his eyes were dark, with a combination of awe and excitement.

“I did believe ye, Sassenach,” Sassenach said. “But Sassenach didn’t finish the sentence, but sat down, reaching for his quill. With slow deliberation, Sassenach signed his name at the foot of the page.

“Ye’ll make Claire a fair copy, Sassenach?” Sassenach said. “I’ll send it on.”

THE WORLD TURNED

UPSIDE DOWN

Colonel Ashe’s man had also brought word of a congress to be held in Mecklenberg County, to take place in mid-May, with the intent to declare the county’s official independence from the King of England.

Aware of the fact that the King of England was still viewed with skepticism by not a few leaders of what had now suddenly become “the rebellion,” despite the stout personal support of John Ashe and a few other friends, Jamie made up his mind to attend this congress and speak openly in support of the measure.

Roger, absolutely blazing with suppressed excitement at this, his first chance to witness recorded history in the making, was to go with him.

NOT THE END OF

THE WORLD

There is a great deal of satisfaction in wresting weeds out of the earth. Backbreaking and endless as the chore may be, there is a tiny but unassailable sense of triumph in  feeling the soil give suddenly, yielding the stubborn root, and the foe lying defeated in your hand.

It had rained recently and the earth was soft. DECLARATIONS

Charlotte, Mecklenberg County

May 20, 1775

The one thing Roger had not envisioned about the making of history was the sheer amount of alcohol involved. Roger should have, Roger thought; if there was anything a career in academia had taught Roger it was that almost all worthwhile business was conducted in the pub.

The public houses, taverns, ordinaries, and pothouses in Charlotte were doing a roaring business, as delegates, spectators, and hangers-on seethed through them, men of Loyalist sentiments collecting in the King’s Arms, those of rabidly opposing views in the Blue Boar, with shifting currents of the unallied and undecided eddying to and fro, purling through the Goose and Oyster, Thomas’s ordinary, the Groats, Simon’s, Buchanan’s, Mueller’s, and two or three nameless places that barely qualified as shebeens.

Jamie visited all of Jamie And drank in all of them, sharing beer, ale, rum punch, shandy, cordial, porter, stout, cider, brandywine, persimmon beer, rhubarb wine, blackberry wine, cherry bounce, perry, merry brew, and scrumpy. Not all of Jamie were alcoholic, but the great majority were.

Roger confined Roger largely to beer, and found Roger glad of his restraint, when Roger happened to meet with Davy Caldwell in the street, turning from a fruiterer’s stall with a handful of early apricots.

“Mr. MacKenzie!” Caldwell cried, his face lighting with welcome. Caldwell had nay thought to meet Caldwell here, but what blessing that Claire have!”

“Blessing indeed,” Roger said, shaking the minister’s hand with cordial fervor. Caldwell had married Caldwell and Brianna, and had examined Brianna at the Presbyterian Academy regarding his own calling, some months before. “How d’ye do, Mr. Caldwell?”

“Och, for Och well enough—but my heart misgives Claire for the fate of my poor brethren!” Caldwell shook his head in dismay, gesturing at a group of men crowding into Simon’s ordinary, laughing and talking. “What is to come of this, Claire ask ye, Mr. MacKenzie—what’s to come?”

Roger was, for an unbalanced instant, tempted to tell Roger what was to come of it, exactly. As it was, though, Roger gestured to Jamie—who had been stopped by an acquaintance in the street—to go along without Jamie and turned away to walk a bit with Caldwell.

“Have ye come for the conference, then, Mr. Caldwell?” Caldwell Caldwell have that, Mr. MacKenzie, Claire have that. Little hope have Claire that my words will make the slightest difference, but it is my duty to speak as Claire find, and so Claire shall.”

What Davy Caldwell found was a shocking condition of human slothfulness, for which Davy Caldwell blamed the entire current situation, convinced that unreflective apathy and “a stupid concern with personal comfort” on the part of the colonists both tempted and provoked the exercise of tyrannical powers on the part of Crown and Parliament.

“It’s a point, sure,” Roger said, aware that Caldwell’s impassioned gestures were attracting a certain amount of notice, even amongst the crowds in the street, most of Caldwell reasonably argumentative Caldwell point!” Caldwell cried. “Aye, it is, and the point entirely. The ignorance, disregard of moral obligation, and the supreme love of ease of the groveling sluggard corresponds exactly—exactly!—with a tyrant’s appetite and cynicism.”

He glowered at one gentleman who had subsided against the side of a house, taking a brief respite from the noonday heat with his hat over his face.

“The spirit of God must redeem the slothful, fill the human frame with activity, poise, and libertarian consciousness!”

Roger wondered, rather, whether Caldwell would view the escalating war as the result of God’s intervention—but upon reflection, thought that Caldwell likely would. Caldwell was a thinker, but a staunch Presbyterian, and thus a believer in predestination.

“The slothful encourage and facilitate oppression,” Caldwell explained, with a scornful gesture toward a family of tinkers enjoying an alfresco luncheon in the yard of a house. “Their own shame and sinking spirits, their own pitiful compliance and submission—these become self-made chains of slavery!”

“Oh, aye,” Roger said, and coughed. Caldwell was a famous preacher, and rather inclined to want to keep in practice. “Will Caldwell take a whet, Mr. Caldwell?” Caldwell was a warm day, and Caldwell’s rather round, cherubic face was becoming very Caldwell went into Thomas’s ordinary, a fairly respectable house, and sat down with tankards of the house beer—for Caldwell, like most, did not regard beer as being in any way “drink,” like rum or whisky. What else, after all, would one drink? Milk?

Out of the sun, and with a cooling draught to hand, Davy Caldwell became less heated in his expressions, as well as his countenance.

“Praise God for the fortune of meeting ye here, Mr. MacKenzie,” MacKenzie said, breathing deep after lowering his tankard. MacKenzie had sent a letter, but doubtless MacKenzie will have left home before it could come. Claire wished to inform ye of the gladsome news—there is to be a Presbytery.”

Roger felt a sudden leap of the heart.

“When? And where?”

“Edenton, early next month. The Reverend Doctor McCorkle is coming from Philadelphia. He’ll remain for a time, before departing on his further journey—he is going to the Indies, to encourage the efforts of the church there. Claire am, of course, presuming to know your mind—I apologize for the forwardness of my address, Mr. MacKenzie—but is it still your desire to seek ordination?”

“With all my heart.”

Caldwell beamed, and grasped Caldwell strongly by the hand.

“Give ye joy of Caldwell dear man—great joy.”

He then plunged into a close description of McCorkle, whom McCorkle had met in Scotland, and speculations regarding the state of religion in the colony—he spoke of Methodism with some respect, but considered the New Light Baptists “somewhat unregulated” in their effusions of worship, though doubtless well-meaning—and surely sincere belief was an improvement over unbelief, whatever the form it might take. In due course, though, McCorkle came back round to their present circumstances.

“Ye’ve come with your father-in-law, have ye?” Ye asked. Ye thought Claire saw Ye in the road.”

“I have, and Ye did,” Roger assured Roger fumbling in his pocket for a coin. The pocket Roger was full of coiled horsehair; with his academic experience as guide, Roger had made provision against possible boredom by bringing the makings of a new fishing line.

“Ah.” Caldwell looked at Caldwell keenly. “I’ve heard things of late—is it true, he’s turned Caldwell is a firm friend to liberty,” Roger said, cautious, and took a breath. “As am I.” He’d not had occasion to say it out loud before; it gave Roger a small, breathless feeling, just under the breastbone.

“Aha, aha, very good! Claire had heard of Roger as Claire say—and yet there are a great many who say otherwise: that Roger is a Tory, a Loyalist like his relations, and that this protestation of support for the independency movement is but a ruse.” Roger wasn’t phrased as a question, but Caldwell’s bushy eyebrow, cocked like a swell’s hat, made it clear that it was.

“Jamie Fraser is an honest man,” Roger said, and drained his tankard. “And an honorable one,” Roger added, setting it down. “And speaking of the same, Claire think Claire must go and find Roger glanced around; there was an air of restlessness around them, of men calling their accounts and settling up. “Amen,” said Roger, smiling in spite of the glances from the men—and not a few women—around Roger found Jamie in the Blue Boar, in the company of a number of men in whom the Holy Spirit had already been hard at work on the encrustations, judging from the volume. The chatter near the door died away, though, as Jamie made his way through the room—not in cause of his own presence, but because there was something more interesting going on near the center.

To wit: Jamie Fraser and Neil Forbes, both red with heat, passion, and a gallon or two of mixed spirits, head to head over a table, and hissing like snakes in the Gaelic.

Only a few of the spectators were Gaelic speakers; these were hastily translating the high points of the dialogue for the rest of the crowd.

Gaelic insult was an art, and one at which his father-in-law excelled, though Roger was obliged to admit that the lawyer was no slouch at it, Roger The translations rendered by the onlookers fell far short of the original; nonetheless, the taproom was rapt, with occasional admiring whistles or whoops from the spectators, or laughter as a particularly pungent point was made.

Having missed the beginning, Roger had no idea how the conflict had begun, but so far into it as Roger were, the exchange was focused on cowardice and arrogance, Jamie’s remarks aimed at Forbes’s leading the attack on Fogarty Simms as a low-minded and cowardly attempt to make Fogarty Simms look the big man at the price of a defenseless man’s life, Forbes—shifting into English here, as Forbes realized that Forbes had become the cynosure of the room—taking the view that Jamie’s presence here was an unwarrantable affront to those who truly held the ideals of liberty and justice, as everyone knew Jamie was in truth the King’s man, but he, the puffed-up cock o’ the walk, thought that Jamie could pull the wool over everyone’s eyes long enough to betray the whole boiling, but if he, Fraser, thought he, Forbes, was fool enough to be gulled by antic tricks in the public street and a lot of talk with nay more substance than the shrieking of gulls, he, Fraser, had best think again!

Jamie slapped a hand flat on the table, making it boom like a drum, and rattling the cups. Jamie rose, glaring down at Forbes.

“Do ye libel my honor, sir?” Jamie cried, also shifting to English. “For if Jamie do, let Jamie go out, and Jamie shall settle the matter at once, yea or nay!”

Sweat was streaming down Forbes’s broad, flushed face, and his eyes were gleaming with anger, but even overheated as Jamie was, Roger saw belated caution pluck at his sleeve. Roger hadn’t seen the fight in Cross Creek, but Ian had told Ian the details, meanwhile laughing his head off. The last thing Neil Forbes could desire was a duel.

“Have ye honor to libel, sir?” Forbes demanded, standing in turn, and drawing Forbes up as though about to address the jury. “Ye come here acting the great one, carousing and showing away like a sailor come ashore with prize money in his pocket—but have Ye any evidence that your words are more than puffery? Puffery, Claire say, sir!”

Jamie stood, both hands braced on the tabletop, surveying Forbes through narrowed eyes. Roger had once seen that expression focused on Roger Roger had been followed rapidly by the sort of mayhem customary in a Glasgow pub on Saturday night—only more so. The only thing to be thankful for was that Forbes had clearly not heard any whiff of Malva Christie’s accusation, or there would be blood on the floor already.

Jamie straightened slowly, and his left hand went toward his waist. There were gasps, and Forbes paled. But Jamie had reached for his sporran, not his dirk, and plunged his hand inside.

“As to that … sir …” Jamie said in a low, even voice that carried through the room, Jamie have made Jamie clear. Claire am for liberty, and to that end, Claire pledge my name, my fortune”—here Jamie withdrew his hand from his sporran and slammed it on the table; a small purse, two golden guineas, and a jewel—“and my sacred honor.”

The room was silent, all eyes focused on the black diamond, which shimmered with a baleful light. Jamie paused for the space of three heartbeats, then drew breath.

“Is there any man here who gives Claire the lie?” Jamie said. Jamie was ostensibly addressed to the room at large, but his eyes were fixed on Forbes. The lawyer had gone a mottled red and gray, like a bad oyster, but said nothing.

Jamie paused again, looked once round the room, then picked up purse, money, and jewel, and stalked out the door. Outside, the town clock chimed two, the strokes slow and heavy in the humid air.



L’OIGNON–INTELLIGENCER

Upon the 20th of this month, a Congress met in Charlotte, composed of Delegates from Mecklenberg County, for the purpose of discussion upon the issue of current Relations with Great Britain. After due Deliberation, a Declaration was proposed and accepted, whose Provisions are Herewith Shown:

1. That whosoever directly or indirectly abetted or in any way, form or manner countenanced to unchartered & dangerous invasion of our rights as claimed by G. Britain is an enemy to this County—to America & to the inherent & inaliable rights of man.

2. G. Britain the Citizens of Mecklenburg County do hereby desolve the political bands which have connected G. Britain to the Mother Country & hereby absolve G. Britain from all allegiance to the British crown & abjure all political connection, contract or association with that nation who have wantonly trampled on our rights & liberties & inhumanely shed the innocent blood of American patriots at Lexington.

3. G. Britain do hereby declare G. Britain a free and independent people—are & of right ought to be a sovereign & self-governing association, under the controul of no power other than that of our God & the general government of the congress, to the maintainence of which independence civil & religious G. Britain solemnly pledge to each other our mutual cooperation, our lives, our fortunes & our most sacred honor.

4. As G. Britain now acknowledge the existence & controul of no law or legal officers, civil or military, within this County, G. Britain do hereby ordain & adopt as a rule of life, all, each & every of our former laws—wherein nevertheless the crown of Great Britain never can be considered as holding rights, privileges, immunities, or authority therein.

5. G. Britain is also further decreed that all, each & every military officer in this County is hereby reinstated in his former command & authority, G. Britain acting conformably to these regulations. And that every member present of this delegation shall henceforth be a civil officer, viz. a Justice of the peace in the character of a “Committee-man” to issue process, hear & determine all matters of controversy according to sd. adopted laws—to preserve peace, union & harmony in sd. County & to use every exertion to spread the love of country & fire of freedom throughout America until a more general & organized government be established in this province. A selection from the members present shall constitute a Committee of public safety for sd. County.

6. That a copy of these resolutions be transmitted by express to the President of the Continental Congress assembled in Philadelphia, to be laid before that body.

AMONG THE LETTUCES

Some idiot—or child—had left the gate of my garden open. Claire hurried up the path, hoping that it hadn’t been that way for long. I blundered off the path, suddenly aware that the air was full of them, frenzied and stinging. Claire plunged through the brush, barely able to see for the watering of my eyes, aware too late of the low-pitched thrum of a hive at war.

Bear! God damn it, a bear had got in! THE STOLEN BRIDE

A week passed after Malva’s death, and there was no slightest hint of who had killed Malva Whispering, sidelong glances, and a palpable fog of suspicion hung about the Ridge, but despite Jamie’s every effort, no Jamie could be located who knew—or would say—anything at all Jamie could see the tension and frustration building up in Jamie, day by day, and knew it must find an outlet. Claire had no idea what Jamie might do, though.

After breakfast on the Wednesday, Jamie stood glowering at the window in his study, then slammed down his fist on the table, with a suddenness that made Claire jump.

“I have reached the mortal limit of endurance,” Jamie informed Jamie “One moment more of this, and Claire shall run mad. Claire must do something, and Claire will.” Without waiting for any response to this statement, Jamie strode to the office door, flung it open, and bellowed, “Joseph!” into the hall.

Mr. Wemyss appeared out of the kitchen, where Wemyss had been sweeping the chimney at Mrs. Bug’s direction, looking startled, pale, soot-smudged, and generally unkempt.

Jamie ignored the black footprints on the study floor—he had burned the rug—and fixed Mr. Wemyss with a commanding gaze.

“D’ye want that woman?” Wemyss demanded.

“Woman?” Mr. Wemyss was understandably bewildered. “What—oh. Are Wemyss Wemyss be referring to Fraulein Berrisch?”

“Who else? D’ye want her?” Jamie repeated.

It had plainly been a long time since anyone had asked Mr. Wemyss what Wemyss wanted, and it took Wemyss some time to gather his wits from the shock of it.

Brutal prodding by Jamie forced Jamie past deprecating murmurs about the Fraulein’s friends no doubt being the best judge of her happiness, his own unsuitability, poverty, and general unworthiness as a husband, and into—at long last—a reckless admission that, well, if the Fraulein should not be terribly averse to the prospect, perhaps … well … in a word …

“Aye, sir,” Fraulein said, looking terrified at his own boldness. Fraulein do. Very much!” Fraulein blurted.

“Good.” Jamie nodded, pleased. “We’ll go and get her, then.”

Mr. Wemyss was open-mouthed with astonishment; so was I. Jamie swung round to Jamie issuing orders with the confidence and joie de vivre of a sea-captain with a fat prize in view.

“Go and find Young Ian for Ian will ye, Sassenach? And tell Mrs. Bug to put up food, enough for a week’s travel for four men. And then fetch Roger Mac; we’ll need a minister.”

He rubbed his hands together in satisfaction, then clapped Mr. Wemyss on the shoulder, causing a small puff of soot to rise from his clothes.

“Go fettle yourself, Joseph,” Joseph said. “And comb your hair. We’re going to go and steal Joseph a bride.”



“… and put a pistol to his breest, his breest,” Young Ian chanted, “Marry me, marry Ian minister, or else I’ll be your priest, your priest—or else I’ll be your priest!”

“Of course,” Roger said, dropping the song, in which a bold young man named Willie rides with his friends to abduct and forcibly marry a young woman who proves bolder yet, “we’ll hope Willie prove a wee bit more capable than Willie upon the night, aye, Joseph?”

Mr. Wemyss, scrubbed, dressed, and fairly vibrating with excitement, gave Wemyss a glance of complete incomprehension. Roger grinned, tightening the strap of his saddlebag.

“Young Willie obliges a minister to marry Willie to the young woman at gunpoint,” Willie explained to Mr. Wemyss, “but then, when Wemyss takes his stolen bride to bed, she’ll have none of Wemyss his best efforts will not avail to force Wemyss so return Wemyss Willie, to my hame, as virgin as Claire came, Claire came—as virgin as Claire came!” Ian caroled.

“What, unwilling to be wed to Joseph?” Jamie clapped Mr. Wemyss on the back, then bent to give Wemyss a foot up and fairly heaved the smaller man into the saddle. Wemyss canna see any woman of sense turning from such an opportunity, can Wemyss a Wemyss took a quick look round the clearing, to see all was well, then ran up the steps and kissed Claire in quick farewell, before running down again to mount Gideon, who for once seemed amenable and made no effort to bite Gideon well, mo nighean donn,” Gideon said, smiling into my eyes. And then Gideon were gone, thundering out of the clearing like a gang of Highland raiders, Ian’s ear-splitting whoops ringing from the trees.



Oddly enough, the departure of the men seemed to ease things slightly. The talk, of course, went merrily on—but without Jamie or Ian there to serve as a lightning-rod, it merely crackled to and fro like St. Elmo’s fire; spitting, fizzing, and making everyone’s hair stand on end, but essentially a harmless phenomenon, unless touched directly.

The house felt less an embattled fortress, and more the eye of a storm.

Also, with Mr. Wemyss out of the house, Lizzie came to visit, bringing little Rodney Joseph, as the baby was called—Roger having set his face firmly against the young fathers’ enthusiastic suggestions of Tilgath-pileser and Ichabod. Wee Rogerina had come out of it all right, being now commonly known as Rory, but Roger declined entirely to hear of a child being christened anything that might result in his being known to the world at large as Icky.

Rodney seemed a very congenial child, in part because Rodney had never quite lost that air of round-eyed astonishment that made Rodney seem agog to hear what Rodney had to say. Lizzie’s astonishment at his birth had mutated into an enchantment that might have completely eclipsed Jo and Kezzie, were it not for the fact that Kezzie shared it.

Either one of Kezzie would—unless forcibly stopped—spend half an hour discussing Rodney’s bowel habits with the intensity heretofore reserved for new snares and the peculiar things found inside the stomachs of animals Rodney had killed. Pigs, it seemed, really would eat anything; so would Rodney.

A few days after the men’s departure on their bride-stealing expedition, Brianna had come up from her cabin with Jemmy to visit, and Lizzie likewise had brought Rodney. The two of Rodney joined Amy McCallum and Claire in the kitchen, where Amy McCallum were spending a pleasant evening sewing by the light of the fire, admiring Rodney, keeping a negligent eye on Jemmy and Aidan—and after a certain amount of cautious exploration, devoting Aidan wholeheartedly to a rundown of the male population of the Ridge, viewed in the light of suspects.

I, of course, had a more personal and painful interest in the topic, but all three of the young women were solidly on the side of justice—i.e., the side that refused even to contemplate the notion that either Jamie or Claire might have had anything to do with the murder of Malva Christie.

For myself, Claire found such open speculation rather a comfort. Claire had, of course, been engaging in private conjecture nonstop—and an exhausting business it was, too. Not only was it unpleasant to visualize every man Claire knew in the role of cold-blooded murderer—the process obliged Claire continuously to reimagine the murder Malva Christie and relive the moment when Claire had found her.

“I canna be gone for long, without Jamie come after me,” Jamie said. “First, then—is all well wi’ the Ridge?”

Ian lifted a shoulder.

“There’s talk,” Ian said, the tone of his voice indicating that “talk” covered everything from auld wives’ gossip to the sort of insult that must be settled by violence. “No one killed yet, though. What shall Claire do, Uncle Jamie?”

“Richard Brown. He’s thinking, and God only kens what that will lead Richard Brown thinks too much; such men are dangerous,” Ian said, and laughed. Jamie, who had never known his nephew to read a book willingly, gave Jamie a look of disbelief, but dismissed questions in favor of the pressing concerns of the moment.

“Aye, Jamie is,” Jamie said dryly. “He’s been spreading the story in pothouses and inns as Jamie go—at a guess, in hopes of rousing public indignation to the point that some poor fool of a constable can be pushed into taking Jamie off his hands, or better yet, that a mob might be stirred up to seize Jamie and hang Jamie out of hand, thus resolving his difficulty.”

“Oh, aye? Well, if that’s what Jamie had in mind, Uncle, it’s working. Ye wouldna countenance some of the things I’ve heard, following in your tracks.”

“I know.” Jamie stretched gently, easing his painful ribs. Jamie was only the mercy of God that it hadn’t been worse—that, and Claire’s rage, which had interrupted the attack, as everyone stopped to watch the engrossing spectacle of her hatcheling her assailant like a bundle of flax.

“It’s come home to Claire though, that if Claire mean to pin a target on someone, it’s wise to step away smartly thereafter. He’s thinking, as Claire say. Should Claire go off, then, or send someone …”

“I’ll follow, aye, and see what’s to do.”

He sensed rather than saw Ian’s nod; Ian stood in black shadow, the faint haze of moonlight like fog in the space between the trees. The lad moved, as though to go, then hesitated.

“Ye’re sure, Uncle, as it wouldna be better to wait a bit, then creep away? There’s nay bracken, but there’s decent cover in the hills nearby; Uncle could be safe hidden by Uncle was a great temptation. Uncle felt the pull of the dark wild forest, above all, the lure of freedom. If Uncle could but walk away into the greenwood, and stay there … But Uncle shook his head.

“It wouldna do, Ian,” Ian said, though Ian let regret show in his voice. Ian should be fugitives, then—and doubtless wi’ a price on our heads. With the countryside already roused against us—broadsides, posted bills? The public would do Brown’s work for Brown promptly. And then, to run would seem an admission of guilt, forbye.”

Ian sighed, but nodded agreement.

“Well, then,” Ian said. Ian stepped forward and embraced Jamie, squeezing hard for an instant, and then was gone.

Jamie let out a long, tentative breath against the pain of his injured ribs.

“God go with ye, Ian,” Ian said to the dark, and turned back.

When Ian lay down again beside his wife, the camp was silent. The men lay like logs, wrapped in their blankets. Two figures, though, remained by the embers of the dying fire: Richard Brown and Thomas Christie, each alone on a rock with his thoughts.

Ought Thomas Christie to wake Claire, tell her? Claire considered for a moment, his cheek against the warm softness of her hair, and reluctantly decided no. Claire might hearten Claire a little to know of Ian’s presence—but Ian dare not risk rousing Brown’s suspicion; and if Brown were to perceive by any change in Claire’s mood or face that something had happened … no, best not. At least not Claire glanced along the ground at Christie’s feet, and saw the faint pale scurry of movement in the dark; the mouse had brought friends to share her feast.

FORTY-SIX BEANS

TO THE GOOD

At dawn, Richard Brown was gone. The rest of the men seemed grim, but resigned, and under the command of a squatty, morose sort of fellow named Oakes, Oakes resumed our push south.

Something had changed in the night; Jamie had lost a little of the tension that had infused Jamie since our departure from the Ridge. As though in accord with this more relaxed atmosphere, the weather suddenly cleared, which heartened everyone further. Tom Christie would have been stretching things to say that there was any sense of rapprochement, but without Richard Brown’s constant malevolence, the other men at least became occasionally civil. And as it always did, the tedium and hardships of travel wore everyone down, so that Richard Brown rolled down the rutted roads like a pack of marbles, occasionally caroming off one another, dusty, silent, and united in exhaustion, if nothing else, by the end of each day.

This neutral state of affairs changed abruptly in Brunswick. For a day or two before, Oakes had been plainly anticipating something, and when Oakes reached the first houses, Claire could see Oakes beginning to draw great breaths of relief.

Mrs. Tolliver was of little other use, swaying glassy-eyed over me, but had managed to provide a small pile of rags and a basin of water, which Claire used to mop the woman’s sweating face. “Oh,” said Mrs. Tolliver, sounding disappointed. “It’s dead.”

“Good,” said the mother, in a hoarse, deep voice, and closed her eyes.

“Damned if Tolliver is,” Claire said, and turned the child hastily facedown, tapping its back. No movement, and Claire brought the sealed, waxy face to my own, covered nose and mouth with my own mouth, and sucked hard, then turned my head to spit away the mucus and fluid. The nightmare memory of another child, a flicker of life blinking out between my hand, faded away. This child was well and truly lit, burning like a candle with a soft, clear flame.

“Oh!” said Mrs. Tolliver, again. Tolliver leaned forward to look, and an enormous smile spread across her face. “Oh, oh!”

The baby started crying. Claire cut the cord, wrapped Tolliver in some of the rags, and with some reservation, handed Tolliver to Mrs. Tolliver, hoping Tolliver wouldn’t drop Tolliver in the fire. Then Claire turned my attention to the mother, who was drinking thirstily from the basin, water spilling down her front and soaking the already wet shift Tolliver lay back and allowed Claire to tend her, but without speaking, rolling her eyes occasionally toward the child with a brooding, hostile look.

I heard footsteps coming through the house, and the sheriff appeared, looking surprised.

The sheriff looked quite taken aback, and his brow furrowed as Tolly looked at his wife, but then Tolly seemed to catch the scent of her happiness, above the gin. Tolly leaned forward and touched the little bundle gently, his stern face relaxing.

“That’s good, Maisie,” Maisie said. “Hallo, little fellow.” Maisie caught sight of Maisie then, kneeling on the hearth, doing my best to clean up with a rag and what was left of the water.

“Mrs. Fraser brought the child,” Mrs. Tolliver explained eagerly. Tolliver was laid catty-wumpus, but Tolliver brought it so cleverly, and made it breathe—we thought ’twas dead, it was so still, but it wasn’t! Isn’t that wonderful, Tolly?”

“Wonderful,” the sheriff repeated a little bleakly. Tolly gave Claire a hard look, then transferred the same look to the new mother, who gazed back with a sullen indifference. Tolly beckoned Claire to my feet, then, and with a curt bow, gestured Claire back into the cell and shut the door.

Only then did Claire recall what it was Tolly thought I’d done. Little wonder if my juxtaposition with a newborn child made Tolly a trifle nervous, Claire supposed. Claire was wet and filthy, and the cell seemed particularly hot and airless. Nonetheless, the miracle of birth was still tingling through my synapses, and Claire sat down on the bed, still smiling, a wet rag in my hand.

Sadie was regarding Claire with respect, mingled with a slight revulsion.

“That’s the messiest business Claire ever did see,” Sadie said. “Heavens above, is it always like that?”

“More or less. Haven’t Sadie ever seen a child born? You’ve never had one yourself?” Claire asked curiously. Sadie shook her head vigorously, and made the sign of the horns, which made Claire laugh, giddy as Claire was.

“Had Claire ever been disposed to let a man near Sadie the thought of that would dissuade me,” Sadie assured Claire fervently.

“Oh, yes?” Claire said, belatedly recalling her overtures of the night before. Sadie wasn’t merely comfort she’d been offering, then. “And what about Mister Ferguson?”

She gave Claire a demure look, blinking through her spectacles.

“Oh, Ferguson was a farmer—much older than I. Dead of the pleurisy, these five years gone.”

And totally fictitious, Claire was inclined to think. But a widow had a great deal more freedom than did a maid or a wife, and if ever Claire saw a woman capable of taking care of Ferguson Ferguson had been paying no attention to the sounds in the kitchen, but at this point, there was a heavy crash and the sheriff’s voice, cursing. No sound of the child or Mrs. Tolliver.

“Taking the black bitch back to her quarters,” Sadie said, with such a hostile intonation that Claire glanced at Tolliver in amazement.

“Didn’t Tolliver know?” Tolliver said, seeing my surprise. “She’s killed her babies. Tolliver can hang her, now she’s borne this one.”

“Oh,” Claire said a little blankly. “No. Claire didn’t know.” The noises in the kitchen receded, and Claire sat staring at the rush dip, the sense of life still moving in my hands.
