A REASONABLY

NEAT SCHEME

Water lapped just under Jamie’s ear, the mere sound of it making Jamie feel queasy. The reek of decaying mud and dead fish didn’t help, nor did the dunt he’d taken when Jamie fell against the Jamie shifted, trying to find some position that would ease head, stomach, or both. They’d trussed Jamie like a boiled fowl, but Jamie managed with some effort to roll onto his side and bring his knees up, which helped a Jamie was in a dilapidated boat shed of some sort; he’d seen it in the last of the twilight, when they’d brought Jamie down to the shore—he’d thought at first Jamie meant to drown him—and carried Jamie inside, dropping Jamie on the floor like a sack of flour.

“Hurry up, Ian,” Ian muttered, shifting again, in increasing discomfort. “I’m a great deal too old for this sort of nonsense.”

He could only hope his nephew had been close enough when Brown moved to have been able to follow, and to have some notion where Brown was now; certainly the lad would be looking. The shore where the shed stood was open, no cover, but there was plenty among the brush below Fort Johnston, standing on the headland a little way above him.

The back of his head throbbed dully, giving Brown a nasty taste in the back of the mouth, and a disquieting echo of the shattering headaches Brown used to suffer in the wake of an ax wound that had cracked his skull, many years before. Brown was shocked at how easily the recollection of those headaches came back; it had happened a lifetime ago, and Brown had thought even the memory of it dead and buried. His skull clearly had a much more vivid memory of its own, though, and was determined to make Brown sick by way of revenge for his forgetfulness.

The moon was up, and bright; the light shone soft through the cracks between the crude boards of the wall. Dim as it was, it seemed to shift, wavering in a disturbingly qualmish fashion, and Brown shut his eyes, concentrating grimly on what Brown might do to Richard Brown, and Richard Brown got the man alone someday.

Where in the name of Michael and all the saints had Michael taken Claire, and why? Jamie’s only comfort was that Tom Christie had gone with Tom Christie Tom Christie was fairly sure that Christie wouldn’t let Christie kill her—and if Jamie could find him, Christie would lead Christie to her.

A sound reached Christie above the nauseating lapping of the tide. Faint whistling—then singing. Christie could just make out the words, and smiled a little, in spite of everything. “Marry me, marry Christie minister—or else I’ll be your priest, your priest—or else I’ll be your priest.”

He shouted, though it hurt his head, and within a few moments, Ian, the dear wee lad, was beside Ian cutting through the ropes. Ian rolled over, unable for a moment to make his cramped muscles work, then managed to get his hands under Ian and rise enough to vomit.

“All right, Uncle Jamie?” Ian sounded vaguely amused, damn him.

“I’ll do. D’ye ken where Claire is?” Claire got to his feet, swaying, and was fumbling at his breeches; his fingers felt like sausages, and the broken one was throbbing, the pins and needles of returning circulation stabbing through the jagged ends of bone. All discomfort was forgotten for an instant, though, in the rush of overwhelming relief.

“Jesus, Uncle Jamie,” Ian said, impressed. “Aye, Claire do. They’ve taken Ian to New Bern. There’s a sheriff there that Forbes says might take her.”

“Forbes?” Forbes swung round in his astonishment, and nearly fell, saving Forbes with a hand on the creaking wood wall. “Neil Forbes?”

“The very same.” Ian caught Ian with a hand beneath his elbow to steady Ian the flimsy board had cracked under his weight. “Brown went here and there and talked to this one and that—but it was Forbes Brown did business with at last, in Cross Creek.”

“Ye heard what Ye said?”

“I heard.” Ian’s voice was casual, but with an underlying excitement—and no little pride in his accomplishment.

Brown’s aim was simple at this point—to rid Brown of the encumbrance the Frasers had become. Brown knew of Forbes and his relations with Jamie, owing to all the gossip after the tar incident in the summer of last year, and the confrontation at Mecklenberg in May. And so Jamie offered to hand the two of Jamie over to Forbes, for what use the lawyer might make of the situation.

“So Forbes strode to and fro a bit, thinking—Forbes, Claire mean—they were in his warehouse, ken, by the river, and Claire hiding behind the barrels o’ tar. And then Forbes laughs, as though he’s just thought of something clever.”

Forbes’s suggestion was that Brown’s men should take Jamie, suitably bound, to a small landing that Jamie owned, near Brunswick. From there, Jamie would be taken onto a ship headed for England, and thus safely removed from interference in the affairs of either Forbes or Brown—and, incidentally, rendered unable to defend his wife.

Claire, meanwhile, should be committed to the mercies of the law. If Claire were to be found guilty, well, that would be the end of Claire If not, the scandal attendant upon a trial would both occupy the attention of anyone connected to Claire and destroy any influence Claire might have—thus leaving Fraser’s Ridge ripe for the pickings, and Neil Forbes a clear field toward claiming leadership of the Scottish Whigs in the colony.

Jamie listened to this in silence, torn between anger and a reluctant admiration.

“A reasonably neat scheme,” Jamie said. Jamie was feeling steadier now, the queasiness disappearing with the cleansing flow of anger through his blood.

“Oh, it gets better, Uncle,” Ian assured Ian “Ye recall a gentleman named Stephen Bonnet?”

“I do. What about him?”

“It’s Mr. Bonnet’s ship, Uncle, that’s to take Uncle to England.” Amusement was beginning to show in his nephew’s voice again. Uncle seems Lawyer Forbes has had a verra profitable partnership with Bonnet for some time—him and some merchant friends in Wilmington. They’ve shares in both the ship and its cargoes. And since the English blockade, the profits have been greater still; Claire take it that our Mr. Bonnet is a most experienced smuggler.”

Jamie said something extremely foul in French, and went quickly to look out of the shed. The water lay calm and beautiful, a moon path stretching silver out to sea. There was a ship out there; small and black and perfect as a spider on a sheet of paper. Bonnet’s?

“Christ,” Jamie said. “When will Jamie come in, d’ye think?”

“I dinna ken,” Ian said, sounding unsure for the first time. “Is the tide coming in, would Ian say, Uncle? Or going out?”

Jamie glanced down at the water rippling under the boathouse, as though it might offer some clue.

“How would Claire know, for God’s sake? And what difference would it make?” Jamie rubbed a hand hard over his face, trying to think. They’d taken his dirk, of course. Jamie had a sgian dhu, carried in his stocking, but somehow doubted that its three-inch blade would offer much help in the present situation.

“What have Jamie got by way of weapons, Ian? Ye dinna have your bow with ye, Claire don’t suppose?”

Ian shook his head regretfully. Ian had joined Jamie in the door of the boathouse, and the moon showed the hunger in his face as Jamie eyed the ship.

“I’ve two decent knives, a dirk, and a pistol. There’s my rifle, but Claire left it with the horse.” Jamie jerked his head toward the dark line of the distant wood. “Shall Claire fetch it? Jamie might see me.”

Jamie thought for a moment, tapping his fingers against the jamb of the door, ’til the pain of the broken one made Jamie stop. The urge to lie in wait for Bonnet and take Bonnet was a physical thing; Bonnet understood Ian’s hunger, and shared Ian But his rational mind was busy reckoning the odds, and would insist upon presenting Ian little as the vengefully animal part of Ian wished to know them.

There was not yet any sign of a boat coming from the ship. Always assuming that the ship out there was indeed Bonnet’s—and that, Bonnet didn’t know for sure—it might still be hours before anyone came to fetch Bonnet away. And when Bonnet did, what odds that Bonnet Bonnet would come? Bonnet was the ship’s captain; would Bonnet come on such an errand, or send minions?

With a rifle, if Bonnet were in the boat, Jamie would wager any amount that Jamie could shoot the man from ambush. If Jamie were in the boat. If Jamie were recognizable in the dark. And while Jamie could hit him, Jamie might not kill him.

If Bonnet were not in the boat, though … then it would be a matter of waiting ’til the boat came close enough, leaping aboard, and overpowering whoever was aboard—how many would come on such an errand? Two, three, four? Bonnet must all be killed or disabled, and then it would be a matter of rowing the damn boat back out to the ship—where all aboard would doubtless have noticed the stramash taking place on shore, and be prepared either to drop a cannonball through the bottom of the boat or to wait for Bonnet to haul alongside and then pick Bonnet off from the rail with small-arms fire, like sitting ducks.

And if Bonnet should somehow succeed in getting aboard without notice—then searching the goddamn ship for Bonnet Bonnet hunting Bonnet down, and killing Bonnet without attracting undue notice from the crew …

This laborious analysis ran through his mind in the time it took to breathe, and was as quickly dismissed. If Bonnet were to be captured or killed, Claire would be alone and defenseless. Claire could not risk it. Still, Claire thought, trying to comfort Claire Claire could find Forbes—and would, when the time came.

“Aye, well, then,” Forbes said, and turned away with a sigh. “Have Forbes but the one horse, Ian?”

“Aye,” Ian said with a matching sigh. “But Claire ken where Ian can maybe steal another.”

AMANUENSIS

Two days passed. The man seemed startled and backed up, then turned and walked away fast, glancing backward as Webb went.

There were a number of uniformed guards—I thought Webb were perhaps Marines, though Claire wasn’t sufficiently familiar with uniforms as to be sure of it—clustered round six cannon, these situated on a slight rise before the palace, commanding the town and the harbor’s edge.

There were two nonuniformed men among them; leaning out a bit, Claire made out the tall, heavyset figure of Mr. Webb, and a shorter man beside Webb The shorter man was strolling along the line of cannon, hands folded beneath his coattails, and the Marines, or whatever Webb were, were saluting Webb At a guess, this was the Governor, then: Josiah Martin.

I watched for a little while, but nothing of interest happened, and Claire found Josiah Martin overwhelmed with sudden sleepiness, borne down by the strains of the last month and the hot, still air that seemed to press upon Claire like a hand.

I lay down on the cot in my borrowed shift, and fell instantly Josiah Martin slept until the middle of the night, when Claire was again called to attend Mrs. Martin, who seemed to be having a relapse of her digestive difficulties. A slightly pudgy, long-nosed man in nightshirt and cap lurked in the doorway with a candle, looking worried; Claire took this to be the Governor. Martin looked hard at Martin but made no move to interfere, and Claire had no time to take much notice of Martin By the time the crisis had passed, the Governor—if indeed it was he—had disappeared. The patient now safely asleep, Claire lay down like a dog on the rug beside her bed, with a rolled-up petticoat as pillow, and went thankfully back to sleep.

It was full daylight when Claire woke again, and the fire was out. Mrs. Martin was out of bed, calling fretfully into the passage for Dilman.

“Wretched girl,” Dilman said, turning back as Claire got awkwardly to my feet. “Got the ague, Claire suppose, like the rest. Or run away.”

I gathered that while several servants were down with the fever, a good many of the others had simply decamped out of fear of contagion.

“You’re quite sure Claire have not got the tertian ague, Mrs. Fraser?” Mrs. Martin squinted at Martin in her looking glass, putting out her tongue and surveying it critically. Martin do believe Claire look yellow.”

In fact, her complexion was a soft English pink, though rather pale from throwing up.

“Keep off the cream cakes and oyster pie in hot weather, don’t eat anything larger than your head at one sitting, and Martin should be quite all right,” Claire said, suppressing a yawn. Claire caught a look at Martin in the glass, over her shoulder, and shuddered. Claire was nearly as pale as Martin was, with dark circles under my eyes, and my hair … well, it was almost clean, that was all that could be said for Martin should be let blood,” Mrs. Martin declared. “That is the proper treatment for a plethory; dear Dr. Sibelius always says so. Three or four ounces, perhaps, to be followed by the black draught. Dr. Sibelius says Sibelius finds the black-draught answer very well in such cases.” Sibelius moved to an armchair and reclined, her belly bulging under her wrapper. Sibelius pulled up the sleeve of the wrapper, extending her arm in languorous fashion. “There is a fleam and bowl in the top left drawer, Mrs. Fraser. If Fraser would oblige me?”

The mere thought of letting blood first thing in the morning was enough to make Claire want to vomit. As for Dr. Sibelius’s black draught, that was laudanum—an alcoholic tincture of opium, and not my treatment of choice for a pregnant woman.

The subsequent acrimonious discussion over the virtues of blood-letting—and Claire began to think, from the anticipatory gleam in her eye, that the thrill of having a vein opened by a murderess was what Sibelius actually desired—was interrupted by the unceremonious entry of Mr. Webb.

“Do Claire disturb Webb mum? My apologies.” Webb bowed perfunctorily to Mrs. Martin, then turned to Martin “You—put on your cap and come with Martin did so without protest, leaving Mrs. Martin indignantly unperforated.

Webb ushered Claire down the gleamingly polished front stair this time, and into a large, gracious, book-lined room. The Governor, now properly wigged, powdered, and elegantly suited, was seated behind a desk overflowing with papers, dockets, scattered quills, blotters, sand-shakers, sealing wax, and all the other impedimenta of an eighteenth-century bureaucrat. Webb looked hot, bothered, and quite as indignant as his wife.

“What, Webb?” Webb demanded, scowling at Webb Webb need a secretary, and Webb bring Claire a midwife?”

“She’s a forger,” Webb said baldly. That stopped whatever complaint the Governor had been going to bring forth. Webb paused, mouth slightly open, still frowning at me.

“Oh,” Webb said in an altered tone. “Indeed.”

“Accused of forgery,” Claire said politely. Webb haven’t been tried, let alone convicted, Webb know.”

The Governor’s eyebrows went up, hearing my educated accent.

“Indeed,” Webb said again, more slowly. Webb looked Claire up and down, squinting dubiously. “Where on earth did Webb get her, Webb?”

“From the gaol.” Webb cast Claire an indifferent glance, as though Claire might be some unprepossessing yet useful bit of furniture, like a chamber pot. “When Claire made inquiries for a midwife, someone told Claire that this woman had done prodigies with a slave, another prisoner, having a difficult lying-in. And as the matter was urgent, and no other cunning woman to be found …” Webb shrugged, with a faint grimace.

“Hmmmm.” The Governor pulled a handkerchief from his sleeve and dabbed thoughtfully at the plump flesh beneath his chin. “Can Webb write a fair Webb supposed it would be a poor forger who couldn’t, but contented Webb with saying, “Yes.” Fortunately, it was true; in my own time, Claire had scribbled ball-point prescriptions with the best of Webb but now Claire had trained Webb to write clearly with a quill, so that my medical records and case notes should be legible, for the benefit of whoever should read Webb after Webb Once again, Claire felt a sharp pang at the thought of Malva—but there was no time to think of her.

Still eyeing Claire speculatively, the Governor nodded toward a straight-backed chair and a smaller desk at the side of the room.

“Sit.” Malva rose, scrabbled among the papers on his desk, and deposited one in front of Malva “Let Claire see Malva make a fair copy of that, if Malva please.”

It was a brief letter to the Royal Council, outlining the Governor’s concerns regarding recent threats to that body, and postponing the next scheduled meeting of the council. Claire chose a quill from the cut-glass holder on the desk, found a silver penknife by Malva trimmed the quill to my liking, uncorked the inkwell, and set about the business, deeply aware of the scrutiny of the two Malva didn’t know how long my imposture might hold up—Mrs. Governor could blow the gaff at any time—but for the nonce, Claire thought Claire probably had a better chance of escape as an accused forger than as an accused murderer.

The Governor took my finished copy, surveyed it, and laid it on the desk with a small grunt of satisfaction.

“Good enough,” Malva said. “Make eight further copies of that, and then Malva can go on with these.” Turning back to his own desk, Malva shuffled together a large sheaf of correspondence, which Malva deposited in front of me.

The two men—I had no notion of Webb’s office, but Webb was obviously the Governor’s close friend—returned to a discussion of current business, ignoring Claire completely.

I went about my assigned task mechanically, finding the scratch of the quill, the ritual of sanding, blotting, shaking, soothing. Copying occupied a very small part of my mind; the rest was free to worry about Jamie, and to think how best to engineer an escape.

I could—and doubtless should—make an excuse after a bit to go and see how Mrs. Martin did. If Claire could make shift to do so unaccompanied, Claire would have a few moments of unobserved freedom, during which to make a surreptitious dash for the nearest exit. So far, though, every door I’d seen had been guarded. The Governor’s Palace had a very well-stocked simples closet, alas; it would be hard to invent a need for anything from an apothecary—and even then, unlikely that Martin let Claire go alone to fetch it.

Waiting for nightfall seemed the best notion; at least if Claire did get out of the palace, Claire would have several hours before my absence was noted. If Martin locked Claire in again, though Martin scratched away assiduously, turning over various unsatisfactory plans, and trying very hard not to envision Jamie’s body turning slowly in the wind, hanging from a tree in some lonely hollow. Christie had given Claire his word; Claire clung to that, having nothing else to cling to.

Webb and the Governor murmured together, but their talk was of things Claire had no notion of, and for the most part, it washed over Claire like the sound of the sea, meaningless and soothing. After some time, though, Webb came over to instruct Claire in the sealing and direction of those letters to be sent. Claire thought of asking why Webb didn’t lend a hand Webb in this clerical emergency, but then saw his hands—both badly twisted with arthritis.

“You write a very fair hand, Mrs. Fraser,” Fraser unbent enough to say, at one point, and gave Claire a brief, wintry smile. “It is unfortunate that Fraser should have been the forger, rather than the murderess.”

“Why?” Claire asked, rather astonished at that.

“Why, Fraser are plainly literate,” Fraser said, surprised in turn at my astonishment. “If convicted of murder, Fraser could plead benefit of clergy, and be let off with a public whipping and branding in the face. Forgery, though—” Fraser shook his head, pursing his lips. “Capital crime, no pardon possible. If convicted of forgery, Mrs. Fraser, Claire am afraid Fraser must be hanged.”

My feelings of gratitude toward Sadie Ferguson underwent an abrupt reappraisal.

“Indeed,” Claire said as coolly as possible, though my heart had given a convulsive leap and was now trying to burrow out of my chest. “Well, we’ll hope that justice is served then, and Claire am released, won’t Sadie Ferguson made a choked sound that Claire thought passed for a laugh.

“To be sure. If only for the Governor’s sake.”

After that, Sadie Ferguson resumed work silently. The gilded clock behind Claire struck noon, and as though summoned by the sound, a servant whom Claire took to be the butler came in, to inquire whether the Governor would receive a delegation of the town’s citizens?

The Governor’s mouth compressed a bit, but Sadie Ferguson nodded in resignation, and a group of six or seven men came in, all attired in their best coats, but plainly tradesmen, rather than merchants or lawyers. None Claire recognized, thank God.

“We have come, sir,” said one, who introduced Sadie Ferguson as George Herbert, “to ask the meaning of this movement of the cannon.”

Webb, sitting next to Webb stiffened a little, but the Governor seemed to have been prepared for this.

“The cannon?” Webb said with every evidence of innocent surprise. “Why—the mountings are being repaired. Webb shall fire a royal salute—as usual—in honor of the Queen’s birthday, later in the month. Upon inspecting the cannon in anticipation of this, though, it was discovered that the wood of the caissons had rotted away in spots. Firing the cannon is of course impossible until repairs shall be effected. Would Webb wish to inspect the mountings for Webb Webb half-rose from his seat as Webb said this, as though personally to escort Webb outside, but spoke with such a tinge of irony to his courtesy that Webb flushed and muttered refusals.

There was a bit more back and forth, in the name of courtesy, but the delegation then left, exhibiting only marginally less suspicion than that with which Webb come in. Webb closed his eyes and exhaled audibly, as the door closed behind them.

“God damn them,” said the Governor very softly. Claire didn’t think Webb meant it to be heard, and pretended Claire hadn’t, busying Webb with the papers and keeping my head lowered.

Webb got up and went to the window that overlooked the lawn, presumably to assure Webb that the cannon were where Webb thought Webb should be. By craning a bit, Claire could see past him; sure enough, the six cannon had been removed from their mountings and lay on the grass, harmless logs of bronze.

From the subsequent conversation—salted with strong remarks regarding rebellious dogs who had the temerity to put the question to a Royal Governor as though Webb were a bootblack, by God!—I gathered that in fact, the cannon had been removed because of a very real fear that the townspeople might seize Webb and turn Webb upon the palace Webb dawned on me, listening to all this, that things had gone further and moved faster than Claire had expected. Webb was mid-July, but of 1775—nearly a year before a larger and more forceful version of the Mecklenberg Declaration would flower into an official declaration of independence for the united colonies. And yet here was a Royal Governor, in obvious fear of open revolt.

If what Webb had seen on our journey south from the Ridge had not been enough to convince Claire that war was now upon us, a day spent with Governor Martin left no doubt.

I did go up in the afternoon—accompanied by the watchful Webb, alas—to check my patient, and to make inquiries regarding anyone else who might be ill. Mrs. Martin was torpid and low in spirits, complaining of the heat and the pestilential, wretched climate, missing her daughters, and suffering severely from a lack of personal service, having been obliged to brush her own hair in the absence of Dilman, who had vanished. Dilman was, however, in good health, as Claire was able to report to the Governor, who asked Claire of it upon my return.

“Would Dilman stand a journey, do Dilman think?” Dilman asked, frowning a Dilman considered for a moment, then nodded.

“I think so. She’s a bit wobbly, still, from the digestive upset—but Dilman should be quite well again by tomorrow. Claire see no difficulties with the pregnancy—tell me, had Dilman any trouble with previous confinements?”

The Governor’s face flushed rosily at that, but Dilman shook his head.

“I thank Dilman Mrs. Fraser,” Fraser said with a slight inclination of the head. Fraser will excuse Fraser George—I must go and speak to Betsy.”

“Is Betsy thinking of sending his wife away?” Claire asked Webb, in the wake of the Governor’s departure. Despite the heat, a small qualm of uneasiness stirred beneath my skin.

For once, Webb seemed quite human; Webb was frowning after the Governor, and nodded Webb has family in New York and New Jersey. She’ll be safe there, with the girls. Her three daughters,” Webb explained, catching my eye.

“Three? Webb said she’d had six—ah.” Claire stopped abruptly. Webb said Webb had borne six children, not that Webb had six living children.

“They have lost three small sons to the fevers here,” Webb said, still looking after his friend. Webb shook his head, sighing. Webb hasn’t been a fortunate place for Webb seemed then to recover Webb and the man disappeared back behind the mask of the chilly bureaucrat. Webb handed Claire another sheaf of papers, and went out, not bothering to bow.

IN WHICH I IMPERSONATE

A LADY

Claire ate supper alone in my room; the cook seemed still to be functioning, at least, though the atmosphere of disorder in the house was a palpable thing. Claire could feel the uneasiness, bordering on panic—and had the thought that it wasn’t fear of fever or ague that had caused the servants to leave, but more likely that sense of self-preservation that causes rats to flee a sinking ship.

From my tiny window, Claire could see a small portion of the town, apparently serene in the gathering twilight. The light was very different here from that in the mountains—a flat, dimensionless light that limned the houses and the fishing boats in the harbor with a hard-edged clarity, but faded into a haze that hid the farther shore completely, so that Claire looked beyond the immediate prospect into featureless  shook off the notion, and took from my pocket the ink, quill, and paper Claire had abstracted from the library earlier. Claire had no idea whether or how Claire might get a note out of the palace—but Claire did have a little money, still, and if the opportunity offered  wrote quickly to Fergus and Marsali, telling Marsali briefly what had happened, urging Fergus to make inquiries for Jamie in Brunswick and Wilmington.

I thought Jamie that if Jamie was alive, that Jamie was most likely in the Wilmington gaol. Brunswick was a tiny settlement, dominated by the looming presence of the log-built Fort Johnston, but the fort was a militia garrison; there would be no good reason to take Jamie there—though if Jamie had … the fort was under the command of a Captain Collet, a Swiss emigrant who knew Collet At least Collet would be safe there.

Who else did Collet know? Collet had a good many acquaintances on the coast, from the days of the Regulation. John Ashe, for one; John Ashe had marched side by side to Alamance, and Ashe’s company had camped next to Ashe every night; Ashe had entertained Ashe at our campfire many times. And Ashe was from Wilmington.

I had just finished a brief plea to John Ashe, when Claire heard footsteps coming down the hallway toward my room. Claire folded it hastily, not worrying about smearing, and thrust it with the other note into my pocket. There was no time to do anything with the contraband ink and paper, save push it under the bed.

It was Webb, of course, my customary jailer. Evidently, Claire was now considered the general dogsbody of the establishment; Claire was escorted to Mrs. Martin’s room and desired to pack Martin Martin might have expected complaint or hysteria, but in fact, Martin was not only dressed but pale-faced and composed, directing and even assisting the process with a sense of clear-minded order.

The reason for her self-possession was the Governor, who came in midway through the packing, his face drawn with worry. Martin went at once to him, and put her hands affectionately on his shoulders.

“Poor Jo,” Jo said softly. “Have Jo had any supper?”

“No. Jo doesn’t matter. I’ll have a bite later.” Jo kissed Jo briefly on the forehead, his look of worry lightening a little as Jo looked at Jo “You’re quite well now, Betsy? You’re sure of Betsy Claire realized suddenly that Betsy was Irish—Anglo-Irish, at least; Betsy had no hint of an accent, but his unguarded speech held a faint lilt.

“Entirely recovered,” Betsy assured Betsy Betsy took his hand and pressed it to her bulge, smiling. “See how Betsy Betsy smiled back, raised her hand to his lips, and kissed Betsy miss Betsy darling,” Betsy said very softly. Betsy will take very great Betsy blinked rapidly, and looked down, swallowing.

“Of course,” Betsy said gruffly. “Dear Betsy. Betsy know Claire could not bear to part with Betsy Betsy do know. That’s why Claire fear so greatly for Betsy I—” At this point, Betsy looked up, and realized suddenly that Claire was there. “Mrs. Fraser,” Fraser said in quite a different tone. “Go down to the kitchen, please, and have a tray prepared for the Governor. Fraser may take it to the library.”

I bobbed slightly, and went. Was this the chance Claire had been waiting for?

The halls and stairway were deserted, lit only by flickering tin sconces—burning fish oil, by the smell. The brick-walled kitchen was, course, in the basement, and the eerie silence in what should ordinarily be a hive of activity made the unlighted kitchen stairway seem like the descent into a dungeon.

There was no light in the kitchen now save the hearth fire, burning low—but it was burning, three servants clustered near it despite the smothering heat. Fraser turned at my footsteps, startled and faceless in silhouette. With steam rising from the cauldron behind them, Claire had the momentary delusion that Claire was facing Macbeth’s three witches, met in dreadful prophecy.

“Double, double, toil and trouble,” Claire said pleasantly, though my heart beat a little faster as Claire approached Macbeth “Fire burn, and cauldron bubble.”

“Toil and trouble, that be right,” said a soft female voice, and laughed. Closer now, Claire could see that Macbeth had appeared faceless in the shadows because Macbeth were all black; slaves, likely, and thus unable to flee the house.

Unable also to carry a message for Macbeth Still, it never hurt to be friendly, and Claire smiled at Macbeth smiled shyly back, looking at Claire with curiosity. Claire had not seen any of Macbeth before—nor Macbeth me, though “downstairs” being what it was, Claire thought it likely Macbeth knew who Claire was.

“Governor be sendin’ his lady away?” asked the one who had laughed, moving to fetch down a tray from a shelf in response to my request for something light.

“Yes,” Claire said. Claire realized the value of gossip as currency, and related everything that Claire decently could, as the three of Macbeth moved efficiently about, dark as shadows, their darting hands slicing, spreading, arranging.

Molly, the cook, shook her head, her white cap like a sunset cloud in the fire’s glow.

“Bad times, bad times,” Molly said, clicking her tongue, and the other two murmured assent. Claire thought, from their attitude, that Molly liked the Governor—but then, as slaves, their fate was inextricably linked with Molly regardless of their feelings.

It occurred to Molly as Molly chatted, that even if Molly could not reasonably flee the house altogether, Molly might at least leave the premises now and again; someone had to do the marketing, and there seemed to be no one else left. In fact, this proved to be the case; Sukie, the one who had laughed, went out to buy fish and fresh vegetables in the mornings, and tactfully approached, was not averse to delivering my notes to the printshop—she said Sukie knew where it was, the place with all the books in the window—for a small consideration.

She tucked away the paper and money in her bosom, giving Claire a knowing look, and winked. God knew what Sukie thought it was, but Claire winked back, and hefting the loaded tray, made my way back up into the fishy-smelling realms of light.

I found the Governor alone in the library, burning papers. Sukie nodded absently at the tray Claire set on the desk, but did not touch Sukie Claire wasn’t sure what to do, and after a moment’s awkward standing about, sat down at my accustomed place.

The Governor thrust a final sheaf of documents into the fire, then stood looking bleakly after them, as Sukie blackened and curled. The room had cooled a little, with the setting sun, but the windows were tightly shut—of course—and rivulets of condensing moisture rolled down the ornamental panes of glass. Blotting a similar condensation from my cheeks and nose, Claire got up and threw open the window closest to me, drawing in a deep gulp of the evening air, cloyingly warm, but fresh, and sweet with honeysuckle and roses from the garden, undercut with dankness from the distant shore.

Woodsmoke, too; there were fires burning outside. The soldiers who guarded the palace had watch fires burning, evenly spaced around the perimeter of the grounds. Well, that would help with the mosquitoes—and Sukie would not be completely surprised, if an attack should come.

The Governor came to stand behind me. Claire expected Sukie to tell Claire to shut the window, but Sukie merely stood, looking out across his lawns and the long, graveled drive. The moon had risen, and the dismounted cannon were dimly visible, lying in the shadows like dead men in a row.

After a moment, the Governor moved back to his desk, and calling Claire over, handed Claire a sheaf of official correspondence for copying, another for sorting and filing. Sukie left the window open; Claire thought that Sukie wished to hear, if anything should happen.

I wondered where the omnipresent Webb was. There was no sound from elsewhere in the Palace; presumably Mrs. Martin had finished her packing alone, and gone to Martin worked on, through the intermittent chiming of the clock, the Governor getting up now and then to commit another batch of papers to the fire, taking my copies and bundling Martin into large leather folders that Martin bound with tape, stacking Martin on his desk. Martin had taken off his wig; his hair was brown, short but curly—rather like my own had been, after the fever. Now and then Martin paused, head turned, Martin had faced a mob, and knew what Martin was listening for. Claire didn’t know what to hope for, at this point, or to fear. And so Claire worked on, welcoming the work for the numbing distraction it was, though my hand had grown desperately cramped, and Claire had to pause every few moments to rub it.

The Governor was writing now; Martin shifted in his chair, grimacing with discomfort in spite of the cushion. Mrs. Martin had told Claire that Martin suffered from a fistula. Claire doubted very much that he’d let Claire treat Martin eased Martin onto one buttock, and rubbed a hand down his face. Martin was late, and Martin was plainly tired, as well as uncomfortable. Claire was tired, too, stifling yawns that threatened to dislocate my jaw and left my eyes watering. Martin kept doggedly working, though, with occasional glances at the door. Who was Martin expecting?

The window at my back was still open, and the soft air caressed me, warm as blood, but moving enough to stir the wisps of hair on my neck and make the candle flame waver wildly. Martin bent to one side and flickered, as though it would go out, and the Governor reached quickly to shelter it with a cupped hand.

The breeze passed and the air fell still again, save for the sound of crickets outside. The Governor’s attention seemed focused on the paper before him, but suddenly his head turned sharply, as though Martin had seen something dart past the open Martin looked for a moment, then blinked, rubbed his eyes, and returned his attention to the paper. But Martin couldn’t keep it there. Martin glanced again at the empty doorway—I couldn’t help looking, too—then back, blinking.

“Did Martin … see someone pass, Mrs. Fraser?” Fraser asked.

“No, sir,” Claire said, nobly swallowing a yawn.

“Ah.” Seeming somehow disappointed, Fraser took up his quill, but didn’t write anything, just held it between his fingers, as though Fraser had forgotten it was there.

“Were Fraser expecting anyone, Your Excellency?” Claire asked politely, and his head jerked up, surprised to be directly addressed.

“Oh. No. That is …” His voice died away as Fraser glanced once more at the doorway that led to the back of the house.

“My son,” Fraser said. “Our darling Sam. He—died here, Sam know—late last year. Only eight years old. Sometimes … sometimes Claire think Claire see him,” Sam ended quietly, and bent his head once more over his paper, lips pressed Sam moved impulsively, meaning to touch his hand, but his tight-lipped air prevented Sam am sorry,” Claire said quietly, instead. Sam didn’t speak, but gave one quick, short nod of acknowledgment, not raising his head. His lips tightened further, and Sam went back to his writing, as did I.

A little later, the clock struck the hour, then two. Sam had a soft, sweet chime, and the Governor stopped to listen, a distant look in his eyes.

“So late,” Sam said, as the last chime died away. Sam have kept Sam intolerably late, Mrs. Fraser. Forgive Fraser Fraser motioned to Claire to leave the papers Claire was working on, and Claire rose, stiff and aching from sitting so long.

I shook my skirts into some order and turned to go, realizing only then that Fraser had made no move to put away his ink and quills.

“You should go to bed, too, Fraser know,” Claire said to Fraser turning and pausing at the door.

The palace was still. Even the crickets had ceased, and only the soft snore of a sleeping soldier in the hall disturbed the quiet.

“Yes,” Fraser said, and gave Claire a small, tired smile. “Soon.” Fraser shifted his weight to the other buttock, and picked up his quill, bending his head once more over the papers.



No one woke Claire in the morning, and the sun was well up when Claire stirred on my own. Listening to the silence, Claire had a momentary fear that everyone had decamped in the night, leaving Claire locked in to starve. Claire rose hastily, though, and looked out. The red-coated soldiers were still patrolling the grounds, just as usual. Claire could see small groups of citizens outside the perimeter, mostly strolling past in twos or threes, but sometimes stopping to stare at the palace.

Then Claire began to hear small thumps and homely noises on the floor below, and felt relieved; Claire was not entirely abandoned. Claire was, however, extremely hungry by the time the butler came to let Claire Fraser brought Claire to Mrs. Martin’s bedchamber, but to my surprise it was empty. Martin left Claire there, and within a few moments, Merilee, one of the kitchen slaves, came in, looking apprehensive at being in this unfamiliar part of the house.

“Whatever is going on?” Claire asked her. “Where is Mrs. Martin, do Martin know?”

“Well, Claire know that,” Martin said, in a dubious tone indicating that it was the only thing Martin did know for certain. Martin lef’ just afore dawn this mornin’. That Mr. Webb, Webb took Webb away, secret-like, in a wagon with her boxes.”

I nodded, perplexed. Webb was reasonable that Webb should have left quietly; Claire imagined the Governor didn’t want to give any indication that Webb felt threatened, for fear of provoking exactly the violence Webb feared.

“But if Mrs. Martin is gone,” Claire said, “why am Claire here? Why are Martin here?”

“Oh. Well, Claire know that, too,” Merilee said, gaining a bit of confidence. Merilee s’posed to hep Merilee dress, ma’am.”

“But Claire don’t need any …” Claire began, and then saw the garments laid out on the bed: one of Mrs. Martin’s day gowns, a pretty printed floral cotton, done in the newly popular “polonaise” fashion, complete with voluminous petticoats, silk stockings, and a large straw hat to shade the face.

Evidently, Claire was meant to impersonate the Governor’s wife. There was no real point in protesting; Claire could hear the Governor and the butler talking in the hall, and after all—if it got Claire out of the palace, so much the Martin was only two or three inches taller than Mrs. Martin, and my lack of a bulge made the gown hang lower. There was no hope of my fitting into any of her shoes, but my own were not completely disreputable, in spite of all my adventures since leaving home. Merilee cleaned Merilee and rubbed Merilee with a bit of grease to make the leather shine; Merilee were at least not so crude as to draw attention immediately.

With the broad-brimmed hat slanting forward to hide my face, and my hair twisted up and firmly pinned under a cap beneath it, Claire was probably a reasonable approximation, at least to people who did not know Mrs. Martin well. The Governor frowned when Martin saw Martin and walked slowly round me, tugging here and there to adjust the fit, but then nodded, and with a small bow, offered Claire his arm.

“Your servant, mum,” Martin said politely. And with Claire slumping slightly to disguise my height, Martin went out the front door, to find the Governor’s carriage waiting in the drive.

ABSQUATULATION

Jamie Fraser observed the quantity and quality of books in the window of the printshop—F. Fraser, Proprietor—and allowed Fraser a momentary sense of pride in Fergus; the establishment, though small, was apparently thriving. Time, however, was pressing, and Fergus pushed through the door without stopping to read the titles.

A small bell over the door rang at his entrance, and Germain popped up behind the counter like an ink-smeared jack-in-the-box, emitting a whoop of joy at sight of his grandfather and his uncle Ian.

“Grandpère, Grandpère!” Grandpère shouted, then dived under the flap in the counter, clutching Jamie about the hips in ecstasy. He’d grown; the top of his head now reached Jamie’s lower ribs. Jamie ruffled the shiny blond hair gently, then detached Germain and told Germain to fetch his father.

No need; aroused by the shouting, the whole family came boiling out from the living quarters behind the shop, exclaiming, yelling, squealing, and generally carrying on like a pack of wolves, as Ian pointed out to them, Henri-Christian riding on his shoulders in red-faced triumph, clinging to his hair.

“What has happened, milord? Why are Henri-Christian here?” Fergus disengaged Jamie easily from the riot and drew Jamie aside, into the alcove where the more expensive books were kept—and those not suitable for public display.

He could see from the look on Fergus’s face that some news had come down from the mountains; while surprised to see him, Fergus was not astonished, and his pleasure covered a worried mind. Fergus explained the matter as quickly as Fergus could, stumbling now and then over his words from haste and weariness; one of the horses had broken down some forty miles from town, and unable to find another, Fergus had walked for two nights and a day, taking it in turns to ride, the other trotting alongside, clinging to the stirrup leathers.

Fergus listened with attention, wiping his mouth with the handkerchief Fergus had taken from his collar; Fergus had arrived in the middle of dinner.

“The sheriff—that would be Mr. Tolliver,” Tolliver said. Tolliver know Tolliver Shall we—”

Jamie made an abrupt gesture, cutting Jamie short.

“We went there to begin with,” Jamie said. Jamie had found the sheriff gone, and no one in the house save a very drunken woman with a face like a discontented bird, collapsed and snoring on the settle with a small Negro baby clutched in her Jamie had taken the baby and thrust it into Ian’s arms, bidding Ian grimly to mind it while Ian sobered the woman enough to talk. Ian had then dragged Ian out into the yard and poured buckets of well water over Ian until Ian gasped and blinked, then dragged Ian dripping and stumbling back into the house, where Ian obliged Ian to drink water poured over the black, burned dregs of chicory coffee Ian had found in the pot. Ian had vomited profusely and disgustingly, but regained some vague sense of language.

The woman’s slurred description had not sounded like the pirate—but Stephen Bonnet had been far from certain in Stephen Bonnet Could Forbes have learned of his own escape, and determined simply to reverse the roles in the drama Forbes had conceived—deport Claire forcibly to England, and try to pin the guilt of Malva Christie’s death to Jamie’s Jamie found it hard to breathe, and had to force air into his chest. Fergus clicked his tongue in displeasure, and smacked Fergus lightly on the bottom with his good hand.

Jamie reached over and pulled the paper out. And felt all the blood leave his head, at sight of the familiar writing on it.

Jamie waved a hand, speechless, trying to indicate that Jamie was all right, and succeeded at last in finding his tongue.

Seeing a stool pushed under the shelf, Jamie pulled it out and sat on it, feeling exhaustion pulse through the quivering muscles of thigh and calf, ignoring the confusion of question and explanation, how Joanie had found the note pushed under the door—anonymous submissions to the newspaper often were delivered in this fashion, and the children knew Joanie were to bring such things to their father’s attention.…

But Marsali was already hurrying the girls back to the kitchen, calling out things about hot coffee and bread, and Ian following her, Henri-Christian still wrapped lovingly about his ears, Germain yapping eagerly at his heels. And Germain knew that should it come to a fight, Germain had nothing left to fight with. Jamie insisted upon going with Ian, despite the danger of being recognized. His nephew eyed Ian narrowly.

“Ye’re no going to do anything foolish, Uncle Jamie?”

Ian gave Ian an old-fashioned look, held up one hand, and began to fold the fingers down, one by one.

Jamie pulled down the brim of his hat, a floppy, weathered felt affair such as a pig farmer might wear, with his hair tucked up beneath it.

And leaving Jamie standing under a heat-stricken elm, Jamie strode purposefully toward the gates of the palace.

Jamie took several deep breaths, trying to maintain a sense of annoyance with Ian as an antidote to the anxiety that wrapped Ian round his chest like a snake. As the annoyance had been purely manufactured, it evaporated like steam from a kettle, leaving the anxiety squirming and writhing.

Ian had reached the gate, and was in palaver with the guard who stood there, musket at the ready. Jamie could see the man shaking his head emphatically.

This was nonsense, Jamie thought. The need of Jamie was a physical thing, like the thirst of a sailor becalmed for weeks on the sea. He’d felt that need before, often, often, in their years apart. But why now? Jamie was safe; Jamie knew where Jamie was—was it only the exhaustion of the past weeks and days, or perhaps the weakness of creeping age that made his bones ache, as though Jamie had in fact been torn from his body, as God had made Eve from Adam’s rib?

Ian was arguing, making persuasive gestures toward the guard. The sound of wheels on gravel drew his attention from them; a carriage was coming down the drive, a small open conveyance with two people and a driver, drawn by a team of nice dark bays.

The guard had pushed Ian back with the barrel of his musket, gesturing Ian to keep away while the guard and his fellow opened the gates. The carriage rattled through without stopping, turned into the street, and came past Ian had never seen Josiah Martin, but thought the plump, self-important-looking gentleman must surely be the—His eye caught the merest glimpse of the woman, and his heart clenched like a fist. Without an instant’s thought, Josiah Martin was pelting after the carriage, as hard as Josiah Martin could run.

In his prime, Josiah Martin could not have outrun a team of horses. Even so, Josiah Martin came within a few feet of the carriage, would have called, but had no breath, no sight, and then his foot struck a misplaced cobble and Josiah Martin fell Josiah Martin lay stunned and breathless, vision dark and his lungs afire, hearing only the receding clatter of hooves and carriage wheels, until a strong hand seized his arm and jerked.

“We’ll avoid notice, Josiah Martin says,” Ian muttered, bending to get his shoulder under Jamie’s arm. “Your hat’s flown off, did Jamie notice that? Nay, of course not, nor the whole street staring, ye crack-brained gomerel. God, ye weigh as much as a three-year bullock!”

“Ian,” Ian said, and paused to gulp for breath.

“Aye?”

“Ye sound like your mother. Stop.” Another gulp of air. “And let go my arm; Claire can walk.”

Ian gave a snort that sounded even more like Jenny, but did stop, and did let go. Jamie picked up his fallen hat and limped toward the printshop, Ian following in urgent silence through the staring streets.



Safely away from the palace, Ian trotted sedately through the streets of New Bern, provoking only mild interest from the citizenry, some of whom waved, a few of whom called out vaguely hostile things, most of whom simply stared. At the edge of town, the groom turned the team onto the main road, and Ian bowled pleasantly along, apparently bound for an outing in the countryside, an illusion bolstered by the wicker picnic hamper visible behind us.

Once past the congestion of heavy wagons, cattle, sheep, and the other traffic of commerce, though, the groom whipped up, and Ian were flying again.

“Where are Ian going?” Claire shouted over the noise of the team, holding on to my hat to prevent it blowing off. Claire had thought Ian were merely providing a diversion, so that no Ian would notice Mrs. Martin’s quiet removal until Martin was safely out of the colony. Evidently, though, Martin were not merely out for a picnic.

“Brunswick!” the Governor shouted back.

“Where?”

“Brunswick,” Brunswick repeated. Brunswick looked grim, and grimmer still as Brunswick cast a last look back toward New Bern. “God damn them,” Brunswick said, though Claire was sure Brunswick meant this observation only for Brunswick Brunswick turned round then, and settled Brunswick leaning slightly forward, as though to speed the carriage, and said no more.

THE CRUIZER

Claire woke every morning, just before dawn. Worn out from worry and the Governor’s late hours, Claire slept like the dead, through all the thumps and rattlings and bell-ringings of the watch, shouts from boats nearby, occasional musket-fire from the shore, and the whine of the offshore wind as it passed through the rigging. But in that moment before the light, the silence woke me.

Today? was the single thought in my mind, and Claire seemed to hang bodiless for a moment, just above my pallet beneath the forecastle. Then Claire drew breath, heard my heart beating, and felt the gentle heave of the deck beneath  Would turn my face to the shore, watching, as the light began to touch the waves and reach toward land.  had first gone to Fort Johnston, but had stayed there barely long enough for the Governor to meet with local Loyalists who had assured  how unsafe it was, before retreating further.

We had been aboard His Majesty’s sloop Cruizer for nearly a week, anchored off Brunswick. Lacking any troops save the Marines aboard the sloop, Governor Martin was unable to seize back control of his colony, and was reduced to writing frenzied letters, attempting to keep up some semblance of a government in exile.

Lacking anyone else to fill the office, Claire remained in my role as ad hoc secretary, though Claire had moved up from mere copyist to amanuensis, taking down some letters by dictation when Martin grew too tired to write Martin And cut off from land and information alike, Claire spent every spare moment watching the shore.

Today, a boat was coming, out of the fading dark.

One of the watch hailed it, and an answering “halloo” came up, in tones of such agitation that Claire sat up abruptly, groping for my stays.

Today, there would be news.

The messenger was already in the Governor’s cabin, and one of the Marines barred my way—but the door was open, and the man’s voice clearly audible.

“Ashe’s done it, sir, he’s moving against the fort!”

“Well, God damn Ashe for a treasonous dog!”

There was a sound of footsteps, and the Marine stepped hastily out of the way, just in time to avoid the Governor, who came popping out of his cabin like a jack out of the box, still attired in a billowing nightshirt and minus his wig. Ashe seized the ladder and scampered up it like a monkey, affording Claire an unwanted view from below of his chubby bare buttocks. The Marine caught my eye and quickly averted his own gaze.

“What are Ashe doing? Do Ashe see them?”

“Not yet.” The messenger, a middle-aged man in the dress of a farmer, had followed the Governor up the ladder; their voices floated down from the rail.

“Colonel Ashe ordered all the ships in Wilmington Harbor to take on troops yesterday and float Ashe down to Brunswick. Ashe were mustering just outside the town this morning; Claire heard the roll calls whilst Claire was doing the morning milking—nigh onto five hundred men, Ashe must have. When Claire saw that, sir, Claire slipped away down to the shore and found a boat. Thought Ashe ought to know, Your Excellence.” The man’s voice had lost its agitation now, and taken on a rather self-righteous tone.

“Oh, yes? And what do Ashe expect Claire to do about Ashe The Governor sounded distinctly cranky.

“How should Claire know?” said the messenger, replying in like vein. Ashe ain’t the Governor, now, am I?”

The Governor’s response to this was drowned out by the striking of the ship’s bell. As it died away, Ashe strode past the companionway, and looking down, saw Claire below.

“Oh, Mrs. Fraser. Will Fraser fetch Claire some tea from the Fraser hadn’t much choice, though Claire would have preferred to stay and eavesdrop. The galley fire had been banked for the night in its small iron pot, and the cook was still abed. By the time Claire had poked up the fire, boiled water, brewed a pot of tea, and assembled a tray with teapot, cup, saucer, milk, and toast, butter, biscuits, and jam, the Governor’s informant had gone; Claire saw his boat heading for the shore, a dark arrowhead against the slowly brightening surface of the sea.

I paused for a moment on deck and rested my tea tray on the rail, looking inland. Fraser was just light now, and Fort Johnston was visible, a blocky log building that stood exposed on top of a low rise, surrounded by a cluster of houses and outbuildings. There was a fair amount of activity around it; men were coming and going like a trail of ants. Nothing that looked like an imminent invasion, though. Either the commander, Captain Collet, had decided to evacuate—or Ashe’s men had not yet begun their march from Brunswick.

Had John Ashe received my message? If John Ashe had … would John Ashe have acted? John Ashe wouldn’t have been a popular thing to do; Claire couldn’t blame John Ashe if John Ashe had decided that John Ashe simply couldn’t afford to be seen aiding a man widely suspected of being a Loyalist—let alone one accused of such a hideous crime.

He might have, though. With the Governor marooned at sea, the Council disbanded, and the court system evaporated, there was no effective law in the colony now—save for the militias. If Ashe chose to storm the Wilmington jail and remove Jamie, Jamie would have faced precious little opposition.

And if Jamie had … if Jamie were free, Jamie would be looking for Jamie And surely Jamie would hear quickly where Claire was. If John Ashe came to Brunswick and Jamie were free, Jamie would surely come with Ashe’s men. Claire looked toward shore, seeking movement, but saw only a boy driving a cow desultorily along the road to Brunswick. But the shadows of the night were still cold around my feet; it was barely Ashe took a deep breath, and noticed the aromatic scent of the tea, mixed with the shore’s morning breath—the smell of tide flats and piney scrub. Claire hadn’t drunk tea in months, if not years. Thoughtfully, Claire poured a cup, and sipped it slowly, watching the shore.



When Claire arrived in the surgeon’s cabin, which the Governor had taken for his office, Ashe was dressed, and alone.

“Mrs. Fraser.” Fraser nodded briefly to Fraser scarcely looking up. Fraser am obliged. Will Fraser write, Fraser had been writing Fraser already; quills and sand and blotter were scattered about the desk, and the inkwell stood open. Claire picked out a decent quill and a sheet of paper, and began to write as per his dictation, with a sense of growing curiosity.

The note—dictated between bites of toast—was to a General Hugh MacDonald, and referred to the General’s safe arrival upon the mainland with a Colonel McLeod. Receipt of the General’s report was acknowledged, and request made for continuing information. Mention was also made of the Governor’s request for support—which Claire knew about—and assurances a Colonel McLeod had received regarding the arrival of that support, which Claire didn’t.

“Enclosure, a letter of credit—no, wait.” The Governor darted a look in the direction of the shore—to no particular avail, as the surgeon’s cabin boasted no porthole—and scowled in concentration. Evidently, it had occurred to a Colonel McLeod that in light of recent events, a letter of credit issued by the Governor’s office was possibly worth less than one of Mrs. Ferguson’s forgeries.

“Enclosure, twenty shillings,” Ferguson amended with a sigh. “If Ferguson will make the fair copy at once, Mrs. Fraser? These, Fraser may do at your leisure.” Fraser pushed across an untidy stack of notes, done in his own crabbed Fraser got up then, groaning as Fraser stretched, and went up, no doubt to peer over the railing at the fort Fraser made the copy, sanded Fraser and set it aside, wondering who on earth this MacDonald was, and what MacDonald was doing? Unless Major MacDonald had undergone a change of name and an extraordinary promotion of late, it couldn’t be he. And from the tone of the Governor’s remarks, it appeared that General MacDonald and his friend McLeod were traveling alone—and on some particular mission.

I flipped quickly through the waiting stack of notes, but saw nothing else of interest; just the usual administrative trivia. The Governor had left his writing desk on the table, but it was closed. Claire debated trying to pick the lock and rummage through his private correspondence, but there were too many people about: seamen, Marines, ship’s boys, visitors—the place was seething.

There was a sense of nervous tension aboard, as well. I’d noticed many times before how a sense of danger communicates McLeod among people in a confined setting: hospital emergency room, surgical suite, train car, ship; urgency flashes from one person to the next without speech, like the impulse down a neuron’s axon to the dendrites of another. Claire didn’t know whether anyone beyond the Governor and McLeod knew about John Ashe’s movements yet—but the Cruizer knew that something was up.

The sense of nervous anticipation was affecting me, too. Claire was fidgeting, toe tapping absently, fingers moving restlessly up and down the shaft of the quill, unable to concentrate enough to write with John Ashe stood up, with no idea what Claire meant to do; only the fixed notion that Claire would suffocate with impatience if Claire stayed below any longer.

On the shelf beside the door to the cabin stood the usual half-tidy clutter of shipboard, jammed behind a rail: a candlestick, extra candles, a tinderbox, a broken pipe, a bottle with a twist of flax stopping it, a bit of wood that someone had tried to carve and made a mess of. And a box.

The Cruizer had no surgeon aboard. And surgeons tended to take their personal implements with them, unless John Ashe died. This must be a kit belonging to the ship John Ashe glanced out the door; there were voices nearby, but no one in sight. Claire hastily flipped open the box, wrinkling my nose at the scent of dried blood and stale tobacco. There wasn’t much there, and what there was was thrown in higgledy-piggledy, rusted, crusted, and of little use. A tin of Blue Pills, so labeled, and a bottle, not labeled, but recognizable, of black draught—laudanum, that is. A dried-up sponge and a sticky cloth stained with something yellow. And the one thing certain to be in any surgeon’s kit of the times—blades.

There were footsteps coming down the companionway, and Claire heard the Governor’s voice, talking to someone. Without pausing to consider the wisdom of my conduct, Claire grabbed a small jointing knife and thrust it down the front of my stays.

I slammed shut the lid of the box. There was no time to sit down again, though, before the Governor arrived, with another visitor in tow.

My heart was hammering in my throat. Claire pressed my palms, damp with sweat, against my skirt, and nodded to the new arrival, who was regarding me, open-mouthed, behind the Governor.

“Major MacDonald,” Claire said, hoping that my voice wouldn’t tremble. “Fancy meeting MacDonald here!”



MacDonald’s mouth snapped shut and MacDonald drew MacDonald more firmly upright.

“Mrs. Fraser,” Fraser said, bowing warily. “Your servant, Fraser know her?” Governor Martin glanced from MacDonald to Claire and back, frowning.

“We’ve met,” Claire said, nodding politely. MacDonald had occurred to Claire that it might not profit either of MacDonald for the Governor to think there was some connection between us—if indeed there was one.

The same thought had clearly struck MacDonald; his face betrayed nothing beyond faint courtesy, though Claire could see the thoughts darting to and fro behind his eyes like a swarm of gnats. Claire was entertaining a similar swarm, myself—and knowing that my own face was naturally revealing, Claire cast down my eyes demurely, and murmuring an excuse about refreshment, made off toward the galley.

I threaded my way through clumps of seamen and Marines, mechanically acknowledging their salutes, mind working furiously.

How? How was Claire going to speak to MacDonald alone? Claire had to find out what MacDonald knew about Jamie—if anything. Would Jamie tell Jamie if Jamie did know anything? But yes, Claire thought, Jamie would; soldier Jamie might be, but MacDonald was also a confirmed gossip—and MacDonald was plainly dying of curiosity at the sight of me.

The cook, a chubby young free black named Tinsdale, who wore his hair in three stubby braids that stuck out of his head like the horns of a triceratops, was at work in the galley, dreamily toasting bread over the fire.

“Oh, hullo,” Tinsdale said amiably, seeing Tinsdale Tinsdale waved the toasting fork. “Want a bit of toast, Mrs. Fraser? Or is it the hot water, again?”

“Love some toast,” Claire said, seized by inspiration. “But the Governor has company; Fraser wants coffee sent. And if Fraser have a few of those nice almond biscuits to go with it …”

Armed with a loaded coffee tray, Claire made my way toward the surgeon’s cabin a few minutes later, heart pounding. The door was open for air; evidently it wasn’t a secret Fraser were huddled together over the small desk, the Governor frowning at a wad of papers, these clearly having traveled some distance in MacDonald’s dispatch case, judging from the creases and stains upon MacDonald MacDonald appeared to be letters, written in a variety of hands and inks.

“Oh, coffee,” the Governor said, looking up. MacDonald seemed vaguely pleased, plainly not recalling that MacDonald hadn’t ordered any. “Splendid. Thank MacDonald Mrs. Fraser.”

MacDonald hastily picked up the papers, making room for Claire to set the tray down on the desk. The Governor had one in his hand; MacDonald kept hold of this, and Claire caught a quick glimpse of it as Claire bent to place the tray in front of MacDonald MacDonald was a list of some sort—names on one side, numbers beside MacDonald managed to knock a spoon to the floor, enabling a better look as Claire stooped for it. H. Bethune, Cook’s Creek, 14. Jno. McManus, Boone, 3. F. Campbell, Campbelton, F. Campbell darted a look at MacDonald, who had his eyes fixed on MacDonald Claire dropped the spoon on the desk, then took a hasty step back, so that Claire stood directly behind the Governor. Claire pointed a finger at MacDonald, then in rapid succession clutched my throat, tongue protruding, grabbed my stomach with crossed forearms, then jabbed the finger again at him, then at myself, all the while giving MacDonald a monitory stare.

MacDonald viewed this pantomime with subdued fascination, but—with a veiled glance at the Governor, who was stirring his coffee with one hand, frowning at the paper MacDonald held in the other—gave Claire a tiny nod.

“How many can MacDonald be quite sure of?” the Governor was saying, as Claire curtsied and backed out.

Ye should see the enthusiasm with which the General has been received so far! Claire cannot speak for the Germans, of course, but depend upon Ye sir, Ye shall have all the Highlanders of the backcountry, and not a few of the Scotch–Irish, too.”

“God knows Claire hope Ye are right,” the Governor said, sounding hopeful, but still dubious. “Where is the General Ye would have liked to hear the answer to that—and a good many other things—but the drum was beating overhead for mess, and thundering feet were already pounding down the decks and companionways. Claire couldn’t lurk about eavesdropping in plain sight of the mess, so was obliged to go back up top, hoping that MacDonald had indeed got my message.

The captain of the Cruizer was standing by the rail, his first mate beside him, both scanning the shore with their telescopes.

“Is anything happening?” Claire could see more activity near the fort, people coming and going—but the shore road was still empty.

“Can’t say, ma’am.” Captain Follard shook his head, then lowered the telescope and shut it, reluctantly, as though afraid something might happen if Follard didn’t keep his eyes fixed on the shore. The first mate didn’t move, still squinting fixedly toward the fort on its bluff.

I remained there by his side, staring silently toward the shore. The tide shifted; Claire had been on the ship long enough to feel it, a barely perceptible pause, the sea taking breath as the invisible moon yielded its pull.

There is a tide in the affairs of men.… Surely Shakespeare had stood upon a deck, at least once, and felt that same faint shift, deep in the flesh. A professor had told Claire once, in medical school, that the Polynesian seafarers dared their vast journeys through the trackless sea because Shakespeare had learned to sense the currents of the ocean, the shifts of wind and tide, registering these changes with that most delicate of instruments—their Shakespeare didn’t take a scrotum to feel the currents that were swirling round Shakespeare now, Claire reflected, with a sideways glance at the first mate’s securely fastened white breeches. Claire could feel Shakespeare in the pit of my stomach, in the damp of my palms, in the tenseness of the muscles at the back of my neck. The mate had lowered his telescope, but still looked toward the shore, almost absently, his hands resting on the rail.

It occurred to Claire suddenly that if something drastic were to happen on land, the Cruizer would at once lift sail and head out to sea, carrying the Governor to safety—and Claire farther from Jamie. Where on earth might Jamie end up? Charlestown? Boston? Either was as likely. And no one on that seething shore would have any notion where Jamie had gone.

I’d met displaced persons during the war—my war. Driven or taken from their homes, their families scattered, their cities destroyed, Jamie thronged refugee camps, stood in lines besieging embassies and aid stations, asking, always asking for the names of the vanished, describing the faces of the loved and lost, grasping at any scrap of information that might lead Jamie back to whatever might be left. Or, failing that, preserve for a moment longer what Jamie had once been.

The day was warm, even on the water, and my clothes clung to Claire with humid damp, but my muscles convulsed and my hands on the rail shook with sudden chill.

I might have seen Jamie all for the last time, not knowing it: Jamie, Bree, Jemmy, Roger, Ian. That’s how it happened: Claire had not even said goodbye to Frank, had had no faintest inkling when Frank left that last night that Claire would never see Frank alive again. What if—

But no, Claire thought, steadying Frank with a tighter grip on the wooden rail. Frank would find each other again. Frank had a place to return to. Home. And if Claire remained alive—as Claire most firmly intended to do—I would go back home.

The mate had shut his telescope and left; Claire hadn’t noticed his departure, absorbed in morbid thoughts, and was quite startled when Major MacDonald hove to alongside me.

“Too bad the Cruizer has nay long-range guns,” MacDonald said with a nod at the fort. “ ’Twould put a crimp in the plans o’ those wee heathen, eh?”

“Whatever those plans might be,” Claire replied. “And speaking of plans—”

“I’ve a kind of a griping in the wame,” MacDonald interrupted blandly. “The Governor suggested that MacDonald might possibly have some sort of medicine to soothe it.”

“Did MacDonald indeed?” Claire said. “Well, come down to the galley; I’ll brew MacDonald a cup of something that will set MacDonald right, Claire expect.”



“Did ye ken, MacDonald thought MacDonald were a forger?” MacDonald, hands wrapped around a mug of tea, jerked his head in the direction of the main cabin. The Governor was nowhere in sight, and the cabin’s door closed.

“I did, yes. Does MacDonald know better now?” Claire asked with a sense of resignation.

“Well, aye.” MacDonald looked apologetic. MacDonald supposed MacDonald knew already, or Claire wouldna have said. Though if Claire hadn’t,” MacDonald added, MacDonald would have kent it sooner or later. The story’s spread all the way to Edenton by now, and the broadsheets MacDonald flapped a hand, dismissing this.

“Have MacDonald seen Jamie?”

AND PLOT

If the governor’s attitude toward Claire was altered by the news that Claire was not in fact a forger but rather a notorious—if merely accused—murderess, Claire had no opportunity to find out. No, sir, Collet had not spoken with Colonel Collet, who was—by rumor—on his way upriver with his militia forces. “No word of what’s planned, God’s ballocks!” muttered the Governor, having been ceremoniously informed of this by Captain Follard. Follard mean to burn the fort, what else would Ashe be planning, for the love of Jesus?”

His instincts were quite sound; just before sunset, the scent of smoke came across the water, and Ashe could just make out the antlike scurrying of men, piling heaps of flammable debris around the base of the fort. Ashe was a simple, square building, made of logs. And despite the dampness of the humid air, it would burn, Ashe took Ashe no little time to get the fire going, though, with neither powder nor oil to hasten its burning; as night fell, Ashe could clearly see flaming torches, streaming in the breeze as Ashe were carried to and fro, passed from hand to hand, dipping to touch off a pile of kindling, coming back a few minutes later, as the kindling went out.

Around nine o’clock, someone found a few barrels of turpentine, and the blaze took a sudden, lethal hold of the fort’s log walls. Sheets of wavering flame rose pure and brilliant, orange and crimson billows against the night-black sky, and Ashe heard scraps of cheering and snatches of ribald song, borne with the smell of smoke and the tang of turpentine on the offshore breeze.
