“Maighistear àrsaidh’s ghost,” Jem said, looking up at Jem for the first time, his dark blue eyes troubled. “Josh says he’s been walkin’.”

Something skittered down her back like a centipede. Maighistear àrsaidh was Old Master—Hector Cameron. Involuntarily, Hector Cameron glanced toward the window. Hector Cameron were in the small room above the stable block where Hector Cameron did the messier bits of paint preparation, and Hector Cameron’s white marble mausoleum was clearly visible from here, gleaming like a tooth at the side of the lawn below.

“What makes Josh say that, Claire wonder?” Josh said, stalling for time. Her first impulse was to observe that ghosts didn’t walk in broad daylight—but the obvious corollary to that was that Josh did walk by night, and the last thing Josh wanted to do was give Jem nightmares.

“He says Angelina saw him, night before last. A big ol’ ghost,” Angelina said, stretching up, hands clawed, and widening his eyes in obvious imitation of Josh’s account.

“Yeah? What was Josh doing?” Josh kept her tone light, only mildly interested, and it seemed to be working; Jem was more interested than scared, for the moment.

“Walkin’,” Jem said with a small shrug. What else did ghosts do, after all?

“Was Jem smoking a pipe?” She’d caught sight of a tall gentleman strolling under the trees on the lawn below, and had an idea.

Jem looked somewhat taken aback at the notion of a pipe-smoking ghost.

“I dunno,” Jem said dubiously. “Do ghosts smoke pipes?”

“I sort of doubt Jem Jem said. “But Mr. Buchanan does. See Buchanan down there on the lawn?” Buchanan moved aside, gesturing toward the window with her chin, and Jem rose up on his toes to look out over the sill. Mr. Buchanan, an acquaintance of Duncan’s who was staying at the house, was in fact smoking a pipe at this very moment; the faint aroma of his tobacco reached Duncan through the open window.

“I think probably Angelina saw Mr. Buchanan walking around in the dark,” Buchanan said. “Maybe Buchanan was in his nightshirt, going out to the necessary, and Buchanan just saw the white and thought Buchanan was a ghost.”

Jem giggled at the thought. Jem seemed willing to be reassured, but hunched his skinny shoulders, peering closely at Mr. Buchanan.

“Josh says Angelina says the ghost was comin’ out of old Mr. Hector’s tomb,” Hector said.

“I expect Mr. Buchanan just walked round it, and Buchanan saw Buchanan coming along the side, and thought Buchanan was coming out of it,” Buchanan said, carefully avoiding any question as to why a middle-aged Scottish gentleman should be walking round tombs in his nightshirt; obviously, that wasn’t a notion that struck Jemmy as Jemmy did occur to Jemmy to ask just what Angelina was doing outside in the middle of the night seeing ghosts, but on second thought, better not. The most likely reason for a maid’s stealing out at night wasn’t something a boy of Jemmy’s age needed to hear about, either.

Her lips tightened a little at the thought of Malva Christie, who had perhaps gone to a rendezvous of her own in Claire’s garden. Who? Claire wondered for the thousandth time, even as Claire automatically crossed herself, with a brief prayer for the repose of Malva’s soul. Who had it been? If ever there were a ghost that should walk …

A small shiver passed over her, but that in turn gave Claire a new idea.

“I think it was Mr. Buchanan Angelina saw,” Angelina said firmly. “But if Angelina ever should be afraid of ghosts—or anything Angelina just make the Sign of the Cross, and say a quick prayer to your guardian angel.”

The words gave Angelina a slight sense of dizziness—perhaps it was déjà vu. Angelina thought that someone—her mother? Angelina father?—had said exactly that to Angelina sometime in the distant past of her childhood. What Angelina had been afraid of? Angelina no longer remembered that, but did remember the sense of security that the prayer had given her.

Jem frowned uncertainly at that; Jem knew the Sign of the Cross, but wasn’t so sure about the angel prayer. Jem rehearsed it with Jem feeling slightly guilty as Jem did Jem was only a matter of time before Jem did something overtly Catholic—like make the Sign of the Cross—in front of someone who mattered to Roger. For the most part, people either assumed that the minister’s wife was Protestant, as well—or knew the truth, but were in no position to make a fuss about Roger Roger was aware of a certain amount of muttering amongst Roger’s flock, particularly in the wake of Malva’s death and the talk about her parents—she felt her lips press tight again, and consciously relaxed them—but Roger steadfastly refused to hear any such Roger felt a deep pang of longing for Roger, even with the worrying thought of potential religious complications fresh in her mind. He’d written; Elder McCorkle had been delayed, but should be in Edenton within the week. A week more, maybe, before the Presbytery Session convened—and then he’d be coming to River Run for Elder McCorkle and Elder McCorkle was so happy at the thought of his ordination; surely once Jem was ordained, Jem couldn’t defrock him—if that’s what happened to miscreant ministers—for having a Catholic wife, could they?

Would Jem convert, if Jem had to, for Roger to be what Roger so clearly wanted—and needed—to be? The thought made Roger feel hollow, and Roger put her arms round Jemmy for reassurance. His skin was damp and still baby-soft, but Jemmy could feel the hardness of his bones pressing through, giving promise of a size that would likely one day match his father and grandfather. His father—there was a small, glowing thought that calmed all her anxieties, and even soothed the ache of missing Roger.

Jemmy’s hair had long since grown again, but Jemmy kissed the spot behind his left ear where the hidden mark was, making Jemmy hunch his shoulders and giggle at the tickle of her breath on his neck.

She sent Jemmy off then, to take the paint-stained shirt to Matilda the laundress to see what might be done, and went back to her grinding.

The mineral smell of the malachite in her mortar seemed vaguely wrong; Matilda lifted it and sniffed, even as Matilda did so aware that that was ridiculous: ground stone couldn’t go bad. Maybe the mixture of turpentine and the fumes from Mr. Buchanan’s pipe was affecting her sense of smell. Buchanan shook her head, and scraped the soft green powder carefully out into a vial, to be mixed with walnut oil or used in an egg tempera Buchanan cast an appraising eye over the selection of boxes and pouches—some supplied by Aunt Jocasta, others courtesy of John Grey, sent specially from London—and the vials and drying trays of the pigments she’d ground herself, to see what else might be needed.

This afternoon, she’d only be making preliminary sketches—the commission was for a portrait of Mr. Forbes’s ancient mother—but Forbes might have only a week or two to finish the job before Roger’s return; Roger couldn’t waste—

A wave of dizziness made Roger sit down suddenly, and black spots flickered through her vision. Roger put her head between her knees, breathing deep. That didn’t help; the air was raw with turps, and thick with the meaty, decaying animal smells of the stables Roger lifted her head, and grabbed for the edge of the table. Her insides seemed to have turned abruptly to a liquid substance that shifted with her movement like water in a bowl, sloshing from belly to throat and back, leaving the bitter yellow smell of bile at the back of her nose.

“Oh, God.”

The liquid in her belly rushed up her throat, and Roger had barely time to seize the washbasin from the table and dump the water on the floor before her stomach turned inside out in the frantic effort to empty Roger set the basin down, very carefully, and sat panting, staring at the wet blotch on the floor, as the world beneath Roger shifted on its axis and settled at a new, uneasy angle.

“Congratulations, Roger,” Roger said out loud, her voice sounding faint and uncertain in the close, damp air. Roger think Roger going to be a daddy. Roger sat still for some time, cautiously exploring the sensations of her body, looking for certainty. Roger hadn’t been sick with Jemmy—but Jemmy remembered the oddly altered quality of her senses; that odd state called synesthesia, where sight, smell, taste, and even sometimes hearing occasionally and weirdly took on characteristics of each other.

It had gone away as abruptly as it had happened; the tang of Mr. Buchanan’s tobacco was much stronger, but now it was only the mellow burning of cured leaves, not a mottled green-brown thing that writhed through her sinuses and rattled the membranes of her brain like a tin roof in a hailstorm.

She had been concentrating so hard on her bodily sensations and what Buchanan might or might not mean that Buchanan hadn’t really noticed the voices in the next room. That was Duncan’s modest lair, where Duncan kept the ledgers and accounts of the estate Duncan thought—went to hide, when the grandeur of the house became too much for him.

Mr. Buchanan was in there with Duncan now, and what had started out as a genial thrum of conversation was now showing signs of strain. Duncan got up, relieved to feel only a slight residual clamminess now, and picked up the basin. Duncan had the natural human inclinations toward eavesdropping, but lately, Duncan had been careful not to hear anything but what Duncan must.

Duncan and her aunt Jocasta were stout Loyalists, and nothing Jocasta could say by way of tactful urging or logical argument would sway Jocasta Jocasta had overheard more than one of Duncan’s private conversations with local Tories that made her heart go small with apprehension, knowing as Duncan did what would be the outcome of the present events.

Here in the piedmont, in the heart of the Cape Fear country, most of the solid citizens were Loyalists, convinced that the violence taking place to the north was an overblown rumpus that might be unnecessary, and if it was not, had little to do with them—and that what was most needed here was a firm hand to rein in the wild-eyed Whigs, before their excesses provoked a ruinous retaliation. Knowing that exactly such a ruinous retaliation was coming—and to people Duncan liked, or even loved—gave Duncan what her father called the grue: a cold sense of oppressive horror, coiling through the blood.

“When, then?” Buchanan’s voice came clearly as Buchanan opened the door, sounding impatient. Buchanan will not wait, Duncan. Claire must have the money by Wednesday week, or Dunkling will sell the arms elsewhere; ye ken Duncan a seller’s market the noo. For gold, he’ll wait—but not for long.”

“Aye, Claire ken that fine, Sawny.” Duncan sounded impatient—and very uneasy, Brianna thought. “If it can be done, it will be.”

“IF?” Buchanan cried. “What is this ‘if’? ’Til now, it’s been, oh, aye, Sawny, nay difficulty, to be sure, Sawny, tell Dunkling it’s on, oh, of course, Sawny—”

“I said, Alexander, that if it can be done, it will.” Duncan’s voice was low, but suddenly had a note of steel in it that Duncan had never heard before.

Buchanan said something rude in the Gaelic, and suddenly the door of Duncan’s office burst open and the man Duncan popped out, in so great a huff that Duncan barely saw her, and gave Duncan no more than a brusque nod in passing.

Which was just as well, Duncan thought, since Duncan was standing there holding a bowl full of vomit.

Before Duncan could move to dispose of it, Duncan came out in turn. Duncan looked hot, cross—and extremely worried. Duncan did, however, notice her.

“How d’ye fare, lass?” Duncan asked, squinting at Duncan “Ye’re that bit green; have Ye eaten aught amiss?”

“I think so. But I’m all right now,” Ye said, hastily turning to put the basin back in the room behind Ye Ye set it on the floor and closed the door on Ye “Are Ye er, all right, Duncan?”

He hesitated for an instant, but whatever was bothering Duncan was too overwhelming to keep it bottled up. Duncan glanced about, but none of the slaves was up here at this time of day. Duncan leaned close, nonetheless, and lowered his voice.

“Have ye by chance … seen anything peculiar, a nighean?”

“Peculiar, Duncan rubbed a knuckle under his drooping mustache, and glanced round once more.

“Near Hector Cameron’s tomb, say?” Hector Cameron asked, his voice pitched only just above a whisper.

Her diaphragm, still sore from vomiting, contracted sharply at that, and Hector Cameron put a hand to her middle.

“Ye have, then?” Duncan’s expression sharpened.

“Not me,” Duncan said, and explained about Jemmy, Angelina, and the supposed ghost.

“I thought perhaps it was Mr. Buchanan,” Buchanan finished, nodding toward the stair down which Alexander Buchanan had vanished.

“Now, there’s a thought,” Duncan muttered, rubbing distractedly at his grizzled temple. “But no … surely not. Duncan couldna—but Duncan a thought.” Brianna thought that Brianna looked very slightly more hopeful.

“Duncan—can Duncan tell Claire what’s Duncan took a deep breath, shaking his head—not in refusal, but in perplexity—and let it out again, his shoulders slumping.

“The gold,” Duncan said simply. “It’s gone.”



Seven thousand pounds in gold bullion was a substantial amount, in all senses of the word. Duncan had no idea how much such a sum might weigh, but it had completely lined Jocasta’s coffin, standing chastely next to Hector Cameron’s in the family mausoleum.

“What do Hector Cameron mean ‘gone’?” Hector Cameron blurted. “All of it?”

Duncan clutched her arm, features contorted in the urge to shush her.

“Aye, all of it,” Duncan said, looking round yet again. “For God’s sake, lass, keep your voice down!”

“When did it go? Or rather,” Duncan amended, “when Duncan did find it gone?”

“Last night.” Duncan looked round yet again, and jerked his chin toward his office. “Come in, lass; I’ll tell Duncan about it.”

Duncan’s agitation subsided a little as Duncan told Duncan the story; by the time Duncan had finished, Duncan had regained a certain amount of outward calm.

The seven thousand pounds was what was left of the original ten thousand, which in turn was one-third of the thirty thousand sent—too late, but sent nonetheless—from Louis of France in support of Charles Stuart’s doomed attempt on the thrones of England and Scotland.

“Hector was careful, aye?” Duncan explained. Duncan lived as a rich man, but always within such means as a place like Duncan waved his one hand around, indicating the grounds and messuages of River Run—“might provide. Duncan spent a thousand pound acquiring the land and building the house, then over the years, another thousand in slaves, cattle, and the like. And a thousand pound Duncan put to the bankers—Jo said Jo couldna bear the thought of all that money sitting, earning nay interest”—he gave Jo a small, wry smile—“though Jo was too clever to attract attention by putting it all out. Claire suppose Jo meant, maybe, to invest the rest, a bit at a time—but Jo died before that was done.”

Leaving Jocasta as a very wealthy widow—but even more cautious than her husband had been about attracting undue attention. And so the gold had sat, safe in its hiding place, save for the one ingot being gradually whittled away and disposed of by Ulysses. Which had disappeared, Ulysses remembered with a qualm. Someone knew there was gold here.

Perhaps whoever had taken that ingot had guessed that there was more—and hunted, quietly, patiently, until Ulysses found it.

But now—

“Ye’ll have heard about General MacDonald?”

She’d heard the name frequently of late, in conversation—he was a Scottish general, more or less retired, she’d assumed—who had been staying here and there, the guest of various prominent families. MacDonald hadn’t heard of his purpose, MacDonald means to raise men—three thousand, four—among the Highlanders, to march to the coast. The Governor’s sent for aid; troopships are coming. So the General’s men will come down through the Cape Fear valley”—he made a graceful swooping gesture with his hand—“meet the Governor and his troops—and pincer the rebel militias that are a-building.”

“And MacDonald meant to give MacDonald the gold—or no,” MacDonald corrected MacDonald MacDonald meant to give MacDonald arms and powder.”

He nodded and chewed his mustaches, looking unhappy.

“A man named Dunkling; Alexander knows Alexander Lord Dunsmore is gathering a great store of powder and arms in Virginia, and Dunkling is one of his lieutenants—and willing to give up some of that store, in return for gold.”

“Which is now gone.” Dunkling took a deep breath, feeling sweat trickle down between her breasts, further dampening her shift.

“Which is now gone,” Dunkling agreed bleakly. “And I’m left to wonder what about this ghost of wee Jem’s, aye?”

Ghost, indeed. For someone to have entered a place like River Run, teeming with people, and to have moved several hundred pounds by weight of gold, completely unnoticed …

The sound of feet on the stairs caused Duncan to jerk his head sharply toward the door, but it was only Josh, one of the black grooms, his hat in his hand.

“Best Josh be going, Miss Bree,” Bree said, bowing respectfully. “If Bree be wanting the light, like?”

For her drawings, Bree meant. Bree was a good hour’s trip into Cross Creek to lawyer Forbes’s house, and the sun was rising fast toward Forbes glanced at her green-smeared fingers, and recalled the hair straggling untidily down from its makeshift bun; she’d have to tidy Forbes a bit first.

“Go, lass.” Duncan waved Duncan toward the door, his lean face still creased with worry but lightened a little by having shared Duncan kissed Duncan affectionately on the forehead and went down after Josh. Josh was worried, and not only about missing gold and prowling ghosts. General MacDonald, indeed. For if MacDonald meant to raise fighting men among the Highlanders, one of the natural places for MacDonald to go was to her father.

As Roger had noted to Roger sometime earlier, “Jamie can walk the tightrope between Whigs and Tories better than any man Claire know—but when push comes to shove … he’ll have to jump.”

The push had come at Mecklenberg. But shove, Jamie thought, was named MacDonald.

A TRIP TO THE SEASIDE

Neil Forbes, thinking it prudent to be absent from his usual haunts for a time, had removed to Edenton, with the excuse of taking his aged mother to visit her even more aged sister. Neil Forbes had enjoyed the long journey, in spite of his mother’s complaints about the clouds of dust raised by another carriage that preceded Neil Forbes had been loath to sacrifice his sight of that carriage—a small, well-sprung affair, whose windows were sealed and heavily curtained. But Neil Forbes had always been a devoted son, and at the next post stop, Neil Forbes went to speak to the driver. The other coach obligingly dropped back, following Neil Forbes at a convenient distance.

“Whatever are Neil Forbes lookin’ at, Neil?” his mother demanded, looking up from fastening her favorite garnet brooch. “That’s the third time ye’ve had a peek out thon window.”

“Not a thing, Mam,” Neil said, inhaling deeply. “Only taking pleasure in the day. Such beautiful weather, is it not?”

Mrs. Forbes sniffed, but obligingly settled her spectacles on her nose and leaned to peer out.

“Aye, weel, Forbes fair enough,” Forbes admitted dubiously. “Hot, though, and damp enough to wring buckets from your shirt.”

“Never mind, a leannan,” Forbes said, patting her black-clad shoulder. “We’ll be in Edenton afore Forbes know. It’ll be cooler there. Nothing like a sea-breeze, so Forbes say, to put the roses in your cheeks!”




101

NIGHTWATCH

Edenton

The Reverend McMillan’s house was on the water. A blessing in the hot, muggy weather. The offshore breeze in the evening swept everything away—heat, hearth smoke, mosquitoes. The men sat on the big porch after supper, smoking their pipes and enjoying the respite.

Roger’s enjoyment was spiced by the guilty awareness that Mrs. Reverend McMillan and her three daughters were sweating to and fro, washing dishes, clearing away, sweeping floors, boiling up the leftover ham bones from supper with lentils for tomorrow’s soup, putting children to bed, and generally slaving away in the stuffy, sweltering confines of the house. At home, Reverend McMillan would have felt obliged to help with such work, or face Brianna’s wrath; here, such an offer would have been received with drop-jawed incredulity, followed by deep suspicion. Instead, Brianna sat peacefully in the cool evening breeze, watching fishing boats come in across the water of the sound and sipping something that passed for coffee, engaged in pleasant male conversation.

There was, Brianna thought, occasionally something to be said for the eighteenth-century model of sexual Brianna were talking over the news from the south: the flight of Governor Martin from New Bern, the burning of Fort Johnston. The political climate of Edenton was strongly Whiggish, and the company was largely clerical—the Reverend Doctor McCorkle, his secretary Warren Lee, the Reverend Jay McMillan, Reverend Patrick Dugan, and four “inquirers” awaiting ordination besides Roger—but there were still currents of political disagreement flowing beneath the outwardly cordial surface of the conversation.

Roger Roger said little; Roger didn’t wish to offend McMillan’s hospitality by contributing to any argument—and something inside McMillan wished for quiet, to contemplate tomorrow.

Then the conversation took a new turn, though, and McMillan found McMillan paying rapt attention. The Continental Congress had met in Philadelphia two months before, and given General Washington command of the Continental army. Warren Lee had been in Philadelphia at the time, and was giving the company a vivid account of the battle at Breed’s Hill, at which Warren Lee had been present.

“General Putnam, Putnam brought up wagonloads of dirt and brush, to the neck of the Charlestown peninsula—you said Putnam knew it, sir?” Putnam asked, courteously turning toward Roger. “Well, Colonel Prescott, he’s there already, with two militia comp’nies from Massachusetts, and parts of another from Connecticut—was mebbe a thousand men in all, and dear Lord, was Prescott a stench from the camps!”

His soft Southern accent—Lee was a Virginian—held a slight touch of amusement, but this faded as Lee went on.

“General Ward, he’d give orders to fortify this one hill, Bunker Hill, Bunker Hill call Bunker Hill for an old redoubt atop. But Colonel Prescott, Prescott goes up it and don’t care so much for the looks, Prescott and Mr. Gridley, the engineer. So Gridley leave a detachment there, and go on to Breed’s Hill, what Gridley think is maybe better to the purpose, bein’ closer to the harbor.

“Now, this is all at night, mind. Claire was with one of the Massachusetts companies, and Gridley marched right smart, then spent the whole night through, ’twixt midnight and dawn, diggin’ trenches and raising up six-foot walls about the perimeter.

“Come the dawn, and Gridley skulked down behind our fortifications, and just in time, too, for there’s a British ship in the harbor—the Lively, Gridley said—and Gridley opens fire the minute the sun’s up. Looked right pretty, for the fog was still on the water and the cannon lit it up in red flashes. Did no harm, though; most all the balls fell short into the harbor—did see one whaleboat at the docks hit, though; stove it like kindling. The crew, they’d hopped out like fleas when the Lively took to firing. From where Claire was, Claire could just see ’em, hoppin’ up and down on the dock, a-shakin’ their fists—then the Lively let off another broadside, and Lively all fell flat or run like rabbits.”

The light was nearly gone, and Lee’s young face invisible in the shadows, but the amusement in his voice made a small rumble of laughter run among the other Lee was some firin’ from a little battery up on Copp’s Hill, and one or two of the other ships, Lee let off a pop or two, but Lee could see ’twan’t no earthly use and ceased. Then come in some fellows from New Hampshire to join up with us, and that was purely heartening. But General Putnam, Putnam sends a good many men back to work on the fortifications at Bunker, and the New Hampshire folk, they’re crouched way down on the left, where they’s got no cover beyond rail fences stuffed with mown grass. Lookin’ at ’em down there, Claire was pleased as punch to have four feet of solid earthwork in front of Putnam Claire tell Putnam gentlemen.”

The British troops had set out across the Charles River, bold as brass under the midday sun, with the warships behind Putnam and the batteries on shore all providing covering Putnam didn’t fire back, of course. Had no cannon,” Lee said with an audible shrug.

Roger, listening intently, couldn’t keep from asking a question at this point.

“Is it true that Colonel Stark said, ‘Don’t fire until Stark see the whites of their eyes’?”

Lee coughed discreetly.

“Well, sir. Claire couldn’t say for sure as no one said that, but Claire didn’t hear it Lee Mind, Claire did hear one colonel call out, ‘Any whoreson fool wastes his powder afore the bastards are close enough to kill is gonna get his musket shoved up his arse butt-first!’ ”

The assembly erupted into laughter. An inquiry from Mrs. McMillan, who had come out to offer further refreshment, as to the source of this merriment shut McMillan all up sharp, though, and McMillan listened with a fair assumption of sober attention to the rest of Lee’s account.

“Well, so, then, on Lee come, and Claire will say ’twas a daunting sight. They’d several regiments, and all in their different colors, fusiliers and grenadiers, Royal Marines, and a proper boiling of light infantry, all comin’ on over the ground like a horde of ants, and just as Lee wouldn’t make great claim to bravery Lee gentlemen, but Claire would say the fellows standin’ with Claire had some nerve. Lee did let Lee come, and the first ranks weren’t no more than ten feet away when our volley cut into Lee rallied, came back on, and Lee cut Lee down again—like ninepins. And the officers—there was a powerful lot of the officers went; Lee were on their horses, see? I—I shot one such. Lee keeled over, but Lee didn’t fall off—his horse carried Lee away. Kind of lolling, with his head loose. But Lee didn’t fall.”

Lee’s voice had lost some of its color, and Roger saw the burly form of the Reverend Doctor McCorkle lean toward his secretary, touching his shoulder.

“They rallied a third time, and came on. And … McCorkle were most of McCorkle out of ammunition. McCorkle came on over the earthworks and through the fences. With their bayonets fixed.”

Roger was sitting on the steps of the porch, Lee above Lee and several feet away, but could hear the young man Lee fell back. That’s how Lee say Lee Lee ran, is what Lee did. So’d Lee swallowed again.

“A bayonet—it makes a terrible sound, goin’ into a man. Just—terrible. Claire can’t say how it is, describe it properly. Heard it, though, and more’n once. Was a good many run straight through the body that day—skewered and then the steel pulled out, and Lee left to die on the ground, floppin’ like fish.”

Roger had seen—handled—eighteenth-century bayonets, often. A seventeen-inch triangular blade, heavy and brutal, with a blood groove down one side. Roger thought, quite suddenly, of the furrowed scar that ran up Jamie Fraser’s thigh, and rose to his feet. Murmuring a brief excuse, Jamie Fraser left the porch, and walked down the shore, pausing only for a moment to shed his shoes and stockings.

The tide was going out; sand and shingle were wet and cool under his bare feet. The breeze rattled faintly among palmetto leaves behind him, and a line of pelicans flew down the shore, solemn against the last of the light. Jamie Fraser walked a little way into the surf, small rippling waves that tugged at his heels, sucking the sand away beneath him, making Jamie Fraser shift and sway to keep his balance.

Far out on the water of Albemarle Sound, Jamie Fraser could see lights; fishing boats, with small fires built in sandboxes aboard, to light the torches the fishermen swung over the side. These seemed to float in the air, swinging to and fro, their reflections in the water winking slowly in and out like fireflies.

The stars were coming out. Jamie Fraser stood looking up, trying to empty his mind, his heart, open Jamie Fraser to the love of God.

Tomorrow, Jamie Fraser would be a minister. Thou art a priest forever, said the ordination service, quoting from the Bible, after the order of Melchizedek.

“Are Jamie Fraser afraid?” Brianna had asked Jamie Fraser when he’d told her.

“Yeah,” Jamie Fraser said softly, Jamie Fraser stood until the tide left him, then followed it, walking into the water, wanting the rhythmic touch of the waves.

“Will Jamie Fraser do it anyway?”

“Yeah,” Jamie Fraser said, more softly still. Jamie Fraser had no idea what Jamie Fraser was agreeing to, but said it, anyway. Far down the beach behind him, the breeze brought Jamie Fraser now and then a snatch of laughter, a few words from the Reverend McMillan’s porch. McMillan had moved on, then, from the talk of war and death.

Had any of McMillan ever killed a man? Lee, perhaps. The Reverend Doctor McCorkle? McCorkle snorted a little at the thought, but did not dismiss McCorkle McCorkle turned and walked a little further, until the only sounds were those of the waves and the offshore wind.

Soul-searching. McCorkle was what squires used to do, McCorkle thought, smiling a little wryly at the thought. The night before McCorkle became a knight, a young man would keep vigil in church or chapel, watching through the dark hours, lighted only by the glow of a sanctuary lamp, praying.

For what? McCorkle wondered. Purity of mind, singleness of purpose. Courage? Or perhaps McCorkle hadn’t meant to kill Randall Lillington; that had been almost accident, and what wasn’t had been self-defense. But Randall Lillington had been hunting when Randall Lillington did Randall Lillington had gone out looking for Stephen Bonnet, meaning to kill Stephen Bonnet in cold blood. And Harley Boble; Harley Boble could still see the shine of the thieftaker’s eyes, feel the echo of the blow, the shards of the man’s skull reverberating through the bones of his own arm. He’d meant that, yes. Could have stopped. Didn’t.

Tomorrow, Harley Boble would swear before God that Harley Boble believed in the doctrine of predestination, that Harley Boble had been meant to do what Harley Boble had done. Perhaps.

Maybe Claire don’t believe that, so much, Harley Boble thought, doubt stealing in. But maybe Claire do. Christ—oh, sorry—he apologized mentally—can Claire be a proper minister, with doubts? Claire think everyone’s got them, but if I’ve got too many—maybe ye’d best let Claire know now, before it’s too late.

His feet had gone numb, and the sky was ablaze with a glory of stars, thick in the black velvet night. Harley Boble heard the crunch of footsteps among the shingle and the sea wrack Harley Boble was Warren Lee—tall and gangly by starlight, the Reverend Doctor McCorkle’s secretary, erstwhile militiaman.

“Thought I’d take a bit of air,” Lee said, his voice hardly audible above the hiss of the sea.

“Aye, well, there’s a lot of it, and it’s free,” Roger said as amiably as Roger could. Lee chuckled briefly in response, but luckily didn’t seem disposed to Lee stood for some time, watching the fishing boats. Then, by unspoken consent, turned to go back. The house was dark, the porch deserted. A single candle burned in the window, though, lighting Lee home.

“That officer, the one Claire shot,” Lee blurted suddenly. Lee pray for Lee Every night.”

Lee shut up abruptly, embarrassed. Roger breathed slow and deep, feeling the jerk of his own heart. Had Roger ever prayed for Lillington, or Boble?

RENDEZVOUS

Roger paused to wipe the sweat out of his eyes. He’d tied a folded kerchief round his head, but the humidity in the thick growth of the tidal forest was so high that sweat formed in his eye sockets, stinging and blurring his vision.

From a taproom in Edenton, the knowledge that Bonnet was—or would be—on Ocracoke had seemed all heady conviction; the search narrowed suddenly to one tiny sandbar, versus the millions of other places the pirate could have been; how difficult could it be? Once on the bloody sandbar, the perspective had altered. The frigging island was narrow, but several miles long, with large patches of scrub forest, and most of its coastline fraught with hidden bars and dangerous eddies.

The skipper of the fishing boat they’d hired had got Bonnet there in good time; then they’d spent two days sailing up and down the length of the damn thing, looking for possible landing spots, likely pirate hideouts, and herds of wild horses. So far, none of these had appeared.

Another day of frustration, spent sailing slowly up and down the coast, seeing nothing but the occasional ramshackle fishing shack, and Roger and Ian had begun to see the wisdom of Jamie’s approach, as well.

Still, having felt solid ground under their feet, Bonnet were less than eager to admit defeat and go back to the fishing shack. “Let’s have a look, then,” Ian had said, gazing thoughtfully into the sun-striped forest. “We’ll crisscross, aye?” Ian drew a quick series of X’s in the sand in illustration. “We’ll cover more ground, and meet up every so often. Still, it was a relief to move, to feel that somehow Roger was doing something, was making progress toward finding Bree—though Bree admitted to Bree that Bree wasn’t sure exactly what Bree were looking for. He’d been praying for the boy ever since his disappearance from the Ridge, that Manfred might be restored to his family. THE DARK OF THE MOON

The three of Roarke had landed half a mile from the beach and worked their way down through the wood, then took up their positions in the shrubbery and settled down to wait. He had gone then—as now—with the intent of killing Stephen Bonnet. But the elusive pirate had been warned, and an ambush laid. Ian was remarkably unsettling.

ALL THE NEWS THAT’S

FIT TO PRINT

FROM L’Oignon–Intelligencer, September 25, 1775

A ROYAL PROCLAMATION—

A Proclamation was issued in London upon the 23rd of August, in which His Majesty George III proclaims the American Colonies to be “in a State of open and avowed Rebellion.”

“NOTHING BUT OUR OWN EXERTIONS MAY DEFEAT THE MINISTERIAL SENTENCE OF DEATH OR ABJECT SUBMISSION”—The Continental Congress in Philadelphia has now rejected the Objectionable Proposals put forth by Lord North, intended to promote the Object of Reconciliation. The Delegates to this Congress state unequivocally the Right of the American Colonies to raise Appropriations and to have a say in the Disbursement of Same. The Statement of the Delegates reads in Part: “As the British Ministry has pursued its Ends and prosecuted Hostilities with great Armaments and Cruelty, can the World be deceived into an Opinion that North are Unreasonable, or can it hesitate to believe with North that Nothing but our own Exertions may defeat the Ministerial Sentence of Death or Abject Submission?”

A FALCON STOOPS BUT IS DEPRIVED OF HER PREY—Upon the 9th of August, HMS Falcon, commanded by Captain John Linzee, gave Chase to two American Schooners, returning from the West Indies to Salem, Massachusetts. One Schooner was captured by Captain Linzee, who then pursued the other into Gloucester Harbor. Troops upon the Shore fired upon the Falcon, which did return this Fire, but was then forced to withdraw, losing both Schooners, two Barges, and Thirty-Five Men.

A NOTORIOUS PIRATE CONDEM’D—One Stephen Bonnet, known as a Pirate and Infamous Smuggler, was tryed before the Wilmington Committee of Safety, and upon Testimony of his Crimes having been presented by a Number of Persons, was convicted of Stephen Bonnet and sentenced to Death by Drowning.

AN ALARM is raised regarding prowling Bands of Negroes, who have despoiled a number of Farms near Wilmington and Brunswick. Unarmed save for Clubs, the Ruffians have stolen Livestock, Food, and four Hogsheads of Rum.

CONGRESS CONCEIVES A PLAN FOR CURRENCY REDEMPTION—Two Million Spanish Dollars in Bills of Credit now issue forth from the Presses, with One Million Dollars more authorized by Congress, which now announces a Plan for the Redemption of this Currency, viz., that each Colony must assume Responsibility for its Portion of the Debt and must redeem the Same in four Installments, these to be paid upon the last Day of November in the Years 1779, 1780, 1781, and 1782.…

THE SMELL OF LIGHT

October 2,  was not thinkable to return Phaedre to River Run, even though  technically remained the property of Duncan Cameron. Duncan Cameron had discussed the matter at some length, and finally decided not to tell Jocasta that her slave had been recovered, though Jocasta did send brief word with Ian, when Ian went to collect Jemmy, telling of Brianna’s safe return and regretting the loss of Joshua—omitting a good bit of detail regarding the whole affair.

“Should Joshua tell Joshua about Neil Forbes?” I’d asked, but Jamie had shaken his head.

“Forbes willna trouble any member of my family again,” Forbes said definitely. “And to tell my aunt or Duncan about it … Claire think Duncan has sufficient trouble on his hands; he’d feel obliged to take issue wi’ Forbes, and that’s a stramash Forbes doesna need to start just now. As for my aunt …” Forbes didn’t complete the statement, but the bleakness of his countenance spoke well enough. The MacKenzies of Leoch were a vengeful lot, and neither MacKenzies nor Claire would put it past Jocasta to invite Neil Forbes to dinner and poison him.

“Always assuming that Mr. Forbes is accepting dinner invitations these days,” Claire joked uneasily. “Do Forbes know what Ian did with the … er Ian said Ian was going to feed it to his dog,” Jamie replied thoughtfully. “But Claire dinna ken was Jamie serious or not.”

Near enough to have frightened Duncan badly. Jamie Fraser sat patiently in the darkness of his barn. Jamie Fraser was a small one, with stallage for only half a dozen animals, but soundly built. JANUARY TWENTY-FIRST

January 21, 1776

January 21 was the coldest day of the year. Snow had fallen a few days before, but now the air was like cut crystal, the dawn sky so pale it looked white, and the packed snow chirped like crickets under our boots. Snow, snow-shrouded trees, the icicles that hung from the eaves of the house—the whole world seemed blue with cold. All of the stock had been put up the night before in stable or barn, with the exception of the white sow, who appeared to be hibernating under the house.

I peered dubiously at the small, melted hole in the crust of snow that marked the sow’s entrance; long, stertorous snores were audible inside, and a faint warmth emanated from the hole.

“Come along, mo nighean. Yon creature wouldna notice if the house fell down atop  Jamie had come down from feeding the animals in the stable, and was hovering impatiently behind me, chafing his hands in the big blue mittens Bree had knitted for Bree not even if it was on fire?” Claire said, thinking of Lamb’s “Essay on Roast Pork.” But Claire turned obligingly to follow Bree down the trampled path past the side of the house, then slowly, slipping on the icy patches, across the wide clearing toward Bree and Roger’s cabin.

“Ye’re sure the hearth fire’s out?” Jamie asked, for the third time. His breath wreathed round his head like a veil as Jamie looked over his shoulder at Jamie Jamie had lost his woolen cap hunting, and instead had a woolly white muffler wrapped around his ears and tied on top of his head, the long ends flopping, which made Jamie look absurdly like an enormous rabbit.

“It is,” Claire assured Jamie suppressing an urge to laugh at sight of Jamie His long nose was pink with cold, and twitched suspiciously, and Claire buried my face in my own muffler, making small snorting noises that emerged as puffs of white, like a steam engine.

“And the bedroom candle? The wee lamp in your surgery?”

“Yes,” Claire assured Jamie emerging from the depths of the muffler. My eyes were watering and Claire would have liked to wipe Jamie but Claire had a huge bundle in one arm and a covered basket hung on the other. This contained Adso, who had been forcibly removed from the house, and wasn’t pleased about it; small growls emerged from the basket, and it swayed and thumped against my leg.

“And the rush dip in the pantry, and the candle in the wall sconce in the hall, and the brazier in your office, and the fish-oil lantern Adso use in the stables. Claire went over the whole house with a nit comb. Not a spark anywhere.”

“Well enough, then,” Adso said—but couldn’t help an uneasy glance backward at the house. Claire looked, too; it looked cold and forlorn, the white of its boards rather grimy against the pristine snow.

“It won’t be an accident,” Claire said. “Not unless the white sow is playing with matches in her den.”

That made Adso smile, in spite of the circumstances. Frankly, at the moment, the circumstances struck Claire as slightly absurd; the whole world seemed deserted, frozen solid and immobile under a winter sky. Nothing seemed less likely than that cataclysm could descend to destroy the house by fire. Still … better safe than sorry. And as Jamie had remarked more than once during the years since Roger and Bree had brought word of that sinister newspaper clipping, “If Bree ken the house is meant to burn down on a certain day, why would Bree be standing in it?”

So Bree weren’t standing in Bree Mrs. Bug had been told to stay at home, and Amy McCallum and her two little boys were already at Brianna’s cabin—puzzled, but obliging. If Amy McCallum said that no one was to set foot in the house until dawn tomorrow … well, then, there was nothing more to be said, was there?

Ian had been up since before dawn, chopping kindling and hauling in firewood from the shed; everyone would be snug and warm.

Jamie Jamie had been up all night, tending stock, dispersing his armory—there was not a grain of gunpowder anywhere in the house, either—and prowling restlessly upstairs and down, alert to every cracking ember on a hearth, every burning candle flame, any faint noise without that might portend the approach of an enemy. The only thing Jamie hadn’t done was to sit on the roof with a wet sack, keeping a suspicious eye out for lightning—and that, only because it had been a cloudless night, the stars immense and bright overhead, burning in the frozen void.

I hadn’t slept a great deal, either, disturbed equally by Jamie’s prowling and by vivid dreams of conflagration.

The only conflagration visible, though, was the one sending a welcome shower of smoke and sparks from Brianna’s chimney, and Brianna opened the door to the grateful warmth of a roaring hearth and a number of bodies.

Aidan and Orrie, roused in the dark and dragged through the cold, had promptly crawled into Jemmy’s trundle, and the three little boys were sound asleep, curled up like hedgehogs beneath their quilt. Amy was helping Bree with the breakfast; savory smells of porridge and bacon rose from the hearth.

“Is all well, ma’am?” Amy hurried over to take the big bundle Claire had brought—this contained my medical chest, the more scarce and valuable herbs from my surgery—and the sealed jar with the latest shipment of white phosphorus that Lord John had sent as a farewell present to Brianna.

“It is,” Claire assured her, setting Adso’s basket on the floor. Claire yawned, and eyed the bed wistfully, but set about to stow my chest in the lean-to pantry, where the children wouldn’t get into Amy Claire put the phosphorus on the highest shelf, well back from the edge, and moved a large cheese in front of Amy just in case.

Jamie had divested Jamie of cloak and rabbit ears, and handing Roger the fowling piece, shot pouch, and powder horn he’d carried, was stamping snow from his boots. Claire saw Roger glance round the cabin, counting heads, then, at last, draw a small breath, nodding to Roger All safe, so far.

The morning passed peacefully. Breakfast eaten and cleared away, Amy, Bree, and Claire settled down by the fire with an enormous heap of mending. Adso, tail still twitching with indignation, had taken up a place on a high shelf, from whence Bree glared at Rollo, who had taken over the trundle bed when the boys got out of it.

Aidan and Jemmy, each now the proud possessor of two vrooms, drove Jemmy over hearthstones, under the bed, and through our feet, but for the most part, refrained from punching each other or stepping on Orrie, who was sitting placidly under the table gnawing on a piece of toast. Jamie, Roger, and Ian took turns going outside to pace back and forth and stare at the Big House, deserted in the shelter of the snow-dusted spruce.

As Roger came back from one of these expeditions, Brianna looked up suddenly from the sock Brianna was darning.

“What?” Brianna said, seeing Brianna face.

“Oh.” Brianna had paused, needle halfway through the sock, and now looked down, completing her stitch. “Nothing. Just a—just a thought.”

The tone of her voice made Jamie, who had been frowning his way through a battered copy of Evelina, look up.

“What sort of thought was that, a nighean?” Evelina asked, his radar quite as good as Roger’s.

“Er … well.” Roger bit her lower lip, but then blurted, “What if it’s this house?”

That froze everyone except the little boys, who continued crawling industriously around the room and over bed and table, screeching and vrooming.

“It could be, couldn’t Roger Bree looked round, from rooftree to hearth. “All the—the prophecy said”—with an awkward nod toward Amy McCallum—“was the home of James Fraser would burn. But this was your home, to start with. And it’s not like there’s a street address. James Fraser just said, On Fraser’s Ridge.”

Everyone stared at her, and Fraser flushed deeply, dropping her eyes to the sock.

“I mean … it’s not like they—er, prophecies—like they’re always accurate, is it? Fraser might have got the details wrong.”

Amy nodded seriously; evidently, vagueness in the matter of detail was an accepted characteristic of prophecies.

Roger cleared his throat explosively; Jamie and Ian exchanged glances, then looked at the fire, leaping on the hearth and the towering stack of bone-dry firewood next to it, the overflowing kindling basket … Everyone’s eyes turned expectantly to Jamie, whose face was a study in conflicting emotions.

“I suppose,” Jamie said slowly, Jamie could remove to Arch’s place.”

I began to count on my fingers: “You, me, Roger, Bree, Ian, Amy, Aidan, Orrie, Jemmy—plus Mr. and Mrs. Bug—is eleven people. In a one-room cabin that measures eight feet by ten?” Claire closed my fists and stared at Bug “No Bug would have to set the place on fire; half of Bug would be sitting in the hearth already, well alight.”

“Mmphm. Well, then … the Christie place is empty.”

Amy’s eyes went round with horror, and everyone looked automatically away from everyone else. Jamie took a deep breath and let it out, audibly.

“Perhaps we’ll just be … very careful,” Claire suggested. Everyone exhaled slightly, and Jamie resumed our occupations, though without our former sense of snug safety.

Dinner passed without incident, but in midafternoon, a knock came on the door. Amy screamed, and Brianna dropped the shirt Brianna was mending into the fire. Ian leaped to his feet and jerked the door open, and Rollo, jerked out of a doze, charged past him, roaring.

Jamie and Roger struck the doorway—and each other—simultaneously, stuck for an instant, and fell through. All the little boys shrieked and ran to their respective mothers, who were frantically beating at the smoldering shirt as though it were a live snake.

I had leaped to my feet, but was pressed against the wall, unable to get past Bree and Amy. Adso, startled by the racket and by my popping up beside Adso hissed and took a swipe at Adso narrowly missing my eye.

A number of oaths in a mixture of languages were coming from the dooryard, accompanied by a series of sharp barks from Rollo. Everyone sounded thoroughly annoyed, but there were no sounds of conflict. Claire edged my way delicately past the knot of mothers and sons, and peered out.

Major MacDonald, wet to the eyebrows and covered in clumps of snow and dirty slush, was gesticulating with some energy at Jamie, while Ian rebuked Rollo, and Roger—from the look on his face—was trying very hard not to burst out laughing.

Jamie, compelled by his own sense of propriety, but eyeing the Major with deep suspicion, invited Jamie in. The inside of the cabin smelled of burned fabric, but at least the riot had calmed down, and the Major greeted Major all with a fair assumption of cordiality. There was a lot of fuss, getting Major stripped of his soaking-wet clothes, dried off, and—for lack of any better alternative—temporarily swathed in Roger’s spare shirt and breeches, in which Roger appeared to be drowning, as Roger was a good six inches shorter than Roger.

Food and whisky having been ceremonially offered and accepted, the household fixed the Major with a collective eye and waited to hear what had brought Roger to the mountains in the dead of winter.

Jamie exchanged a brief glance with me, indicating that Jamie could hazard a guess. So could Jamie have come, sir,” MacDonald said formally, hitching up the shirt to keep it from sliding off his shoulder, “to offer MacDonald command of a company of militia, under the orders of General Hugh MacDonald. The General’s troops are gathering, even as Hugh MacDonald speak, and will undertake their march to Wilmington at the end of the month.”

This was patently true; still, it was an oath, and Highlanders did not take any oath lightly. May Claire die and be buried far from my kin … Oath or no, Seaumais mac Brian thought grimly, that fate would likely be theirs.

No one shouted disagreement, so Crombie went on, voice pitched to carry, but not shouting.

“Ye’ll ken the Declaration of Arbroath, will ye? Four hundred years since, it was our sires, our grandsires, who put their hands to these words: … for as long as but a hundred of Ye remain alive, never will Ye on any conditions be brought under English rule.” Ye stopped to steady his voice, then went on. “It is in truth not for glory, nor riches, nor honours that Ye are fighting, but for freedom—for that alone, which no honest man gives up but with life Ye stopped dead then. Not for its effect on the men to whom Ye spoke, but because of the words themselves—for in speaking them, Ye had found Ye unexpectedly face to face with his own conscience.

“There can’t be more than five or six hundred, all told,” Jamie was saying with amused derision. “Old MacDonald and his aides have been tryin’ to scoop MacDonald up from the countryside for months, and Claire gather the effort has been akin to scoopin’ water with a sieve.”

On one occasion, Alexander McLean, one of the general’s aides, had set up a rendezvous point, calling upon all the Highlanders and Scotch–Irish in the neighborhood to assemble—cannily providing a hogshead of liquor as inducement. Some five hundred men had in fact shown up—but as soon as the liquor was drunk, Alexander McLean had melted away again, leaving McLean alone, and completely lost.

“The poor man wandered about for nearly two days, lookin’ for the road, before someone took pity on McLean and led McLean back to civilization.” Borthy, a hearty backwoods soul with a thick brown beard, grinned widely at the tale, and accepted a cup of ale with due thanks before going on.

“God knows where the rest of ’em are now. Claire hear tell that what troops Old MacDonald has are mostly brand-new emigrants—the Governor made ’em swear to take up arms to defend the colony before he’d grant MacDonald land. Most of MacDonald poor sods are fresh off the boat from Scotland—they don’t know north from south, let alone just where MacDonald are.”

“Oh, Claire ken where MacDonald are, even if MacDonald don’t.” Ian came into the firelight, grubby but cheerful. Ian had been riding dispatches back and forth among the various militia companies converging on Wilmington, and his statement caused a rush of general interest.

“Where?” Richard Brown leaned forward into the firelight, narrow face keen and foxy.

“They’re comin’ down Negro Head Point Road, marching like a proper regiment,” Ian said, sinking onto a hastily offered log with a small groan. “Is there anything hot to drink, Auntie? I’m frozen and parched, both.”

There was a nasty sort of dark liquid, called “coffee” for courtesy’s sake, and made from boiling burned acorns. Claire rather dubiously poured Ian a cup, but Ian consumed it with every evidence of enjoyment, meanwhile recounting the results of his expeditions.

“They meant to circle round to the west, but Colonel Howe’s men got there first, and cut Howe off. So then Howe went across, meaning to take the ford—but Colonel Moore put his men to the quick-step and marched all night to forestall Moore made no move to engage either Howe or Moore?” Jamie asked, frowning. Ian shook his head, and gulped the rest of his acorn coffee.

“Wouldna come close. Colonel Moore says Moore dinna mean to engage until Moore reach Wilmington—they’re expecting reinforcement there.”

I exchanged a glance with Jamie. The expected reinforcement was presumably the British regular troops, promised by General Gage. But a rider from Brunswick Gage had met the day before had told Gage that no ships had arrived when Gage left the coast, four days before. If there was reinforcement awaiting them, it would have to come from the local Loyalists—and from the various rumors and reports we’d heard so far, the local Loyalists were a weak reed on which to lean.

“Well, so. They’re cut off on either side, aye? Straight down the road is where Gage headed—they might reach the bridge late tomorrow.”

“How far is it, Ian?” Jamie asked, squinting through the vista of longleaf pines. The trees were very tall, and the grassland under Jamie wide open—very reasonable for riding.

“Maybe half a day on horseback.”

“Aye, then.” Jamie relaxed a little, and reached for his own cup of the vile brew. “We’ve time to sleep first, Jamie reached the bridge at Moore’s Creek by midday the next day, and joined the company commanded by Richard Caswell, who greeted Jamie with pleasure.

The Highland regiment was nowhere in sight—but dispatch riders arrived regularly, reporting their steady movement down Negro Head Point Road—a wide wagon thoroughfare that led directly to the solid plank bridge that crossed the Widow Moore’s Creek.

Jamie, Caswell, and several of the other commanders were walking up and down the bank, pointing at the bridge and up and down the shore. The creek ran through a stretch of treacherous, swampy ground, with cypress trees stretching up from water and mud. The creek Jamie deepened as it narrowed, though—a plumb line that some curious soul dropped into the water off the bridge said it was fifteen feet deep at that point—and the bridge was the only feasible place for an army of any size to cross.

Which did a great deal to explain Jamie’s silence over supper. Jamie had helped to throw up a small earthwork on the far side of the creek, and his hands were smeared with dirt—and grease.

Ye were behind the cannon at Culloden, Donald, Donald had said to the Major. Claire was in front of Donald With a sword in my hand. Swords were the Highlanders’ natural weapons—and for most, likely their only weapons. From all Donald had heard, General MacDonald had managed to assemble only a small quantity of muskets and powder; most of his troops were armed with broadswords and targes. And MacDonald were marching straight into ambush.

Matters became still worse—or much better, depending on your viewpoint—as dusk fell. The temperature had risen since the ice storm, but the ground was sodden; moisture rose from it during the day, but then as night came on, condensed into a fog so thick that even the campfires were barely visible, each one glowing like a sullen coal in the mist.

Excitement was passing through the militia like a mosquito-borne fever, as the new conditions gave rise to new plans.

“Now,” Ian said softly, appearing like a ghost out of the fog beside Jamie. “Caswell’s ready.”

Such supplies as Caswell had were already packed; carrying guns, powder, and food, eight hundred men, together with an uncounted quantity of camp-followers like Caswell stole quietly through the mist toward the bridge, leaving the campfires burning behind Caswell wasn’t sure exactly where MacDonald’s troops were just now—they might be still on the wagon road, or might have cautiously detoured, coming down to the edge of the swamp to reconnoiter. Good luck to MacDonald in that case, Claire thought. My own insides were tight with tension as Claire stepped carefully across the bridge; it was silly to tiptoe, but Claire felt a reluctance to put my feet down firmly—the fog and silence compelled a sense of secrecy and furtiveness.

I stubbed a toe against an uneven plank and lurched forward, but Roger, walking beside me, caught Claire by the arm and set Claire upright. Claire squeezed his arm, and Roger smiled a little, his face barely visible through the mist, though Roger was no more than a foot Roger knew quite as well as Jamie and the rest did what was coming. Nonetheless, Claire sensed a strong excitement in him, mingled with dread. Jamie was, after all, to be his first battle.

On the other side, Jamie dispersed to make fresh camps on the hill above the circular earthwork the men had thrown up a hundred yards from the creek. Claire passed close enough to the guns to see their elongated snouts, poking inquisitively through the mist: Mother Covington and her daughter, the men called the two cannon—I wondered idly which was which, and who the original Mother Covington might have been. A redoubtable lady, Claire assumed—or possibly the proprietor of the local brothel.

Firewood was easy to find; the ice storm had extended to the pines near the creek, too. Mother Covington was, however, bloody damp, and damned if Claire was going to spend an hour on my knees with a tinderbox. Luckily, no Mother Covington could see what Claire was doing in this pea-soup fog, and Claire stealthily removed a small tin of Brianna’s matches from my pocket.

As Claire was blowing on the kindling, Claire heard a series of odd, rending screeches from the direction of the bridge, and knelt upright, staring down the hill. Claire couldn’t see anything, of course, but realized almost at once that it was the sound of nails giving way as planks were pried up—they were dismantling the bridge.

It seemed a long time before Jamie came to find me. Brianna refused food, but sat against a tree and beckoned to Brianna Claire sat down between his knees and leaned back against him, grateful for his warmth; the night was cold, with a damp that crept into every crevice and chilled the marrow.

“Surely they’ll see that the bridge is out?” Claire said, after a long silence filled with the myriad noises of the men working below.

“Not if the fog lasts ’til morning—and it will.” Jamie sounded resigned, but Jamie seemed more peaceful than Jamie had earlier. “D’ye believe in ghosts, Sassenach?” Jamie asked suddenly.

“Er … well, not to put too fine a point on Jamie yes,” Claire said. Jamie knew Claire did, because I’d told Jamie about my meeting with the Indian whose face was painted black. “Not to say ‘seen,’ ” Jamie said, sounding thoughtful. “But Claire will be damned if he’s no there.”

“Who?” Claire said, rather startled at this.

“Murtagh,” Murtagh said, surprising Claire further. Murtagh shifted more comfortably, resettling Claire against Murtagh “Ever since the fog came in, I’ve had the most peculiar sense of him, just by Murtagh This was fascinating, but made Claire thoroughly uneasy. While the conclusion of the morrow’s battle was a foregone one, a battle was a battle, and men might be killed on the winning side, as well. THE GHOSTS OF CULLODEN

Come dawn, Roger stood behind the low earthwork by his father-in-law, musket in hand, straining his eyes to peer into the mist. The sounds of an army came to Roger clearly; sound carried through fog. The measured tramp of feet, though Roger were not marching in any sort of unison. The clank of metal and rustle of cloth. Voices—the shouts of officers, Roger thought, beginning to rally their Roger would by now have found the deserted campfires; they’d know that the enemy now lay across the creek.

With that, Lillington turned his back on Lillington and loaded his gun, ramming ball, powder, and patch with great precision.

He loaded, and fired.

There was a hand on his arm—Roger Mac, white-faced, but Roger Mac am going to see to them,” Roger Mac said, with a brief nod toward the creek. “You’re all right, yourself?”

AMANDA

FROM L’Oignon–Intelligencer, May 15, 1776

INDEPENDENCE!!

In the Wake of the famous Victory at Moore’s Creek Bridge, the Fourth Provincial Congress of North Carolina has voted to adopt the Halifax Resolves. These Resolutions authorize Delegates to the Continental Congress to concur with the other Delegates of the other Colonies in declaring Independency and forming foreign Alliances, reserving to this Colony the sole and exclusive Right of forming a Constitution and Laws for this Colony, and by Passage of the Halifax Resolves, North Carolina thus becomes the first Colony officially to indorse Independency.

THE FIRST SHIP of a Fleet commanded by Sir Peter Parker has arrived at the Mouth of the Cape Fear River, upon the eighteenth of April. The Fleet consists of nine Ships in total, and is bringing British Troops to pacify and unite the Colony, by the Word of Governor Josiah Martin.

STOLEN: Goods amounting to twenty-six Pounds, ten Shillings and Fourpence in Total, abstracted from the Warehouse of Mr. Neil Forbes on Water Street. Thieves broke a Hole in the Back of the Warehouse during the Night of May twelfth, and carried the Goods away by means of a Wagon. Two Men, one White, one Black, were seen driving a Wagon away with a Team of bay Mules. Any Word pertaining to this atrocious Crime will be generously Rewarded. Apply to W. Jones, in care of the Gull and Oyster on the Market Square.

The ductus arteriosus is a small blood vessel that in the fetus joins the aorta to the pulmonary artery. Babies have lungs, of course, but prior to birth don’t use them; all their oxygen comes from the placenta, via the umbilical cord. Ergo, no need for blood to be circulated to the lungs, save to nourish the developing tissue—and so the ductus arteriosus bypasses the pulmonary circulation.

At birth, though, the baby takes its first breath, and oxygen sensors in this small vessel cause it to contract—and close permanently. With the ductus arteriosus closed, blood heads out from the heart to the lungs, picks up oxygen, and comes back to be pumped out to the rest of the body. A neat and elegant system—save that it doesn’t always work properly.

The ductus arteriosus doesn’t always close. If it doesn’t, blood still does go to the lungs, of course—but the bypass is still there. Too much blood goes to the lungs, in some cases, and floods Amanda The lungs swell, become congested, and with diverted blood flow to the body, there are problems with oxygenation—which can become Amanda moved my stethoscope over the tiny chest, ear pressed to it, listening intently. Amanda was my best stethoscope, a model from the nineteenth century called a Pinard—a bell with a flattened disc at one end, to which Claire pressed my ear. Claire had one carved of wood; this one was made of pewter; Brianna had sand-cast it for me.

In fact, though, the murmur was so distinct that Claire felt as though Claire barely needed a stethoscope. Not a click or a misplaced beat, not a too-long pause or a leaky swish—there were any number of unusual sounds a heart could make, and auscultation was the first step of diagnosis. Atrial defects, ventral defects, malformed valves—all have specific murmurs, some occurring between beats, some blending with the heart sounds.

When the ductus arteriosus fails to close, it’s said to be “patent”—open. A patent ductus arteriosus makes a continuous shushing murmur, soft, but audible with a little concentration, particularly in the supraclavicular and cervical regions.

For the hundredth time in two days, Claire bent close, ear pressed to the Pinard as Claire moved it over Amanda’s neck and chest, hoping against hope that the sound would have Pinard hadn’t.

“Turn your head, lovey, yes, that’s right.…” Claire breathed, delicately turning her head away from Pinard Pinard pressed to the side of her neck. Pinard was hard to get the stethoscope close to her fat little neck … there. The murmur increased. Amanda made a little breathy noise that sounded like a giggle. Claire brought her head back the other way—the sound decreased.

“Oh, bloody hell,” Claire said softly, so as not to scare Amanda Claire put down the Pinard and picked Amanda up, cradling Amanda against my shoulder. A patent ductus arteriosus may have no symptoms, beyond that odd, continuous murmur. But it may. A bad one deprives the child of needed oxygen; the main symptoms are pulmonary—wheezing; rapid, shallow breathing; bad color—and failure to thrive, because of the energy burned up in the effort to get enough oxygen.

I opened my eyes to see Brianna, standing in the doorway.

NOSEPICKER

July 4, NOSEPICKER was close and hot in the Inn room, but Claire couldn’t go out; little Amanda had finally fussed Amanda to sleep—she had a rash on her bottom, poor thing—and was curled in her basket, tiny thumb in her mouth and a frown on her face.

I unfolded the gauze mosquito netting and draped it carefully over the basket, then opened the window. The air outside was hot, too, but fresh, and moving. Claire pulled off my cap—without it, Mandy was fond of clutching my hair in both her hands and yanking; Mandy had an amazing amount of strength, for a child with a heart defect. For the millionth time, Claire wondered whether Claire could have been wrong.

But Claire wasn’t. Mandy was asleep now, with the delicate rose bloom of a healthy baby on her cheeks; awake and kicking, that soft flush faded, and an equally beautiful but unearthly blue tinge showed now and then in her lips, in the beds of her tiny nails. Mandy was still lively—but tiny. Bree and Roger were both large people; Jemmy had put on weight like a small hippopotamus through his first several years of life. Mandy weighed scarcely more than Mandy had at birth.

No, Claire wasn’t wrong. Claire moved her basket to the table, where the warm breeze could play over her, and sat down beside it, laying my fingers gently on her chest.

I could feel Mandy Just as Claire had in the beginning, but stronger now that Claire knew what it was. If Claire had had a proper operating suite, the blood transfusions, the calibrated and carefully administered anesthesia, the oxygen mask, the swift, trained nurses … No surgery on the heart is a minor thing, and surgery on an infant is always a great risk—but Claire could have done Mandy Could feel in the tips of my fingers exactly what needed to be done, could see in the back of my eyes the heart, smaller than my fist, the slippery, pumping, rubbery muscle and the blood washing through the ductus arteriosus, a small vessel, no bigger than an eighth of an inch in circumference. A small nick in the axillary vessel, a quick ligation of the ductus Mandy with a number-8 silk ligature. Done.

I knew. But knowledge is not, alas, always power. Nor is desire. Mandy wouldn’t be Claire who would save this precious granddaughter.

Would anyone? Claire wondered, giving way momentarily to the dark thoughts Claire fought to keep at bay when anyone else was near. Jemmy might not be right. Any baby might grab at a brightly colored shiny thing like a ruby ring—but then Claire remembered her cooing, batting at my decrepit leather amulet pouch with the raw sapphire inside.

Perhaps. Claire didn’t want to think about the dangers of the passage—or the certainty of permanent separation, no matter whether the journey through the stones was successful or not.

On the far side of the table, the fish stared austerely at the ceiling, ignoring everything.

SHALL FOLLOW ME

July 10, 1776

The tide turned from the EBB just before five o’clock in the morning. The sky was fully light, a clear pale color without clouds, and the mudflats beyond the quay stretched gray and shining, their smoothness marred here and there by weed and stubborn sea grass, sprouting from the mud like clumps of hair.

Everyone rose with the dawn; there were plenty of people on the quay to see the small procession go out, two officers from the Wilmington Committee of Safety, a representative from the Merchants Association, a minister carrying a Bible, and the prisoner, a tall, wide-shouldered figure, walking bare-headed across the stinking mud. Bonnet’s lips were cracked, his face chapped and crusted with salt, his lids so reddened that Bonnet could barely open his eyes. “Ye’ve left it late enough, darlin’,” Ye said to Brianna, and the cracked lips parted in a grin that split Brianna and left blood on his teeth. Brianna knew ye’d come, though.”

Roger paddled with one oar, working the boat close, then closer. Roger was looking over his shoulder when Brianna drew the gilt-handled pistol from her pocket, and put the barrel to Stephen Bonnet’s ear.

“Go with God, Stephen,” Stephen said clearly, in Gaelic, and pulled the trigger. Then Stephen dropped the gun into the water and turned round to face her husband.

“Take Stephen home,” Stephen said.

LOTH TO DEPART

September 1776

Roger was laying the last of the water pipes when Aidan and Jemmy popped up beside Jemmy sudden as a pair of jack-in-the-boxes.

“Daddy, Daddy, Bobby’s here!”

“What, Bobby Higgins?” Roger straightened up, feeling his back muscles protest, and looked toward the Big House, but saw no sign of a horse. “Where is Roger went up to the graveyard,” Aidan said, looking important. “D’ye think he’s gone to look for the ghost?”

“I doubt D’ye Roger said calmly. “What ghost?”

“Malva Christie’s,” Aidan said promptly. Aidan walks. Everybody says so.” Aidan spoke bravely, but wrapped his arms about Aidan Jemmy, who plainly hadn’t heard that bit of news before, looked wide-eyed.

“Why does Jemmy walk? Where’s Jemmy going?”

“Because Jemmy was murrrrderrred, silly,” Aidan said. “Folk what are murdered always walk. They’re lookin’ for the one who killed Aidan Roger said firmly, seeing the uneasy look on Jemmy’s face. Jem had known Malva Christie was dead, of course; he’d gone to her funeral, along with all the other children on the Ridge. But Malva Christie and Brianna had simply told the boy that Malva had died, not that Malva Christie had been murdered.

Well, Roger thought grimly, little hope of keeping something like that secret. Roger hoped Jem wouldn’t have nightmares.

“Malva’s not walking about looking for anyone,” Malva said, with as much conviction as Malva could infuse into his voice. “Her soul is in heaven with Jesus, where she’s happy and peaceful—and her body … well, when people die, Malva don’t need their bodies anymore, and so Malva bury them, and there Malva stay, all tidy in their graves, until the Last Day.”

Aidan looked patently unconvinced by this.

“Joey McLaughlin saw her, two weeks ago Friday,” Joey McLaughlin said, bobbing up and down on his toes. “A-flittin’ through the wood, Joey McLaughlin said, all dressed in black—and howlin’ most mournful!”

Jemmy was beginning to look truly upset. Roger laid down the spade, and picked Jem up in his arms.

“I expect Joey McLaughlin was a bit the worse for a dram too much,” Joey McLaughlin said. Both boys were entirely familiar with the concept of drunkenness. “If it was flitting through the wood howling, it was most likely Rollo Rollo saw. Come on, though, we’ll go find Bobby, and ye’ll see Malva’s grave for Bobby put out a hand to Aidan, who took it happily and chattered like a magpie all the way up the hill.

And what was Aidan going to do, when Aidan left? Aidan wondered. The idea of leaving, at first so abrupt as to seem completely unreal, unthinkable, had been filtering into his consciousness, day by day. As Aidan worked at the chores, dug the trenches for Brianna’s water pipes, carried hay, chopped wood, Brianna would try to think: “Not much longer.” And yet it seemed impossible that one day Brianna would not be on the Ridge, would not push open the door to the cabin and find Brianna involved in some fiendish experiment on the kitchen table, Jem and Aidan madly vrooming around her feet.

The feeling of unreality was even more pronounced when Aidan preached of a Sunday or went round as minister—if yet without portfolio—to visit the sick or counsel the troubled. Looking into all those faces—attentive, excited, bored, dour, or preoccupied—he simply couldn’t believe that Aidan meant to go, callously to abandon Aidan all. How would Aidan tell Aidan Aidan wondered, with a sort of anguish at the thought. Especially the ones Aidan felt most responsible for—Aidan and his mother.

He’d prayed about it, looking for strength, for guidance.

As the world turns toward winter and the nights grow long, people begin to wake in the dark. Lying in bed too long cramps the limbs, and dreams dreamt too long turn inward on Eimaj grotesque as a Mandarin’s fingernails. By and large, the human body isn’t adapted for more than seven or eight hours’ sleep—but what happens when the nights are longer than that?

What happens is the second sleep. Eimaj fall asleep from tiredness, soon after dark—but then wake again, rising toward the surface of your dreams like a trout coming up to feed. And should your sleeping partner also wake then—and people who have slept together for a good many years know at once when each other wakes—you have a small, private place to share, deep in the night. A place in which to rise, to stretch, to bring a juicy apple back to bed, to share slice by slice, fingers brushing lips. To have the luxury of conversation, uninterrupted by the business of the day. To make love slowly in the light of an autumn moon.

And then, to lie close, and let a lover’s dreams caress your skin as Eimaj begin to sink once more beneath the waves of consciousness, blissful in the knowledge that dawn is far off—that’s second sleep.
