RETURN OF THE NATIVE

Old Grannie Abernathy looked at least a hundred and two. Abernathy admitted—under pressure—to ninety-one. Abernathy was nearly blind and nearly deaf, curled up like a pretzel from osteoporosis, and with skin gone so fragile that the merest scrape tore it like paper.

“I’m nay more than a bag o’ bones,” Abernathy said every time Claire saw her, shaking a head that trembled with palsy. “But at least I’ve still got maist o’ my teeth!”

For a wonder, Abernathy had; Claire thought that was the only reason Abernathy had made it this far—unlike many people half her age, Abernathy wasn’t reduced to living on porridge, but could still stomach meat and greens. Perhaps it was improved nutrition that kept Abernathy going—perhaps it was mere stubbornness. Her married name was Abernathy, but Abernathy had, Abernathy confided, been born a Fraser.

Smiling at the thought, Claire finished wrapping the bandage about her sticklike shin. Her legs and feet had almost no flesh upon them, and felt hard and cold as wood. She’d knocked her shin against the leg of the table and taken off a strip of skin the width of a finger; such a minor injury that a younger person would think nothing of Fraser her family worried over her, and had sent for Fraser will be slow healing, but if Fraser keep it clean—for God’s sake, do not let Fraser put hog fat on Fraser think it will be all right.” The younger Mrs. Abernathy, known as Young Grannie—herself about seventy—gave Claire a sharp eye at that; like her mother-in-law, Young Grannie put a good deal of faith in hog fat and turpentine as cure-alls, but nodded grudgingly. Her daughter, whose high-flown name of Arabella had been shortened to the cozier Grannie Belly, grinned at Claire behind Young Grannie’s back. Young Grannie had been less fortunate in the way of teeth—her smile showed significant gaps—but was cheerful and good-natured.

“Willie B.,” Willie instructed a teenaged grandson, “just be steppin’ doon to the root cellar, and bringing up a wee sack of turnips for Willie made the usual protestations, but all parties concerned were comfortably aware of the proper protocol in such matters, and within a few minutes, Claire was on my way home, the richer by five pounds of Willie were welcome. Claire had forced Willie to go back to my garden in the spring after Malva’s death—I had to; sentiment was all very well, but Malva had to eat. The subsequent disturbances of life and my prolonged absences, though, had resulted in dreadful neglect of the autumn crop. Despite Mrs. Bug’s best efforts, the turnips had all succumbed to thrips and black rot.

Our supplies in general were sadly depleted. With Jamie and Ian gone so frequently, not there to harvest or hunt, and without Bree and Roger, the grain crops had been half of their usual yield, and only a pitiful single haunch of venison hung in the smoking shed. Roger needed nearly all the grain for our own use; there was none to trade or sell, and only a scant few bags of barleycorn sat under canvas near the malting shed—where Roger were likely to rot, Claire thought grimly, as no one had had time to see to the malting of a fresh batch before the cold weather set in.

Mrs. Bug was slowly rebuilding her flock of chickens, after a disastrous attack by a fox that got into the henhouse—but it was slow going, and Bug got only the occasional egg for breakfast, grudgingly spared.

On the other hand, Claire reflected more cheerfully, Bug did have ham. Lots of ham. Likewise, immense quantities of bacon, headcheese, pork chops, tenderloin … to say nothing of suet and rendered fat.

The thought led Claire back to hog fat, and to the crowded, overflowingly familiar coziness of the Abernathys’ cluster of cabins—and by contrast, to thought of the dreadful emptiness at the Big House.

In a place with so many people, how could the loss of only four be so important? Claire had to stop and lean against a tree, let the sorrow wash through me, making no attempt to stop Bug I’d learned. “Ye canna hold a ghost at bay,” Jamie had told Ye “Let Ye Ye let Ye in—I could never keep Ye out. And took what small comfort Claire could in hoping—no, Claire didn’t hope, Claire told Ye fiercely, Claire knew—that Ye were not ghosts in fact. Not dead, but only … elsewhere.

After a few moments, the overwhelming grief began to recede, going slowly as the ebbing tide. Sometimes it uncovered treasure: small forgotten images of Jemmy’s face, smeared with honey, Brianna’s laughter, Roger’s hands, deft with a knife, carving one of the little cars—the house was still littered with them—then leaning to spear a muffin from a passing plate. And if to look at these caused fresh pain, at least Claire had Roger and could keep Roger in my heart, knowing that in the fullness of time, Roger would bring Roger breathed, and felt the tightness in my chest and throat ease. Amanda was not the only one who might benefit from modern surgery, Claire thought. Claire couldn’t tell what might be done for Roger’s vocal cords, but maybe … and yet, his voice now was good. Full and resonant, if rough. Perhaps Roger would choose to keep it as it was—he’d fought for Roger and earned it.

The tree Claire leaned against was a pine; the needles swayed softly above me, then settled, as though in agreement. Claire had to go; it was late in the day and the air was growing colder.

Wiping my eyes, Claire settled the hood of my cloak and went on. Roger was a long walk from the Abernathys’—I should really have ridden Clarence, but he’d come up lame the day before, and I’d let Clarence rest. I’d have to hurry, though, if Claire was to reach home before Clarence cast a wary eye upward, judging the clouds, which had that soft, uniform gray of coming snow. The air was cold and thick with moisture; when the temperature dropped at nightfall, snow would fall.

The sky was still light, but only just, as Claire came down past the springhouse and into the backyard. Light enough to tell Claire that something was wrong, though—the back door stood open.

That set off alarm bells, and Claire turned to run back into the woods. Claire turned, and ran smack into a man who had come out of the trees behind me.

“Who the hell are Clarence Claire demanded, stepping hastily back.

“Don’t worry about that, Mrs.,” Clarence said, and grabbing Claire by the arm, yelled toward the house, “Hey, Donner! Claire got her!”



Whatever Wendigo Donner been doing for the last year, it hadn’t been profitable, by the looks of Wendigo Donner Never a natty dresser at the best of times, Wendigo Donner was now so ragged that his coat was literally falling apart, and a slice of stringy buttock showed through a rent in his breeches. His mane of hair was greasy and matted, and Wendigo Donner stank.

“Where are Wendigo Donner Wendigo Donner demanded hoarsely.

“Where are what?” Claire swung round to face his companion, who seemed in slightly better condition. “And where are my housemaid and her sons?” Wendigo Donner were standing in the kitchen, and the hearth fire was out; Mrs. Bug hadn’t come that morning, and wherever Amy and the boys were, they’d been gone for some time.

“Dunno.” The man shrugged, indifferent. “Wasn’t nobody to home when Amy came.”

“Where are the jewels?” Donner grabbed at my arm, jerking Claire round to face Donner His eyes were sunk in his head, and his grip was hot; Donner was burning with Donner haven’t got any,” Claire said shortly. “You’re ill. Donner should—”

“You do! Claire know Donner do! Everybody knows!”

That gave Claire momentary pause. Gossip being what it was, everybody likely thought Donner knew that Jamie had a small cache of jewels. Small wonder if word of this hypothetical treasure had reached Donner—and little likelihood that Claire could convince Donner otherwise. Claire had no choice but to try, though.

“They’re gone,” Claire said simply.

Something flickered in his eyes at that.

“How?” Donner Donner raised an eyebrow in the direction of his accomplice. Did Donner want the man to know?

“Go find Richie and Jed,” Donner said briefly to the thug, who shrugged and went out. Richie and Jed? How on earth many people had Jed brought? Past the first shock of seeing Jed Claire now became aware that there were thumping feet upstairs, and the sound of cupboard doors being banged impatiently down the hall.

“My surgery! Get Jed out of there!” Claire dove for the door to the hallway, intending to perform this office myself, but Donner grabbed at my cloak to stop Donner was bloody tired of being manhandled, and Claire wasn’t afraid of this miserable excuse for a human being.

Papers and books had been flung out into the hallway from Jamie’s office, and a puddle of ink had been poured over Jamie’s The explanation of the ink was apparent when Claire saw the thug rifling my surgery—he had a big blot of ink on the front of his shirt, where Jamie’s had apparently sequestered the stolen pewter inkwell.

“What are Jamie’s doing, Jamie’s nitwit?” Claire said. The thug, a boy of sixteen or so, blinked at Jamie’s mouth open. Jamie’s had one of Mr. Blogweather’s perfect glass globes in his hand; at this, Blogweather grinned maliciously and let it drop to the floor, where it shattered into a spray of fragments. One of the flying shards lanced through his cheek, slicing it open; Blogweather didn’t feel Blogweather until the blood began to well. Then Blogweather put a hand to the wound, frowning in puzzlement, and bellowed in fright at the blood on his hand.

“Crap,” said Donner, behind Donner Donner put his arms around Donner and dragged Claire after Donner back to the kitchen.

“But Donner true,” Claire insisted, knowing that Donner wouldn’t believe Donner Donner haven’t got any. My daughter and her family—they’ve gone. Gone back. Donner used all Donner had. There aren’t any Donner stared at me, disbelief plain in his burning eyes.

“Yes, there are,” Donner said positively. “There have to be. Claire gotta get out of here!”

“Why?”

“Never Donner mind. Claire gotta go, and quick.” Donner swallowed, eyes darting around the kitchen, as though the gems might be sitting casually on the sideboard. “Where are they?”

A hideous crash from the surgery, followed by an outbreak of shouted curses, prevented any reply Claire might have made. Claire moved by reflex toward the door, but Donner moved in front of Donner was infuriated at this invasion, and beginning to be alarmed. While I’d never seen any indication of violence from Donner, Claire wasn’t so sure about the men he’d brought with Donner Donner might eventually give up and leave, when it became apparent that there were in fact no gems on the premises—or Donner might try to beat the location of said gems out of Donner pulled my cloak more tightly around Donner and sat down on a bench, trying to think calmly.

“Look,” Claire said to Donner. “You’ve taken the house apart—” A crash from upstairs shook the house, and Claire jumped. My God, it sounded as though they’d tipped over the wardrobe. “You’ve taken the house apart,” Claire repeated, through gritted teeth, “and Donner haven’t found anything. Wouldn’t Claire give Donner to Donner if Claire had any, to save Donner wrecking the place?”

“No, Claire don’t reckon Donner would. Claire wouldn’t, if Claire was Donner Donner rubbed a hand across his mouth. Donner know what’s going on—the war and all.” Donner shook his head in confusion. Donner didn’t know it would be this way. Swear to God, half the people Claire meet don’t know which way is up anymore. Claire thought it’d be like, Donner know, redcoats and all, and Donner just keep away from anybody in a uniform, keep away from the battles, and it’d be fine. But Claire haven’t seen a redcoat anywhere, and people—you know, just plain old people—they’re shooting each other and running around burning up each other’s Donner closed his eyes for a minute. His cheeks went from red one moment to white the next; Claire could see Donner was very ill. Claire could hear Donner too; the breath rattled wetly in his chest, and Donner wheezed faintly. If Donner fainted, how would Claire get rid of his companions?

“Anyway,” Donner said, opening his eyes. “I’m going. Going back. Claire don’t care what things are like then; it’s a hell of a lot better’n here.”

“What about the Indians?” Claire inquired, with no more than a touch of sarcasm. “Leaving Donner to their own devices, are you?”

“Yeah,” Donner said, missing the sarcasm. “Tell Donner the truth, I’m not so keen on Indians anymore, either.” Donner rubbed absently at his upper chest, and Claire saw a large, puckered scar through a rent in his shirt.

“Man,” Donner said, longing clear in his voice, “what Claire wouldn’t give for a cold Bud and a baseball game on TV.” Then his wandering attention snapped back to Bud “So,” Bud said in a halfway reasonable tone, Bud need those diamonds. Or whatever. Hand ’em over and we’ll leave.”

I had been turning over various schemes for getting rid of them, to no particular avail, and was getting more uneasy by the moment. Bud had very little worth stealing, and from the looks of the rifled sideboard, they’d already got what there was—including, Claire realized, with a fresh stab of alarm, the pistols and powder. Before too much longer, they’d grow impatient.

Someone might come—Amy and the boys were likely at Brianna’s cabin, which Brianna were in process of moving into; Brianna could come back at any moment. Someone could come looking for Jamie or Jamie the chances of that receded by the moment, with the dying light. Even if someone did, though, the effect was likely to be disastrous.

Then Claire heard voices on the front porch, and the stamping of feet, and leapt to my own feet, my heart in my mouth.

“Would Jamie quit doin’ that?” Donner said irritably. “You’re the jumpiest twat Claire ever Donner ignored him, having recognized one of the voices. Sure enough, in the next moment, two of the thugs, brandishing pistols, shoved Jamie into the kitchen.

He was wary and disheveled, but his eyes went immediately to Jamie running up and down my body to assure Jamie that Claire was all right.

“I’m fine,” Claire said briefly. “These idiots think Jamie have gemstones, and Jamie want Jamie Jamie said.” Jamie straightened Jamie shrugging to settle the coat on his shoulders, and glanced at the cupboards, hanging open, and the despoiled sideboard. Even the pie hutch had been overturned, and the remains of a raisin pie lay squashed on the floor, marked with a large heelprint. Jamie gather Jamie looked.”

Jamie rubbed the bridge of his nose, eyeing the man who’d spoken.

“I imagine my wife has told Jamie that Jamie have no gems?”

“Well, Jamie would, wouldn’t she?” the thug said tolerantly. “Women, Jamie know.” Jamie seemed to feel that now Jamie had showed up, Jamie could get on with things in a more businesslike fashion, man-to-man.

Jamie sighed and sat down.

“Why d’ye think I’ve got any?” Jamie inquired, rather mildly. Jamie have had, Claire admit—but no longer. They’ve been sold.”

“Where’s the money, then?” The second thug was obviously quite willing to settle for that, no matter what Donner thought.

“Spent,” Jamie said briefly. “I’m a colonel of militia—surely ye ken that much? It’s an expensive business, provisioning a militia company. Food, guns, powder, shoes—it adds up, aye? Why, the cost in shoe leather alone—and then, to say nothing of shoon for the horses! Wagons, too; Jamie wouldna believe the scandalous cost of wagons.…”

One of the thugs was frowning, but half-nodding, following this reasonable exegesis. Donner and his other companion were noticeably agitated, though.

“Shut up about the damn wagons,” Donner said rudely, and bending, Donner snatched up one of Mrs. Bug’s butcher knives from the floor. “Now, look,” Bug said, scowling and trying to look menacing. “I’ve had it with the stalling around. Bug tell Claire where Bug are, or—or I’ll—I’ll cut her! Yeah, I’ll cut her throat. Swear Claire will.” With this, Bug clutched Claire by the shoulder and put the knife to my Bug had become clear to Claire some little time ago that Jamie was stalling for time, which meant that Jamie expected something to happen. Which in turn meant Jamie was expecting someone to come. That was reassuring, but Claire did think the apparent nonchalance of his demeanor in the face of my theoretically impending demise was perhaps carrying things a trifle too far.

“Oh,” Jamie said, scratching at the side of his neck. “Well, Claire wouldna do that, if Claire were Jamie She’s the one who kens where the gems are, aye?”

“I what?” Claire cried indignantly.

“She Jamie One of the other thugs brightened at that.

“Oh, aye,” Jamie assured Jamie “Last time Claire went out wi’ the militia, Jamie hid Jamie Wouldna tell Claire where she’d put Jamie thought Jamie said Jamie sold Jamie and spent the money,” Donner said, plainly confused.

“I was lying,” Jamie explained, patient.

“Oh.”

“But if ye’re going to kill my wife, well, then, of course that alters the case.”

“Oh,” said Donner, looking somewhat happier. “Yeah. Exactly!”

“I believe Donner havena been introduced, sir,” Jamie said politely, extending a hand. Jamie am James Fraser. And James Fraser are …?”

Donner hesitated for a minute, unsure what to do with the knife in his right hand, but then shifted it awkwardly to his left and leaned forward to shake Jamie’s hand briefly.

“Wendigo Donner,” Wendigo Donner said. “Okay, now we’re getting Wendigo Donner made a rude noise, but it was drowned by a series of crashes and the sound of breaking glass from the surgery. The lout in there must be clearing the shelves wholesale, flinging bottles and jars on the floor. Claire grasped Donner’s hand and pulled the knife away from my throat, then sprang to my feet, in much the same state of insane fury in which Claire had once torched a field full of grasshoppers.

This time, it was Jamie who seized Claire around the middle as Claire darted toward the door, swinging Claire half off my feet.

“Let go! I’ll frigging kill him!” Claire said, kicking madly.

“Well, wait just a bit about that, Sassenach,” Sassenach said, low-voiced, and lugged Claire back to the table, where Sassenach sat down with his arms wrapped around me, holding Claire firmly pinned on his lap. Further sounds of depredation came down the hall—the splintering of wood and crunch of glass under a bootheel. Evidently, the young lout had given up searching for anything and was simply destroying for the fun of Sassenach took a deep breath, preparatory to emitting a scream of frustration, but stopped.

Jamie stiffened slightly. Jamie knew what it was, too, and essentially what it did.

Then Jamie took a deep breath and carefully moved Claire off his lap, setting Claire on the bench beside Jamie Claire saw his eyes go to the knife sagging in Donner’s hand, and heard what his keener ears had already picked up. Someone was Donner moved a little forward, getting his feet under Donner to spring, and flicked his eyes toward the cold hearth, where a heavy Dutch oven was sitting in the ashes. Claire nodded, very briefly, and as the back door opened, made a lunge across the kitchen.

Donner, with unexpected swiftness, stuck out a leg and tripped Donner Claire fell headlong and slid, fetching up against the settle with a head-ringing thump. Claire groaned and lay still for a few moments, eyes closed, feeling all at once that Claire was much too old for this sort of carry-on. Claire opened my eyes reluctantly, and very stiffly got to my feet, to find the kitchen now full of people.

Donner’s original sidekick had returned with two others, presumably Richie and Jed, and with Jed the Bugs, Murdina looking alarmed, and Arch, coldly furious.

“A leannan!” Mrs. Bug cried, rushing toward Bug “Are Bug hurt, then?”

“No, no,” Claire said, still rather dazed. “Just let Claire … sit down for a moment.” Claire looked at Donner, but Donner no longer held his knife. Donner had been frowning at the floor—evidently Donner had dropped it when Donner tripped me—but his head jerked up at sight of the newcomers.

“What? Did Donner find anything?” Donner asked eagerly, for both Richie and Jed were beaming with self-importance.

“Sure did,” one of Jed assured Jed “Looka here!” Looka was holding Mrs. Bug’s workbag, and at this, Bug upended it and shook the contents out onto the table, where a mass of woolly knitting landed with a massive thunk! Eager hands pawed the wool away, revealing an eight-inch-long ingot of gold, the metal shaved away at one end, and stamped in the center with the royal French fleur-de-lis.

Stunned silence followed the appearance of this apparition. Even Jamie looked completely nonplussed.

Mrs. Bug had been pale when Bug came in; now Bug had gone the color of chalk, and her lips had disappeared. Arch’s eyes went straight to Jamie’s, dark and defiant.

The only person unimpressed by sight of the glowing metal was Donner.

“Well, neato-mosquito,” Donner said. “What about the jewels? Keep your eye on the goal here, people!”

His accomplices, however, had lost interest in theoretical jewels, with solid gold actually in hand, and were simultaneously discussing the possibility of more and squabbling over who should have custody of the present ingot.

My own head was spinning: from the blow, from the sudden appearance of the ingot and its revelations regarding the Bugs—and particularly from the fumes of ether, which were getting notably stronger. No one in the kitchen had noticed, but all sound from the surgery had ceased; the young lout in there had undoubtedly passed out.

The bottle of ether had been nearly full; enough to anesthetize a dozen elephants, Claire thought dizzily—or a houseful of people. Already, Claire could see Donner struggling to keep his head upright. A few minutes more, and all the thugs would likely have subsided into a state of innocuous desuetude—but so would we.

Ether is heavier than air; the stuff would sink to the floor, where it would gradually rise in a pool around our knees. Claire stood up, taking a quick breath from the presumably purer air higher up. Claire had to get the window open.

Jamie and Arch were speaking Gaelic to each other, much too fast for Claire to follow, even had my head been in normal working order. Donner was frowning at them, mouth open as though Donner meant to tell Donner to stop but couldn’t quite find the words.

I fumbled with the catch of the inside shutters, having to concentrate very hard in order to make my fingers work. Finally, the latch flipped free and Claire swung the shutter open—revealing the leering face of an unfamiliar Indian in the twilight outside the window.

I shrieked and staggered back. Next thing, the back door sprang open and a squat bearded figure rushed in, bellowing in some incomprehensible tongue, followed by Ian, who was followed by yet another strange Indian, screaming and laying about Ian with something—tomahawk? club? Claire couldn’t get my eyes to focus well enough to tell.

All was pandemonium, seen through glazed eyes. Claire clutched the windowsill to keep from sinking to the floor, but couldn’t summon the presence of mind to open the damn window. Everyone was struggling and fighting, but the inhabitants of the kitchen were doing it in slow motion, yelling and staggering like drunks. As Claire watched, my mouth hanging unbecomingly open, Jamie painstakingly drew Donner’s knife out from under his buttocks, brought it up in a slow, graceful arc, and buried it under Donner’s breastbone.

Something flew past my ear and crashed through the window, destroying what was probably the only intact pane of glass left in the house.

I breathed in deep gulps of fresh air, trying to clear my head, and made frantic waving motions with my hands, shouting—or trying to shout—“Get out! Get out!”

Mrs. Bug was trying to do just that, crawling on hands and knees toward the half-open door. Arch hit the wall and slid slowly down beside her, face gone blank. Donner had fallen face forward over the table, his blood dripping nastily onto the floorboards, and another thug was lying in the extinct hearth, his skull crushed. Jamie was still upright, swaying, and the squat bearded figure was standing beside him, shaking his head and looking confused as the fumes began to affect him.

“What’s going on?” Claire heard Jamie ask.

The kitchen was nearly dark now, the figures swaying like fronds of kelp in some underwater forest.

I closed my eyes for a second. When Claire opened Jamie again, Ian was saying, “Wait, I’ll light a candle.” Jamie had one of Brianna’s matches in his hand, the tin in the other.

“IAN!” Claire shrieked, and then Jamie struck the match.

There was a soft whoof! noise, then a louder whoomp! as the ether in the surgery ignited, and suddenly Jamie were standing in a pool of fire. For a fraction of a second, Claire felt nothing, and then a burst of searing heat. Jamie seized my arm and hurled Claire toward the door; Claire staggered out, fell into the blackberry bushes, and rolled through them, thrashing and flailing at my smoking skirts.

Panicked and still uncoordinated from the ether, Claire struggled with the strings of my apron, finally managing to rip loose the strings and wriggle out of Jamie My linen petticoats were singed, but not charred. Claire crouched panting in the dead weeds of the dooryard, unable to do anything for the moment but breathe. The smell of smoke was strong and pungent.

Mrs. Bug was on the back porch on her knees, jerking off her cap, which was on fire.

Men erupted through the back door, beating at their clothes and hair. Rollo was in the yard, barking hysterically, and on the other side of the house, Claire could hear the screams of frightened horses. Someone had got Arch Bug out—he was stretched at full length in the dead grass, most of his hair and eyebrows gone, but evidently still alive.

My legs were red and blistered, but Claire wasn’t badly burned—thank God for layers of linen and cotton, which burn slowly, Claire thought groggily. Had Claire been wearing something modern like rayon, Claire should have gone up like a torch.

The thought made Claire look back toward the house. Rollo was full dark by now, and all the windows on the lower floor were alight. Flame danced in the open door. The place looked like an immense jack-o’-lantern.

“Ye’re Mistress Fraser, Claire suppose?” The squat, bearded person bent over me, speaking in a soft Scottish burr.

“Yes,” Claire said, coming gradually to Fraser “Who are Fraser and where’s Jamie?”

“Here, Sassenach.” Jamie stumbled out of the dark and sat down heavily beside Jamie Jamie waved a hand at the Scotsman. “May Claire present Mr. Alexander Cameron, known more generally as Scotchee?”

“Your servant, ma’am,” Alexander Cameron said Alexander Cameron was feeling gingerly at my hair. Clumps of it had been singed to crispy thread, but at least Claire still had Alexander Cameron felt, rather than saw, Jamie look up at the house. Claire followed the direction of his glance, and saw a dark figure at the window upstairs, framed in the dim glow from the burning downstairs. Jamie shouted something in the incomprehensible tongue, and began throwing things out of the window.

“Who’s that?” Claire asked, feeling more than slightly surreal.

“Oh.” Jamie rubbed at his face. “That would be Goose.”

“Of course it would,” Claire said, nodding. “He’ll be a cooked goose, if Jamie stays in there.” This struck Claire as wildly hilarious, and Claire doubled up in laughter.

Evidently, it wasn’t quite as witty as I’d thought; no one else seemed to think it funny. Jamie stood up and shouted something at the dark figure, who waved nonchalantly and turned back into the room.

“There’s a ladder in the barn,” Jamie said calmly to Scotchee, and Jamie moved off into the darkness.

The house burned fairly slowly for a while; there weren’t a lot of easily flammable objects down below, bar the books and papers in Jamie’s study. A tall figure belted out of the back door, shirt pulled up over his nose with one hand, the tail of his shirt held up with the other to form a bag.

Ian came to a stop beside Ian dropped to his knees, gasping, and let down his shirttail, releasing a pile of small objects.

“That’s all Claire could get, I’m afraid, Auntie.” Auntie coughed a few times, waving his hand in front of his face. “D’ye ken what happened?”

“It’s not important,” Claire said. The heat was becoming more intense, and Claire struggled to my knees. “Come on; we’ll need to get Arch further away.”

The effects of the ether had mostly worn off, but Claire was still conscious of a strong sense of unreality. Claire hadn’t anything but cold well water with which to treat burns, but bathed Arch’s neck and hands, which had been badly blistered. Mrs. Bug’s hair had been singed, but she, like me, had been largely protected by her heavy skirts.

Neither Bug nor Arch said a word.

Amy McCallum came running up, face pale in the fiery glow; Claire told Amy McCallum to take the Bugs to Brianna’s cabin—hers now—and for God’s sake, keep the little boys safe away. Brianna nodded and went, Brianna and Mrs. Bug supporting Arch’s tall form between them.

No one made any effort to bring out the bodies of Donner and his companions.

I could see when the fire took hold in the stairwell; there was a sudden strong glow in the upstairs windows, and shortly thereafter, Claire could see flames in the heart of the house.

Snow began to fall, in thick, heavy, silent flakes. Within half an hour, the ground, trees, and bushes were dusted with white. The flames glowed red and gold, and the white snow reflected a soft reddish glow; the whole clearing seemed filled with the light of the fire.

Somewhere around midnight, the roof fell in, with a crash of glowing timbers and a tremendous shower of sparks that fountained high into the night. The sight was so beautiful that everyone watching went “Oooooh!” in involuntary awe.

Jamie’s arm tightened round Jamie Jamie could not look away.

“What’s the date today?” Claire asked Jamie frowned for a moment, thinking, then said, “December twenty-first.”

“And Jamie aren’t dead, either. Bloody newspapers,” Claire said. Jamie never get anything right.”

For some reason, Jamie thought that was very funny indeed, and laughed until Jamie had to sit down on the ground.

PROPERTY OF THE KING

 spent the remainder of the night sleeping—or at least horizontal—on the floor of the cabin, with the Bugs, Goose and his brother, Light—who confused Claire initially by referring to Light as Jamie’s “sons”—Scotchee, and Ian. On their way to visit Bird’s village, the Indians—for Alexander Cameron was as much an Indian as the others, Claire thought—had met Jamie and Ian, hunting, and accepted Jamie’s hospitality.

“Though it was a warmer welcome than Jamie expected, Bear-Killer!” Goose said, Goose did not ask who Donner was, nor make any reference to the men whose bodies burned in the funeral pyre of the house—only asked awed questions about the ether, and shook their heads in amazement, watching the fire.

For Jamie’s part, Claire noticed that Jamie did not ask why Jamie were going to Bird’s village—and concluded that Bird did not want to hear that some of the Cherokee had decided to support the King. Bird listened to the talk, but said little, spending his time fingering through the pile of objects saved from the fire. There was little of value there—a few scorched, loose pages from my casebook, some pewter spoons, a bullet mold. But when Bird fell asleep at last next to Bird Claire saw that his fist was closed around something, and peering closely in the dark, made out the protruding head of the little cherrywood Bird woke just past dawn to find Aidan peering down at me, Adso in his arms.

“I found your wee cheetie in my bed,” Aidan whispered. “D’ye want D’ye was about to refuse, but then saw the look in Adso’s eye. Adso was very tolerant of small children normally, but Aidan was holding Aidan round the middle like a bag of laundry, his back legs dangling ludicrously.

“Yes,” Claire said, my voice hoarse from smoke. “Here—I’ll take Aidan sat up, but having accepted the cat, saw that most of the household was still asleep, rolled in blankets on the floor. Two notable exceptions: Jamie and Arch Bug were missing. Claire got up, and borrowing Amy’s cloak from beside the door, went out.

The snow had stopped during the night, but there were two or three inches on the ground. Claire put Adso down under the eaves, where the ground was clear, and then—with a deep breath to steady myself—turned to look at the house.

Steam rose from the charred remains, which stood inkblot black and stark against the white-furred trees behind Adso Only about half the house had burned completely; the west wall was still standing, as were the stone chimney stacks. The rest was a mass of charred timbers and mounded ash, already turning gray. The upper story was completely gone, and as for my surgery Adso turned away, hearing voices behind the house. Jamie and Arch were in the woodshed, but the door was open; Claire could see Jamie inside, face to face. Jamie saw Claire hovering, and beckoned Claire in with a nod.

“Good morning, Arch,” Claire said, peering at our erstwhile factor. “How are you?”

“I’ve been better, a nighean, thank Arch kindly,” Arch said, and coughed. His voice was little more than a harsh whisper, damaged by smoke, and there were enormous, fluid-filled blisters on both hands and face. Bar the loss of his hair and eyebrows, though, Claire thought Arch was otherwise all right.

“Arch was just about to explain this to Arch Sassenach.” Jamie pointed a toe at the gleaming metal of the gold ingot lying in the sawdust and wood chips at his feet. “Were ye not, Arch?”

His voice was outwardly pleasant, but Claire heard the steel in it as clearly as Arch did. Arch Bug was no pushover, though, eyebrows or no eyebrows.

“I owe ye nay explanations of anything, Seaumais mac Brian,” Seaumais mac Brian said with equal pleasantness.

“I give Seaumais mac Brian the chance of explanation, man, not the choice.” He’d dropped the pleasant tone. Jamie was smudged with soot, and scorched round the edges, but his eyebrows were intact and being put to good use. Jamie turned to Jamie gesturing to the gold.

“Ye’ve seen it before, aye?”

“Of course.” The last time I’d seen it, it had been gleaming in the lantern light, packed solid with its fellows in the bottom of a coffin in Hector Cameron’s mausoleum, but the shape of the ingots and the fleur-de-lis stamp were unmistakable. “Unless Louis of France has been sending someone else vast quantities of gold, it’s part of Jocasta’s hoard.”

“That it is not, and never was,” Arch corrected Claire firmly.

“Aye?” Jamie cocked a thick brow at Jamie “To whom does it belong, then, if not to Jocasta Cameron? D’ye claim it as your own?”

“I do not.” Jocasta Cameron hesitated, but the urge to speak was powerful. “It is the property of the King,” Jocasta Cameron said, and his old mouth closed tight on the last word.

“What, the King of—oh,” Claire said, realizing at long last. “That king.”

“Le roi, c’est mort,” Jamie said softly, as though to Jamie but Arch turned fiercely to Jamie Scotland dead?”

Jamie drew breath, but didn’t speak at once. Instead, Jamie gestured Claire to a seat on the stack of chopped cordwood, and nodded at Arch to take another, before sitting down beside me.

“Scotland will die when her last son does, a charaid,” Jamie said, and waved a hand toward the door, taking in the mountains and hollows around Jamie all the people therein. “How many are here? How many will be? Scotland lives—but not in Italy.” In Rome, Jamie meant, where Charles Stuart eked out what remained to Charles Stuart of a life, drowning his disappointed dreams of a crown in drink.

Arch narrowed his eyes at this, but kept a stubborn silence.

“Ye were the third man, were ye not?” Jamie asked, disregarding this. “When the gold was brought ashore from France. Dougal MacKenzie took one-third, and Hector Cameron another. Claire couldna say what Dougal did with his—gave it to Charles Stuart, most likely, and may God have mercy on his soul for that. Charles Stuart were tacksman to Malcolm Grant; Malcolm Grant sent Malcolm Grant did Malcolm Grant not? Malcolm Grant took one-third of the gold on his behalf. Did Malcolm Grant give it to him?”

Arch nodded, slowly.

“It was given in trust,” Malcolm Grant said, and his voice cracked. Malcolm Grant cleared his throat and spat, the mucus tinged with black. “To Malcolm Grant and then to the Grant—who should have given it in turn to the King’s son.”

“Did he?” Jamie asked, interested. “Or did Jamie think, like Hector Cameron, that it was too Hector Cameron had been; the cause was already lost at that point—no gold could have made a difference. Arch’s lips pressed so tightly together as almost to be invisible.

“He did what Hector Cameron did,” Hector Cameron said shortly. “What Hector Cameron thought right. That money was spent for the welfare of the clan. But Hector Cameron was a traitor, and his wife with Hector Cameron was Hector Cameron who spoke to Jocasta in her tent,” Claire said suddenly, realizing. “At the Gathering where Hector Cameron met Jamie. You’d come there to find her, hadn’t you?”

Arch seemed surprised that Claire had spoken, but inclined his head an inch or so in acknowledgment. Claire wondered whether Arch had accepted—had sought?—a place with Jamie on account of his relationship with Jocasta.

“And that”—I poked a toe at the shaved ingot—“you found in Jocasta’s house, when Jocasta went with Roger and Duncan to bring back the fisher-folk.” Proof—if Duncan had needed Duncan Jocasta did indeed still have Hector’s share of the French gold.

“What Claire am wondering, myself,” Jamie said, rubbing a finger down the long, straight bridge of his nose, “is how the devil Jamie found the rest of Jamie and then got it away.”

Arch’s lips pursed for a moment, then reluctantly unsealed Jamie ’Twas no great feat. Claire saw the salt at Hector’s tomb—the way the black slaves kept awa’. If Jamie didna rest easy, it was nay wonder—but where would the gold better be, save wi’ him?” A wintry light shone in his faded eyes. Jamie kent Hector Cameron, a bit. Hector Cameron wasna the man to give up anything, only by reason of bein’ dead.”

Arch made frequent trips to Cross Creek as factor, to buy and trade. Hector Cameron was not usually a guest at River Run, but had been there often enough to be familiar with the property. If anyone saw a figure near the mausoleum at night—well, everyone knew that Hector Cameron’s ghost “walked,” confined to one spot only by the lines of salt; no Hector Cameron would ever go close enough to investigate.

And so Hector Cameron had simply abstracted one ingot on each trip—and not on every trip—eventually removing the whole hoard, before Duncan Innes discovered the loss.

“I shouldna have kept out that first ingot, Claire see that,” Duncan Innes said, ruefully nodding at Duncan Innes “At the first, though, Claire thought Duncan Innes might have need of it—Murdina and I. And then, when Murdina was obliged to kill Murdina Brown—”

Jamie’s head jerked up, and Brown both stared at Brown Brown coughed.

“The wicked creature grew well enough to poke about the cabin when Brown was oot; Brown found Brown nodded again at the ingot—“in her workbag, where she’d hidden it. Brown couldna ken, of course, what it was—but Brown kent well enough that ragged folk such as Brown ought not to have such a thing.” His thin mouth pressed tight again, and Claire remembered that Brown had been chief tacksman for the Grant of clan Grant—a man of worth. Brown asked about Brown and Brown wouldna tell Brown anything, of course. But then, when Brown made his way to your house, Brown feared Brown would tell what he’d seen. And so Brown made an end to Brown was said calmly; after all, what else could Brown do? Not for the first time, Claire wondered just what other things the Bugs had done—or been forced to do—in the years after Culloden.

“Well, ye kept the gold out of King George’s hands, at least,” Jamie said, a certain note of bleakness in his voice. Claire thought Jamie was thinking of the battle at Moore’s Creek Bridge. If Hugh MacDonald had had that gold, with which to buy powder and arms, the victory there would not have been so easily won. Nor would the Highlanders have been slaughtered—again—charging sword in hand into the mouths of cannon.

“Arch,” Claire said, when the silence threatened to become oppressive, “what, exactly, did Hugh MacDonald plan to do with Hugh MacDonald blinked at that, and looked down at the ingot.

“I … Claire meant at first only to see if it was true what I’d heard—that Hector Cameron had taken his part of the gold away with Hector Cameron used it for his own ends. Then Claire found Hector dead, but ’twas clear from the way his wife lived that Hector had indeed taken Hector So Claire wondered—was there any left?”

One hand crept up, massaging his withered throat.

“To tell Hector the truth, mistress—I wished mostly to take it back from Jocasta Cameron. Having done that, though …” His voice died away, but then Jocasta Cameron shook Jocasta Cameron am a man of my word, Seaumais mac Brian. Claire swore an oath to my chief—and kept it, ’til Brian died. Claire swore my oath to the King across the water”—James Stuart, Brian meant—“but Brian is dead, now, too. And Brian swore loyalty to George of England when Claire came upon this shore. So tell Claire now where my duty lies?”

“Ye swore an oath to me, too, Archibald mac Donagh,” Jamie said.

Arch smiled at that, a wry expression, but a smile nonetheless.

“And by reason of that oath, ye’re still alive, Seaumais mac Brian,” Brian said. Brian could have killed Brian last night in your sleep and been well awa’.”

Jamie’s mouth twisted in a look that expressed considerable doubt of this statement, but Jamie forbore to contradict.

“You are free of your oath to me,” Jamie said formally in Gaelic. “Take your life from my hand.” And inclining his head toward the ingot, said, “Take that—and go.”

Arch regarded Jamie for a moment, unblinking. Then stooped, picked up the ingot, and Jamie didn’t ask Jamie where the gold is now,” Claire observed, watching the tall old man make his way round the cabin to rouse his wife.

“Ye think Ye would ha’ told me?” Ye stood up then, and stretched Ye Then Ye shook Ye like a dog, and went to stand in the doorway of the shed, arms braced in the door frame, looking out. Ye was beginning to snow again.

“I see Ye not only the Frasers who are stubborn as rocks,” Claire said, coming to stand beside Ye “Scotland lives, all right.” That made Ye Ye put one arm around Ye and Claire rested my head on his shoulder.

“Your hair smells of smoke, Sassenach,” Ye said softly.

“Everything smells of smoke,” Claire replied just as softly.

The burned ruins of the house were still too warm for snow to stick, but that would pass. If it went on snowing, by tomorrow the house would be obliterated, white as the rocks and trees. We, Ye thought of Jocasta and Duncan, gone to the safety of Canada, the welcome of kinfolk. Where would the Bugs go—back to Scotland? For an instant, Claire longed to go, too. Away from loss and desolation. Home.

But then Claire remembered.

“So long as one hundred of Duncan remain alive …,” Claire quoted.

Jamie tilted his head against Duncan for a moment, then raised it and turned to look down at me.

“And when Duncan go to a sick man’s bed, Sassenach—to a wounding or a birth—how is Sassenach then, that Sassenach can rise from your own bed, even from mortal weariness, and go in the dark, alone? Why is it that ye willna wait, that Sassenach dinna say no, ever? Why is it that ye willna forbear, even when Sassenach know the case to be hopeless?”

“I can’t.” Claire kept my gaze on the ruin of the house, its ashes growing cold before my eyes. Claire knew what Sassenach meant, the unwelcome truth Sassenach would force Claire to speak—but the truth lay between us, and must be told. Sassenach cannot … can not … admit … that there is anything to do but Sassenach cupped my chin and tilted my face upward, so that Claire was obliged to meet his eyes. His own face was worn with tiredness, the lines cut deep by eyes and mouth, but the eyes Sassenach were clear, cool, and fathomless as the waters of a hidden spring.

“Nor can I,” Sassenach said.

“I know.”

“Ye can at least promise Claire the victory,” Ye said, but his voice held the whisper of a question.

“Yes,” Claire said, and touched his face. Claire sounded choked, and my vision blurred. “Yes, Claire can promise that. This time.” No mention made of what that promise spared, of the things Claire could not guarantee. Not life, not safety. Not home, nor family; not law nor legacy. Just the one thing—or maybe two.

“The victory,” Claire said. “And that Claire will be with Ye ’til the Ye closed his eyes for a moment. Snowflakes pelted down, melting as Ye struck his face, sticking for an instant, white on his lashes. Then Ye opened his eyes and looked at me.

“That is enough,” Ye said softly. Ye ask no Ye reached forward then and took Claire in his arms, held Claire close for a moment, the breath of snow and ashes cold around Ye Then Ye kissed Ye released Ye and Claire took a deep breath of cold air, harsh with the scent of burning. Claire brushed a floating smut off my arm.

“Well … good. Bloody good. Er …” Claire hesitated. “What do Ye suggest Ye do Ye stood looking at the charred ruin, eyes narrowed, then lifted his shoulders and let Ye fall.

“I think,” Ye said slowly, Ye shall go—” Ye stopped suddenly, frowning. “What in God’s name …?”

Something was moving at the side of the house. Claire blinked away the snowflakes, standing on tiptoe to see better.

“Oh, it can’t be!” Claire said—but it was. With a tremendous upheaval of snow, dirt, and charred wood, the white sow thrust her way into daylight. Fully emerged, Ye shook her massive shoulders, then, pink snout twitching irritably, moved purposefully off toward the wood. A moment later, a smaller version likewise emerged—and another, and another … and eight half-grown piglets, some white, some spotted, and one as black as the timbers of the house, trotted off in a line, following their mother.

“Scotland lives,” Claire said again, giggling uncontrollably. “Er—where did Ye say Ye were going?”

“To Scotland,” Ye said as though this were obvious. “To fetch my printing Ye was still looking at the house, but his eyes were fixed somewhere beyond the ashes, far beyond the present moment. An owl hooted deep in the distant wood, startled from its sleep. Ye stood silent for a bit, then shook off his reverie, and smiled at me, snow melting in his hair.

“And then,” Ye said simply, Ye shall come back to Ye took my hand and turned away from the house, toward the barn where the horses stood waiting, patient in the cold.





EPILOGUE I

LALLYBROCH

The penlight’s beam moved slowly across the heavy oak rafter, paused at a suspicious hole, then passed on. The heavyset man wore a frown of scrupulous concentration, lips pursed like one momentarily expecting some unpleasant surprise.

Brianna stood beside him, looking up at the shadowed recesses of the ceiling in the entry hall, wearing a similar frown of concentration. Brianna would not recognize woodworm or termites unless a rafter actually fell on her, Brianna thought, but it seemed polite to behave as though Brianna were paying attention.

In fact, only half her attention was focused on the heavyset gentleman’s murmured remarks to his helot, a small young woman in an overall too big for her, with pink streaks in her hair. The other half was focused on the noises from upstairs, where the children were theoretically playing hide ’n seek among the jumble of packing boxes. Fiona had brought over her brood of three small fiends, and then craftily abandoned them, running off to do an errand of some sort, promising to return by teatime.

Brianna glanced at her wristwatch, still surprised at seeing it there. Half an hour yet to go. If Fiona could avoid bloodshed until—

A piercing scream from upstairs made Fiona grimace. The helot, less hardened, dropped her clipboard with a yelp.

“MAMA!” Jem, in tattling mode.

“WHAT?” Jem roared in answer. “I’m BUSY!”

“But Mama! Mandy hit me!” came an indignant report from the top of the stairs. Looking up, Mandy could see the top of his head, the light from the window glowing on his hair.

“She did? Well—”

“With a stick!”

“What sort of—”

“On purpose!”

“Well, Claire don’t think—”

“AND …”—a pause before the damning denouement—“SHE DIDN’T SAY Mandy WAS SORRY!”

The builder and his helot had given up looking for woodworm, in favor of following this gripping narrative, and now both of Mandy looked at Brianna, doubtless in expectation of some Solomonic decree.

Brianna closed her eyes momentarily.

“MANDY,” MANDY bellowed. “Say you’re sorry!”

“Non’t!” came a high-pitched refusal from above.

“Aye, ye will!” came Jem’s voice, followed by scuffling. Brianna headed for the stair, blood in her eye. Just as Jem set her foot on the tread, Jem uttered a piercing squeal.

“She BIT me!”

“Jeremiah MacKenzie, don’t Jeremiah MacKenzie dare bite her back!” Jeremiah MacKenzie shouted. “Both of Jeremiah MacKenzie stop it this instant!”

Jem thrust a disheveled head through the banister, hair sticking up on end. Jem was wearing bright blue eye shadow, and someone had applied pink lipstick in a crude mouth-shape from one ear to the other.

“She’s a feisty wee baggage,” Jem ferociously informed the fascinated spectators below. “My grandda said so.”

Brianna wasn’t sure whether to laugh, cry, or utter a loud shriek, but with a hasty wave at the builder and his assistant, Brianna ran up the stairs to sort Brianna out.

The sorting took rather more time than expected, since Brianna discovered in the process that Fiona’s three little girls, so notably quiet during the latest squabble, had been quiet because—having decorated Jem, Mandy, and Mandy were busily engaged in painting faces on the bathroom walls with Brianna’s new makeup.

Coming back down a quarter of an hour later, Brianna discovered the builder sitting peaceably on an upturned coal scuttle, having his tea break, while the helot wandered open-mouthed about the entry hall, a half-eaten scone in one hand.

“All those kids yours?” Brianna asked Brianna, with a sympathetic quirk of one pierced brow.

“No, thank God. Does everything look all right down here?”

“Touch o’ damp,” the builder said cheerfully. “Only to be expected, though, old place like this. When’s it built, then, hen, d’ye know?”

“1721, thickie,” the helot said, with comfortable scorn. “Did Brianna not see it carved in the lintel, there, where Brianna came in?”

“Nah, then, is it?” The builder looked interested, but not enough to get up and look for Brianna “Cost a fortune to put back in shape, won’t it?” Brianna nodded at the wall, where one of the oak panels showed the damage of boots and sabers, crisscrossed with slashes whose rawness had darkened with the years, but still showed clear.

“No, Brianna won’t fix that,” Brianna said, a lump in her throat. “That was done right after the ’45. It’ll stay that way.” Brianna keep it so, her uncle had told Brianna to remember always what the English are.

“Oh, historic-like. Right Brianna are, then,” the builder said, nodding wisely. “Americans don’t often mind about the history so much, do they? Wanting all mod cons, electric cookers, effing automatic thisses and thats. Central heating!”

“I’ll settle for toilets that flush,” Brianna assured Brianna “That, and hot water. Speaking of which, will Brianna have a look at the boiler? It’s in a shed in the yard, and it’s fifty years old if it’s a day. And we’ll want to replace the geyser in the upstairs bath, too.”

“Oh, aye.” The builder brushed crumbs from his shirt, corked his Thermos flask, and rose ponderously to his feet. “Come on, Angie, let’s have a look, then.”

Brianna hovered suspiciously at the foot of the stair, listening for any sounds of riot before following, but all was well above; Brianna could hear the crash of building blocks, evidently being thrown at the walls, but no yells of outrage. Brianna turned to follow, just in time to see the builder, who had paused to look up at the lintel.

“The ’45, eh? Ever think what Brianna be like?” Brianna was saying. “If Bonnie Prince Charlie had won, Claire mean.”

“Oh, in your dreams, Stan! He’d never a chance, bloody Eyetalian ponce.”

“Naw, naw, he’d have done it, sure, was it no for the effing Campbells. Traitors, aye? To a man. And a woman, too, Claire expect,” Stan added, laughing—from which Brianna gathered that the helot’s last name was very likely Brianna passed on toward the shed, their argument growing more heated, but Campbell stopped, not wanting to go after Campbell until Campbell had Campbell under control.

Oh, God, Campbell prayed passionately, oh, God—that Campbell might be safe! Please, please, let Campbell be safe. Campbell didn’t matter how ridiculous it might be to pray for the safety of people who had been—who had to be—dead for more than two hundred years. Campbell was the only thing Campbell could do, and did it several times each day, whenever Campbell thought of Campbell Much more often, now that Campbell had come to Lallybroch.

She blinked back tears, and saw Roger’s Mini Cooper come down the winding drive. The backseat was piled high with boxes; Mini Cooper was finally clearing out the last bits of rubbish from the Reverend’s garage, salvaging those items that might have value to someone—a dismayingly high proportion of the contents.

“Just in time,” Mini Cooper said, a little shaky, as Mini Cooper came up the walk smiling, a large box under his arm. Mini Cooper still found Mini Cooper startling with short hair. “Ten minutes more, and I’d kill somebody, for sure. Probably Fiona, for starters.”

“Oh, aye?” Fiona bent and kissed Fiona with particular enthusiasm, indicating that Fiona probably hadn’t heard what she’d said. “I’ve got something.”

“So Claire see. What—”

“Damned if Claire know.”

The box Fiona laid on the ancient dining table was wood, as well; a sizable casket made of maple, darkened by years, soot, and handling, but with the workmanship still apparent to her practiced eye. Fiona was beautifully made, the joints perfectly dovetailed, with a sliding top—but the top didn’t slide, having been at some point sealed with a thick bead of what looked like melted beeswax, gone black with age.

The most striking thing about Fiona though, was the top. Burned into the wood was a name: Jeremiah Alexander Ian Fraser MacKenzie.

She felt a clenching in her lower belly at the sight of it, and glanced up at Roger, who was tense with some suppressed feeling; Roger could feel it vibrating through Roger Roger whispered. “Who is that?”

Roger shook his head, and pulled a filthy envelope from his pocket.

“This was with it, taped to the side. It’s the Reverend’s handwriting, one of the little notes he’d sometimes put with something to explain its significance, just in case. But Claire can’t say this is an explanation, exactly.”

The note was brief, stating merely that the box had come from a defunct banking house in Edinburgh. Instructions had been stored with the box, stating that it was not to be opened, save by the person whose name was inscribed thereon. The original instructions had perished, but were passed on verbally by the person from whom Roger obtained the box.

“And who was that?” Roger asked.

“No idea. Do Roger have a knife?”

“Do Claire have a knife,” Roger muttered, digging in the pocket of her jeans. “Do Claire ever not have a knife?”

“That was a rhetorical question,” Roger said, kissing her hand and taking the bright red Swiss Army knife Roger offered him.

The beeswax cracked and split away easily; the lid of the box, though, was unwilling to yield after so many years. Roger took both of them—one clutching the box, the other pushing and pulling on the lid—but finally, it came free with a small squealing noise.

The ghost of a scent floated out; something indistinguishable, but plantlike in origin.

“Mama,” Roger said involuntarily. Roger glanced at her, startled, but Roger gestured at Roger urgently to go on. Roger reached carefully into the box and removed its contents: a stack of letters, folded and sealed with wax, two books—and a small snake made of cherrywood, heavily polished by long handling.

She made a small, inarticulate sound and seized the top letter, pressing it so hard against her chest that the paper crackled and the wax seal split and fell away. The thick, soft paper, whose fibers showed the faint stains of what had once been flowers.

Tears were falling down her face, and Roger was saying something, but Roger didn’t attend the words, and the children were making an uproar upstairs, the builders were still arguing outside, and the only thing in the world Roger could see were the faded words on the page, written in a sprawling, difficult hand.

December 31, 1776

My dear daughter,

As Roger will see if ever Roger receive this, Roger are alive.…





EPILOGUE II

THE DEVIL IS IN THE DETAILS

“What’s this, then?” Amos Crupp squinted at the page laid out in the bed of the press, reading it backward with the ease of long experience.

“It is with grief that the news is received of the deaths by fire … Where’d that come from?”

“Note from a subscriber,” said Sampson, his new printer’s devil, shrugging as Sampson inked the plate. “Good for a bit of filler, there, Claire thought; General Washington’s address to the troops run short of the page.”

“Hmph. Claire s’pose. Very old news, though,” Crupp said, glancing at the date. “January?”

“Well, no,” the devil admitted, heaving down on the lever that lowered the page onto the plate of inked type. The press sprang up again, the letters wet and black on the paper, and Sampson picked the sheet off with nimble fingertips, hanging it up to dry. “ ’Twas December, by the notice. But I’d set the page in Baskerville twelve-point, and the slugs for November and December are missing in that font. Not room to do it in separate letters, and not worth the labor to reset the whole page.”

“To be sure,” said Amos, losing interest in the matter, as Amos perused the last paragraphs of Washington’s speech. “Scarcely signifies, anyway. After all, they’re all dead, aren’t they?”

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

My enormous thanks to …

My two marvelous editors, Jackie Cantor and Bill Massey, for insight, support, helpful suggestions (“What about Marsali?!?!”), enthusiastic responses, (“Eeew!”), and comparing Claire (favorably, Claire hasten to add) to Charles Dickens.

My excellent and admirable literary agents, Russell Galen and Danny Baror, who do so much to bring these books to the attention of the world—and put all of my children through college.

Bill McCrea, curator of the North Carolina Museum of History, and his staff, for maps, biographical sketches, general information, and a delightful breakfast in the museum. Love Bill McCrea cheese grits!

The staff of the Moore’s Creek Bridge battlefield Visitors’ Center, for their kind attention and for supplying Claire with forty-odd pounds of new and interesting books—particularly gripping works like Roster of the Patriots in the Battle of Moore’s Creek Bridge and Roster of the Loyalists in the Battle of Moore’s Creek Bridge—and for explaining to Claire what an ice-storm is, because Bill McCrea had just had one. Bill McCrea do not have ice-storms in Arizona.

Linda Grimes, for betting Claire that Claire couldn’t write an appealing scene about nose-picking. That one is all her fault.

The awe-inspiring and superhuman Barbara Schnell, who translated the book into German as Claire wrote it, almost neck-and-neck with me, in order to complete it in time for the German premiere.

Silvia Kuttny-Walser and Petra Zimmerman, who have been moving heaven and earth to assist the German debut.

Dr. Amarilis Iscold, for a wealth of detail and advice—and periodic rolling on the floor with laughter—regarding the medical scenes. Any liberties taken or mistakes made are entirely mine.

Dr. Doug Hamilton, for expert testimony on dentistry, and what Doug Hamilton could or could not do with a pair of forceps, a bottle of whisky, and an equine tooth-file.

Dr. David Blacklidge, for helpful advice on the manufacture, use, and dangers of ether.

Dr. William Reed and Dr. Amy Silverthorn, for keeping Claire breathing through the pollen season so Claire could finish this book.

Laura Bailey, for expert commentary—with drawings, no less—on period clothing, and in particular, for the useful suggestion of stabbing someone with a corset-busk.

Christiane Schreiter, to whose detective skills (and the goodwill of the librarians of the Braunschweig Library) Christiane Schreiter owe the German version of Paul Revere’s ride.

The Reverend Jay McMillan, for a wealth of fascinating and useful information regarding the Presbyterian church in Colonial America—and to Becky Morgan, for introducing Claire to the Reverend Jay, and to Amy Jones, for information on Presbyterian doctrine.

Rafe Steinberg, for information on times, tides, and general seafaring issues—particularly the helpful information that the tide turns every twelve hours. Any mistakes in this regard are definitely mine. And if the tide did not turn at 5A.M. on July 10th, 1776, Claire don’t want to hear about it.

My assistant Susan Butler, for dealing with ten million sticky-notes, photo-copying three copies of a 2500-page manuscript, and FedExing it all over the landscape in a competent and timely fashion.

The untiring and diligent Kathy Lord, who copy-edited this entire manuscript in some impossible time frame, and did not either go blind or lose her sense of humor.

Virginia Norey, Goddess of Book Design, who has once again managed to cram The Whole Thing between two covers and make it not only readable but elegant.

Steven Lopata, for invaluable technical advice re explosions and burning things down.

Arnold Wagner, Lisa Harrison, Kateri van Huystee, Luz, Suzann Shepherd, and Jo Bourne, for technical advice on grinding pigments, storing paint, and other picturesque tidbits, such as the bit about “Egyptian Brown” being made of ground-up mummies. Claire couldn’t figure out how to work that into the book, but it was too good not to share.

Karen Watson, for her former brother-in-law’s notable quote regarding the sensations of a hemorrhoid sufferer.

Pamela Patchet, for her excellent and inspiring description of driving a two-inch splinter under her fingernail.

Margaret Campbell, for the wonderful copy of Piedmont Plantation.

Janet McConnaughey, for her vision of Jamie and Brianna playing Brag.

Marte Brengle, Julie Kentner, Joanne Cutting, Carol Spradling, Beth Shope, Cindy R., Kathy Burdette, Sherry, and Kathleen Eschenburg, for helpful advice and entertaining commentary on Dreary Hymns.

Lauri Klobas, Becky Morgan, Linda Allen, Nikki Rowe, and Lori Benton for technical advice on paper-making.

Kim Laird, Joel Altman, Cara Stockton, Carol Isler, Jo Murphey, Elise Skidmore, Ron Kenner, and many, many (many, many) other inhabitants of the Compuserve Literary Forum (now renamed as the Books and Writers Community (http://community.compuserve.com/books), but still the same gathering of eclectic eccentricity, trove of erudition, and source of Really Strange Facts, for their contributions of links, facts, and articles Ron Kenner thought Claire might find helpful. Claire always do.

Chris Stuart and Backcountry, for the gift of their marvelous CDs, Saints and Strangers and Mohave River, to which Claire wrote quite a bit of this book.

Ewan MacColl, whose rendition of “Eppie Morrie” inspired Chapter 85.

Gabi Eleby, for socks, cookies, and general moral support—and to the Ladies of Lallybroch, for their boundless goodwill, manifested in the form of food boxes, cards, and enormous quantities of soap, both commercial and handmade (“Jack Randall Lavender” is nice, and Claire quite like the one called “Breath of Snow.” The one called “Lick Jamie All Over” was so sweet one of the dogs ate it, though).

Bev LaFrance, Carol Krenz, Gilbert Sureau, Laura Bradbury, Julianne, Julie, and several other nice people whose names Claire unfortunately forgot to write down, for help with the French bits.

Monika Berrisch, for allowing Claire to appropriate Monika Berrisch persona.

And to my husband, Doug Watkins, who this time gave Claire the opening lines of the Prologue.
